name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the recommendation for the second reading of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the European Union Agency for law enforcement cooperation (Europol) (14957/2/2015 - C8-0130/20 16 - 2013/0091 (COD)) (Reporter: Aguston Daaz de Mera Garcia Consuegra (A8-0164/2016)).

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President; good morning, Commissioner, dear colleagues, friends and friends. I have been working on this mandatory regulation for more than three years. As rapporteur, I have had the same intention from the outset: to provide Europol with a Regulation which had the necessary tools to effectively fulfil its tasks and objectives.  The main objective of the European Union Agency for Police Cooperation is to support and strengthen the action of the competent authorities of the Member States and their mutual cooperation in the prevention and combating of terror, serious crime and thirty other offences, such as drug trafficking, trafficking in human beings, illicit trafficking of organs , kidnapping, illegal detention, hostage-taking, racism and xenophobia, blackmail, counterfeiting of currency and means of payment, computer crime, illicit trafficking in weapons, ammunition and explosives, sexual abuse and others, as well as up to thirty. During the first reading we managed to avoid the merger between Europol and Cepol, which was backed by this House by 610 votes in favour. This result was also achieved through the good collaboration and work of the shadow rapporteurs, whom I pay tribute to with gratitude. In the process of second reading, the degree of cooperation and consensus of my colleagues has again been remarkable. I would therefore like to reiterate my gratitude for all the effort you have made during these three long years of negotiations. I held a total of ten tripartite dialogues: three under the Italian Presidency, three under the Latvian Presidency and four under the Luxembourg Presidency, with whom I reached a good agreement on 27 November; I also want to thank all of them. I would also like to highlight and thank Victoria Amici, the Commission representative, for her high professionalism.  From the result achieved at this second reading I would like to point out: Europol plays a key role in the fight against the terrible scourge of jihadist terror. The Regulation will therefore provide it with better capabilities and instruments in this area. Highlights have been the creation in January of the ECTC ( European Counter-Terrorism Centre – a unit that combines resources of information, intelligence and support to deal with terror. In addition, it will provide legal basis to the IRU (Internet Content Notification Unit). It is a fundamental tool for combating terrorist propaganda and online extremist activities. This unit within Europol will identify extremist online content and contact internet service providers to get them removed as quickly as possible — deleted, I mean the content, of course.  The Agency, in order to attack all forms of crime for which it is competent, collects, preserves, processes, analyses and exchanges information, including criminal intelligence. It also develops threat assessments, strategic analysis and operational analysis; all this always under the support of the police agency, i.e. national units and liaison officers, which are the link between Europol and the competent authorities of the Member States. For example, it will be national units that are necessarily notified without delay of any information and connections between criminal acts affecting them. In addition, Europol has the possibility to coordinate the organising and conduct of operational investigations and actions to support and strengthen , two key words , the actions of the Member States. For the first time, Europol will be able to process data from private entities, always under a high degree of privacy, but which will allow Europol to better combat crimes as terrible as child abuse. All this always under a robust data protection architecture, among other things thanks to the role of the European Data Protection Supervisor, who, as an independent body, will always cooperate with national data protection authorities. In addition, there will be special treatment for sensitive data, all always following the premises of the data protection package, approved at the last plenary session.  Under this new mandate, the governance of the Agency will be improved, increasing its effectiveness, in particular as regards the Governing Body and the Director of Europol. And this Regulation will set a precedent for the other agencies with regard to parliamentary scroverny. Article 88 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union clearly calls for Europol's activities to be controlled by Parliament, together with national parliaments. That is why we have set up a joint parliamentary control group. Finally, I would like to stress that prevention against organized crime is the best operational cooperation between existing agencies. Europol will therefore allow Eurojust access and consultation of its data.  It has been a long legislative path, but the result has been satisfactory and will allow Europol to continue working twenty-four hours a day, every day of the week.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by expressing my thanks to the rapporteur Mr Díaz de Mera García Consuegra. He and his team have done a great job in adopting this critical piece of legislation, after three years of tireless work, to reach this compromise. I can congratulate him on the result and express my thanks for the excellent cooperation we had.  What makes this regulation critical is that our fight against terrorism is at the very top of the political agenda. 82% of the citizens of Europe tell us in a very recent survey that they want the European Union to intervene more on terrorism than now. Once this regulation is applied in spring 2017, it will give us the right framework for this to happen, first of all, by making Europol an information hub for law enforcement in the Union. Paris and Brussels showed this very clearly. Information exchange is our Achilles heel. Member States have to coordinate more closely and effectively. Complex investigations have to be supported by sound analysis. Europol can have clear added value in this respect. The other major improvement is the democratic scrutiny by this Parliament. Our new rules will ensure this accountability on Europol’s activities, together with national parliaments.  The protection of personal data will also be strengthened. I consider, therefore, the outcome of our work on this file to be positive. Europol’s legal basis has been aligned to the Treaty of Lisbon, and the objectives of the Europol reform – to make Europol more accountable, effective and efficient – have been fully achieved. Nonetheless, I would like to refer you to the two declarations that the Commission made in Council already, which I would like to highlight today as well. The first concerns the governance of Europol. We remain convinced of the benefits of establishing an Executive Board as part of the governance structure of Europol and other agencies. We will keep following the situation on the governance of Europol, and within the next two years we will examine whether further proposals on this point are necessary. The second concerns the need to ensure coherence between the Europol Regulation and the Data Protection reform package. In the light of our recent adoption of the new EU data protection rules, and the upcoming review of the data protection rules for EU institutions and agencies, we need to ensure consistency and avoid duplication. It should be clear, therefore, that functions exercised by the Cooperation Board set up in this regulation, will in the future be exercised by the newly created European Data Protection Board.  I welcome today’s important step and I look forward to hearing your interventions.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – The safety of European citizens is under greatest test since the end of the Cold War. There are several reasons for this: among other things, that we have invested too little in defence and security. We have fallen into a security vacuum, and today we face security threats. This has been met by aggressive Russian policy, this has been perceived by terrorist networks, everyone competing with the European Union in a global market where the position of the European Union, the largest economic power in the world, is inadequate.  In the current sensitive security situation, it is of the utmost importance that, after three years of negotiations, the European Parliament and the Council have finally reached an agreement on the European Police Office. I am pleased that we will be voting today on a new regulation that will give Europol more powers in the fight against terrorism, cyber and organised crime and other serious criminal phenomena. It will have the opportunity to create specialised rapid intervention units. The exchange of information between Member States and Europol will also be better.  I am also proud of my political group, which in the negotiations has ensured the inclusion of a legal basis for the full functioning of the Europol unit, including the prevention of terrorist propaganda on the Internet. Thus, We have strengthened Europol, human resources and financially, giving it powers and a legal framework. European citizens, however, would say that it is about time it proved.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Tomorrow is a big day – we will adopt the Europol regulation at second reading. It took us more than three years and more than 80 meetings. It has been a persevering process and Mr De Mera has managed this process with care and collegial control. I would like to thank him very much for this, and also for all the colleagues who have cooperated with him as shadow rapporteur – it was a very good working atmosphere. The regulation adapts the provisions to the Lisbon Treaty. However, it also brings improvements for the security of Europe's citizens. It de-bureaucratises cross-border cooperation and makes it possible to combat organised crime and terrorism more effectively.  This regulation is able to make Europol's structures more efficient and democratic, to strengthen parliamentary control and to have strict data protection rules in place.  It is particularly important that parliamentary control should be carried out jointly with the national parliaments. This is one of the few pieces of legislation that focuses on interinstitutional cooperation with national parliaments. This common supervisory body could and should also be a school in other areas. Interparliamentary cooperation is one of the important pillars of the European project. I also think it is important that we have succeeded – we managed to follow up on this data protection legislation in the last session of this plenary, which adopted the data protection package – and to bring the new provisions into line with these developments. This will strengthen Europol's credibility, and this is a prerequisite for more efficient cooperation, for greater acceptance of the authority and also for the willingness to increase the exchange of data.  The merger of CEPOL and Europol was also an important issue. We decided to fend off this because we wanted to strengthen the focus of the individual institutions. We have also taken this pragmatic approach in other areas, such as the Internet Observatory, where I still believe that a separate piece of legislation would have been better. But time has been running out, so it made sense to go down this path. I believe that we will adopt a good regulation. It will improve Europol's work in the interests of our citizens and is also a good basis for further integration in police cooperation, which are, of course, necessary.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Europol needs new tools to face new challenges. Today, after a long period of negotiation, we are finally providing ourselves a renewed mandate to tackle the huge security challenges we all face. Under the excellent leadership of Rob Wainwright, Europol has become a critical hub for cooperation, operational support and intelligence exchange throughout the EU. This regulation gives Europol the legal tools needed to respond more swiftly to threats and it gives our constituents and our Member States confidence that Europol is conforming to extremely high standards of data protection and transparency. It allows MEPs and national parliaments to keep watch over their actions to ensure accountability, something which can only strengthen trust in our law enforcement cooperation across the Union. More importantly, this regulation gives a solid basis for the work of Europol’s Internet Referral Unit to be stepped up. With terrorist organisations increasingly using social media as a recruitment tool, and thousands of Twitter and Facebook accounts being created for recruitment purposes, we need to work together to take down this material as soon as it is posted.  Through this regulation, Europol can work directly with social media providers – providers who have frankly too often washed their hands of responsibility for the propaganda posted on their platforms. Europol is not a European FBI, and it does not need to be. It should continue to operate as a hub for information exchange and for cooperation and coordination amongst all of those in law enforcement. Our fight against terrorism and serious crime is one where we are too often several steps behind our enemy. This regulation is an important step in closing that gap. Europol has made Europe and the UK a safer place for nearly 20 years, and, Mr Díaz de Mera García Consuegra, I congratulate you on your hard work and your persistence in making sure we get a quality regulation which will aid Europol in its continued fight against human trafficking, child exploitation, terrorism and, of course, smuggling.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: for the ALDE Group. Madam President! Let me begin by thanking Mr Böge. I would like to take the necessary information, i.m. to Mr Díaz de Mera, the rest of the rapporteurs and the European institutions for the hard work. It has been a lengthy process and I am convinced that from next year Europol will be much better equipped to support Member States in the fight against serious, cross-border crime and terrorism. As ALDE's rapporteur, I personally would have liked Europol to have been strengthened even further so that Europol could ask the Member States to launch investigations and at least to justify its refusal. I would also have liked the sharing of information between Member States to be made compulsory in order to prevent some Member States from having to hold knowledge that other Member States could use.  This is happening right now on a voluntary basis, and that is not enough. The transnational nature of the Paris and Brussels attacks underlines that information sharing and police cooperation are essential to counter the terrorist threat. Unfortunately, there are far too many examples of the exact opposite. Let me just say a simple: the terrorists from the Paris attack in November travelled by car from Belgium to France, were stopped at the border, but they were released again because the French authorities did not have access to image identification. Unfortunately, there are several examples of both lack of information and lack of coordination.  Going forward, it is therefore essential that we become better at sharing information between Member States. This is the prerequisite for us to be able to prevent new tragic events together. To the Member States, I would say: 'Do not wait for the next tragedy to take place before you step up your joint efforts with Europol!' I say 'yours' and I say it with envy because Denmark, my home country, stands to have to leave Europol because the people voted 'no' to Europol in a referendum last year. The coming months will show whether it is possible to negotiate an agreement on Europol in time. It is, of course, my hope that Denmark can become a full member of Europol. However, in my book, incomplete parallel agreements are not the optimal solution, either for Denmark or for Europe. I congratulate everyone on the new stronger Europol. It is a key tool in the fight against organised crime and the fight against terrorism.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would also like to thank the rapporteur, who has worked with us fairly and with respect, despite the different positions we have always had. For us, the question has always been decisive: what do we really want from a police force, and how is policing really to be coordinated throughout Europe by Europol? We want Europol to help ensure that citizens are effectively protected in their fundamental rights, that crimes are specifically and effectively investigated and investigated, and that democratically organised and controlled cooperation takes place. That was our ambition. The question is: has Europol lived up to this? We believe that there are undoubtedly some improvements, but overall we are not satisfied. Instead of actually promoting effective cross-border crime by clearly limiting the definition of offences, the list of offences will be significantly expanded, so that Europol is made competent for virtually everything possible. Europol is becoming a data hole, and we criticise the fact that the Internet Referral Unit is effectively creating, without any legal basis or reduction, an institution that ultimately decides on the love and unwelcomeness of Internet data. And in addition, they want to cooperate with third parties, with private actors, and ultimately decide on this exchange of data, what is good and what is evil on the Internet. We reject that. We are also quite disappointed with the joint parliamentary control group. We were expecting more. It is without decision-making power, without real rights of access. Europol really remains the black box, and that is why we reject the whole thing.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, Europol is the European agency responsible for supporting national police and judicial authorities in the fight against international crime and terrorism. The most recent terrorist attacks have increased the need for a stronger European police agency, with greater capacity to facilitate cross-border cooperation and the exchange of information between Member States. In this context, Europol needed to be adequately equipped to support Member States in the prevention, analysis and investigation of crimes throughout the Union. However, the more powerful Europol is, the greater parliamentary control of its activities and the greater the legal guarantees must also be to avoid illegitimate mass surveillance of citizens or indiscriminate exchange and analysis of personal data, which could be disproportionate, unnecessary and contrary to the fundamental rights of those to whom it should serve. Europol operates within the European Union. However, organized crime does not stop at our borders. Better cooperation with third States and international organizations is therefore also needed. The Regulation we are debating today has aimed at strengthening Europol and avoiding certain risks of police meddling in our lives. I should also mention that there are issues in the text that still displease my group. For example, to quote only two: the fact that the Executive Director of Europol does not respond directly to the European Parliament in the exercise of his duties, but to the Council; or how the legal basis has been introduced so that the IRU (Internet Referral Unit) can continue to perform functions that it already began to develop on July 1, 2015. We have therefore kept our amendment on this subject, in order to recall, as agreed to the end, that the IRU would be the subject of its own development, in a separate legislative proposal. However, I would like to thank Mr Díaz de Mera for his efforts to improve various aspects of the text. My group will obviously vote in favour of the amendment we have tabled, but it also supports the text as a whole, and it does so because it is now a necessary and unass alternative instrument in view to achieve better and more effective cross-border cooperation between European Union law enforcement agencies and to improve the exchange of information with third countries in the fight against transnational crimes.

name: Petr MACH
text: on the efdd group. – Ladies and gentlemen, when we vote on this proposal, you will find one single motion to vote, and that is my proposal to reject this standard, made on behalf of the Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy faction. We do not have the opportunity to table amendments to the text at all and I think this is a denial of the principle of parliamentary democracy. Originally, a few years ago, the European Commission put forward a completely different proposal. It was at the heart of the merger of Europol and the European Police College (CEPOL). This has completely fallen out of the way and, outside this Parliament, Europol has been transformed into a completely new organisation. The intergovernmental service organisation of police forces has become a police agency, essentially a secret police, subordinate to the European Commission, subordinate to the Council. By its decision, the Commission will be able to transmit data collected by Europol to other international organisations. At the last meeting, you agreed that private companies, airlines, would have to automatically transfer data, account numbers, addresses and people's names. And this new Europol will even be able to transfer this data to private individuals and will be essentially out of our control. The proposal is trying to pretend to have some level of scrutiny, but all it requires from the board is a ridiculous thing – for there to be an equal number of men and women. But it is actually a dangerous institution, which is why please vote in support of my motion to dismiss.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for All of them, or at least the majority in this Parliament, are today celebrating the major blow to terrorism in Europe by giving Europol the agency new powers to extend the exchange of data within Europe. There was a great deal of consensus on this, the rapporteur says. Perhaps that is what should worry us most, precisely that there is far too much consensus in this Parliament on the issue of further data exchange in Europe. The fact that the representative of the so-called Liberal Group, of all people, is saying here that there is not yet enough obligation to exchange data and that more of them is needed is a real joke. Ladies and gentlemen! We in Europe are not in a position to comply with the rules that we have adopted in the past – the protection of external borders under Schengen, compliance with the Dublin Agreement in the area of the right of asylum – within the European Union. And now you want to set up new rules to combat the problems that have arisen because you cannot comply with the old rules. That cannot be the seriousness of this Parliament! We must finally approach the old rules and comply with them and not always establish new rules in this Parliament in order to eliminate the problems that arise only by the fact that we no longer comply with the law.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Madam President, Europol is being re-established as a European Union body by strengthening and extending its repressive role to the full. It intervenes in the Member States by setting up national liaison centres with Europol. It has the right to require them to prosecute a wide range of offences. Under the convenient pretext of combating terrorism, it becomes a centre for a huge amount of personal data, even for the social interactions of everyone, a hub for the exchange of this information with security authorities and secret services of the Member States and third countries, in particular the United States, even with individuals such as, for example, by monitoring the Internet in liaison with business groups in the sector. Your claims of alleged data protection and parliamentary accountability are a mockery and an alibi for legitimising this repressive action. At the heart of the file is political and social action aimed at countering grassroots movements against the unpopular policy of the European Union and governments. The labour movement can, by strengthening its fight, also face the repressive mechanisms of shielding the power of monopolies, which it must overthrow. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague, I do not know if you have read the regulation or this document at all. Therefore, I would like to know your answer. Can you explain to us how Europol will become a repressive agency? Have you ever been to Europol to see it? Do you know how Europol works? I'm begging for an answer.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI), answer a question with a "blue card". – There is no need for someone to visit Europol's offices to understand its character. It is the text itself that gives this repressive character. If one reads it carefully, one will find that the subject matter of the information that Europol collects for all the personal habits and activities of each person is greatly broadened. And of course, the person who reads it carefully will understand that the subject of information is particularly focused on social, political and trade union activity because it is precisely these points that those who want to control social action are afraid of. This is where Europol's repressive nature lies.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I am quite astonished at how some colleagues from the far right, but unfortunately also from the left, shine here with complete cluelessness. I am sorry, we have here an agency to assist in the cooperation and coordination of the various police and security institutions of the Member States. Secondly, the Internet Referral Unit does not arbitrarily remove anything, but in some cases cruel crimes are immediately removed from the web, so that they can no longer be clicked on by millions of voyeurs, who may have paid in part to enjoy the sexual abuse of children on the Internet. I think it is right that Europol should do such work in cooperation with third parties. If there are doubts, you can go to court and file a suit. This is what we call the rule of law in our system. You can also revok. Europol does not have the right to impose measures on an institution at all. This is the responsibility of the relevant institutions provided for by the Member States in the rule of law. I don't know what cluelessness plagues some here. Passenger data will not be passed on arbitrarily to third parties. They are encrypted and must not be passed on to anyone at all, and there are strict restrictions on what they can be used for in the first place, and the staff is specifically trained. I think that the Europol reform has been very successful. I warmly congratulate the rapporteur, Augusten D'az de Mera Garcia Consuegra, and the co-rapporteurs. I also think that the opinion of my colleague from the ALDE is right that we need more data exchange between the Member States, because the criminals no longer know borders. Commissioner, I would also like to congratulate you on the commission's proposal. I would like the Commission to provide Europol with the extra staff that the Authority needs even more, because at 30 alone we will not be able to do so. However, I believe that the draft as a whole has been well-received, and I hope that colleagues on the right will not tell such nurse tales. There have been amendments en masse, mr President, but unfortunately you were not there.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, I greet rapporteur Díaz de Mera and the shadow rapporteurs who have worked with him on this regulation, achieved after more than two years of negotiations, because The Member States resist 'lisbonising' police cooperation, i.e. further integration through Europol. It is important that changes do not remain on paper and effectively represent a change of mentalities and practices.  As the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels have tragically exposed, one of our biggest challenges is the lack of coordination between police and security agencies at national and European level, which takes advantage of increasingly transnational organised crime, including terrorism. This Regulation requires the strengthening of democratic control to be exercised by the European Parliament in association with national parliaments. It is therefore our responsibility to require our governments to share information through Europol and to cooperate with Europol. There can be no greater consideration than the security of our citizens and, in this sense, it was also important that Parliament was able to impose in this regulation respect for the principles of the protection of personal data, which is essential to facilitate the interoperability of police databases as well and to strengthen the internet reference unit. This regulation is the recognition of Europol as essential in the fight against terrorism and other organised crime, as recently illustrated in the dismantling, in collaboration with the Portuguese police, of a mafia network of Russian origin, which laundered capital through the control of football clubs in Portugal.  But this cannot hold states accountable for doing what they have to do at national and European level against organised crime and terrorism at the police, judicial, legislative level, cooperation between intelligence services and the articulation of internal and external security strategies and policies.  If Member States continue to compete in a race to the bottom in gold visa programmes or investor programs and in the preservation of tax havens, with no other criteria other than the money they bring, then let us not be surprised to find that they are effectively countering the efforts of Europol and our law enforcement agencies, opening doors to the import of organised crime networks , including terrorists.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: – My delegation is satisfied with the outcome of the trialogue negotiations. Europol, the EU's agency for cooperation between police forces, is being strengthened. The N-VA has long been insisting on this. In this way, Europol is even better able to assist member states in the fight against serious crime and terrorism. For example, it is now legally regulated that Europol may, for example, identify jihadist tweets via contacts in those Member States to the provider concerned. That company can then delete those hate speech messages because they violate its terms and conditions. So far, that specialised cell within Europol has already sent 1 000 removal requests, more than half of which have been granted. An excellent practice, which is so concreted from now on.  In addition, Europol will now also have a more modern and flexible data management system worthy of the 21st century. If all Member States are now to effectively exchange information and europol is placed at the centre of that data exchange, then that is certainly a great step forward.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, it is with conviction that I will vote for the 'Europol' regulation which is before us today, after several years of work. In particular, I would like to welcome the clear provisions that will enhance the effectiveness of the European Centre for Combating Terrorism by improving the exchange of information. I still welcome the possibility given to Europol to exchange information with private companies, which will, in some cases, allow service providers - Facebook, for example - to remove pages that promote the Islamic State. Finally, I welcome the fact that this future regulation will place Europol under the joint democratic control of European and national parliamentarians. I have two regrets, however: Europol has not been given sufficient authority to take initiative, particularly for the opening of criminal investigations, and nothing serious is planned to create even an embryo of a European intelligence service. I hope that the future will not make the Council regret not having done so in time.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, all authorities must be subject to adequate scrutiny. We in Sinn Féin understand, of course, the need for enhanced cooperation between countries, especially when it comes to tackling terrorism, drug dealing and human trafficking. Now we also believe that all powers must be held to account. The removal of the joint supervisory body – the only genuine oversight group with on-premises access to Europol activity – means new powers will not be adequately monitored. This is deeply unfortunate, particularly as this report aims to mandate Europol with handling substantive amounts of personal data and seeks to empower Europol to determine what online content is legal. With all power comes responsibility, and accountability breeds responsibility. I think that is something that everyone in this House would agree with.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Agustin De Mera, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Daaz de Mera, for his excellent work on this report. I would like to thank you for your good work. Our shadow rapporteur has already said that there has indeed been great progress on this Europol regulation. I believe that we must all state that this is progress for the European Union. We have a new regulation for Europol that will create more Europe in the field of law enforcement, in the area of policing – this is an important step. It is also an important step that it contains clear data protection rules, that we also bring them into line with the data protection package that we have adopted.  This not only creates trust among citizens, and it not only requires the legitimacy of Europol's action, but it is also a prerequisite for better exchange of information between the Member States and their police and judicial authorities – in this case, the police and law enforcement authorities, and also europol itself.  I would have liked, or we as Greens would have liked to have gone further in two places. The first is indeed something that needs to be done now, and that is better equipping europol's joint investigation teams. Because I don't think it will be about simply amassing more and more data and then letting the computers do the work for themselves, but it will be important to better network the police officers on the ground, to provide resources and equipment to carry out joint investigations – across borders. This is something that needs to be worked on now. And we Greens would have liked a public-law framework to be created in the area of information sharing to third-party private individuals. This is not the case, the information is not treated in the same way as in the case of the state in the private sector. We have tabled an amendment here and, unlike our colleagues on the extreme right, we are democratically involved in this procedure and we want to improve it. I am campaigning for this, including for the amendment. Otherwise, however, we will also adopt this Europol regulation.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are talking about reforming Europol, the European police authority. Europol will collect data and exchange it with public and private bodies. There will be an Internet research department that searches the Internet and social networks for content. Europol accesses public and private databases and collects personal data, stores, processes and passes on: name, address, nationality, occupation, gender, passport data, identity cards and driver's license, fingerprints, DNA profiles, suspected membership in a criminal organisation, former employers, photos, immutable characteristics, any nickname, pseudonyms, bank data, account balance, deposits, shares, real estate holdings, shares and links to companies, The agency is also interested in the lifestyle you maintain, creates movement profiles and stores frequently frequented places and possible drug abuse. She knows your communication channels and your means of transport. In short, Europol will know everything and then create a hazard rating. In the name of the fight against terrorism, one thing seems to me to be at risk here: the data security of all citizens.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Madam President, one of the side effects of globalisation is the increase in threats against the countries of Europe and their qualitative upgrading. These threats relate mainly to terrorism, cyber attacks and organised crime. The peoples of Europe feel insecure and the security of their personal data is being undermined. The European Police Office, Europol, is the body that is called upon to deal with these threats in cooperation with the police and judicial authorities of other countries. In order to be able to carry out this task successfully, it must exchange information with these services and with services from third countries, and at this point we must pay particular attention. Since this information also concerns personal data, it must be ensured at all costs that the security requirement does not violate human rights. Information should only be provided when it is almost certain that a citizen is suspected of carrying out acts of a terrorist or related nature. Finally, it must be ensured that this information is not used to prosecute political opponents, either by undemocratic governments or by governments with an undemocratic and statusative culture.

name: Michał BONI
text: – Madam President, what are the crucial elements of our response to terrorism and security threats? Many of us pointed out that stronger European cooperation and coordination in this area are essential, and with this a stronger and better—managed Europol. This amended regulation is a step in the right direction. It will give us important preventive tools. Prevention is at this stage the key. Europol will have more access to the relevant data, which in consequence will be processed more efficiently. There will be the data from Member States, but also from non-public parties, which is important for effective prevention and investigation.  The new Internet Referral Unit (IRU) will play an important role in combating terrorist propaganda, radicalisation online and organisation of crime groups. The recognition made by IRU and the new model of cooperation with internet providers, will allow to leave out the violent content or start early—warning investigations. On the other hand, we have strengthened the data protection rules that apply to Europol so that we can keep the balance and built trust. We have strengthened the possibilities of Europol cooperation with other European agencies also, for better synergy and efficiency. What remains valid is that Member States must share information with Europol for this system to work. Otherwise the agency will not be able to work within its full capacity. Finally, I want to thank especially the rapporteur Augustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra for his determination.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today we are giving the green light to the reform of Europol, and there are strong reasons for this 'yes' vote. Crime does not stop at national borders. It is therefore essential for Europol to be strengthened and for cooperation between Europol, national authorities and other EU agencies to be improved. The reform will improve the exchange of data between them. In addition, modern administrative structures ensure greater efficiency. In the future, Europol will also be able to respond more quickly to threats, in particular through the creation of special forces. It is equally important for the reform that we have adopted high common standards for data protection across the EU, for businesses, but also for law enforcement. And these standards will now also apply in principle to Europol. The call for hatred and violence on the Internet can lead to crimes in the real world. It is therefore necessary for obviously illegal content that is publicly available to disappear quickly from the Internet. The Internet Reporting Centre created for this purpose now has a solid legal basis. In addition to effective action, robust data protection rules are important in exchanges between Europol and Facebook and Co., and that is precisely what is ensured. The current working basis of the police authority was adopted before the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. That is why it is right that the reform should now bring Europol to the Lisbon standard. The enhanced powers of the European Parliament will be taken into account. It should be stressed that, for the first time, there will be a joint parliamentary control committee at an EU agency, consisting of members of the relevant committee of this House and members of the national parliaments. All this shows that security, data protection and democratic control are not contradictory, but they must be compatible.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This is a good decision for the security of citizens of European countries and of Europe as a whole. It is a pity that it comes so late. I have the impression that if it were not for the dramatic terrorist attacks of recent times, the work would have continued. Opponents of the regulation falsely portray this idea as centralist and threatening civil rights. This is a rational idea of the necessary increase in EUROPOL's powers, including the creation of a unit that will track suspicious content online while maintaining balance and scrutiny by Parliament. The far right does not trust the European Union, and the left, the far left, has today presented a sly vision of freedom in which there is no place for security. Both tendencies serve the public debate badly, that is a good rational decision

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Citizens deserve a Europe in which it is easy to move between Member States. It is this freedom of movement on which we have built our prosperity, and that is why the reintroduction of border controls is so damaging, both to the economy and to the freedom of citizens. However, just as ordinary citizens move between borders, we must recognise and face the consequences of organised crime doing exactly the same. I am pleased that Parliament has now managed, thanks largely to the rapporteur, Mr Díaz de Mera, to come a long way, but much, much more is needed before we can seriously face the threat to our citizens. What we need is a European FBI, with the full capacity to combat serious organised crime operationally. Only a common European police force could seriously tackle and combat cross-border crime syndicates. What we have today is a step in the right direction. Much more remains.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: Madam President! Good colleagues! With the reform of Europol, we are moving from equal intergovernmental police cooperation to the establishment of a supranational police authority. It will be so much time that their area will be extended so that in future they will have to cover all areas where the European Union has a policy, which means, in other words, virtually all areas. At the same time, when we link it to many more powers to juggle information about citizens, i think it is frankly strange that this Parliament is forgetting to defend the legal certainty of its citizens. Surely it is unacceptable for Europol to cooperate with private companies, such as the United States. Facebook to collect information about citizens, mind you, without the necessary democratic scrutiny of why the information is collected and what is happening to it.  We must be firm that police cooperation is important and good. It is essential that we have good and well-functioning police cooperation, but with this reform, the price is simply too high.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as rapporteur for the report on combating organised crime and corruption, I cannot help but welcome the agreement reached on the Europol regulation. The results achieved in the negotiations, aimed at making Europol more efficient and more accountable, without prejudicing but rather strengthening the control role of the national parliaments, and also the data protection regime, are certainly to be welcomed.  It is essential that the Union, through Europol, effectively supports the efforts of the Member States in the fight against serious crime, which effectively supports the exchange of information which, as we have seen, has not always worked so far. I am thinking at the moment in particular of the fight against mafia-type organised crime, corruption and terrorism, which go beyond national borders and which therefore require a holistic approach on a European scale. From this point of view, the creation of joint investigation teams, the exercise of Europol's power of initiative and the necessary cooperation of the Member States will help to usher in a new season of effective and effective fight against the Mafia, corruption and terrorism.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, Europol's role has always been to ensure effective cooperation between Member States on information relating to criminal activity, including, of course, terrorism. In the current context, there is a need for a strong and authoritative institution that strictly controls environments where suspicious activities could arise that would endanger the lives of European citizens. Looking at the evolution of the institution we will see that we have expanded its tasks, without taking into account its response capacity. It is important that the instruments that Europol will use provide it with considerable but real power to protect the citizens of the European Union. We need an authoritative institution that acts pertinently, only in the interests of the European citizen and not an institution that is subordinate to politics. We must not politicise this body, but we must let professionals do their job.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by congratulating my colleague Agustín Díaz de Mera on the excellent work he has done, as is customary. We advocate a United Europe that protects and promotes the freedom of its citizens, and we want to build a real area of freedom, security and justice. We are not those who think freedom and security are opposed. On the contrary, freedom without security is anarchy and security without freedom is dictatorship. And we know that the Union does not exist without its Member States — something that is particularly true when we talk about internal security.  This agreement is reasonable, pragmatic and balanced. It's more of a concrete achievement. It's not a European FBI, but that's not possible right now. But it's a warning to the Member States.  On 22 March in Brussels or 13 November in Paris, it was already unacceptable for terrorists to benefit from disarticulation and lack of exchange of information between Member States. With a strengthened EUROPOL, we are complying with our part at European level. It is now from the Member States that is expected more: more cooperation, more information sharing and more use of the instruments at their disposal.  Mutual trust is not created by decree, but we are creating the conditions for it to exist and to strengthen itself. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (presented pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: blue-card question. – I can agree with a lot of things you said about freedom, solidarity and responsibility, but you said that the legislation we are now voting is not on a European FBI, and that this is not possible. Well, you know the point of view of the ALDE Group: we really want to go one step further. So I wanted to ask you why is a European FBI at the moment not possible, because I really think we need it?

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. "Thank you so much for the question.  I can share your opinion. What I think is that, right now, a European FBI is not possible. Why is it not possible? Because what we are trying to create is mutual trust between Member States. What we have seen throughout this process with the lack of information sharing is that Member States do not trust each other. It is not possible at this time — let's be clear, let's be pragmatic, let's be reasonable — to go further than what is achieved with this excellent agreement negotiated by Mr Díaz de Mera.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I should like to begin by thanking Mr Díaz de Mera and all those who have worked with him on his excellent work. Updating the regulatory framework governing Europol's activities is, in fact, an indispensable measure to increase the efficiency of cooperation between the authorities involved in combating crime, and therefore for a safer Europe. In recent years Europol has made an effective contribution to the fight against the most serious cross-border crimes, providing national authorities with intelligence analysis and logistical support in carrying out joint operations. And today it is all the more necessary to approve the reform of Europol, given that the new security threats in Europe urgently need a common response. In the light of the tragic events in Paris and Brussels, there is an increasing need to strengthen police cooperation instruments in the European Union. Europol will now have a new legal basis specifying its powers and extending its powers, while respecting data protection rules and fundamental rights. In this respect, the decision to introduce a mechanism for monitoring Europol's activities by the European Parliament together with the national parliaments is to be welcomed. It should also be emphasised that the new regulation will ensure a robust data protection regime, in line with existing instruments at European level, including through the provision of a personal data protection authority at Europol and the involvement of data protection guarantors at European and national level. Today's vote comes after 3 years of negotiations, but we can be satisfied with our work because we are going to dismiss a text that strengthens the role of the Agency, although I cannot fail to stress that only the real and timely cooperation between the Member States and the Member States will enable the Europol Agency to play even more effectively the role of combating the phenomenon of international terrorism and to provide valuable support for identifying and dismantling the criminal organisations that manage the the most serious crimes, including, for example, trafficking in human beings.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are talking about Europol today, and this is a classic case of balancing interests. On the one hand, we all want internal security to be strengthened. At the same time, we all want data protection to be given as much priority as possible, which means that, in principle, data must be collected and stored very sparingly. However, what really surprised me this morning, some speakers have now referred only to the aspect of data protection. That, of course, has jumped too short.  In fact, balancing interests means that you have to focus on both. And I believe that this draft, which we are deconsidering today, has succeeded in balancing our interests. We must ensure that the security authorities have the necessary data. I believe that this is exactly the right step in this direction, so that we can combat cross-border crime, because we have just seen – especially in Germany – that hundreds of thousands of people are unregistered and we do not know where they are. This must stop. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the "blue card" procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I would argue with you a little bit, because where do you think the guarantees that prevent individual States from using the information they receive against their own nationals are?

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for that question. I believe that we cannot go so far as to ensure that data protection is so far away that we always want guarantees that nothing will ever go wrong. Life is full of risks. I see the balance of interests in this area being safeguarded and I believe that the regulation that is now being proposed here is a move in the right direction. We will have to watch the whole thing very closely. In the light of practice, it will have to be seen whether this data is used sensibly, and I am very much in favour of us monitoring this explicitly and permanently.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Madam President, I congratulate The Member and rapporteur Agustín Díaz de Mera, first of all; also to the shadow rapporteurs. The police forces, professional and democratic, are one of the pillars of our security but, in addition, they are one of the keys to living with personal and political freedom. They play their lives when it's necessary for us.  In this globalized world, the adoption of the new Europol is good news if governments do not curb the Agency's new capabilities. From this Parliament we must ask the States to send the most capable agents for the functions of the Governing Body, not bureaucrats or lobists. We appeal to your responsibility.  We in Parliament must ensure loyalty in the loyal and unstoppered scrutiny of our new roles because we need it, because we owe it to the victims of the most serious crimes, the most vulnerable and all citizens.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Madam President, Europol is an agency of the European Union which is part of the deepening of the European integration process, with the main objective of complying with the law. A deepening that, seeking to justify itself also in the name of combating terrorism, extends the scope, inter alia, to crimes that act against the interests of Union policies, opening the way for an interventionist stance in any area and sector, in particular in restricting the freedoms of civic and political intervention. An infrastructure which, in the margins of the Member States, imposes itself and overlaps with them, in a clear posture attentive to their sovereignty and the autonomy of their own security forces and the desirable cooperation between States.  Together with other policies, mechanisms and infrastructurethat already exist or have been created, the strengthening of their funding and the extension of the scope of intervention affirms and continues the security posture of this European Union, which imposes control and restrictions on the freedoms and fundamental rights of citizens, which we reject.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Commissioner, I do not agree with what the prime minister said here, because it is really nonsense. Sometimes things fall down here in this room, I think a lot of people have not read the text at all and really have no idea about europol's work. I personally consider Europol to be one of the most important components for ensuring security in Europe. As I have seen in recent years, its cooperation with the Member States lacks not only systematicity, but also efficiency. Thanks to this regulation, we will now try to change that. After all, it must be automatic for the relevant authorities and Europol to share information and personal data on dangerous and potentially dangerous persons, I stress this. How else can we combat crime, organised crime or terrorism and ensure the security of the citizens of the European Union? In today's interconnected Europe, it is not possible that data transfers simply will not work. I am therefore a long-standing supporter of strengthening Europol, not only in the area of finance, but also in the area of competences. However, this is not possible unless there is a reorganisation of cooperation between the various institutions, both national and European. No organization can respond flexibly to new challenges and threats when it is not flexible enough. Here, neither extra funding nor any capacity increase will help. Here only the use of logic will help.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, I support this legislative initiative because it gives Europol new responsibilities, not least in training and training police officers, without inducing state sovereignty and the principle of subsidiarity. I believe that the solution under which each Member State establishes or appoints a specific national unit as a liaison body between Europol and the competent national authorities is adequate, as it will preserve the competences of the Member States without reducing the functionality and efficiency of Europol. I also welcome the enhanced scrutiny of Europol, which will be carried out through the Joint Parliamentary Scrutiny Group by the European Parliament and national parliaments, as this approach ensures transparency and respect for human rights. In addition to ordinary people, Europe has brought both criminal and terrorist groups closer to them and made their jobs much easier. That is why today more than ever we need quality cooperation between Member States in the fight against organised crime and a strong Europol.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Madam President! With the new Europe Agreement, Europe can step up its efforts against organised crime against terrorism and against cybercrime. We can now react more quickly in a world that is getting smaller and smaller. Today, we are giving Europol a stronger mandate to be better equipped to combat cross-border crime and terrorism. And that's what's needed! We are now making it easier to target our investigations into organised crime, and we are setting up specialised units to respond immediately to terrorism and crime.  I have had 25 years of my working life in the police and have seen how international crime has evolved in recent years. We need to develop and give the police better tools. If there are politicians who are opposed to this agreement or cannot vote for it, yes, I do not know whether it is based on ignorance or the stories of suckers, as Mrs Hohlmeier mentioned in her speech. What is the reason for it, I shall not be able to determine; But I would like to congratulate you on a good deal.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent It is a good day, with the commitment of the greatest possible constructive majority in this European Parliament to strengthen Europol. Congratulations to our rapporteur who has worked on this with the Shadows over the last few years. Building on this, however, I would like to address the next phase of development. I welcome Commissioner Avramopoulos' announcement to strengthen Europol to take further steps and to define the new needs in the fight against terrorism and organised crime over the next two years.  Looking at Europol's current capabilities, it is clear that the task of coordination alone in pure cooperation cannot be successful in the fight against high-tech terrorist networks and globalised organised crime. Europe must win this cruel battle. Europe must therefore be even stronger. The consequence is a European Security Union. A European Security Union, in which Europol must be a supranational agency, with its own member-led units under central command in cross-border operations across Europe. In this major step forward, I hope that the Commission will act accordingly efficiently. Yes, a European FBI can be at the end of this process – not in an EU as a union of states, but with the clout to guarantee the safety of European citizens.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think I can say without fear of denial that Europol is carrying out the functions it has been given to date with great professionalism and with excellent results. But the international scene has changed radically and is constantly evolving. Just think of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, just think of the immigration emergency that continues to be so.  That is why, today more than yesterday, Europol needs to be strengthened, through a significant increase in budgetary appropriations, with a consequential increase in the number of men and resources that will allow, also as provided for in this regulation, in an absolutely intelligent way, the establishment of specialised units to combat cybercrime and terrorist propaganda online, while also promoting better coordination between the police and intelligence forces of the Member States. , which has perhaps not happened on time to date. That is why I welcome this important regulation.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, in the first place I would, of course, like to greet our colleague Agustín Díaz de Mera for the excellent report he has produced, and I would essentially like to draw attention, indeed as a member of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, to three fundamental aspects of this renewal or revision of the Europol regime.  The first is that we are finally adapting europol's framework to the Treaty of Lisbon: it is a very important point, and that is, in particular, with what is the main aspect of my view, which is democratic control. It is an essential aspect that a police force can itself be, shall we say, scrutinised and scrutinised by the European Parliament.  On the other hand, too, the set of guarantees given in the case of data protection. Effectively combating crime today, in many cases, today, the collection of data, coordination and exchange of information, of a lot of information, which is sensitive, and therefore the data protection regime must be properly taken care of.  I would like to make a point here: many people have said that crime is living without borders today. It is important to understand this: she already lived without borders; those who lived with borders were the Member States. So crime has been in organised networks for a long time, and we are the ones who must also organise ourselves in network in order to combat this phenomenon. I believe that another important step has been taken here in order to have a police force capable of tackling the new phenomenon of cross-border crime.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: – Madam President, I would first like to congratulate Mr Díaz de Mera and the other colleagues on the tenacity in achieving the most powerful instrument possible to combat cross-border organised crime and terrorism within the European Union and in relation to third countries. The latest attacks within our borders, in Paris and Brussels, but also the previous ones in Madrid and London, have highlighted the dramatic and urgent need to provide a sufficiently strong and agreed-by legal framework for all to strongly support our European police, civil guards and law enforcement forces, who needed this European backing to strengthen and improve their work. This Regulation for Europol means greater investment in prevention through risk analysis and cooperation, but also more shared intelligence, including necessary infiltration, ending sanctuaries and more capacities to fight not only terrorism, but also against those other crimes underlying terrorism: dramatic human trafficking, money laundering and evasion and tax fraud , and also cyberattacks in a society like ours.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, in recent years both Europol's capabilities and budget have been increasing, especially in the fight against terrorism. But the practical results are disappointing. This has been shown recently, both in France and Belgium. Emphasis must certainly be placed on the fight against terrorism, particularly in specific regions of Member States. But this must be done with respect for the private lives of the citizens of the Union. On the contrary, it is being attempted, in the name of combating terrorism, to feed further repression and surveillance of citizens at pan-European level from state budgets, and while this policy has proven to have shown its limits in the fight against terrorism. The European Union should encourage Member States to spend money on guarding their borders, as well as on social inclusion and employment programmes for Muslim populations living for decades in Member States of the European Union. This is the only way to prevent terrorism effectively.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent terrorist attacks and growing threats in cyberspace have highlighted the need to strengthen our intelligence system in order to promote greater coordination and greater capacity for joint action. Europol is given more powers and its ability to respond immediately to terrorist threats and border crimes is enhanced.  I particularly welcome the strengthening of the role of the Internet Referral Unit, Europol's unit engaged in the fight against terrorist propaganda online, which will have to identify content considered dangerous and provide support to national governments. The new governance rules will enable Europol to step up its efforts to combat terrorism and cybercrime. One positive aspect of the reform is also democratic control over the agency.  In short, a step forward has been taken, but it is still not enough. Given the high level of threat, I think it is necessary to propose a further strengthening of Europol, both for support for operations on the ground and for the activities of its centre for the exchange of information on criminal activities.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, we need a strong European Security and Intelligence Union. This Europol proposal is a compromise. But let's not forget that there is no compromise with terrorists and criminals. That's why I'm not satisfied. I think we need to take it a step further and do it as soon as possible. I can understand that there are disagreements in the EU over various situations. When it comes to the security and intelligence situation, we can't find ourselves in this situation we're in. We know what's been going on in the last few months. We have Schengen in question. Since we already have freedom of movement, we must have a mandatory exchange of information. We need a strong, unified, security and intelligence union.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I support the new regulation for Europol. I believe that European citizens need a better legal framework for the fight against terrorism and their safety. The new regulation improves cross-border cooperation and anti-crime actions. It is one of the few pieces of legislation that focuses on national parliaments and the European Parliament. This means an increase in the quality of democracy. It is good that the new regulation also provides for data protection, but as I have said many times, the protection of personal data must go to the place where it does not affect security. Improving Europol's governance will lead to an increase in the safety of European citizens. The exchange of information between Member States must work and no longer be, Commissioner, the Achilles heel. We must no longer hear, after a terrorist act, that it is the exchange of information that did not work. People's lives are the most important thing and we must not discount anything that supports the safety of citizens.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would also like to join in the voices which from this Parliament are celebrating the completion of this legislative procedure; who congratulate my colleague in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, Mr Díaz de Mera, as rapporteur, because we are indeed doing work which is to update, in accordance with the Lisbon Treaty, a crucial tool to combat cross-border crime in its worst forms. Illicit human trafficking, drug trafficking, arms trafficking, corruption, money laundering from illicit businesses effectively require up-to-date Europol.  But more needs to be done. Political will to really make Europol the embryo of that European FBI. There was a time, a before and after, in the history of integration in the United States in which it was learned that, in the fight against insecurity and crime, it was imperative to end impunity for the simple dossier of crossing the border from one state to another. It is time for Europeans to learn the lesson by making Europol the embryo of a genuine European FBI.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – I welcome the reform in question by the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation. In the light of the recent terrorist attacks mentioned here by many colleagues, it is important that Europol is able to respond more quickly and actively to terrorist threats. The safety of European citizens must come first. It is therefore important that we start to control internet threats more intensively, which can lead to real crimes.  We urgently need to improve cooperation between individual Member States and ensure that Europol investigators are also able to investigate across borders, for which they must be provided with adequate financial and material resources. This legislation does not in any way jeopardise the civil liberties of citizens of the Member States of the European Union; Europol will be under the democratic control of the European Parliament and national parliaments.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, firstly I would like to express my thanks for the contribution of this House to this debate. The common denominator of almost all here is that we must respond to the need of our citizens for more safety and this is what we are trying to do through this reform, because we all know that terrorism and serious transnational crime – as you mentioned, and of course I endorse this point of view – does not acknowledge borders. Our law enforcement authorities are responsible for the security of our citizens. To effectively track the perpetrators they need a true hub for information exchange, with full operational and analytical support. With the improved framework we are putting in place, Europol will be able to connect the dots and give Member States the support they need to fight terrorism and serious crime. Europol will be able to do this more efficiently and more effectively. It will now be more accountable and will work in full respect of our data protection rules. I encourage you today to vote in favor of the compromise text. Let us put in motion what we have discussed together for years and let us make it work for our citizens.  COMMISSION STATEMENT Commission statement on the Common Approach to the EU Decentralised Agencies  "The Commission recalls that the agreed text is not fully aligned with the principles of the Common Approach on the EU decentralised agencies. Therefore the agreement reached between the EP and the Council on the governance of the agency is without prejudice to any future legislative texts. The Commission remains convinced of the benefits of establishing an Executive Board as part of the governance structure of Europol and other agencies. The Commission will review the situation concerning Europol governance within the next two years, in particular with a view to determining whether further proposals on this point will be warranted."  Commission statement on the Cooperation Board  "The European Commission consider that, following the adoption of the proposed General Data Protection Regulation and Data Protection Directive for data processing in the police and justice sector and in light of the announced review of Regulation (EC) No 45/2001, to ensure effectiveness and consistency and avoid unnecessary duplication, the functions exercised by Cooperation Board set up in this Regulation shall be exercised by the newly created European Data Protection Board."

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President; Thank you, Mr Avramopoulos, Commissioner, I am referring to your two interventions in terms of gratitude, greatly ingesting your words because you actually put your finger on the sore. This is more coordination, more analysis, more parliamentary control and more data protection. Basically, that's what it's all about. It is a question of us having an Agency that is a powerful information exchange centre and that has very developed its analysis capacity to protect Europeans. One qualm: I support what Maite Pagazaurtundúa said; with reference to governance, it must be taken into account that the Board of Directors has to have a lot of professional and unso politicians. And then, with reference to the speeches of colleagues, I thank them very much. I give you a summary: there have been forty-two interventions; based on knowledge of cause; others, in intuitive knowledge. In any case, all of them are worthy of valuation and worthy of respect. Very grateful for the coincidental ones, and regret the disagreeants, but they are in their rightful right. In any case, I would like to simplify by saying that, of the forty-two interventions, thirty-two supported the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs in their work. There are six of these who want Europol even more, mainly located in the ALDE Group. And lastly I would like to dedicate it to the Green Group, and to value its action and to value its political commitment. Thank you for supporting the Europol Regulation, regardless of whether you have your qualms, tabled an amendment which is more than basically in shape and which concerns the processing of the IRU. In any case, thank you all for this fruitful debate and for this collaboration which I repeat, I value so much and thank you from the shadow rapporteurs.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place from 12:00 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. Europol's contribution to the fight against terrorism and serious crime is potentially very useful, as recent news events have also demonstrated the centrality of the exchange of information between national intelligence. The proposal for a regulation, which should therefore update its operation in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon, is therefore welcome. In addition to introducing greater democratic control by the European and national Parliament over Europol's activities, it has improvements in terms of the protection of processed data, which had previously been identified and complained of. The hope is that the agency can provide valuable, effective and reliable support to the fight against transnational crime, while respecting strict respect for the dictates of the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – The new regulation on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) is a step forward for police cooperation in the Member States. Cooperation between supervisory authorities, at national and EU level, will contribute to the establishment of a high and harmonised level of information exchange and data protection, encompassing police and judicial activities in the Union. I believe that Europol must have access to the exchange of information with NGOs and be able to ask social networks to delete ISIS pages from their websites. The creation of special units to respond immediately to possible terrorist attacks and other forms of organised crime is indispensable. Equipping Europol with the EU Online Content Reporting Unit will make it possible to remove terrorist propaganda websites, and the new Anti-Terrorist Counter-Terrorism Centre and the European Cybercrime Centre will ensure the prevention of the spread of terrorism. Member States should be required in the future to transmit to Europol all the data necessary to achieve the Agency's objectives.

name: Julia PITERA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ensuring a high level of harmonised data protection in the European Union, including police and judicial action, is crucial for respecting and protecting the fundamental rights of EU citizens. Close and effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and EU level based on security, the area of freedom and justice is necessary. Over the years, Europol's operational competences have gradually expanded. Recently, units have been set up to increase the agency's powers of analysis and counter-terrorism. They include the European Cybercrime Centre and the EU's online reporting unit to combat terrorist propaganda and other online extremist activities. The latest entity is the European Counter-Terrorism Centre established on 1 January 2016. The new Europol Regulation (2013/0091(COD)), which enters into force in all EU Member States on 1 May 2017, establishes legal tools to strengthen the security of EU citizens and to effectively fight terrorism. In order to strike a balance, the focus should be on security on the one hand and on protecting citizens' privacy on the other. The most important thing is close European cooperation and coordination between the various authorities.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. – When we talk about european police office and law enforcement, we must not forget respecting and protecting the fundamental rights of EU citizens. Close and effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at Member State and European Union level is crucial in this regard. With good cooperation, we will achieve efficiency and avoid duplication of activities.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Europe's priority now is to fight crime.
