In this situation, the cooperation of the European institutions in the fight against this practice must be improved. The European Union should step up its efforts to combat terrorism, trafficking in human beings and drugs, prevent physical and sexual violence against children and reduce such widespread crimes in cyberspace. The European police must constantly increase their effectiveness. Europol is a key body in the fight against all illegal activities that are so common at this time. Better exchange of information is needed. Data collection, storage and analysis activities need to be improved. Countering terrorist propaganda will make Europe's citizens feel safer. I would like to mention that the cooperation undertaken to maintain an adequate level of security has been established by the European institutions, but not comprehensively enough that no new project needs to be drawn up to improve the existing system. Appropriate legislation must be adopted to protect sensitive personal data. The coordination of the measures taken needs to be improved, which will, as a result, ensure much-needed security in Europe.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – It is good that the European Parliament is dealing with the extension of Europol's anti-terrorist competences. However, I am critical of the fact that this debate and recommendations are only being taken up now. There is no doubt that we must significantly improve the effectiveness of the fight against terrorism in Europe and respond more quickly to threats. Experience with the fight against terrorists shows that it requires much closer cooperation between countries and a stronger role for Europol. This European office based in The Hague should create and update databases on terrorist threats. EU Member States should be required to provide Europol with data so that they can use the information contained in one integrated database themselves, rather than seeking it in each of the 28 EU countries. This also requires an increase in the resources and staffing of the European Counter-Terrorism Centre within europol. If we are consistent in implementing these measures, this will undoubtedly increase the chances of fighting terrorist threats more effectively.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the recommendation for second reading of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research purposes, education, training, volunteering, student exchange and au pair work (14958/2/2015 - C8-0131/2016 - 2013/0081 (COD)) (Reporter: Cecilia Wikstrom (A8-0166/2016)).

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, allow me to start by thanking the entire team that has worked on this important dossier over a number of years and a special thanks, of course, to my own assistant and to the shadow rapporteurs and their teams, as well as for the excellent work by the Secretariat of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and colleagues in the Commission. I have had the pleasure of working together with several very competent presidencies also and here a special word of gratitude needs to be expressed to the Luxembourg Presidency for their enormous efforts on this dossier, without which I doubt we would be standing here today.  Competitiveness is all about attracting excellent intellectuals from all over the world to come to the European Union and make their contribution in our different Member States. The excellent researchers, entrepreneurs and students of the world will help us develop the growing competitive business of tomorrow. In doing so, they will be the ones to bring economic growth, employment and social progress to our economies and societies. For far too long, this continent has crippled itself completely unnecessarily, imposing bureaucracy and hindering creative and productive minds that only want to make their contribution to our societies.  Let me give you some concrete examples. When we started working on this directive, my home country, Sweden, had a system where graduate researchers, doctors, engineers and others who had received a PhD from outside Europe were given 14 days to basically leave the country once they had completed their studies or their research projects. Instead of putting to use the knowledge and experience of these people whom we had helped to educate and had invested a lot of money in, we pushed them away and most of them went to other places in the world – to the US, to Canada and to Australia – and made their contributions to society there.  With the directive we are about to vote on tomorrow, all masters students, as well as researchers, will now have the possibility to stay up to nine months in the EU to apply for jobs or start a business after they have concluded their studies or research. The mobility regime for students will be greatly improved by the new directive. Students will be able to move from day one with a simple notification. Before, they needed a full application. As for researchers, mobility is also improved with the extension of short-term mobility up to six months, compared with three months before. The minimum time that students are allowed to work will also be increased from 10 hours to 15 hours a week.  Before the revision of the Directive, the entry into the EU of family members of researchers was previously fully discretional upon Member States and they had absolutely no right to intra-EU mobility and no right to access the labour market. The present proposals constitute a major step forward by ensuring that family members can easily accompany researchers to Europe and they are allowed to work. This is very important for the attractiveness of European universities when they are competing to attract the best minds from all over the world.  Finally, the scope of the directive will be increased. Trainees are now added as a mandatory category and European Voluntary Service volunteers are added as a mandatory category and au pairs as an optional category. It should be noted that this is actually the first time ever that we have granted protection to au pairs through an EU instrument. Before the review, unremunerated trainees were optional, they are now covered. In these days when we talk mostly about migration – internal migration policy – I think it is especially important that we manage to conclude on a major dossier which promotes legal migration to the EU. We need far more of this in the days to come and I hope that we can continue to be ambitious in this regard. Thank you once again to everyone that has contributed to this great success.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by saying that I am really glad that we are finalising the revision of the Directive on students and research. Today I fulfil also my commitment that I gave you during the hearing one and a half year ago. This updated directive makes the EU more attractive for talents from abroad and, therefore, makes the European Union more competitive on the global scale. I would like to express my thanks, in particular, to Ms Wikström and the shadow rapporteurs, who have done a fantastic job. Thanks to your excellent work we have managed to keep a really ambitious text.  Κυρία Wallström ξέρω ότι μιλάτε και ελληνικά και θα ήθελα να σας πω και στην κοινή μας γλώσσα ένα μεγάλο ευχαριστώ! Η συμβολή σας ήταν και είναι καθοριστική. The conclusion of the negotiations is important for several reasons. Firstly, we have clearly improved the immigration rules for students and researchers. Their rights are now more clearly defined. Secondly, intra-EU mobility rules have been improved so that knowledge and skills can circulate more freely within the European Union. Thirdly, students can now work a minimum of 15 instead of 10 hours per week, which means they contribute more to our economy and they can also be financially more independent.  With the new instrument, graduates and researchers have a right to look for a job or to set up a business once they have finished their studies or research. Finally, we now also have binding EU-wide rules for trainees and volunteers within the European Voluntary Service. In parallel, for the first time we will also have common rules for third—country national au pairs, though only optionally.  Let me also underline that the agreement sends out important messages in these challenging times. First of all, we welcome talent from outside of the European Union to come to us to study, carry out research, learn or volunteer. Those who would like to stay longer to work or to create a business are invited to do so. Equally importantly, we show that the EU sticks to its commitments to improve legal migration routes.  Understandably, a lot of focus is now on the refugee crisis and people seeking protection. But migration is not just about asylum. It is also about mobility and empowerment, and facilitating that through legal channels. This is an important part of our overall migration policy and we deliver, as promised.  Overall, could we have done better? Yes, there is almost always room for improvement. The Commission, together with this Parliament, has insisted throughout the negotiations that Member States’ discretionary powers with regard to rejecting an application may only be used when strictly necessary and, of course, justified.  We made it clear in our joint statement to the political compromise that such discretionary power by the Member States should only be used on a case-by-case basis. It should take into account the specific circumstances of the third—country national and the principle of proportionality, and on the basis of evidence or serious and objective reasons. I can reiterate that the Commission will ensure that Member States implement this provision in line with this interpretation when transposing the directive and will inform Parliament and the Council thereof.  Today Europe attracts 45% of international students worldwide but the international higher education landscape is changing rapidly. Such students and researchers are an asset and a contribution and I welcome the agreement on the revised EU rules to facilitate that contribution even more.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the PPE Group also very much welcomes this agreement. Europe needs to be attractive in the global competition for talents. We have a knowledge—based economy and facilitating the entry of researchers, students and unremunerated trainees to bring their skills to Europe is important to sustain European growth, innovation and jobs. We need to train, develop and keep talents in Europe to match the needs of our companies, our academic institutions, our universities and other research institutions.  The PPE goal has been to have a system that strikes the right balance between facilitating access and, at the same time, preventing abuse. I am glad that we have reached our goal. With this directive we move from cumbersome, long, fragmented procedures to common, clear and simple rules across Europe. We are cutting red tape, we are providing legal certainty. One of the main achievements is the intra—EU mobility, the possibility for students and researchers to continue their activities in another Member State without having to leave Europe and reapply again for entry. This will, of course, encourage cross—fertilisation, exchange of knowledge, people—to—people contact and also the possibility to finalise research projects or degrees. Let us be clear. This directive is not about letting more people into Europe. The rules are clear. Member States will continue to decide how many entry permits are granted and they will also have the possibility to do labour market checks when deciding on admission. This is not about students and researchers taking European jobs. On the contrary, it is about them contributing to creating jobs in Europe. So students and researchers will be given the possibility to work, but the rules of the labour market will remain national. Applicants for admission have to clearly show that they are able to support themselves and they are not living on social benefits. I hope that this big achievement will not be undermined by populist rhetoric.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. Europe has still not fully recovered from the consequences of the economic crisis and the demographic picture remains unchanged. Due to complex and long bureaucratic processes and modest investments in development, research and education, we are lagging behind the world's most advanced in the acquisition of young talent. We're wasting a lot of potential, and they're going somewhere else.  The revised rules will make it easier for many young people to stay and work in the European Union, give them more rights, allow them to work more and research while studying, and the possibility to stay in Europe for another year after completing their studies. More rights will now be enjoyed by their family members. The fact is that they are more successful in attracting young talent to the rest of the world today, and if we do not change that, we have an uncertain future ahead.  The revised rules, which we will be voting on at noon, and I believe we also get strong support, are the result of long and difficult negotiations, but we have managed a great victory. Through the efforts of socialists and democrats, we have succeeded in ensuring that young foreign students, researchers, practit professionals, volunteers and nannies have simpler and faster procedures for obtaining visas or permits to enter, more social or labour rights and health and legal protection. It has been the case so far because of a lack of legal protection that has often led to exploitation. They will now be included in the legal framework. We must stop the exploitation of foreign young people once and for all, and Europe must set an example.  I am convinced that these new rules will have a positive impact on cultural, scientific and social cross-border ties and people-to-people contacts. Only an innovative and more competitive Europe will create new jobs and make it more attractive to young talent from all over the world.  Despite the important achievements, However, I regret that, from now on, Member States will have the opportunity to refuse an application for a visa or an entry permit even without good reason. Without this clause, the Council did not want to turn on the green light to the directive. In Parliament, therefore, we will closely monitor the implementation of the rules in practice and, in the event of abuse, take appropriate action.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This is a good decision, it is good that we have been dealing with two important issues since the morning. The first concerns security, the second is about Europe's openness, because that is what it is all about, free access and good conditions for staying in Europe for those who are engaged in research, learning – students and volunteers. This is a question of Europe's global responsibility, as well as the competitiveness of our countries. From the point of view of Polish experience, this directive is also the most positive factor. I want to tell you that Poland is besieged by students from Ukraine, by scientists from Ukraine. These are thousands of people who want to tie their fates to Poland, so it makes sense to approximate legislation in this area. All this must be linked to the scientific policy of the European Union, to cooperation between universities, to better exchanges within the European Union itself.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I take my hat off to the remarkable work that has been done by our colleague, Cecilia Wikstrom. Congratulations, dear colleague.  To live up to its ambitions and destiny, Europe must at least meet three challenges. First, invest heavily in innovation, i.e. intelligence to boost growth and create jobs. Second, maintain and strengthen its social model by guaranteeing equal rights and combating all forms of discrimination. Thirdly, not to fall back on itself but to radiate in the world the original synthesis that it wants to promote between its growth model and its unique social model.  It is in the light of these three requirements that I fully support the proposal before us today. Its aim is, first of all, to facilitate access to European territory for highly qualified people. Tomorrow, thanks to this proposal, a student will be able to come to Europe more easily, he will have more opportunities for work and mobility and the right to stay for twelve months in the Union in order to look for a job. Furthermore, I welcome the more favourable conditions offered to researchers, both in terms of family reunification and mobility, by allowing them to continue their research in other Member States than the one that provided them with their residence permits.  But I also intend to emphasise, with the same vigour, the contribution of this proposal to the development of the European social model. I am pleased that status is finally being offered to au pairs and unpaid trainees, which are fragile if any, and therefore susceptible to exploitation. Europe is thus true to itself, both in its economic ambition and in its social vocation. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Thank you very much for the opportunity to ask, Mr President, and to you, Congressman. I share your optimism, by the way, and I will vote for this proposal. But we have to say that this was born three years ago, when the migration crisis was not as fierce as it is now. Do you see the protection mechanisms of this proposal as sufficient against anti-foreigner tendencies?

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: "blue card" answer. "Your question seems important to me. I think we all agree that tomorrow we must organise legal routes of access to European territory, defining the conditions and modalities so that at the same time people can come in safe conditions and that this is positive for us, for the European economy, for them and for the development of the European Union. So I think this proposal is going in the right direction, even though it has taken a long time to arrive.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, today we approve of ensuring greater freedom of movement for a small group of people and the large parliamentary groups in the House welcome the supposedly progressive progress. They fill their mouths talking about free movement, while people are being gassed at borders and prevented from finding a safe place to settle on our continent.  Today, everyone is talking about facilitating access and stay on our continent for researchers and senior students, but they are the same ones who vote in favor of speeding up and increasing deportation and shielding our borders.  It seems that only the rights of an elite matter, because those fleeing war or fleeing exploitation are expelled and returned to the places from which they have fled thanks to that European Union-Turkey Agreement.  It is enormously classist whether or not you can enter the European Union depending on whether or not you have had access to higher education. But the People's Party said that during all negotiations: that it is not about migration, but about added value for businesses, that is, that is what we people are: if we serve big companies, if we serve so that large companies can have benefits, we can enter; if not, then we are expelled.  They start by wanting only those who come to investigate or come to do PhDs to come, but how are they going to end up? Will they end up like Slovakia's fellow Social Democrats, who just want to welcome Christian refugees?   (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr President, dear colleague, from the outset I want to say that I do not share what you have said.  I support the report, it is very welcome, but I ask you: do you really think that we really do not have to think about the security of citizens and that there is the possibility of selecting people entering the Member State, in the Member States in order to ensure our citizens security? Do you really not think that we need to improve security in the European Union?

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: "blue card" response. – No, I believe that what we have to do in the European Union is to comply with international legality and to welcome all those who are fleeing wars or fleeing exploitation in their countries. I believe that linking security to migration is extremely dangerous and is sending a message which is not a positive thing for the values we are supposed to stand for in the European Union.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to add my thanks to our rapporteur for the work that she has done on this, and just say a word to the previous speaker: I would agree with a lot of what you have said, but I do not think we are necessarily making a choice here – by restricting the rights of some, you do not necessarily expand the rights of others. I think this is an important piece of legislation, and I think it is important not only for the individuals concerned or for the institutions with which some of them may be studying or working, but it is also an important part of a soft foreign policy. Some of the questions raised here today about the difficulties of access – about the feeling that you are not actually wanted as a student or a researcher in the European Union – have been raised with a number of us during many of the delegation trips that we have travelled on to various third countries.  I also want to say that I welcome the Commission’s statement in terms of its interpretation of transposition, about rejection being based on a case-by-case basis, because I think that is really important. I, too, on behalf of my Group, welcome the improvements within this directive in terms of reducing a number of the barriers and the difficulties that people have faced. While we were working on this report, we came across cases of people who had not been able to take up research positions because they had waited so long for various permissions. That not only affected their lives, but the research projects on which they were coming to work.  We also welcome the possibilities of having greater opportunities to finalise your research if there have been particular problems during the course of it, and of course the questions about families being able to stay together is also extremely important. For volunteers, the question about this possibility to develop intercultural understanding, we see the exchange of expertise, too, as crucial for strengthening civil society – such an important part of any democracy.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this debate is about rules for people coming from outside the European Union into the European Union, whether for studying, for research, for training, for voluntary work, to become an au pair or for an educational project. Quite often this kind of migration actually does have a positive impact on society, so I am not going to stand here and argue that international students coming to the UK, paying fees to British universities, helping some of the top universities in the world to survive, is in any way a bad thing. In fact, in a lot of ways I would rather have non-EU students than EU students coming to the United Kingdom under the current rules, because we actually get a rather rough deal when the British Government gives EU students loans which are often not repaid.  So what is the problem? Well, although people coming to the UK to study can be a good thing, it is also a decision that we should take as the British people ourselves, based on common sense and thinking about what we need for our colleges and our universities and what is right for the United Kingdom. This EU nonsense, expecting us to extend these changes not just to those who wish to study or do research here but also to their families and also for an additional 18 months after the course of study is completed, is likely to result in something approaching a free—for—all.  At the moment, we in the UK do have an opt—out, so the side in the British referendum campaign which is currently busy claiming that Brexit will lead inexorably to World War III are going to be the ones that will accuse me of scaremongering. But an opt-out is only an opt-out until some bright spark decides that they want us to opt back in. After that, it is too late, because of the ratchet principle of the acquis communautaire in this Union. Maybe you trust David Cameron not to opt back in and maybe you trust Jeremy Corbyn, but watch the Labour Party in today’s vote, because if Labour votes for this today you can bet that any future Labour government would vote to opt us back in. So whenever we have an opt—out, you have to ask yourself: do you trust Cameron, do you trust Corbyn, and do you trust every future British Prime Minister? If you cannot say yes to all three, the bottom line is that by voting to stay in the European Union, you vote to risk handing over control of our immigration policy to Brussels.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: on behalf of the ENF group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, several years ago there was talk of the European Union having the best high schools in the world, and of the United States having the best universities in the world. Of course, it was a simplified irony, but these expressions at the level of common understanding turn into stereotypes that generate serious mistakes when taken up as correct political dogmas. Of course, facilitating the access of young people from third countries to the European education system is a noble and generous idea. I'm not opposed to that idea! The more valuable young people in European universities, the better. But I want to point out that the devil is hiding in the details. It's not enough to have brains, you also need to know what to do with them and how to put them to work. Does the European Union have a strategy for this? Do we know how to make specialists of Member States trained in the European Union not just a form of brain draining? Do we know how to convince them to go back to their countries and become a relay of European culture and science? Finally, do we know how to make these contacts increase the level of our universities?  The European Union is not a vessel to be filled, but a flame that must illuminate!

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, it is a mockery that immigration from outside the Union is a source of influx of highly skilled people, and I explain. Young people in the Member States face serious problems of unemployment and access to the specialised labour market. Especially in Greece and the countries of the South, undergraduate and postgraduate graduates are forced either to flee their home countries or to work undeclared, uninsured and uncertain about the future. What excuse will you make to the two hundred thousand young people who have left Greece for the right-wing and left-wing memoranda? What have you done about the decimation of the Greek population, the deforestation of the scientific elite and the unimaginable youth unemployment rate? Those who promote projects to strengthen cultural links and enrich cultural diversity have no right to force Member States to accept third-country nationals under the guise of scientific potential. Greek and European nationalists are no less humanistic and socially sensitive as you accuse us of. The demographic deterioration of Europe is a ticking time bomb for Europe and a direct threat to national security, to the social cohesion of the states. Excellent young scientists can grow up with similar incentives in their own countries.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first of all like to congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their work on this proposal for a directive. Indeed, the agreement reached with the Council makes it possible to clarify and improve the conditions for trainees, volunteers, students and non-European pupils for the benefit of the Union and its Member States, as well as countries of origin. I would like to highlight three things. Firstly, this directive will have to be used by the Member States to achieve the Europe 2020 targets. The entry and stay requirements for students and researchers, in particular, will encourage faster internationalization of our teaching systems. It is about making the Union more attractive, more competitive and achieving a Europe of knowledge and innovation: that is our objective, and we are taking a real step forward today. Another important asset of the text, which can be welcomed, is that it presents measures to ensure better protection for trainees by giving a Member State the opportunity to ensure that the internship does not replace a job. Finally, I call here for this new directive to be taken into account in the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy.  Education, research and the promotion of cultural exchanges remain objectives and ways to build bridges between Europe and its neighbours, especially with the Mediterranean region. This directive makes perfect sense if it is used with our neighbours. It is a mutual investment between us and our neighbours for, in particular, young people, and we know how crucial it is to provide opportunities for young people in certain countries in our neighbourhood. I am pleased that we can conclude this issue and encourage, here, a controlled intelligent policy and circular migration.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, responsible management of migration also means, and above all, opening up legal and legal channels of legal immigration. Thus, with the adoption of this directive, Parliament and the Council take note of the need to harmonise procedures and make it easier for researchers, students, pupils, volunteers and children on an equal footing to enter and stay.  With today's vote, we are paving the way for a future common migration policy based on channels of regular access to the European Union. Of course, these are still temporary economic migration measures, but a first step has been taken. Thanks to the changes made by this House during the legislative procedure, third-country nationals will have the right to enter, reside and carry out part of their research or studies in one or more Member States. The same right will also be granted to pupils, volunteers and equal workers. We recognise the right of these same persons to treat them in the same way as the Member State concerned. Students and researchers recognise the possibility of staying for a period after the expiry of their studies or research in order to enable them to find a job or start a business.  Demographic challenges and multiple labour shortages, not only highly specialised, require us to review fragmented national policies on economic migration, to focus on general rules on the entry and residence of workers from third countries. Opening up channels for economic migrants would also be the most effective measure to counter the modern slavery that is increasingly taking root in our territories, through the exploitation of labour by migrant workers, especially women. It is a fact, Mr President: Europe can only prosper if it facilitates the mobility of knowledge, goods and people.

name: Sander LOONES
text: – Should we accept our asylum responsibility? Yes, we should. But let's also honestly ask the question: when is alleged mercy naivety? Let us honestly identify the challenges of taking in asylum seekers. If we want and need to provide them with a social safety net, we will also need a strong economy to support that.  And so we get to the theme of this debate: how can we bring top-level students and researchers to Europe? How do we ensure that we attract that global top talent and thus strengthen our welfare state? At the same time, we must not be naïve, because when we look at the environment, when we look at Europe, we also see very high youth unemployment. We also have to charge for that. This proposal also does so effectively by allowing the Member States to decide for themselves how many visas they grant and how many do not, but also by leaving our social welfare state and social security with the Member States. That seems to me to be a real win-win situation.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after complex negotiations, this Directive reaches the stage when it can be applied to all third-country nationals who are requesting to be admitted to a European country to complete a path of research, study, practice or volunteering.  I believe that we all in this house share the same reflection: among the dreams achieved by the European Union, among the most powerful successes of European integration, is the Erasmus programme. Today, thanks to this Recommendation, we take another step towards a global Erasmus system, towards even stronger cultural and educational cooperation at the international level.  This text aims to simplify the regulatory framework for attracting youth talent to the European Union. The requirements of a modern society require strengthening social and cultural ties through a constructive exchange of excellence beyond European borders.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome this directive because we understand that it favours the social and labour integration of those non-Eu-Community people who, after their studies are completed, decide to research or work in Europe, and we understand that this is something that will have positive effects on our societies and in our economies in the short and medium term. However, it is a starting point, it is not yet a point of arrival, there are many aspects to be improved, for example, with regard to groups such as au pairs or au pairs, which often live in situations of unprotection, with working conditions of absolute misery. And these are not a few cases: in 2014 there were 59,000 Spaniards working in this sector. Being an au pair shouldn't be synonymous with cheap labor. We also hope that this Directive will serve to eliminate discriminatory practices, such as those of some regional governments, for example in Spain, which charge three times as many non-EU students. We therefore hope that it will be fulfilled and that equal treatment of European and third-country citizens will be ensured.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, as a member of the Committee on Culture and Education, I have a great interest in issues that have something to do with training and education. You estimate that in the coming years, the research and development sector will require an additional 1,000,000 jobs. Why not give them to our unemployed - about 12% in the euro area, 40% in France? Students who are bac 5 students do not have a job one year after their studies. On the other hand, you say in the explanatory statement that our best researchers and innovators are moving in their thousands to countries where conditions are more favourable. If the conditions were made right, there would be no brain drain. Bringing in cheap labour that can move unhindered throughout the European Union, what about our own unemployed, our students and our researchers? Do they have less talent than migrants? As for development policy, it would mean that young people could be trained at home to be the future elites of their country and contribute to the development of their own country. Colleagues, I respect your wishful thinking for the growth of Europe, I would just like you to seek to do so with the Europeans.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I believe that this directive, which has been under discussion for more than three years, is indeed already in a state where we can support it. It should meet the objective of simplifying the rules on entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purpose of study, research. This merges the rules for students and researchers and extends the scope to trainees, volunteers and au pairs. Although, in the case of the latter two, these rules are not mandatory for the Member States, and I think it is right that the principle of subsidiarity is respected here. The conditions set in this way have the potential to attract young, talented people to the European Union, which, of course, promotes mobility. They also make the European Union a more attractive environment for talented people from all over the world. I think this is necessary to improve Europe's competitiveness. We are moving in this direction in a similar way to the United States of America, which has long attracted talent into its territory. I also see as positive the fact that the directive gives researchers the opportunity to bring their family members to the European Union as well. I think this is the right case for family reunification. I see as partly controversial the possibility for students to stay in the European Union for at least nine months after graduation or research, but I think there has been a reasonable compromise here too. I therefore support the result.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Mr President, legal migration is not a danger to the European Union and its Member States. On the contrary, they represent an asset for our economies and an opportunity for the future, all the more so in the face of the important demographic challenge we face. The Group of Socialists and Democrats fully supports this directive, which will clarify and harmonize the conditions for students and researchers to enter and stay in Europe, as well as voluntary trainees and au pairs.  This text contains many necessary advances to make the Union more attractive to citizens of third countries who constitute a veritable breeding ground for new talent. Enhanced rights are guaranteed for students and researchers, especially with regard to the right to work. Their mobility is facilitated at European level, which will also apply to their loved ones. It was also essential that the directive remove many administrative obstacles and thus facilitate admission procedures. I welcome this text, which is in addition to the EU's panel of measures on legal migration. It will only revitalise the European area of education and research, and offer positive prospects for our societies, both from a social and cultural point of view. More than that, it is entirely in line with our desire to open safe and legal paths to Europe.  However, we should go beyond this fragmented approach, which continues to apply only to certain categories of people. The next step will have to be to propose a comprehensive framework, which governs the stay of third-country nationals in the EU, in order to be able to meet the needs of the European labour market.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: – I welcome the future decision of the European Parliament. Europe must be home to all smart, young scientists innovators. To refugee pressures, Europe must respond with the attraction and selection of highly qualified young scientists. But what do we do about brain draining inside the European Union?  My homeland Bulgaria is a victim of emigration. Millions of young and smart Bulgarians were banished abroad from hunger and misery and became part of the intellectual elite of Britain, France, Spain and other European countries.  However, we must approach carefully and with the necessary safeguards for European nations. We must selectively pass for Europe only to those students and scientists who are sure to increase our intellectual potential and high-tech industries for which there is a shortage of labour.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Mr President, this directive is supposed to facilitate the arrival of foreign students in the European Union, so that they can train and use their skills in their country of origin. But in reality, this directive will create new channels of legal immigration. These nationals are called upon to stay in Europe to supposedly make up for a shortage of skilled labour, which is totally grotesque, because, finally, if our young graduates do not emigrate by the thousands each year to escape mass unemployment, we would not be here today to try to plug the brain drain, for which you are the main culprits. In truth, this directive will once again contribute to increasing competition between newly graduated labour market candidates, to the great satisfaction of large companies who will benefit from a skilled and cheap workforce. In short, this directive reflects the Commission's contempt for our young people who are suffering from unemployment and contempt for countries whose future depends mainly on the return of their brains and talents.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, in the cut-throat global competition for highly skilled professionals, attracting and keeping talent from outside the EU is an ever—increasing challenge. Unfortunately, thousands of the best researchers and innovators have already chosen to head to the US, Australia or Canada, where they are welcomed with more favourable conditions.  Human capital represents one of the key assets to achieving smart growth. The Europe 2020 strategy has already recognised that to remain globally competitive and to meet its targets, Europe needs at least one million more research jobs. In this context, it is essential that we also attract highly skilled third country national students and researchers. This is why having a common set of rules on admission and residence requirements in the European Union would greatly contribute to increasing the attractiveness of the EU as a destination for talent. I think that the agreement reached on the final text, by reducing administrative red tape and allowing increased intra—EU mobility and access for students to our labour markets by preventing attempts to abuse that system, will bring us one step closer to attracting the best and brightest minds to our economies.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, the European Union is not in good shape, is it? In fact, it is going through the worst crisis in its history and almost everything has been going wrong for a long time, but when I am asked for a short answer to what I appreciate most about European construction, I say without a doubt: the free movement of people. And what do I fight the most? The negative look at immigration that practically opens very few—if any—windows to regular immigration.  Well, this recasting of two directives, which must be welcomed by the work of your rapporteur, our colleague Mrs Wikstrom, is a step in the right direction. Because it not only regulates and strengthens the rights of students, researchers, phD students, trainees – paid or unpaid – volunteer service and au pair staff, but also certifies a strengthening of those rights in relation to the limitation of their working day and their "backpack" also of social rights.  But above all, it opens a regular immigration door to an ageing Europe that urgently needs it, not just qualified personnel. But, I stress, it is only a limited step that needs to be expanded with a clear strengthening of the smart European migration policy of managing migration flows, not only for students and researchers, but in general with all those who are in a position to contribute to the support of our social model, with their work, with their contribution to social contributions and the support of public services that characterize the way we are European , more in crisis and worse crisis than ever before.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Mr President, in the current migration crisis, we often forget that, in addition to illegal migrants and refugees, Europe is also attractive to highly skilled third-country workers. An ageing population and a shortage of skilled labour are worrying in terms of the need to develop information technology, digital market and research, which must be the future of the European economy. That is why conditions must be created to attract the best staff in the world.  I therefore welcome the agreement reached with the Council on facilitated travel of students and researchers from third countries within the European Union. Given the cross-border nature of many research and the joint work of a number of European research centres, such facilitated movement is extremely important not only for scientists, but especially for the development of European science.  At the same time, of course, the need to find jobs for the millions of unemployed European citizens – especially young people – should not be overlooked and to create conditions so that they can set up a thriving European business and find jobs that match their qualifications and abilities.  As European lawmakers, it is our duty to protect the interests and rights of European citizens in particular, and I therefore call once again for respect for the right to free movement within the European Union without applying discriminatory measures or treatment to citizens of certain Member States.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Wikström for her work. The directive we are going to vote on today has a strong symbolic value. It does not only establish a coordinated and transparent regulatory framework to make entry into Europe more accessible to third-country nationals for study reasons, but also determines the conditions for student mobility, not the flight but the circulation of brains, in order to create a labour market open to researchers, not only from Europe. We are giving the opportunity to increase the skills of those - and there are many of them - who want to come to Europe to train, to acquire knowledge and to live internship experiences that will be expendable not only in the Union but also in the countries of origin. To have succeeded, for example, in increasing the minimum limit of weekly hours to enable students to carry out part-time work means giving them the practical opportunity for on-the-job training in order to develop professional profiles that can be immediately spent on the labour and enterprise markets. The directive outlines how to welcome those who believe in and appreciate the European design into the world of training, research and therefore work and see Europe as a pole of excellence, culture and opportunities. And these are mutual opportunities, because Europe, in order to remain competitive on the world stage, needs highly qualified people in different areas of research and innovation.   I also consider this directive to be an important piece of European immigration policy, which marks the road to legal migration, looking above all at young people, especially students and researchers, promoting and supporting intra- and non-European mobility.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We live in a time of globalisation of prosperity. It is based on the dissemination of education, knowledge and science. Action and knowledge sharing are therefore not only an investment in human capital, but also the building of the foundations for economic development and growth. It is also about building bridges of trust between the peoples of other countries and the countries of the old continent. People who gain knowledge here in the European Union later become natural ambassadors of our culture outside our continent. They are therefore not only pro-social, but also aimed at increasing mutual understanding and tolerance. For these reasons, the proposed rules should be strongly supported.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – The present Directive meets the needs identified in the reports on the implementation of the previous two Directives in order to remedy the shortcomings identified. It is important to ensure legal certainty and, in particular, to provide a single legal framework for different groups of persons coming to the European Union from third countries. Existing provisions are important to be simplified and included in a single instrument, and the directive should also aim to strengthen people-to-people contacts, especially in relation to countries within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy or to the European Union's strategic partners.  Migration for the purposes set out in this Directive will promote the creation and acquisition of knowledge and skills, and with this Directive the European Union should also be made more attractive as a place for research and innovation, thereby achieving the Union's progress in strengthening overall competitiveness and growth. The provisions of this Directive are without prejudice to the competence of Member States to regulate the scope of admission of third-country nationals for the purpose of carrying out work, but to achieve the best possible conditions at EU level, in accordance with the principle of proportionality.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Madam President, one of the indicators of the competitiveness and development of society and economy is the ability to attract talent, and we have been closed and unattractive to scientists and researchers for too long. In knowledge, we can only grow if we share it with others who bring their ideas, innovations and new views to us. Colleague Corazza Bildt pointed out excellently that we should not be afraid that students and researchers from third countries will take jobs away from our young people. On the contrary – the effect will be that together they will create more new jobs. It's a synergy we need to be open to. We've waited too long, but it's never too late for good solutions. The new mobility rules for students and researchers from outside the EU are simple and tailored to their needs. We are finally sending them a welcome message and look forward to working with them together.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that today's directive, after a long gestation period, thanks to Parliament's work, finally creates common conditions and rules so that students, researchers, trainees, but also volunteers and third-country stagiaires can enter and stay in Europe to study, but also to start a business. There are common guarantees about the minimum length of stay, which may be longer for researchers, about the possibility of doing some work to support themselves, but also of bringing family members. This is an important first step towards finally defining a general framework for global mobility in higher education, volunteering and research, on the basis of positive but limited experience in the erasmus and Erasmus mundus numbers, but also for the internationalisation of European universities, research centres and businesses.  So it is not just a question of immigration, as someone has said, but it is at last a new perspective, that of internationalisation, the competitiveness of Europe and different cooperation, which is now being called for by our universities, businesses and research centres.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, at a time when Europe is full of armies of millions of unemployed young people, at a time when, on the occasion of the negotiation of Britain, a restriction of the labour rights of the union's own citizens is under way, at a time when over 200,000 young scientists from Greece and thousands of other young people from the European South are migrating to the countries of the hard core of the Union. , at a time when hundreds of thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants are flooding Into Greece and the other countries of the Union, we are discussing the new directive and the arrangements which give the opportunity for low-paid legal employment to third-country nationals covering the few available jobs in Europe, at a time when thousands of young people from Greece and the countries of the European region will be crowding into employment services. We are also well aware that in Greece they work on hunger wages in various hotels thousands of third-country nationals, who are supposedly doing internships, while thousands of Greek hotel employees are unemployed. You understand that this cannot be accepted by European societies. The same applies to the directive under discussion.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – I would like to join my colleagues who have already congratulated my colleague Wikström on the prepared report on the regulation being prepared.  In this regard, I would like to talk about the mobility of young people, which are reopening. These are new opportunities for acquiring, inviting talent, human capital to the European Union, where, of course, they can leave their added value or transfer their knowledge, transfer their skills back to their homelands and contribute to the development of their country.  This regulation is particularly important because it is balanced. It is not only about unifying the rules within the European Union that allow young people to live better and work during their study and work research mobility, but also allows Member States that have reserved the discretion to reject an application on the basis of individual treatment. So both approaches are met, both criteria.  I would like to stress that this regulation will have an additional impact on better mobility, especially for our population.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I think this is an excellent proposal. The European Union rightly prides itself on being the biggest donor in humanitarian development aid in the world and we bring in migrants who are fleeing persecution, etc. But, on the other side of the coin, we actually deny ourselves the opportunity of helping the most talented people who, by coming here, can add value to what is happening in Europe and when – or if – they go back to their own country, they will add huge value back there in due course. So this is a very sensible proposal. If you want to be the best, you must attract the best, and this is the best way of doing it: helping researchers, students, volunteers, etc. These are people with talent who can make a difference, and having them all together and creating an opportunity that creates jobs in itself and makes progress and innovation is a great idea.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I do not need to repeat why it is really important that we have agreed to revise and update EU rules on foreign students and researchers. As the context on migration and mobility evolves, it is understood that so should our rules and policies.  The agreed text is a very important element of our overall migration approach. It sends the important signal that the European Union is a globally competitive and welcoming destination for much—needed students and researchers from abroad. At the same time, it provides for a clear legal framework which does not mix up other categories such as asylum seekers or refugees, and it does not touch on Member States’ competences to grant access to the labour market. This agreement is ambitious and balanced and will allow Europe to attract more talented students and researchers in the future who can contribute to our societies and to our economies. As many of you have insisted on this, I will repeat that the Commission has insisted, together with you, that Member States’ discretionary powers with regard to rejecting an application may only be used when strictly necessary and justified, and we will of course be monitoring this. As I mentioned earlier, let us not forget that migration and mobility are also about empowerment, creativity and socio-economic development. COMMISSION STATEMENT Joint declaration by the European Parliament and the Commission on the grounds for rejection (Article 20) The European Parliament and the Commission understand point (f) of Article 20(2) of this Directive as allowing Member States to reject an application only on a case-by-case basis and taking into account the specific circumstances of the third-country national and the principle of proportionality and on the basis of evidence or serious and objective reasons. The Commission will ensure that Member States implement this provision in line with this interpretation when transposing the Directive, and will inform the Parliament and the Council thereof, in the framework of its obligations under Article 39.  The European Parliament and the Commission consider that the inclusion of this provision in this Directive should not constitute a precedent for future legal migration instruments.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, we live in a globalised world where competitiveness between countries and continents is increasing. It is all about attracting the most skilled people: intellectuals, entrepreneurs and researchers. The EU must invest in intelligence, and this revised directive provides a lot of added value compared to the current directives. By improving the conditions for students and researchers, we are fostering growth and prosperity in the EU, and this is very much needed. When we talk about migration today, we tend to talk about asylum migration, but asylum is just one part of the migration scheme. Legal migration is the second part, and this is one instrument of legal migration that is indeed needed. We need many more in order to strike the right balance between asylum and legal migration. Today’s achievement  strengthens the academic status of European Union universities worldwide, it makes the EU more attractive, and it allows knowledge and excellence to flow more freely.  I am proud today of my team in this House. I am happy that this directive is one instrument that will foster growth and prosperity and give us hope for a better future, where entrepreneurs, innovators and researchers will help us to maintain our welfare all over the EU and also to increase and improve it. I am also happy that this is the first step in the right direction. There is much more to do, but we can do it and we can manage together.   Κύριε Επίτροπε, σας ευχαριστώ πάρα πολύ από την καρδιά μου.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, May 11, 2016, at 12.00 p.m. (The sitting was suspended at 11.40 a.m. and resumed at 12.00 p.m.) Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – I consider it essential that the Union and the Member States form common principles of immigration policy, which will constitute the basic standard for the residence, work and education of persons legally residing in the territory of the Member States. The proposed directive, which regulates the original directives of 2004 and 2005, complements the existing list of beneficiaries on paid trainees and aupairs. The unification of residence rules for beneficiaries and the unification of authorisations and time limits will remove the uncertainty and existing diverse procedural requirements for beneficiaries legally residing in the Territory of the Union for a period exceeding three months. Such support for the legal residence of such persons from third countries will help to prevent their possible discrimination and exploitation and provide them with guarantees of fair treatment, legal protection and certainty. At the same time, communication between Member States will be improved, the exchange and transfer of skills with third countries will be promoted and mutual economic, cultural and social relations will be strengthened.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes). *** We have a request for a point of order from a colleague of ours who would like to address us.

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: – Mr President, on a point of order regarding Rule 130 on parliamentary written questions (PQs). Regardless of our party or personal views we are all parliamentarians and one of the most important powers we have is the ability to hold the executive to account through parliamentary PQs, but these PQs are now being treated with contempt by the services. Questions are not receiving proper answers, they are evasive, incomplete and dismissive, and the timescale for answering is frequency exceeded. Rule 130(5) states six weeks is the acceptable deadline, yet some are taking up to 11 weeks. We are also being made subject to bureaucratic limits on questions, imposed by those very same technocrats. This undermines democracy and must be urgently remedied. (Applause)

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Thank you very much but I was reminded that those limits were our decision, so perhaps we should also consider that. In any case, we have taken note and certainly will pass this over to the relevant authorities.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The subject of the vote is the extension of the exemptions provided for in the regulation for the capital requirements of negotiators on the other part of goods. We in the 5 Star Movement want regulation that is appropriate to the risk profile of these negotiators. This derogation covers, without giving a precise timetable, yet another inefficiency of the European agencies, specifically EBA and ESMA, which had the task of formulating an appropriate proposal for a regulation. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. This is a simplified procedure for approving exempting those operating on the market from the capital requirements applicable to financial institutions, as long as specific regulation for this sector is prepared. The Council agreed that the exemption should be maintained until 2020. I voted favorably.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because the Commission is delaying more than necessary the development of specific rules for such importers in the EU. The report extends the extension developed by the European Commission for these importers in the application of the provisions for regulating capital requirements. This regulation lacks the specific provisions that should apply to commodity operators and its direct application could affect many necessary imports, but with this extension proposed by the Commission such economic operators are falling within a legal limbo that can allow very dangerous practices, both in the environmental and financial spheres. That is why we have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending regulation (EU) 575/2013 with regard to exemptions for commodity traders.  The proposed amendment would allow commodity traders to benefit from an extension of the exemptions from the large risk and capital requirements of the CRR Regulation until December 31, 2020. These exemptions avoid forcing these investment companies to increase their capital to continue their activities. However, they represent a significant risk to commodity markets, particularly through the massive use of derivatives, which can lead to high volatility and cause prices to vary for no fundamental reason, while having negative consequences for the real economy. I therefore believe that the very fragile situation in our financial system should encourage the Commission to regulate these activities rather than to ask for additional time.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. While I support strong regulation of investment firms, I believe a review into the regulation of these firms should be completed before MEPs decide whether commodity dealers should be exempt from any requirements. The proposed regulation aimed to extend an exemption for commodity dealers from large exposure requirements and own funds requirements contained within the current Capital Requirements Regulation from the end of 2017 to the end of 2020. There are several aspects Sinn Féin is opposed to in the Capital Requirements Regulation and we would likely oppose the exemption from these requirements for commodity dealers on the basis that they are often large investment firms that engage in high-risk investment practices. But I abstained instead of rejecting the proposal because the Commission is engaged in carrying out a review that will include both general investment firms and commodity dealers to determine what regulation is most appropriate to deal with the risk profile of both. The review will not be completed before the current sunset clause in the CRR will expire at the end of 2017, so I prefer not to vote on whether or not to continue the exemption until the review is completed.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The proposed amendment will allow commodity traders to benefit from an extension of exemptions from the high risk and capital requirements of the regulation until December 31, 2020. The Commission considers it necessary to extend the exemptions already planned, taking into account the time required to complete the review of investment firms and to develop, adopt and implement the legislation that could result from this process. The companies involved represent a significant risk to commodity markets, particularly through the massive use of derivatives, which can lead to high volatility and cause prices to vary for no fundamental reason, while having negative consequences for the real economy. It therefore became detrimental to the financial stability of our economies to leave room for the Commission to carry out work that should have been done long before the 2008 financial crisis. The very fragile situation of our financial system should prompt the Commission to regulate these activities, even if it means being too cautious, rather than asking for an additional three years of time. I voted against report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution. There have already been three years for rules to be drafted; a suggestion that it could take a total of seven years is absurd. Just how complex do we expect rules which take seven years to draft to be? I am concerned that this will result in incredibly bad rules; I therefore voted against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution, which applies to credit institutions and investment firms trading in raw materials. It is necessary that this revision lead to the establishment of a prudential framework adapted to their situation. In order to ensure a stable legislative framework, exemptions already planned until 2017 should be extended, taking into account the time required to complete the review of investment firms and to develop, adopt and implement legislation that may result from this process.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for exemptions for commodity traders. The requirements laid down in the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) and the Capital Requirements Directive (CRD) apply to both credit institutions and investment firms. The prudential regime applied to investment firms shall be based on the regime applied to credit institutions as a function of the investment services they provide. The Commission has decided to carry out a joint review on the proper arrangements for commodity traders, as well as on the general regime for the prudential supervision of investment firms and to draw up a joint report on those topics. I agree that this is necessary in order to ensure the development of a harmonised prudential framework for all types of investment firms.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The amendment proposed in this report would allow commodity traders to benefit from an extension of exemptions from the CRR requirements, the application of which could force them to significantly increase their mandatory capital to continue their operations and, therefore, increase their costs. In order to prevent such a situation from occurring, the Commission considers it necessary to extend the exemptions already provided by the CRR.  The very fragile situation of our financial system should prompt the Commission to regulate these activities, even if it is too cautious, rather than asking for 3 years of extra time, especially in an area where prices can be so volatile, and all the more so since it should have already acted after the 2008 crisis. So I voted against this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The CRR ("Capital Requirements Regulation") exempts commodity traders ("investment firms whose main activity is exclusively to provide investment services) from high risk and capital requirements, respectively. This waiver expires on December 31, 2017. A sunset clause was originally introduced in the RRC to give regulators time to define a prudential regime tailored to the risk profile of commodity traders. The Commission has therefore decided to undertake a review on an appropriate regime for commodity traders and prudential supervision of investment firms in general. It considered that this was necessary to ensure the development of a coherent prudential framework for all categories of investment firms.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Loones report on exemptions for negotiators on their own behalf of goods. This is a technical measure, which approves the proposal for a regulation presented by the Commission to extend the exemption regime provided for in the Capital Requirements Regulation and the Capital Requirements Directive. These legislative instruments provide for an exemption until 31 December 2017. The Commission has initiated, with the advice of the European Banking Authority and the European Financial Instruments and Markets Authority, the procedure for creating a coherent prudential framework for all types of investment firms, but it seems unlikely that the new legislation will be applied before the expiry of the maximum duration clause. In view of this context, in order to avoid harm to the persons concerned, Parliament decided to approve the proposal to extend the exemption system for as long as is necessary to prepare, adopt and apply the new legislation.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in this vote, which extends exemption from distributors of goods with regard to capital requirements. The Commission is drawing up a new proposal that is not yet ready. We consider that in this context it is not appropriate to remove the exemption automatically. However, we did not want to vote in favour as we oppose the framework directive on capital requirements.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I believe that this extension in the legal regime that applies to undertakings operating on the commodity market is necessary so as not to create legal uncertainty in an area which needs to be reviewed. But this complex process takes a while that we legally don't have. That is why this report provides time and certainness and possibilities to renew this framework with all legal and technical guarantees without suring the activity of these operators. For these reasons I supported this report.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on exemptions for commodity traders should allow them to benefit from an extension until 31/12/2020 of exemptions from the crR regulations' requirements for large risks and capital. Indeed, the current framework for investment firms is under review. However, I do not think that legislation resulting from this process will be completed before the expiry of the existing exemptions is 12/31/2017.  This could force commodity traders to significantly increase their mandatory capital to continue their operations and could, therefore, increase the costs associated with carrying out these activities. The Commission therefore considers it necessary to extend the exemptions already provided for by the CRR, and Article 498 of the CRR wanted the Commission to submit a report to Parliament on the prudential regimes applied to commodity traders on 31 December 2015 "at the latest". However, these companies represent a significant risk to commodity markets (due to the use of derivatives) and I think that we should not leave a time limit when this work should have been carried out long before. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report we are voting on has some unclear passages which I do not entirely agree with, so I have decided to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The requirements laid down in Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 and Directive 2013/36/EU apply to both credit institutions and investment firms. However, Articles 493 and 498 of the Regulation exempted raw material operators from the requirements relating to large exposures and own-fund requirements, respectively. The current resolution, which I have supported, maintains the exemption for commodity operators from the capital requirements applicable to financial institutions, as long as specific regulation for this sector is prepared.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with exemptions for commodity traders. The Capital Requirements Regulation and the Capital Requirements Directive apply to both credit institutions and investment firms. The prudential regime applied to investment firms shall be based on the regime applied to credit institutions as a function of the investment services they provide.  The Commission decided to carry out a joint review on the proper arrangements for commodity traders, as well as on the general arrangements for the prudential supervision of investment firms ('the review of investment firms') and to draw up a joint report on those topics. This is considered necessary to ensure the development of a harmonised prudential framework for all types of investment firms. The review of investment firms has already begun: the Commission has asked the European Banking Authority (EBA) and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) to provide technical advice on the matter. However, the review of investment firms is a complex project that will not be completed by the end of this year. It is therefore unlikely that any legislation will be developed, adopted and put into effect by the end of this review before the expiry of the current exemptions, i.e. by the end of 2017. This would mean that commodity traders would be affected as follows: if no specific prudential system had been introduced before the end of the review of investment firms, they would be subject to all the requirements of the abovementioned Regulation and the Directive from 1 January 2018.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to prevent economic and financial crises, I consider it extremely important to regulate the commodity and capital markets transparently and consistently, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a regulation regulating exemptions for traders of goods. The term 'commodity trader' covers a wide range of players in the energy and commodity markets. The requirements laid down in the CRD and the CRD apply to both credit institutions and investment firms.  The Cr iter ia Regulation exempts traders of goods engaged in the provision of investment services or the carrying out of activities related to financial instruments from large-exposure or capital requirements requirements. As both exceptions expire at the end of 2017, the Commission has decided to carry out one review of the regulation for commodity traders and the prudential supervision of investment firms in general, which will ensure the development of a harmonised prudential framework for all types of investment firms.  In the event that no specific prudential framework is in place by the end of 2017 that could arise from a review of investment firms, commodity traders will be subject to all requirements of the CRR and the CRD from the beginning of 2018.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The aim here is to extend the exemptions enjoyed by commodity traders within the prudential framework defined by the CRR and the 2013/36/EC Capital Requirements Directive until 31 December 2020, without updating them. In fact, according to Article 498 of the RRC, the Commission was due to submit a report to Parliament on these derogations by the end of 2015, which was not done. Given the extreme volatility of commodity markets, it seems wiser for me to regulate these activities as soon as possible in order to avoid the risk of a major financial crisis. I am therefore not in favour of deferring these exemptions as they stand until the end of 2020, and I voted against this text.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that, in order to avoid major shocks for the negotiating sector on its own behalf of goods, arising from the situation of legal uncertainty due to the expiry of the CRR, it is appropriate to extend the exemptions provided for by the latter.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Refining the legislative framework for trade in raw materials and energy is a long process, requiring commitment, great skills as well as accuracy of action. This parliamentary act allows us to take another step in the path of protecting European entrepreneurship and in view of the necessary review of the existing provisions on an appropriate regime for negotiators on their own behalf of goods and for the prudential supervision of investment firms in general, aimed at achieving an acceptable balance between sustainability and equity in the sector and the effective practicability of entrepreneurial action by citizens.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report proposes to extend the exemptions to the Capital Requirement Regulation (CRR) for commodity traders until 31 December 2020. These exemptions avoid forcing these investment companies to increase their capital, as is the case for other institutional investors. I voted against this report. On the one hand, it is quite absurd that these companies should be given leniency by the European regulatory authorities. On the other hand, this flexibility afforded to them weakens the players operating in the financial markets and could therefore again destabilize the banking sector in Europe. The Commission has clearly not taken anything away from the 2008 financial crisis.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account EU Regulation No 17/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 December 1999 on the common organisation of the 575/2013 and Directive 2013/36/EU, the Directives are applied to both credit institutions and investment firms. At the same time, Article 493(1) of the CRR supports freight traders and grants them a derogation from compliance with those requirements with regard to large exposures and own funds requirements.
