From 2017, the two derogations will expire and initially this time limitation clause was included in the CRR to give regulators the time it takes to establish that prudential regulation tailored to the risk profile of traders of goods. I voted in favour of the report on the derogations provided for freight traders because I believe it is necessary to give support to all traders of goods in order for them to give a better return, a favourable return to both the Member States and the European Union.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) and the Capital Requirements Directive (CRD) exempt, until December 2017, own-account negotiators of goods from large exposure requirements and equity requirements respectively. The term 'own-account negotiator of goods' covers a wide range of players in the energy and commodity markets: some deal exclusively with derivative contracts on goods and resemble investment firms in terms of functions and risks, while for others the trade in derivatives on goods is simply an activity ancillary to the production of goods. The Commission has decided to make a single review of an appropriate regime for negotiators on their own behalf of goods and for the prudential supervision of investment firms in general, and the proposed extension should take into account the time needed to conclude the review of investment firms and to prepare, adopt and apply legislation that may result from such a review. Abstention vote.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal to amend the regulation on capital requirements for credit institutions and investment firms (RACs). The amendment concerns exemptions for negotiators on their own behalf of goods from the requirements for large exposures and the own funds requirements. Both exemptions expired on December 31, 2017. This "maximum duration clause" was originally included in the CRR to give regulators time to establish prudential regulation appropriate to the risk profile of negotiators on their own goods. The Commission's review of an appropriate regime for own-account negotiators of goods will not be completed before the end of this year, which makes it extremely unlikely that any legislation can be applied before the expiry of the current exemptions. In order to prevent negotiators on their own account from being subject to all the requirements of the CRR without a conscious decision being taken on the scheme actually most appropriate, I voted in favour of extending these exemptions.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed regulation aimed to extend an exemption for commodity dealers from large exposures requirements and own funds requirements contained within the current Capital Requirements Regulation from the end of 2017 to the end of 2020. While I support strong regulation of investment firms, I believe a review into regulation of these firms should be completed before MEPs decide whether commodity dealers should be exempt from any requirements, which is why I abstained on the report. Sinn Féin is opposed to several aspects of the Capital Requirements Regulation and we would likely oppose the exemption from these requirements for commodity dealers on the basis that they are often large investment firms that engage in high-risk investment practices. However, I did not vote against the proposal because the Commission is carrying out a review that will include both general investment firms and commodity dealers to determine what regulation is most appropriate to deal with the risk profile of both. The review will not be completed before the current sunset clause in the CRR will expire at the end of 2017, so I prefer not to vote on whether or not to continue the exemption until the review is completed.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ EU financial services regulators have had three years to write rules to calculate how much capital commodity dealers should keep in reserve under the Capital Requirements Directive, the Commission is asking for another four years. If the rules are so complicated that they take seven years to write, they will be unworkable. Accordingly UKIP is against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to extend the existing exemptions for commodity dealers as set out in the Capital Requirements Regulation. It will be better to extend these until a review of the framework applicable to investment firms is prepared, adopted and applied.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal to extend exemptions for negotiators' capital requirements on their own account on behalf of goods beyond 32 December 2017. Firstly, I felt it was unfair to choose to use a simplified procedure on this report, which therefore ruled out the possibility of tabling amendments in the ECON Committee. Furthermore, I do not agree to grant further exemptions to negotiators who behave on the markets as genuine investment firms and should therefore be treated as such.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we consider it necessary to review an appropriate regime for commodity traders, as well as for the prudential supervision of investment firms. This is necessary in order to ensure a coherent prudential framework for all types of investment firms

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the proposal to amend Regulation No 136/66/EEC. 575/2013 on exemptions for commodity traders. As this report does not cover all the concerns that exist with regard to the amendment of the regulation, I believe that it should be changed and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 With this document, Parliament has called for a single review both for raw material negotiators and for the prudential supervision of investment firms, in order to better verify the regulatory effectiveness of the European regulations and directives issued in this area. I think it is essential to implement this type of control procedure and I also believe, especially in such sensitive areas, that they must be implemented with the necessary precautions and within the necessary time, which is why we are planning such a broad extension. It is essential that we have a specific prudential framework in this area, and I believe that this report responds effectively to this need, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The term ‘commodity dealer’ covers a wide spectrum of actors in energy and commodity markets: some trade exclusively in commodity derivative contracts and resemble investment firms in terms of functions and risks, whereas others trade commodity derivatives purely as an ancillary activity to commodities production. The requirements laid down in Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 (the ‘Capital Requirements Regulation’ or ‘CRR’) and in Directive 2013/36/EU (the ‘Capital Requirements Directive’ or ‘CRD’) apply to both credit institutions and investment firms. The prudential regime applicable to investment firms is derived from that imposed on credit institutions, adapted as a function of the investment services that they provide.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that it is appropriate to extend the derogation from the Own Resources Regulation. Neither the requirements of the Capital Requirements Regulation nor those of the Own Resources Directive are aimed at traders. Accordingly, I welcome the Commission's proposal to take action separately. The extension should take into account how much time it will take to finalise the securities review, to adopt any legislative proposal and to allow sufficient time for implementation until mandatory application.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – EU financial services regulators have had three years to write rules to calculate how much capital commodity dealers should keep in reserve under the Capital Requirements Directive, the Commission is asking for another four years. If the rules are so complicated that they take seven years to write, they will be unworkable. Accordingly UKIP is against.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation to extend the exemption for negotiators on their own account for goods in order to prevent this category from operating in an unstable regulatory environment in the short term. The application of the requirements for large exposures and own funds to negotiators on their own account for goods should not result from the mere expiry of the exemption, but rather from a carefully reasoned decision. It is therefore appropriate to allow regulators time to establish prudential regulation appropriate to the risk profile of the negotiators on their own account for goods.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because the Commission is delaying more than necessary the development of specific rules for such importers in the EU. The report extends the extension developed by the European Commission for these importers in the application of the provisions for regulating capital requirements. This regulation lacks the specific provisions that should apply to commodity operators and its direct application could affect many necessary imports, but with this extension proposed by the Commission such economic operators are falling within a legal limbo that can allow very dangerous practices, both in the environmental and financial spheres. That is why we have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The requirements set out in the Capital Requirements Regulation and the Capital Requirements Directive apply to both credit institutions and investment firms. The regime applicable to investment firms is derived from the regime imposed on credit institutions and is adapted according to the investment services it provides. I voted for the development of a coherent prudential framework for all types of investment companies.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) currently exempts commodity trading entities from large exposure and own funds requirements. Both exemptions expire on 31 December 2017. This date was originally included in the CRR in order to give the Commission time to review the prudential supervision system applicable to commodity traders and investment firms by the end of 2015. The review in question is still ongoing. Its results will be the basis for establishing an appropriate prudential approach to commodity traders. The aim of this proposal is to extend the current system of treatment of these entities. In this way, we will avoid the situation where in 2018 commodity buyers will have to temporarily comply with all the requirements of the CRR before requirements are introduced that are tailored to their risk profile. I agree with the Commission's proposal, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I was content to support this report which extends the exemptions for commodity dealers from the Capital Requirements Regulation until the end of 2020. This is a logical decision in light of the ongoing review, ensuring commodity dealers will not have to comply with two different sets of regulations in a short period of time.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to simplify the control system by implementing a single review of an appropriate regime for commodity traders. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text is intended to allow commodity traders to benefit from an extension until 31 December 2020 of exemptions from the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) requirements for large risks and capital, in order to avoid the explosion of costs associated with the exercise of these activities. Nevertheless, Article 498 of the CRR required the Commission, before 31 December 2015, to report to Parliament on the prudential regimes applied to these traders.   These companies represent a significant risk to commodity markets, particularly because of the massive use of derivatives and the associated volatility that can cause prices to vary excessively. It is not desirable to let the Commission manage what should have been achieved before the 2008 financial crisis. Defending prudence and supervision of the financial system, I voted against this request for 3 years of additional time.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 We cannot make one or another industry subject to a regulation or directive before the industry is tested. Yes, we really need to make investment firms comply with our legislation, but only after the verification is complete. Indeed, maybe December 31, 2020 is a long way off, but it is better to do the check well and the time not to press the examiners so that they can do the job properly.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as it seeks to extend exemptions from the requirements of large exposures and from own funds requirements in the case of commodity negotiators (= investment firms whose core business concerns only the provision of investment services or financial instruments). These exemptions prolong uncertainty and give the Commission an additional indeterminate period of time to determine the directly necessary prudential regulation for these undertakings.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The prudential regime applicable to investment firms is based on the tax on credit institutions, adapted according to the investment services they offer, and exempts traders specialising in commodity trading from the requirements relating to large risks and capital requirements, respectively. Both exemptions expire on 31 December 2017. However, the analysis on investment firms is a complex project, which will not be completed by the end of this year. The extension should therefore take into account the time it will take to complete the analysis on investment firms and to draw up, adopt and implement any legislation that may result from that analysis.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: detrimental to the financial stability of our economies to leave room for the Commission to carry out work that should have been done long before the 2008 financial crisis.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation in question applies to credit institutions and investment firms, integrating the legal framework governing access to activity, the supervisory framework and prudential rules applicable to credit institutions and investment firms. The aim of this proposal is to extend the existing exemptions granted to operators specialised in commodity trading of high-risk requirements and capital requirements. The objectives of this Regulation are: to prevent and reduce systemic and macroprudential risks, to encourage economically useful banking activities that serve the general interest and to discourage unsustainable financial speculation without real added value. The Regulation states that "The liberalisation of the gas and electricity markets is an objective which is of both economic and political importance (...). Therefore, capital requirements and other prudential rules to be applied to companies operating in these markets should be proportionate and should not unduly interfere in achieving the objective of liberalisation." We have been very critical of this package, particularly as to its inadequacy and perversity – the entire content of the REGULATORY reform carried out by the EU has been determined by financial capital itself. The "regulated" determined which lines would sequest the "regulation" that was going to be applied to it.  We voted against it.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the report because, I agree with the need to extend the exemptions provided for by the CRR for the category of negotiators on their own behalf of goods. I believe, in fact, that if this does not happen, they would be subject to all the requirements of the CRR and CRD regulations, in the field of own funds and large exposures. We would therefore move, even in the absence of a prior and careful assessment, from the current regime in which they are exempt from the requirements for own funds and large exposures, to a temporary regime which would see them forced to comply with all the requirements laid down by the CRR and the CRD. Furthermore, while assuming that the review of investment firms provides a prudential framework tailored to the negotiators on their own account for goods, they would be deprived of stable rules.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The two applicable exemptions for commodity traders expire on 31 December 2017. Commodity traders will therefore lose a stable regulatory framework at the end of 2017. It is therefore important that we extend the current derogations. This extension should take into account the time it will take to complete the review of investment firms and should develop, adopt and apply any legislation that may result from that review.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report as the proposed extension should take into account the time it takes to conclude the review of investment firms and to prepare any relevant legislation.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report as it seeks to extend exemptions from large exposure requirements and equity requirements in cases of commodity negotiators from investment firms whose core business is solely related to the provision of investment services or financial instruments. These exemptions prolong uncertainty and give the Commission an additional indeterminate period of time to determine the directly necessary prudential regulation for these undertakings.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I support the proposed regulation that aims to extend the exemptions laid down in the CRR for commodity dealers from the large exposures and own funds requirements and, accordingly, amend Regulation 575/2013. The prudential framework applicable to investment firms (including commodity dealers) laid down in the CRR and Directive 2013/36/EC (‘the Capital Requirements Directive’) is currently under review. Because it is highly improbable that any legislation that may result from this review can be prepared, adopted and applied before the current exemptions expire (31 December 2017), in order to continue their activities they might be forced to increase the amount of own funds needed to perform their activities. Therefore I welcome the Commission’s proposal to extend the existing exemptions laid down in the CRR and to take into account the amount of time that will be necessary to conclude the investment firms’ review and to prepare, adopt and apply any legislation that may result from that review.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report and congratulated Mr Loones. The provisions of the Crr (CRR - 575/2013/EU) and the Crd (CRD - 2013/36/EU) apply to both credit institutions and investment firms. The capital requirements scheme for investment firms is based on the system applicable to credit institutions, taking into account the investment services provided by investment firms and is an adapted version the same.  The Regulation exempts commodity traders from the provisions on large risk-taking and own funds requirements. However, the concept of 'commodity trader' needs to be clarified: it covers a wide range of economic operators operating on the energy and commodity markets. A review of investment firms is essential for transparency and it would be necessary to prepare a possible act as a result of this review before the expiry of the current exemptions (end of 2017). If this is not possible, the CRR/CRD requirements will be fully applicable from 1 January 2018.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report pending a final regulatory framework, as not extending exemptions to commodity operators would mean that for the time being and until the entry into force of the new framework, commodity operators would be subject to the standard requirements of the CRR and the DRC.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP legislative resolution on the proposal for an EP regulation on exemptions for own-account negotiators, in which the EP essentially accepted the Commission's proposal to extend the initial exemption provided for until the end of 2017. The maximum duration clause of the exemption from compliance with capital and large exposure requirements was provided for in the Regulation on capital requirements for credit institutions and investment firms (CRR), in order to allow own-account negotiators of goods to operate, and to allow regulators time to establish appropriate regulation , from the point of view of prudential and therefore capital requirements. By extending the exemption in time, the Commission intends to maintain the status quo until it has completed its review and drawn up new legislation, in order to prevent the negotiators on their own account of goods from being subject, in the absence of a conscious assessment, to all the prudential measures provided for by the CRR and the CRD Directive and, therefore, to check whether the prudential requirements laid down are also good for this specific category.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report 'Exceptions for commodity traders', following the line of my ECR Group, as it highlights maladministration in relation to the proposed regulation of the European Commission and calls for better solutions to control investment firms.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Goods traders are exempt from the Capital Requirements Ordinance. It does not seem sensible to switch to the existing regulation in the shortest possible time. It is therefore important to establish an appropriate regime for commodity traders and to subject them to a common examination for the supervision of investment firms in general. This ensures a coherent supervisory framework for all types of investment firms.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Along with S&D colleagues, I voted in favour of extending the exemption for commodity dealers, because they have specific needs which cannot be met if they are treated as if they were banks or other investment firms. This extension gives regulators the time they need to set up a prudential regime which works for commodity dealers.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. I voted against the Loones report on derogations for commodity traders on capital requirements. In a kind of symbolic way. I consider that it is absolutely necessary to subject these economic actors to prudential rules, preferably adapted to their specific situations, especially if the bulk of their activities are in the negotiation of derivatives contracts.  The waivers they now enjoy expire in December 2017. They are set out in a regulation, the CRR and the CRD4 to speak in European jargon, which dates back to 2013. The Commission therefore had plenty of time to present its proposals. The renewal of the Commission's membership in 2014 cannot even be used to justify the delay, since the process begins with a technical consultation with two European financial supervisory authorities.  However, it only started in 2015, which makes it impossible, given the length of the European legislative process, to adopt any regulation on time, and motivates the request for an extension of the waiver period. My vote punishes the Commission's lack of forecast, and nothing else.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in this vote, which extends exemption from distributors of goods with regard to capital requirements. The Commission is drawing up a new proposal that is not yet ready. We consider that in this context it is not appropriate to remove the exemption automatically. However, we did not want to vote in favour as we oppose the framework directive on capital requirements.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The fourth Capital Requirements Directive (CRD IV) and the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) introduced new rules governing banks and investment firms. I voted in favour of extending the exemption for commodity dealers, because they have specific needs which cannot be met if they are treated as if they were banks or other investment firms. This extension gives regulators the time they need to set up a prudential regime which works for commodity dealers.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. It is highly improbable that any legislation that may result from this review can be prepared, adopted and applied before the current exemptions expire. To prevent this situation arising, the Commission decided to extend the existing exemptions until 31 December 2020 or the date of entry into force of any amendments, whichever is the earlier.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – I voted to approve exempting those agents operating on the market from the capital requirements applicable to financial institutions, in so far as specific regulation for this sector is prepared.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this proposal to extend the sunset clauses to allow for a fully analysed prudential framework to be put in place for commodity dealers. If the sunset clauses elapsed without setting in place a proper prudential framework for commodity dealers they would become subject to the full requirements of CRR/CRD starting from 1 January 2018. This could force them to significantly increase the amount of own funds that they need to have in order to continue their activities and could therefore increase the related costs of performing those activities. This proposal extends the existing exemptions in CRR to allow for the completion of the report followed by the creation of a tailored framework for these firms.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 2012/2013. 575/2013 as regards exemptions for commodity traders, as this adopts a Commission proposal extending existing exemptions until 31 December 2020. The current course of conduct exempts commodity traders from requirements for high exposures and capital requirements, and it is therefore essential to avoid a temporary course of conduct that would introduce the full requirements of the capital requirements regulation and directive. I certainly believe that the extension should take into account the real and necessary amount of time required to conduct the audit, and I support this report in addition.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. It seems to me to be detrimental to the financial stability of our economies to leave room for the Commission to carry out work that should have been done long before the 2008 financial crisis. I then voted against the text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – EU financial services regulators have had three years to write rules to calculate how much capital commodity dealers should keep in reserve under the Capital Requirements Directive, the Commission is asking for another four years. If the rules are so complicated that they take seven years to write, they will be unworkable. Accordingly UKIP is against.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to extend, until 31 December 2020, the exemptions from the requirements of the CRR Regulation for the high risk and capital available to traders in raw materials, pending the forthoverned the review of the legislation.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Commodity traders are exempt from the rules on large exposures and the own funds requirements of investment firms, as capital coverage by the traded assets is already in place. These exemptions are valid until 31 December 2017. The Commission should have prepared a report by the end of 2015 on an appropriate settlement of this situation, but the review initiated has not yet been completed. In order to exclude commodity traders from the wholesale lending rules and the associated increase in own funds after 31 December 2017 and to allow them to continue their business activities, I am voting in favour of extending the derogation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of extending the exemption for commodity dealers, because they have specific needs which cannot be met if they are treated as if they were banks or other investment firms. This extension gives regulators the time they need to set up a prudential regime which works for commodity dealers.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Commission has decided to carry out a single review to develop an appropriate regime for commodity traders, i.e. economic operators covering a wide range of negotiating actions in the energy and commodity markets. Due to the complexity of this review and the time it takes to draw up a new regulatory framework, the possibility of them being subject to the full requirements of large exposures and equity as defined by the "Capital Requirements Regulation" and of which they are exempt until 2017 is visible. The report therefore proposes to extend the existing exemptions. I agree with the need to draw up a regulatory regime adapted to the profile of these economic operators. However, I have decided to abstain, sharing my group's view that this extension would indirectly legitimise the prudential framework for financial institutions.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. This issue deals with exemptions for negotiators on their own behalf of goods. The Commission has proposed a single review both for negotiators on their own account for goods and for the prudential supervision of investment firms. This review procedure is very complex, to the point where it cannot be completed by the end of the year, and therefore it seems unlikely that any legislation will result from this procedure in a short time. Given that such a delay would have some negative effects, an extension of the exemptions provided for by the CRR to 2017 was considered appropriate in order to ensure the development of a coherent prudential framework for all types of investment firms. Looking at the supported proposal in detail, I think I am voting in favour.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on exemptions for commodity traders.  The proposed amendment would allow commodity traders to benefit from an extension of the exemptions from the large risk and capital requirements of the CRR Regulation until December 31, 2020.  These companies represent a significant risk to commodity markets, particularly through the massive use of derivatives that can lead to high volatility and cause prices to vary for no fundamental reason, while having negative consequences for the real economy. It therefore seems detrimental to the financial stability of our economies to leave room for the Commission to carry out work that should have been done long before the 2008 financial crisis.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The CRR (Capital Requirements Regulation) is a European regulation that governs capital for investment firms, including commodity traders. The latter benefit from a derogation from these requirements.  Based on this observation, a report was asked of the Commission to find a solution and put an end to this special regime. However, this application has not been successful. That is why the text proposes to give commodity traders a new three-year period. I voted against it.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted to approve exempting those agents operating on the market from the capital requirements applicable to financial institutions, as long as specific regulation for this sector is prepared.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because the Commission is delaying more than necessary the development of specific rules for such importers in the EU. The report extends the extension developed by the European Commission for these importers in the application of the provisions for regulating capital requirements. This regulation lacks the specific provisions that should apply to commodity operators and its direct application could affect many necessary imports, but with this extension proposed by the Commission such economic operators are falling within a legal limbo that can allow very dangerous practices, both in the environmental and financial spheres. That is why we have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. When we talk about "operator in raw materials" we should know that we are alluding to a general term covering a wide range of players in the energy and commodity markets.  On the one hand, some traders trade exclusively on commodity derivatives contracts and are similar to investment firms. On the other hand, we find those who trade derivatives on raw materials as a simple auxiliary activity of raw materials. One of the major problems in this report is that commodity operators would be subject to the requirements of the CRR (Capital Requirements Regulation) and the CRD (Capital Requirements Directive) without a deliberate decision justifying that this is the most appropriate treatment for them.  To avoid this situation, the exemptions set out in the CRR need to be extended taking into account the amount of time it will take to conduct a review of investment firms and to be able to apply the most appropriate legislation resulting from such review.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I consider it beneficial to delay the regulation of commodity traders in terms of reserve capital and capital adequacy.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Capital Requirements Regulation implies the 'own funds requirement' principle, which requires credit institutions to have sufficient capital reserves to cover unexpected losses. The requirements of large exposures and own funds have been developed to limit the maximum loss a bank may suffer in the event of a sudden failure of the entity being credited. Thus, the credit institution retains its solvency. Traders of goods would also be subject to this requirement from 1 January 2018. However, the Commission needs to review the framework for investment firms. A coherent prudential framework is needed for these companies. Therefore, as traders of goods fall into this category, I agree to extend the derogations provided for them until the legislative framework is clarified.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The requirements laid down in Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 (the so-based Capital Requirements Regulation), as amended, apply to both credit institutions and investment firms. Under this Regulation, commodity dealers (or investment firms whose main business is investment services or activities related to financial instruments) are exempt from the requirements of large exposures and from own funds requirements. The problem – and thus the reason for the amendment – is that the existing exemptions were set up by the end of 2017. Given that a review of the whole active regulation of investment firms was already underway, there were concerns that the profile authorities would not be able to fully switch to and adapt to the new contractual reality in a time. Consequently, a decision was taken to extend the period of exemption currently provided for in order to complete both the review of the regulation of investment firms and to prepare, adopt and start applying the legislation that might result from this review. Since the current amendments have at least an indirect positive impact on the continued operation of the same energy and commodity market participants at the level of our community, it was necessary to support them.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 This proposal extends for commodity traders whose main business consists in providing investment services or carrying out investment activities, the current exemption from large exposures and own funds requirements in force until 31 December 2017 and extended until 31 December 2020. Given that Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 requires the Commission to draw up a report on an appropriate prudential supervision regime for investment firms, which may follow up on legislative proposals, this period should be extended.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 575/2013 on exemptions for commodity traders because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The report aims to extend exemptions for commodity traders to 26 June 2013 and 2013 to 26 December 2013/36/EC. These two texts set out the European framework for capital. The original expiry date for these exemptions was December 31, 2017. Indeed, the RRC and the 2013/36/EC Directive on capital requirements for investment firms are currently under review. The review process could exceed the aforementioned expiry date, subjecting commodity traders to heavy capital level requirements.  Commodity traders are fond of financial derivatives, which are highly volatile in financial markets. The establishment of specific capital regulations seems to us, for this reason, urgent. It was also a requirement of the RRC under section 498.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 as regards exemptions for negotiators on their own account for goods. A single review was carried out by the Commission on an appropriate regime for negotiators for the prudential supervision of investment firms in general and on their own account for goods, and a single report on the issues in question. This was considered essential to ensure the development of a common prudential framework for all types of investment firms.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – Today we voted on a report on the requirements applicable to credit institutions and investment firms whose main business is exclusively providing investment services or carrying out investment activities. Commodity traders are exempt from capital requirements, however, this exemption will expire on 31 December 2017.The Commission has decided to carry out a single review on the appropriate system for commodity traders and prudential supervision of investment firms in general ('the review of investment firms') and to draw up a single report on the above topics. This seemed necessary to ensure the preparation of a coherent prudential framework for all types of investment firms. A review of investment firms is already under way: the Commission has asked the European Banking Authority (EBA) and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) for technical advice on this matter (EBA/Op/2015/20). However, the review of investment firms is a comprehensive project that will not be completed by the end of this year. It is therefore highly unlikely that any legislation that could result from this review can be drawn up, adopted and applied before the expiry of the existing exemptions, i.e. until the end of 2017. Therefore, time must be obtained. I abstained in the vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important to extend exemptions for traders of raw materials, in order to facilitate their trade. We do not want to create surprises with rules for which traders are not prepared. That is why I voted in favour of this report and we look forward to better regulation, but this must happen when the time comes.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. My support for the proposal amending the Regulation on exemptions for operators in raw materials in order to extend existing exemptions established to allow time for the review of companies that has already begun to be completed. These exemptions exempt commodity operators from the requirements relating to large exposures and own-fund requirements. These exemptions expire at the end of 2017 and we must have planned the situation in case the current assessment for that date has not been completed, as this could cause serious problems.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Regulation 575/2013/EU on capital requirements applies to both credit institutions and investment firms. Articles 493(1) and 498(1) of the Regulation provide that commodity traders shall be exempt from large exposure requirements and own funds requirements. These two exemptions expire in 2017 and a new prudential regulatory framework should be put in place that takes into account the particular circumstances and risks faced by commodity traders in their activity. According to the report, the definition includes those who "exclusively trade commodity derivative contracts", but also those who "trade commodity derivatives solely as an ancillary activity of commodity production". The Commission has decided to examine and establish a new implementing framework concerning both exemptions for traders and a more general regime for prudential supervision of investment firms. The complexity of the procedure may lead to a delay in the completion of the new framework, with the result that there is a risk that the existing regulation will continue to apply without the abovementioned exemptions. I therefore think it is right to extend the validity of the two exemptions beyond their expiry until the adoption of the new regulatory framework.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report prepared by the EP Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, which proposes to extend the exemptions to commodity traders until a prudential framework has been in place for them. This extension will ensure stable operating conditions and a regulatory framework while the investment firms review and pending the preparation of the relevant legislation.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this extension of current legislation that will allow for adequate time to prepare and adopt comprehensive and effective legislation on the risk profile of commodity dealers.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Commodity traders are investment firms whose main activity is to provide or exercise investment services in the energy and raw materials markets (food, industrial,...).  They are therefore the main players in speculation on essential raw materials.  Since 2013 they have benefited from a derogation from the guidelines and regulations on own funds that frame risks, allowing them to speculate without limit. Both waivers expire on December 31, 2017. The report proposes to extend them to allow for the review of these guidelines and possibly create a tailored framework for these companies. I vote against this text which purports to adapt the regulations to the wishes of the starving people.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The purpose of this report was to allow traders to continue to enjoy a departure from the RRC's high risk and capital standards. In order to prevent commodity traders from being forced to increase their amount, therefore the costs associated with their activities are granted a waiver until a new regulation, adjusted, arrives in 2017. However, this solution is not prudent for the real economy. These companies represent a risk through their massive use of derivatives which can create considerable volatility and cause prices to vary for no reason. Regulatory work should have been carried out before the crisis. In view of our fragile economy, these activities should be regulated. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to extend the period of validity of the exemption of operators in goods in respect of certain requirements set out in the CRR (Capital Requirements Regulation). No specific implementation plans are required, as the extension is directly applicable and allows for the continuation of current practices. For the same reasons, there is no need to implement any specific framework for monitoring, evaluation and reporting. On the contrary, these frameworks should be implemented in the context of possible changes to the prudential framework applicable to operators in goods resulting from the analysis of investment firms. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission proposal provides a clear and feasible plan concerning the review of the current exemption of certain requirements for commodity dealers, and delivers a realistic timeframe for the implementation for a new set of rules. Therefore I supported this report that also seeks to minimise unnecessary burdens.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The prudential regime applicable to investment firms results from obligations imposed on credit institutions and adjusted in relation to the function of the investment services they provide. The Commission decided to carry out a single review concerning an appropriate system for commodity traders and the supervision of investment firms in general and to draw up a report. This procedure was considered necessary to ensure that a coherent prudential framework for all types of investment firms was developed. I think it is highly unlikely that any legislation that may result from this review could be prepared, adopted and applied before the current derogations expire (i.e. by the end of 2017). This brings with it certain risks. Firstly, commodity traders would become fully subject to the requirements of the CRR/CRD without knowingly agreeing that such treatment is most appropriate for them. Secondly, assuming that the review of investment firms would result in an adapted prudential framework for commodity traders, they would lose a stable regulatory framework. It is necessary to extend the existing derogations provided for in the CRR. This extension should take into account the time it will take to complete the review of investment firms and should develop, adopt and apply any legislation that may result from that review. I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal in question as it stands.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 as regards exemptions for commodity dealers, which calls to undertake a single review on an appropriate regime for commodity dealers as well as for the prudential supervision of investment firms in general (henceforth ‘investment firms review’) and prepare a single report on the above topics. This was deemed necessary in order to ensure the development of a coherent prudential framework for all types of investment firms.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Articles 493(1) and 498(1) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 exempt commodity traders from the provisions on large risk-taking and own funds requirements. The two exemptions expire on December 31, 2017. The Commission decided to combine the subject of an appropriate system for commodity traders with prudential supervision of investment firms in a single review. This review has begun, but it is almost impossible for a possible act resulting from this review to be completed, adopted and applied before the expiry of the current exemptions (end of 2017).  It is therefore appropriate to extend the scope of those exemptions. To this end, the Commission has proposed to the European Parliament and the Council an amendment to that Regulation. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that Parliament adopt the Commission's proposal. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The requirements set out in The Capital Requirements Regulation (Regulation (EU) No 575/2013) and the Capital Requirements Directive (Directive 2013/36/EU) apply to credit institutions and investment firms. The prudential regime applicable to investment firms is based on the tax on credit institutions, adapted according to the investment services they offer. Articles 493(1) and 498(1) of the CRR exempt traders specialised in the trading of goods from the requirements relating to major risks and capital requirements respectively. I endorse the rapporteur's position, signalling two situations relating to the exemptions identified: freight operators would be subject to all crr and CRD requirements, without consciously deciding that such treatment is what suits them best, and, if the analysis on investment firms results in a specific prudential framework for freight operators, they would be deprived of a stable regulatory framework. In other words, they would move from the current treatment, exemption, to a temporary treatment that includes all the requirements of the CRR and crd, and possibly to that specific framework, within a very short period.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. It seems to me to be detrimental to the financial stability of our economies to leave room for the Commission to carry out work that should have been done long before the 2008 financial crisis. The very fragile situation of our financial system should prompt the Commission to regulate these activities, even if it means being too cautious, rather than asking for an additional three years of time. That is why I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the Commission's position on exemptions for commodity traders relating to large risks and equity, which expire on 31 December 2017. The Commission wants to carry out a review in order to provide an appropriate regime for commodity traders, and more broadly for investment firms, for obligations under the Regulation and the Capital Requirements Directive.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 In plenary, we voted in favour of exemptions for commodity traders. The requirements of the CRD and the CRD apply to credit institutions and investment firms. The CRR exempts commodity traders from the provisions on high risk-taking and own funds requirements. The two exemptions will end on 31 December 2017, so the aim is to extend the existing exemptions provided for in the CRR, thereby avoiding the unstable regulatory framework for commodity traders.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ In March 2016 the Commission decided to extend regulation 575/2013 that exempts commodity dealers from large exposure requirements and from own funds requirements. I have voted for this report that extends the exemption until the 31st of December 2020, in order to save commodity dealers from an unstable regulatory environment in the short term.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 The requirements set out in the Capital Requirements Regulation and the Capital Requirements Directive apply to both credit institutions and investment firms. The prudential regime applicable to investment firms is derived from the regime imposed on credit institutions and is adapted to the investment services they provide. The Commission decided to undertake a single review of an appropriate regime for traders of goods and on the prudential supervision of investment firms in general and to prepare a single report on those issues. This was considered necessary to ensure the development of a coherent prudential framework for all types of investment firms.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported, in my vote today, the adoption of this report on the extension of derogations from certain provisions of the Regulation on capital requirements for traders of goods, because I believe that the predictability of legislation is absolutely necessary to ensure a healthy competitive environment. In this respect, the possibility of these derogations expiring at the end of 2017, without being replaced in time by legislation adapted to this broad spectrum of economic actors, defined by 'commodity traders', would cause instability and lack of legislative coherence. The extension of these derogations until the European Commission has completed its review and the adoption of coherent legislation will give economic actors confidence in the efficiency and coherence of European legislation.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained because, although this report contains useful aspects, it cannot be supported in the sum of the amendments set out.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is necessary to extend the Regulation in order to allow time for the completion of the review of investment firms and for the development and adoption of the necessary legislation on this basis.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is particularly important to extend the period of validity of the exemptions provided for traders in commodities. It should be noted that the review of investment firms has already begun, but will not be completed by the end of this year. It is therefore essential to properly assess the time it will take for investment firms to complete the review when setting a new expiry date. In addition, traders in commodities should maintain the existing arrangements until the end of the review. In view of the current situation, provision should be made for a reasonable period of time for the preparation, adoption and application of new legislation.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ EU financial services regulators have had three years to write rules to calculate how much capital commodity dealers should keep in reserve under the Capital Requirements Directive, the Commission is asking for another four years. If the rules are so complicated that they take seven years to write, they will be unworkable. Accordingly UKIP is against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The exemptions for negotiators on their own account for goods, provided for in the Capital Requirements Regulation to allow authorities to adjust the risk profile of the aforementioned negotiators, will remain in force until 2017. I welcome the Commission's decision to arrive at a single review of the appropriate regime in order to ensure a coherent development of the matter but, as this procedure will take place beyond the time limits within which the exemptions will be made, I believe that an extension of the exemptions under Articles 493(1) and 498(1) is useful. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Regulation 575/2013 exempts commodity dealers from large exposure requirements and from own funds requirements until 31 December 2017. It also requires the Commission to prepare reports by 31 December 2015 on the prudential supervision of commodity dealers and of investment firms in general. Applying large exposure requirements and own funds requirements to commodity dealers should not come as the result of a lapsed exemption but on the basis of a thoroughly reasoned decision. Therefore I vote for the proposal extending the capital requirements exemption for commodity dealers under the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR).

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The requirements laid down in the Capital Requirements Regulation apply to credit institutions and investment firms. Commodity traders are currently exempt from requirements for large exposures and capital requirements, but both exemptions expire on 31 December 2017.  I support the Commission's decision to carry out a single review of an appropriate regime for commodity traders and prudential supervision of investment firms in general as well as the preparation of a single report on these topics. I agree that this needs to be done to ensure that a harmonised prudential framework for all types of investment firms is drafted. However, the audit of investment firms is a complex project and the likelihood that legislation that could result from this audit will be prepared, adopted and applied before the current exemptions expire (i.e. before the end of 2017) is extremely small. If no specific prudential framework is established by then, commodity traders would be subject to full crr/CRD requirements starting on 1 January 2018. Therefore, in order to prevent such a situation, it is appropriate to extend the validity of the existing exemptions set out in the CRR and that is why I supported this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I adopt a position on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 2012/2013; 575/2013 as regards the exemption for commodity traders at first reading, taking up the Commission's proposal. The regulation would solve two problems for commodity traders. First, commodity traders would be subject to the full requirements of the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) and the Capital Requirements Directive (CRD), without a conscious (and well-founded) decision being taken that this is indeed the most appropriate way to deal with them. Second, assuming that a review of investment firms would lead to a specially adapted prudential framework for commodity traders, they would be deprived of a stable regulatory framework.  In a very short period (one to two years), they would move from the current course of conduct, under which they are exempted from requirements for large exposures and capital requirements, to a temporary course of conduct that would include the full requirements of the CRR/CRD and then to the specified specially adapted framework. Therefore, in order to prevent such a situation, it is appropriate to extend the validity of the existing exemptions set out in the CRR. The extension should take into account the amount of time it will take to complete the audit of investment firms and to prepare, adopt and apply legislation that could result from that audit.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported Rep. Loones' report regarding the change in the date of entry into force of the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) and the Capital Requirements Directive (CRD), which would increase regulatory burdens on commodity traders.  Under the CRR Regulation, commodity traders are exempted from requirements for large exposures and from capital requirements, which expire on December 31, 2017. An extension would ensure that the European Commission and regulatory authorities complete the initiated review of an appropriate regime for traders and that prudential supervision is defined and a tailored regulatory framework adopted and legislative changes are properly implemented.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on exemptions for commodity traders, which extends the existing exemptions provided for in the CRR. These exemptions, which exempt commodity traders from large exposure requirements and capital requirements, expire on December 31, 2017. In the meantime, the Commission, with technical assistance from the European Banking Authority (EBA) and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), has begun to carry out a review to establish an appropriate system for commodity traders. However, the possible legislation that is yet to come out of this review is likely to be adopted only after the current exemptions have expired. Therefore, in order to avoid a situation in the meantime where there is a jump in the transition and the full application of crr requirements to commodity entrepreneurs, the existing conditions need to be extended.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The term "own-account negotiator of goods" covers a wide range of players in the energy and commodity markets: some deal exclusively with derivative contracts on goods and resemble investment firms in terms of functions and risks, while for others the exchange of derivatives on goods is simply an ancillary activity to the production of goods. The Commission has decided to carry out a single review of an appropriate regime for negotiators on their own account for goods and for the prudential supervision of investment firms in general and to draw up a single report on the issues in question. This was considered necessary to ensure the development of a coherent prudential framework for all types of investment firms. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Capital Requirements Regulation (or CRR) currently exempts commodity trading entities from large exposure and own funds requirements. Both exemptions expire on 31 December 2017. This date was originally included in the CRR in order to give the Commission time to review the prudential supervision system applicable to traders in goods and investment firms by the end of 2015 and, where appropriate, to propose a legislative system adapted to the risk profile of traders and investment firms. The review in question is still ongoing. Its results will be the basis for establishing an appropriate prudential approach to commodity traders. Therefore, the aim of this proposal is to extend the current treatment system for commodity traders until the review of investment firms is completed and any changes to the existing prudential framework are made, or until 31 December 2020, which is the case earlier. In this way, we will avoid the situation where in 2018 commodity buyers will have to temporarily comply with all the requirements of the CRR before requirements are introduced to match their risk profile within two or three years. I hereby supported the report.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Articles 493(1) and 498(1) of the Capital Requirements Directive exempt traders specialised in the trading of goods from the requirements relating to major risks and capital requirements, respectively. Under the expiry clause contained in the bill, both exemptions expire on 31 December 2017. The expiry period provided for in the legislation would, in the case, allow the examination of the appropriate regime for operators to be goods, unless the Commission had decided to carry out a single analysis of the appropriate regime for operators in goods and for the prudential supervision of investment firms in general. Due to the complexity of this study project, it is estimated that the work will not be completed by the end of the year. It is therefore unlikely that any legislative texts raised by this analysis can be prepared, adopted and implemented before the current exemption is complete. To this end, it is necessary to extend the current exemptions provided for in the Capital Requirements Directive (CRR). This acceptance aims to ensure the stability of the legal framework for economic operators in exceptional conditions, while maintaining the exemption of all requirements contained in the CRR, and it is not decided, in a conscious and informed manner, what is appropriate treatment. I voted for it.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. – EU financial services regulators have had three years to write rules to calculate how much capital commodity dealers should keep in reserve under the Capital Requirements Directive, the Commission is asking for another four years. If the rules are so complicated that they take seven years to write, they will be unworkable. Accordingly UKIP is against.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 It is a question of extending the current exemptions provided for in the CRR (Capital Requirements Regulation) for as long as necessary to complete the analysis on investment firms and to draw up, adopt and implement any legislation that may result from such analysis (not before the end of 2017).

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The requirements laid down in Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 and Directive 2013/36/EU apply to both credit institutions and investment firms. However, Articles 493 and 498 of the Regulation exempted raw material operators from the requirements relating to large exposures and own-fund requirements, respectively. The current resolution, which I have supported, maintains the exemption for commodity operators from the capital requirements applicable to financial institutions, as long as specific regulation for this sector is prepared.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The requirements set out in EU Regulation 575/2013 ("Capital Requirements Regulation" or, according to its English abbreviation, "CRR") and the 2013/36/EC Directive ("Capital Requirements Directive" or "CRD") apply to credit institutions and investment firms. Section 493 and Section 498 of the CRR exempt commodity traders from high risk and capital requirements.  Both waivers expire on December 31, 2017. The Commission has decided to undertake a review on an appropriate regime for commodity traders and prudential supervision of investment firms. It considers it necessary to do so to ensure the development of a coherent prudential framework for all categories of investment firms. However, this review will not be completed until the end of the year.  It is therefore unlikely that legislation resulting from this process could be adopted before the expiry of the current exemptions (end of 2017), which would be not without consequences for commodity traders: if no specific prudential framework resulting from this review applies by then, they will be subject to all the requirements of the RRC and the DRC from 1 January 2018.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's general review of the appropriate commodity trader regime, as well as the review of the general regime for the prudential supervision of investment firms, may have a negative impact on non-investment firms governed by the same Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 (or the Capital Requirements Regulation) in Directive 2013/36/EU (or the Capital Requirements Directive). The Commission seems to have a little hurry – even after asking the European Banking Authority and the European Securities and Markets Authority for advice on this issue, it will not be able to obtain them and turn them into legislation.  All are accepted that the review of investment firms is a complex project that will not be completed by the end of this year. There is therefore a risk that the necessary legislation will not be developed, adopted and applied by the end of 2017 by the end of this review before the current exemptions expire. This would mean that commodity traders would be subject to all requirements of the Capital Requirements Regulation and the Capital Requirements Directive from 1 January 2018. Since all commodity traders cannot be burdened with all the requirements of the Capital Requirements Regulation and the Capital Requirements Directive, and bearing in mind that, following the expiry of the investment firm review, a prudential framework for commodity traders must be established, and the proposal to extend the exemptions provided for in the Capital Requirements Directive must be accepted.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the regulation to extend, until 31 December 2020, the exemptions from the requirements of the CRR Regulation on the large risks and capital enjoyed by commodity traders and to amend accordingly the Regulation (EU) No. 575/2013. The prudential framework for this type of activity is currently under review and it is unlikely that the new legislation will be ready before the expiry of the existing exemptions (i.e., before 31 December 2017).  This is why it is necessary to extend the duration of these exemptions already provided by the CRR.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report follows on from the Commission's proposal to review in full the regulatory framework for entities operating solely on their own behalf on the financial markets as negotiators of derivatives or goods. Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of this report, which follows on from the positive opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and Industrial Policy, and I agree with the principle of extending the exemption from own funds and large exposure requirements for own-account negotiators, so as not to leave the parties in question in an unstable regime during the review phase.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in this vote, which extends exemption from distributors of goods with regard to capital requirements. The Commission is drawing up a new proposal that is not yet ready. We consider that in this context it is not appropriate to remove the exemption automatically. However, we did not want to vote in favour as we oppose the framework directive on capital requirements.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 with regard to the exemptions for traders, because this will give the Commission the necessary time to prepare a proposal before the deadline of 31.12.2017. The Commission now needs to define a new assessment of the risk profile of both commodity traders and investment firms in order to redefine their capital requirements. The aim is to avoid insolvencies and associated risks to the financial sector.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because the Commission is delaying more than necessary the development of specific rules for such importers in the EU. The report extends the extension developed by the European Commission for these importers in the application of the provisions for regulating capital requirements. This regulation lacks the specific provisions that should apply to commodity operators and its direct application could affect many necessary imports, but with this extension proposed by the Commission such economic operators are falling within a legal limbo that can allow very dangerous practices, both in the environmental and financial spheres. That is why we have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, it extends the exemption for commodity dealers as they have specific needs which cannot be met if they are treated as if they were banks or other investment firms. This extension gives regulators the time that is needed to set up a prudential regime which works for commodity dealers without unnecessarily handicapping them.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the extension of the exemption for commodity traders until 31 December 2020, concerning their exemption from the requirements regarding their large exposures and the own funds requirements, because the review and report to be carried out by the Commission on this matter are not yet complete. Thus, the original deadline for exemption (31 December 2017) had to be extended.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has set specific rules for the functioning of credit institutions and investment firms in the Capital Requirements Regulation and the Capital Requirements Directive 2013. According to the original text, commodity traders were to be exempted from large exposure requirements and own funds requirements by the end of 2017. In order to determine the appropriate system for commodity traders, the Commission decided to carry out a review and draw up a report. However, it appears that this review will not be possible to be completed in time and it is therefore highly unlikely that any legislation that may result from this review could be prepared, adopted and applied before the current exemptions for commodity traders expire. It is unfortunate that the Commission's report is being delayed in this way, but I nevertheless voted in favour of extending these derogations. This will prevent commodity traders from being subject to requirements of which they are not sufficiently informed and from losing a stable regulatory framework. Under the draft regulation, these traders will be exempted from the requirements until the end of 2020.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The articles of the CRR exempt commodity traders from large exposure or capital requirements requirements. Both exceptions expire on 31 December 2017. This self-de-icing clause was initially included in the CRR in order to give regulators sufficient time to determine the prudential regime adapted to the risk profile of commodity traders. Commodity traders are considered to be a wide range of players in the energy and commodity markets. The Commission has decided to carry out a single review of the appropriate arrangements for traders in goods and prudential supervision of investment firms in general and to prepare a joint report on the above issues. However, as this is a complex project, it will not be completed until the end of this year. It is therefore unlikely that the legislation resulting from this review would be drafted, adopted and implemented before the expiry of the current exceptions, which means that from then on, traders of goods would be subject to all the requirements of the CRR and the CRD. In order to prevent such a situation, it is appropriate to extend the existing exceptions to the CRR. For this very reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒The term 'commodity traders' covers a wide range of actors in the energy and commodity markets, namely all investment firms whose core business is solely the provision of investment services or the performance of activities related to financial instruments under the Financial Instruments Markets Directive. The requirements laid down in the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) and the Capital Requirements Directive (CRD) apply to both credit institutions and investment firms, with both exemptions highlighting 31 December 2017.  As the review of investment firms is a complex project that will not be completed by the end of this year, it is very unlikely that legislation that could result from this review could be prepared, adopted and applied before the current exemptions expire (i.e. before the end of 2017). The consequences of such an unravelling of the situation would be unfit for commodity traders, which in that case would be subject to the full requirements of crr/CRD as of 1 January 2018. In order to prevent such an undesirable situation, it is important that the validity of existing CRR exemptions is extended by as long as necessary to complete the review of investment firms and to prepare, adopt and apply legislation that could result from that review.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of extending the exemption for commodity dealers, because they have specific needs which cannot be met if they are treated as if they were banks or other investment firms. This extension gives regulators the time they need to set up a prudential regime which works for commodity dealers.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The term 'commodity trader' covers a wide range of actors in the energy and commodity markets. Some trade exclusively in commodity derivatives contracts and resemble investment firms in terms of functions and risks, while for other trading in commodity derivatives, only an analysing activity with the production of goods. Article 493(1) and Article 498(1) of the EIA Capital Requirements Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013 575/2013, traders of goods are exempted from requirements for large exposures and capital requirements. The Commission has decided to carry out a single review of the appropriate regime for commodity traders and prudential supervision of investment firms in general, as it considers that a harmonised prudential framework for all types of investment firms will be ensured. I support the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution amending Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013. 575/2013 because I believe it favours commodity traders and investment firms.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the regulation on exceptions for traders of goods. The exceptions in the CRR, which exempt traders from large exposure or capital requirements, will expire at the end of 2017 and we therefore need a change in the regulation. Otherwise, traders of goods would be subject to all the requirements of the CRR and the CRD. Without an informed (and informed) decision that such treatment is indeed the most appropriate for them, and assuming that a review of investment firms would result in a prudential framework tailored to commodity traders, they would be deprived of a stable regulatory framework.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In this report we have observed an abstention attitude, because we are interested in regulating investment funds that trade commodities, but we disagree with the framework of the Capital Requirements Directive which we voted against as a group since it leaves too many loopholes in the law open for the abuse of the law by investment funds.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The aim is to extend exemptions from large exposure requirements and equity requirements in the case of commodity negotiators (= investment firms whose core business is exclusively for the provision of investment services or financial instruments). These exemptions prolong uncertainty and give the Commission an additional indeterminate period of time to determine the directly necessary prudential regulation for these undertakings.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal to amend Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, which adopted an extension of the scope of the current exemptions provided for in the Crr. The relevant articles of the CRR exempt commodity traders from the provisions on large risk-taking and own funds requirements. The aim of ensuring this march was to give regulators time to develop prudential rules adapted to the risk profile of commodity traders. As both exemptions expire on 31 December 2017 and, as the report points out, it is currently unlikely that the review of investment firms will be completed or that the relevant act will be adopted and applied by the deadline indicated, I supported the extension of the scope of the exemptions.
