All the more so since it would create an unstable situation if, under the current system, in which they are exempted from the provisions on large risk-taking and own funds requirements, commodity traders would first be subject to a temporary system fully enracing the crr/crd requirements and then, within a very short period of time, would be subject to a specific framework tailored to them.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Exclusions of commodity traders from the requirements for large exposures and own funds expire on 31 December 2017. However, the review of investment firms is a complex undertaking that will not be completed by the end of this year. It is therefore highly unlikely that any legal provisions that could be adopted as a result of this review will be prepared and adopted and applied before the expiry of the current exemptions. It is therefore necessary to extend the existing exemptions laid down in the Capital Requirements Regulation. This extension should take into account the time necessary to complete the review of investment firms and to prepare, adopt and apply any provisions that may result from that review. Otherwise, from 2018, trade in goods would have to be subject to obligations under the Capital Requirements Regulation and the Capital Requirements Directive, which are detrimental to such undertakings. Parliament's agreement to adopt at first reading the Commission's proposal on exemptions for traders of goods is the right decision, which is why I decided to vote in favour of the report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European institutions have in recent years developed a number of measures aimed at avoiding economic problems such as those arising during the 2008 international financial crisis. These measures aimed at stricter regulation of the commercial sector, with a view to ensuring greater protection for consumers. One of these measures was the adoption of Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 575/2013 on capital requirements (CRR), coupled with Directive 2013/36/EU on Capital Requirements (CRD), documents applicable to credit institutions and investment firms, derived from the prudential regime imposed on credit institutions. In those documents, there is a derogation for investment services in the securities field from compliance with the requirements for large exposures and own funds requirements respectively. The derogation, valid until 31 December 2017, was considered necessary to give regulators the time it took to establish prudential regulation adapted to the risk profile of traders of goods. In view of the state of assessment of the necessary legislative framework, the Commission considered that an extension of the derogation was necessary until the reviews already undertaken were completed. As this is a request for the coherence of the Union legislative act, I support the extension of the derogation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text on exemptions for commodity traders. The waivers expire on December 31, 2017. A sunset clause was originally introduced in the RRC to give regulators time to define a prudential regime tailored to the risk profile of commodity traders.  The term "commodity trader" covers a wide range of players in the energy and commodities markets: for some, comparable to investment firms in terms of functions and risks, trading derivatives contracts on raw materials is the only activity; for others, it is only an ancillary activity of the production of raw materials.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal to extend the exemptions for commodity dealers to be exempted from large exposure requirement and from own fund requirements until 2020. This will save commodity dealers from an unstable regulatory environment in the short term, and avoid them from disbursing their own funds that they need to have in order to continue their activities and the related costs of performing those activities.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The audit of investment firms is a very complex project and the likelihood that legislation that could come out of this audit will be prepared, adopted and applied before the current exemptions expire, i.e. before the end of 2017, is extremely small. As, as of 1 January 2018, commodity traders should be subject to the full requirements of the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) and the Capital Requirements Directive (CRD), I consider it necessary to extend existing exemptions so that commodity traders can adapt to the requirements. I believe that the extension should take into account the amount of time needed to complete the audit of investment firms and to prepare, adopt and apply legislation that could result from that audit. I therefore supported the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending the Regulation with regard to exemptions for commodity traders.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on cohesion policy in the EU's mountainous regions. Mountain regions account for a significant proportion of EU territory (around 30%). The whole EU depends on the services of mountain ecosystems. Due to extreme conditions and remoteness, these regions are structurally disadvantaged to the point where many mountain regions are facing a decline and ageing population, which can disrupt the natural generation cycle and lead to a decline in social standards and quality of life.  This often leads to higher unemployment rates, social exclusion and migration to cities. Mountain regions offer numerous opportunities to achieve the EU's objectives of employment, cohesion and environmental protection through the sustainable use of their natural resources.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in this vote, which extends exemption from distributors of goods with regard to capital requirements. The Commission is drawing up a new proposal that is not yet ready. We consider that in this context it is not appropriate to remove the exemption automatically. However, we did not want to vote in favour as we oppose the framework directive on capital requirements

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The proposed amendment would allow commodity traders to benefit from an extension of the exemptions from the large risk and capital requirements of the CRR Regulation until December 31, 2020. These companies represent a significant risk to commodity markets, particularly through the massive use of derivatives, which can lead to high volatility and cause prices to vary for no fundamental reason, while having negative consequences for the real economy. It therefore appears to us to be detrimental to the financial stability of our economies to leave room for the Commission to carry out work that should have been done long before the 2008 financial crisis. The very fragile situation of our financial system should prompt the Commission to regulate these activities, even if it means being too cautious, rather than asking for an additional three years of time. So I voted against it.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The term 'commodity trader' wants to cover a wide range of players in the energy and commodity market, as explained in this proposal for a regulation. The assimilation of investment firms may be made, the negotiation of commodity derivative contracts being their only activity, or, for others, it is only a part of the activity of the production of goods. The Capital Requirements Regulation 575/2013 (CRR) grants traders a derogation from compliance with large exposure requirements and own funds requirements by a deadline of 31 December 2017. In this respect, the European Commission has undertaken a single review and is preparing a report on those issues so as to develop a coherent prudential framework for all types of investment firms.  I supported this report because it is appropriate to extend the existing derogations provided for by the CRR. The extension should be granted taking into account the time it will take to conclude the procedure for the review of the investment firms framework and to prepare, adopt and apply the legislation that could result from this review.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The requirements of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 (CRR) and Directive 2013/36/EU (CRD) apply to both credit institutions and investment firms. The capital requirements scheme for investment firms is based on the credit institution scheme and is adapted to take account of the investment services provided by investment firms. With my vote, following the position of the S&D group, I supported it.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in this vote, which extends exemption from distributors of goods with regard to capital requirements. The Commission is drawing up a new proposal that is not yet ready. We consider that in this context it is not appropriate to remove the exemption automatically. However, we did not want to vote in favour as we oppose the framework directive on capital requirements.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe the deadline extension for the exemptions laid down in the CRR Regulation for commodity dealers specified in the Regulation is fully justifiable and legitimate.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I support the proposal extending the exemption in order to protect traders in the short term from the unstable regulatory environment.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a technical decision before which Parliament approves the Commission's proposal at first reading and asks it to be consulted again if it intends to substantially amend its proposal or replace it with another text. The exemption from Article 498(1) of EU Regulation No 575/2013 exempts operators in raw materials from the requirements relating to large exposures and the requirements of own funds. Exemptions expiring on 31 December 2017 and against which the Commission is already carrying out an assessment to find an appropriate regime for operators in raw materials. Because it is highly unlikely that any legislation resulting from this review can be drawn up, adopted and implemented before the expiry of the exemption for this group, I believe it is necessary to extend it so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted to approve exempting those agents operating on the market from the capital requirements applicable to financial institutions, as long as specific regulation for this sector is prepared.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has decided to carry out an analysis of the appropriate regime for operators in goods and for the prudential supervision of investment firms in general. However, the analysis of investment firms is not yet complete (it is expected to be only at the end of the year). In this way, it is a lawyer that it is very unlikely that the legislative texts which may be raised by this analysis can be prepared, adopted and applied before the current exemption expires (i.e. before the end of 2017). This has consequences for operators in goods: if, by that time, no specific prudential framework resulting from the analysis of investment firms has entered into force, they will be subject to all the requirements of the Capital Requirements Regulation and the Capital Requirements Directive from 1 January 2018.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 with regard to the exemptions for goods traders. It concerns the extension of exceptional circumstances for commodity traders with regard to the risk profile of commodity traders. The Commission wanted to use the time to find a tailor-made scheme. So far, it has not been able to do so. I am not convinced that she will be able to do so with a longer window of opportunity for further reflection. Moreover, I consider that the 'Own Resources Regulation' (CRR) and the 'Own Resources Directive' ('CRD') are in any case unsuitable for creating a healthy and sufficiently capitalised banking system.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Written. – I have agreed to this text on the exemption for commodity traders. In certain situations, commodity traders shall be subject to an exception to this Regulation. This was already contained in the original version, but it only applies until December 31, 2017.  Future, adapted legislation will have to provide a specific framework for commodity traders. Of course, this new legislation can only be created on the basis of a thorough evaluation by the European Commission of investment companies in the EU. However, it is expected that this report will not be ready before the deadline of 31 December 2017. The group of traders protected by the exemptions would then be covered by a completely new legislative framework, with potentially negative consequences.  In order to have a lasting, positive effect of the Regulation and to avoid potential negative side effects, we have extended the operation of this exemption until 31 December 2020. In this way, potential destabilising effects created by an uncertain legislative framework are avoided.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the derogations provided for freight traders. The European Commission has decided to undertake a single review of an appropriate regime for traders of goods and on the prudential supervision of investment firms in general, called the review of the investment companies framework, and to prepare a single report to this effect.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting the Commission's position, as adopted by the European Parliament, taking into account what the rapporteur has also tabled.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The current Regulation grants specific exemptions for commodity traders, in particular concerning minimum level of own funds requirements and exposures. As both of these exemptions are only in force until the end of 2017, we have extended their effectiveness for a further three years or until work on the revision of the Regulation is completed. I agree with this principle. I think that, as long as work is already under way to revise the regulation, but they have not been completed by the expiry of the derogations, it would be pointless to change the existing rules for commodity traders for a short time and burden them by suddenly having to meet all the requirements. At the same time, the special status of commodity traders stems from the riskiness of this type of trade, and I believe that extending the exemptions until the new binding rules are laid down will be particularly beneficial in the interests of their legal certainty. I therefore supported the report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 as regards exceptions for traders of goods, Whereas I agree that it is necessary to extend the validity of the existing exceptions to the CRR for traders of goods that would otherwise expire on 31 December 2017, as otherwise this would have negative consequences for traders of goods, as from 1 January 2018 they would be subject to all the requirements of the CRR and the CRD.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Mr President, under the leadership of my compatriot Rob Wainwright, Europol has developed into a crucial hub for intelligence sharing and for operational support between national forces. Today, we have voted to give Europol sharper tools in the fight against organised crime and terrorism, as well as a strong element of supervision by experts and parliamentarians at both national and European level. The Europol Internet Referral Unit has been operational for almost a year, helping to take down Jihadist recruitment propaganda on the internet and on social media. In the first six months, it received over 1700 referral decisions for content to be removed. With this new agreement, it will be able to increase its capabilities in the coming months and enable Europol to continue to play a crucial role in the fight against terrorism and organised crime. For that reason, I supported it today.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, Europol is nothing more than an institution of European police cooperation. Among other things, it is used and receives large amounts of European taxpayers' money to prevent and deal with crimes such as terrorism, trafficking in human beings and trafficking in human beings. Do your colleagues and the Presidency of the European Parliament think that it is time for europol's leaders to come before us and report on what they have done with this taxpayer's money and their potential over the years? I am getting more and more letters asking me whether European police forces did not deliberately allow the tragedies that took place in Europe as an act of terrorism to happen. So much for terrorism. What do you have to show for people smuggling? What do you have to show for international trafficking networks? Lots of texts, lots of money, zero results.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this document. I believe that it makes sense at this time to strengthen Europol's powers. I am not in a supporter of setting up new offices. Personally, I do not support the establishment, for example, of the European Prosecutor's Office.  But this proposal, which does not establish an office, but only strengthens Europol and increases its chances of obtaining information on various trends in cross-border crime, certainly makes sense. In the future, Europol should provide feedback to individual national police departments on trends in the field of international crime, in the field of counter-terrorism. And in order to provide feedback, it must first obtain information from individual national states. I think, and I agree with this, that it is also a good thing that europol's special unit in the fight against terrorism is being strengthened. I think this unit can produce clear results.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, a stronger mandate from Europol is directly proportional to the safety of our citizens. Europol must have a modern data system and a data management system. There is a need for a legal basis for cooperation with private entities and national authorities for Europol. The exchange of data must be carried out in a uniform manner. We cannot fight terrorism, organised crime, without effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at both national and Union level.  We have learned with surprise that twenty-three of the Member States of the Union do not send up-to-date information to the database, for example the Schengen information system, which means that in the Schengen information system database we do not have all the information on those who might attack Europe, to be part of the jihadist group. I call on the Member States to make this effort, fulfil this duty and send the data to the Schengen database.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, we kept on being told in this debate that crime does not recognise national borders. We were told this as though it was some kind of original insight. Of course it does not and for a long time States in Europe have cooperated internationally. We have Interpol, we have the Hague Convention, we have extradition treaties and we recognise time spent in another country’s prison. All of these are instruments that apply globally. That is not what this debate about. It is not what Europol is about.  Europol, as the authors frankly admitted when it was first put forward after Tampere, is about creating a federal police force – their words, not mine. It is about creating a kind of European FBI and that is the choice for us. It is between association and absorption. It is between alliance and assimilation. It is between cooperation and coercion.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The regulation proposed by the Council will improve the data processing, data protection system used by Europol for its day-to-day work, as well as increase their operational capacity and flexibility. As a possible way, the institution's activities will potentially become more efficient and secure from an operational point of view after the document enters into force from 1 May 2017.  The new regulation will replace the one adopted in 2009, thanks to which Europol was also established. Apart from maximising the potential for job efficiency, the new regulation will, by the way, enable national parliaments and the relevant committee of the European Parliament to monitor europol's work together by setting up a joint parliamentary scrutiny group. That is right, it needs to be supported, and the role of the Commission and Parliament in terms of data exchange will be further supported, which is also good when it comes to concluding relevant information exchange agreements between Europol and the partner bodies. Thank you!

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, we all want security, we all want cooperation and we all want to work together with organisations like Interpol. In the UK we want to work together with the Five Eyes network, for example, but I have serious concerns over the lack of transparency in Europol.  The ‘remain’ campaign in the UK seems to imply that leaving the European Union would harm security, but Richard Walton, former Head of Counterterrorism at New Scotland Yard, said membership of the EU does not really convey any benefits that we could not access from outside it. Air Chief Marshal Michael Graydon said our intelligence relationships are with individual member countries, not Europe, so it is irrelevant whether we are in or out.  If we want to work together internationally, of course we will keep working with, we will keep sharing information with other countries, but we do not need to be part of a European Union to do that. We can work together perfectly well and ensure our national security, in fact better rather than worse, and therefore I voted against.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this measure is a step in the right direction: strengthening Europol means strengthening the protection and security of the citizens of the European Union. I believe that the exchange of information must follow an absolutely strict criterion, precisely in order to guarantee uniformity in the collection of information and to combat, especially through new media, and in particular the Internet, what is being done by recruiting young people, who then become instruments of fundamentalism and, above all, of terrorism, which is so disastrous for our society. This is an absolutely positive measure, which I can support with my vote, and I am proud that Parliament is moving in this direction.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, it is, of course, a notorieta that crime knows no borders, and it is therefore important that we too are able to work together. I think that Europol, despite some of the challenges it faces, has managed to earn respect, that it is an organisation that should certainly further enhance police cooperation, and I do not see any indication in the report that has been tabled and which I am happy to support that we are accessing some kind of establishment of a federal police service. This is indeed not the case in my opinion. The need to deepen this cooperation, that the exchange of information really needs to be subject to certain rules, I think that is entirely obvious, and I am therefore glad that this report does not shy away from these issues, and I could therefore, I repeat, support it.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, cosúil leis an gcuid is mó de na Feisirí vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí anseo agus tá áthas orm gur glacadh leis agus go bhfuilimid anois ag tabhairt na hionstraimí do Europol chun troid i gcoinne na sceimhlitheoireachta agus na cibearchoiriúlachta agus mar sin de.  Nuair a thógtar é seo leis an vóta a bhí againn cúpla seachtain ó shin faoi PNR, tá dul chun cinn á dhéanamh againn sa troid i gcoinne na sceimhlitheoireachta. Agus is ceart é sin. Is féidir lenár saoránaigh a rá anois, gur ceart go mbeadh an Eoraip níos sláine agus níos sábháilte dóibh amach anseo. Táimid ag tabhairt buiséad de bhreis agus EUR 2 mhiliún do Europol agus tá sé sin ag teastáil. Is féidir linn a bheith sásta, ar a laghad, go bhfuilimid ar an mbóthar ceart.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote is about the draft regulation establishing the European Union Agency for the Cooperation and Training of Law Enforcement Authorities (Europol). The new regulation will also ensure a robust data protection regime applicable to Europol. All this is aimed at increasing controls in order to effectively combat terrorism and other forms of crime. For these reasons, I voted against the rejection amendment.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the new Regulation which will regulate EUROPOL, in compliance with the Lisbon Treaty for its adaptation to it. EUROPOL is an institution of great relevance in the configuration of the European Union's Freedom, Security and Justice Area. As security functions are the exclusive competence of THE MEMs in their respective territories, EUROPOL plays an important role in coordinating the action of the EEMM in combating certain forms of criminality. EUROPOL acts in practice as a "pool" of information sent by the EEMM on criminal areas under its management field that require specialized analysis from a European dimension. Its objective is the prevention and investigation of the activities of criminal groups operating in different Member States. The new regulation will, for example, have a more effective impact on the fight against terrorism that is being developed on the Network.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. We rejected the Council's proposal for the new Regulation of EuroPol. We are against this agency being endowed with greater powers while maintaining significant opacity that leaves it completely out of public scrutiny. With this new regulation, the principle of subsidiarity disappears, leaving the agency responsible for all european policy issues, which would allow EuroPol to carry out its activities independently in addition to cross-border cooperation without cooperating with the security forces of the Member States. In addition, you will have the ability to collect and store data independently, which may conflict with the laws of different states regarding data protection.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal to reject the text on the European Union Agency for the Cooperation of Law Enforcement (Europol).  In particular, the text provides for the creation of a joint parliamentary monitoring group established by the national parliaments and the competent committee of the European Parliament to ensure political control of Europol's activities.  The Council's position provides an explicit legal basis for reporting content on the internet. In addition, a new provision for information processing and data protection would be incorporated, allowing Europol to establish links and connections between different investigations.  While I am in favour of cooperation between the police services of the Member States, I am strongly opposed to the emergence of a European federal police force.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ There was no final vote on this report as it was at second reading phase. However, I voted in favour of a rejection amendment. The Council proposal enhanced and expanded the remit and operational capacity of Europol, which included giving the enforcement agency the power to determine what online content is illegal or not and substantially increased data collection power. In addition to this enhancing power, the Council proposal sought to remove oversight and monitoring of Europol activity. Whilst the report does subject Europol to tighter data protection restrictions, the removal of the Joint Supervisory Body removes all on-site regulation and the monitoring of national databases. My party has been to the forefront in raising concerns about the current deterioration of much earned civil liberties across Europe at present. This report reflected many of those concerns and I was very concerned with the infringement of basic civil liberties. My party will continue to monitor the infringement of Human Rights and Civil Liberties both in Ireland and in Europe.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the Europol Regulation after three years of work. In the face of an increase in serious and organised crime, and in order to combat terrorism more effectively, I have always advocated better cooperation between Member States and their police services at European level. In the face of threats, Europe, through the Europol Agency, has an essential coordinating role to play. The attacks in Paris and Brussels show the imperative of working together and exchanging information. The Group played an important role in achieving this balanced agreement. In particular, we have obtained joint investigation teams, the establishment of national Europol units and the appointment of liaison officers. The Agency's new powers will be accompanied by strong data protection safeguards and tools to ensure democratic control; this was one of the strong demands of the European Parliament. However, this building is based on the existence of a high degree of confidence, which is not easy to achieve; therefore, the idea of a European Police Office - a form of European FBI - should not be ruled out. This is for us the next, unavoidable step in the construction of a genuine European area of freedom, security and justice.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the amendment tabled by efdd, because I am in favour of the draft law on the EU Agency for Cooperation and Training in law enforcement (Europol). The proposal for a "Lisbonenses" law provides for a legal framework for the replacement of Europol. The Lisbon Strategy meant that europol's structure needed reform, including its overall functioning, governance, supervision, data protection regime and its relations with third countries and international organisations. The Lisbon Strategy is an important step towards greater efficiency at EU level in cooperation with law enforcement agencies and authorities. It also guarantees stronger supervision and a clearer data protection regime.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Our citizens expect more security and more measures to combat terrorism. The recent attacks have only made it clear that organised crime knows no borders. That is why I think it is important to further strengthen Europol in order to promote cooperation between the Member States. The Council's proposal takes an important step here, calling for the establishment of a European Cybercrime Centre in order to specifically counter the Internet propaganda used by criminal organisations to disseminate their criminal activities. It also promotes the exchange of information between the Member States and Europol. Only in this way can Europol effectively evaluate information on the fight against terrorist cells. I have therefore also voted in favour of this report. Nevertheless, it is important for me to stress that more Europe is needed to enable effective action against terrorist cells. I am therefore in favour of a European intelligence service.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The agency is further strengthened. The ENL Group is in favour of cooperation between Member States' police services in the fight against terrorism and serious cross-border crime, but we are wary of the gradual development of some kind of European federal police, which is why I voted in favour of the motion to reject it.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, which will strengthen Europol's mandate. I welcome the adoption of this legislation, which is essential at a time when Europe is facing the terrorist threat. Nevertheless, I regret that the reform is not more ambitious. There is an urgent need for Member States to provide Europol with a genuine investigative capacity and to establish genuine integrated European police cooperation. I hope that European countries will unite to combat the international threat posed by terrorism.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the initiative to enhance Europol’s mandate as the EU’s central law enforcement agency and provide new tools for rapid response to emerging terrorist threats, serious and organised crime. Europol will be able to initiate their own investigations and receive data from Member States on systematic basis. Moreover I totally agree that we need to ensure that this agency has all needed capacities to prevent the online spread of terrorist propaganda, as information is a strong weapon in hands of the terrorists. At the same time new legislation provides better data protection and gives all necessary control on the topic in hands of the European data protection authority.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the European police agency Europol will be able to intensify its efforts in the fight against terrorism and cybercrime and respond faster to threats thanks to the new rules of operation than the Parliament we have adopted. The new powers are accompanied by strict safeguards on data protection and democratic control tools.  The draft legislation, agreed by Parliament and Council negotiators in November 2015, strengthens Europol's powers to ensure that it has the necessary instruments in the face of the threat of cross-border crime and terrorism. Among other developments, the Agency will have more facilities to create specialized units to respond to imminent threats.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the regulation reforming Europol, the European Intergovernmental Criminal Police Agency, in order to strengthen its operational powers in the fight against terrorism.  As terrorist acts do not know the borders, it is increasingly inoperative not to really coordinate between police forces of the Member States of the European Union.  One of the objectives of this text is to make the participation of member States' police forces more systematic and codified, notably through joint investigation teams and the establishment of Europol's national unit. These are long-standing claims by professionals acting in the field.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to strengthen the European Police Office. Europol is an EU law enforcement agency that assists law enforcement authorities in the Member States in the fight against international crime and terrorism. In order to adapt to the new threats, EU governments and the European Parliament have agreed to extend Europol's anti-terrorist powers. The updated rules of operation of the European Police Office (EUROPOL) will allow for greater attention to be paid to the fight against terrorism or cyber-attacks. In turn, the new office powers will be subject to additional democratic scrutiny. The new rules will make it easier to set up specialised units to address emerging threats and will clarify the functions of the European Counter-Terrorism Centre operating from 1 January this year. In addition, in some cases Europol will be able to exchange information with private companies, for example with a view to removing websites of terrorist organisations on social networks.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. As the text went to second reading, I did not have to comment on the text itself; however, I voted in favour of a proposal to reject the Council's position. I am opposed to this strengthening of Europol, because I cannot accept the development of a European federal police force that would undermine the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have obviously approved this proposal, which contains three important advances: 1) first of all, EUROPOL is strengthened in its role as an organisation promoting the mutual cooperation of Member States for the prevention and repression of serious crime and terrorism. The new rules stipulate that Member States should provide EUROPOL with the information they need to carry out its missions. Strengthening the exchange of information at European level is essential if we are to ensure internal security and strengthen Schengen. With the new provisions, EUROPOL is becoming a major player in this European intelligence exchange; 2) the rules on the control of the use of personal data that are required of Europol are strengthened in parallel with the increase of its powers. For example, the European Data Protection Supervisor will be responsible for monitoring the use of data by EUROPOL; 3) Finally, the democratic control of EUROPOL will also be strengthened since the work of EUROPOL will be supervised by a joint parliamentary review group composed of members of both the European Parliament and national parliaments.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the de Mera García Consuegra report on the regulation establishing the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). The project represents an important step forward in combating terrorist activity and cross-border crimes, firstly by promoting a more effective exchange of information between the Member States and Europol. The Agency's powers will be extended to make it easier for it to set up specialised units and to exchange information more quickly with NGOs and private companies. The new powers will also be matched by strengthened control mechanisms. Europol will have to report annually to the European Parliament, the Council, the Commission and the national parliaments on the information provided by the individual Member States; its work will be monitored by the European Data Protection Supervisor and also monitored by a group of MEPs and members of national parliaments.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. During the passage of the European Commission's proposal on the European Police Office (EUROPOL) by the LIBE committee, a problematic text was improved thanks to the amendments of the left-wing groups. For example, through more stringent data protection, in line with the directive recently adopted in LIBE, a broader parliamentary control mechanism or a better definition of EUROPOL's limits of action. However, in its passage through the trilogue, the text has returned to swampy ground as it alters EUROPOL's original purpose of helping national police and judicial authorities combat international crime and terrorism by extending its scope of action to the point of compromising the principle of subsidiarity. The lack of a precise definition of the scope of action, the reduction of parliamentary control, the ability of the Internet Content Notification Unit to exchange data directly with individuals without the participation of Member States, inter alia, seriously calls into question a text which must regulate an agency whose action decisively affects civil liberties. That is why we voted IN FAVOUR to reject the Council's position

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. As the report on the EU Agency for the Cooperation of Law Enforcement (Europol) went to second reading, there was no vote on the merits, but I did vote in favour of a motion to reject the Council's proposal to strengthen Europol. I am opposed to this movement to lead to the creation of a kind of European federal police: since the Eurocrats want a European federal state, let them clearly announce it rather than nibble, piece by piece, the regal prerogatives of the Member States. Under the pretext of combating terrorism, the Council's proposal also provides for an expansion of Europol's powers which constitutes a real threat to the freedom of citizens of European nations, since the Agency would have the possibility of transferring and receiving personal data to private parties. While I am in favour of bilateral cooperation between sovereign states in order to combat terrorism, I cannot validate such a transfer of powers to an EU agency.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Díaz report contains some positive elements, such as the call for greater efforts in the fight against international terrorism. I believe, however, that the text does not condemn the EU's failure to manage its external borders and the resulting mass and uncontrolled immigration, which has already caused serious social and economic problems for our territories. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the European police agency Europol will be able to intensify its efforts in the fight against terrorism and cybercrime and respond faster to threats thanks to the new rules of operation than the Parliament we have adopted. The new powers are accompanied by strict safeguards on data protection and democratic control tools.  The draft legislation, agreed by Parliament and Council negotiators in November 2015, strengthens Europol's powers to ensure that it has the necessary instruments in the face of the threat of cross-border crime and terrorism. Among other developments, the Agency will have more facilities to create specialized units to respond to imminent threats.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation because the Council position was adopted at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). The establishment of a harmonised, high-level data protection system involving the activities of police and judicial authorities in the European Union is a crucial tool for the protection and safeguarding of the fundamental rights of Union citizens. Given that the EU and the Member States are jointly responsible for the area of freedom, security and justice, it is essential to ensure close and effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and European Union level. The European Parliament and the Council are of the opinion that, following the adoption of the proposed General Data Protection Regulation and the Data Protection Directive on data processing in the police and justice sector, Including the new European Data Protection Board, which is about to be established, and in the light of the published review of Regulation (EC) No 45/2001, the different mechanisms for cooperation between the European Data Protection Supervisor and the national supervisory authorities in this field, including the Cooperation Board established by this Regulation, should be reorganised in the future in order to ensure efficiency and consistency and avoid unnecessary duplication of activities, without prejudice to the Commission's right of initiative.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In particular, it is timely to strengthen and endow the European Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation and Training (Europol) with all necessary means to act appropriately in the fight against terrorism. The same applies to the prevention and combating of international organised crime. I therefore voted in favour of the report on Europol today. I support the Agency's strengthened mandate to effectively coordinate and strengthen the cooperation of member states' authorities in the prevention of organised crime and the fight against terrorism. I welcome this text because we have managed to strike the right balance with regard to the protection of personal data without compromising or hindering the success of investigations.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \ I did not support the motion for a resolution rejecting the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol).  I am very pleased that the European Parliament and the Council have finally reached an agreement on Europol, which thus acquires more powers in the fight against terrorism and other types of organised crime.  Following the adoption of the proposal for a general data protection regulation and a data protection directive for data processing in the police and judicial sectors, including the new European Data Protection Board to be established shortly, close and effective cooperation between these authorities at national and European level is crucial to ensure the security of citizens of the European Union.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time when the fight against terrorism is a top priority, the strengthening of Europol is an urgent necessity. Indeed, criminal and terrorist networks are now a real threat to all European citizens, and if we are to meet the challenges before us, we can only update our counter-terrorism and intelligence capabilities. Europol naturally plays a key role in this by assisting and facilitating the exchange of information and expertise between the police forces of the different Member States, and that is why strengthening the Agency is now more necessary than ever. I therefore support the reform of Europol, which aims to optimise its overall functioning, improving its governance and data protection regime, while strengthening its competences and capacity for cooperation with third countries and international organisations.

name: David BORRELLI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote in favour of the Diaz report testifies to the Strong Commitment of the European Parliament to strengthening the protection and security of the citizens of the European Union. The text has positive elements in that it strengthens the mandate of the European Police Agency by providing it with new governance rules and, at the same time, giving it new responsibilities.  Furthermore, the call for greater efforts in the fight against international terrorism, including the monitoring of internet content, is an important sign of prevention against fundamentalism. The new powers conferred on Europol will not weaken data protection guarantees. The European Data Protection Supervisor will monitor the work of the police agency while a joint parliamentary monitoring group will oversee its work. The report as a whole must therefore be welcomed because, in addition to testifying to the Strong Commitment of the European Parliament against Terrorism, it takes a step towards greater exchange of information between the police forces of the individual Member States.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support china's market economy status report. I believe that coordinated strategies should be implemented with our trading partners. I also call on the Commission to use specific anti-dumping rules as China becomes a market economy.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I am in favour of cooperation between Member States' police services in the fight against terrorism and serious cross-border crime, but I am wary of the gradual development of some kind of European federal police. I therefore voted in favour of the amendment to reject the proposal.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – There was no final vote on this report as it was at second reading phase. However, I voted in favour of a rejection amendment. The Council proposal enhanced and expanded the remit and operational capacity of Europol, which included giving the enforcement agency the power to determine what online content is illegal or not and substantially increased data collection power. In addition to this enhancing power, the Council proposal sought to remove oversight and monitoring of Europol activity. Whilst the report does subject Europol to tighter data protection restrictions, the removal of the Joint Supervisory Body removes all on-site regulation and the monitoring of national databases. My party has been to the forefront in raising concerns about the current deterioration of much earned civil liberties across Europe at present. This report reflected many of those concerns and I was very concerned with the infringement of basic civil liberties. My Party will continue to monitor the infringement of Human Rights and Civil Liberties both in Ireland and in Europe.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU and its Member States share responsibility for maintaining the security, justice, freedom and protection of the fundamental rights of EU citizens. Pushing for the creation of common institutions to harmonise activities by implementing genuine cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and Union level is essential to make strategic and operational cooperation between the Member States of the European Union, their intelligence and police forces and partner countries more efficient in the fight against terrorism, mafias, smuggling and international crime. , bearing in mind that the ultimate objective for improving the system must be the creation of an EU police force and intelligence force subject to democratic control by European citizens.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report entrusts national parliaments and the relevant committee of the European Parliament with the responsibility of setting up a monitoring group to oversee the activities of the Union Agency for the Cooperation of Law Enforcement (Europol). The Council, for its part, provides an explicit legal basis for reporting content on the internet. Europol will now be allowed to transfer personal data to private parties.  Of course we are in favour of cooperation between the police services of the Member States in order to combat the development of Islamic fundamentalism and criminal organisations. However, I have opposed this text, which is gradually helping to bring about the emergence of a European federal police force. That is why I voted for the rejection proposal.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 A high and harmonised level of data protection covering police and judicial activities in the Union, I believe is a crucial way of respecting and guaranteeing the fundamental rights of EU citizens. The shared responsibilities of the Union and the Member States in the area of freedom, security and justice are extremely important for close and effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at both national and European level.  Having regard to the Council's approval of first reading and the approval of the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament and of the Council on this resolution, it is noted that this act is adopted in accordance with the Council's position. Once approval, a reorganisation is also necessary in such a way as to ensure effectiveness, consistency and, last but not least, to avoid unnecessary duplication of efforts. I voted in favour of this resolution on the EU Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation and Training (Europol) because I believe that the law needs to be applied as best as possible and in the most simplified way for better legislative coordination in the EU and in the Member States.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 As confirmed by the final vote in the LIBE committee by Mr Syps, i.e. the vote in committee, i.e. the vote in the Libe Committee, i.e. the vote in the Committee on The Fontana, we do not want to reject this proposal out of the way. From our point of view, there are elements that are certainly positive, such as increased investment in the fight against terrorism through intelligence services and enhanced controls on third-country nationals. However, the rapporteur's political choice not to openly condemn the failure of border management and the migration crisis, which has therefore provoked and provokes extraordinary work on the part of Europol, weighs heavily.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the European police agency Europol will be able to intensify its efforts in the fight against terrorism and cybercrime and respond faster to threats thanks to the new rules of operation than the Parliament we have adopted. The new powers are accompanied by strict safeguards on data protection and democratic control tools.  The draft legislation, agreed by Parliament and Council negotiators in November 2015, strengthens Europol's powers to ensure that it has the necessary instruments in the face of the threat of cross-border crime and terrorism. Among other developments, the Agency will have more facilities to create specialized units to respond to imminent threats.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Europol's aim is to create a safer European Union by assisting and cooperating with the law enforcement agencies of the Member States. In a Union without internal borders, it is essential to ensure the safety of citizens by effectively combating terrorism and crime. It is true that terrorism and large-scale crime know no borders. Their misdeeds cannot be facilitated by freedom of movement on European territory. Europol is working to improve the work of police services within the Union.  This regulation gives the European agency appropriate powers to combat terrorism and international crime. It will modernise Europol's governance and strengthen its capacity to cooperate with third countries. We needed such a regulation, particularly in the wake of the attacks on European territory. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this recommendation to allow the European police agency, Europol, to step up its efforts to combat terrorism, cybercrime and other crimes and to respond more quickly to threats. In particular, it will be easier for Europol to set up specialised units to respond immediately to emerging threats.  In some cases, Europol will be able to exchange information directly with private individuals, such as companies or NGOs, so that it can operate more quickly. For example, Europol's special internet monitoring unit will be able to contact directly the providers responsible for a social network such as Facebook and demand that a web page run by Isis be deleted, thus blocking the spread of terrorist propaganda more quickly. These new powers conferred on Europol will go hand in hand with stronger data protection guarantees and instruments of democratic parliamentary control. The European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) will have to monitor Europol's activities and a clear procedure for complaints from EU citizens will be established. A joint parliamentary monitoring group will also oversee Europol's work.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I had several serious concerns with aspects of this report, which in my view amount to an infringement of basic civil liberties. There was no final vote on this report as it was at second reading phase. However, I voted in favour of a rejection amendment. The Council proposal enhances and expands the remit and operational capacity of Europol, including giving the enforcement agency the power to determine what online content is illegal or not and substantially increased data collection power. On top of enhancing power, the Council proposal seeks to remove oversight and monitoring of Europol activity. While the report subjects Europol to tighter data protection restrictions, the removal of the Joint Supervisory Body removes all on-site regulation and the monitoring of Member State databases. I also voted in favour of a Greens amendment calling for the controversial Internet Referral Unit to be legislated on separately.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP are against this report as we are principally against Europol and the extension of power of Europol. Even though this report does increase the potential to scrutinise Europol and hold the institution accountable we believe that the best way to increase safety is to remove Schengen and Europol, and instead have increased member state cooperation through institutions like Interpol.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ It was agreed today that the powers of the European Police Office (Europol) should be significantly strengthened. I believe that Europol needs be strengthened in such uncertain times when we face threats such as extremism and organised crime.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the second reading vote on the new draft regulation establishing the European Union Agency for The Cooperation and Training of Law Enforcement Authorities (Europol). The purpose of the new regulation is to bring the decision currently under Europol into line with the requirements of the Treaty of Lisbon and introduces an EP monitoring mechanism on Europol's activities, in association with national parliaments. A stronger data protection regime applicable to the Agency is also introduced, in particular by ensuring the full independence of Europol's data protection supervisor. Further elements will also be introduced to improve the governance of Europol, so that it can offer more efficient support to Member States to combat terrorism and other serious forms of crime. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. \u2012 The work of the European Union Law Enforcement Agency (Europol) has become more important in recent times than ever before. With recent criminal events, in particular the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, it has become clear that organised crime, in this case Daesh terrorism, knows no borders between the Member States of the European Union. For the Caliphate, the European Union is already a single economic and political entity, and striking at a Member State means hitting the whole Union. The attacks are organised in one state, with material from another state and committed in another. It is clear that only a common police and intelligence force can protect us. The exchange of information and cooperation between Member States is essential in order to counter the advance of this terrorism, which is determined to strike at the economic and political heart of the Union. Europol must be able to function quickly and effectively to combat terrorism, but also all the countless other crimes committed on European soil, for example trafficking in human beings, which is unfortunately linked to the migratory phenomenon of our time, as well as the abuses committed against women and children.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the draft legislative resolution and believe that it is important to have close and effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and EU level.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the recommendation on the Council's position with a view to adopting the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Union Agency for cooperation in the field of law enforcement and the replacement and repeal of relevant Council decisions is an important issue for the functioning of Europol and the policing framework in Europe. As I believe that the absolute strengthening of Europol and its authorisation of autonomous actions with regard to the use of citizens' personal data should not be done recklessly but always with respect for the rights and interests of Europeans, I have decided to vote in favour of rejecting the Council's position.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Progress is slowly being made in the fight against crime at international level, including with regard to the phenomenon of terrorism that has increasingly gripped our Europe recently. This report seeks to bring police and judicial activities closer together in the individual Member States in order to improve cooperation in combating a global problem. It also aims to harmonise data protection with the aim of ensuring effectiveness and coherence and avoiding unnecessary duplication and slowdown. I could therefore only speak in favour (technically, against rejection) of this important proposal because, in my opinion, it represents an effective improvement in the fight against crime and terrorism.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Creating a harmonised, high level of data protection covering police and judicial activities in the Union is crucial as a means of respecting and safeguarding the fundamental rights of Union citizens. Given the shared responsibilities of the Union and Member States in the area of freedom, security and justice, it is essential that there be close and effective cooperation among supervisory authorities at national and Union level.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The revision of the legal basis of the European Police Service had been negotiated for some years now. The guarantees requested at first by Parliament, in particular with regard to data protection, were fundamentally accepted by the Council, thus making it possible to approve them.  After the terrible events of Paris and Brussels, this new regulation became even more important. It is not now that crime - terrorism in particular - has no longer known borders. Conversely, the police remained national and, as has been sadly clear over the past 18 months, they have not cooperated or shared sufficient information. However, mutual trust will not arise by decree, but certainly that in this way better conditions are created for this. It should be highlighted, moreover, that the pragmatism printed on the proposal has enabled the support and support of the Member States, on whom internal security still depends essentially.  I am not one of those who consider the proposal to be perfect, but it is certainly reasonable, balanced and, above all, allows for a concrete advance in police cooperation at European level, so I support its adoption.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because, in order to combat terrorism and serious and organised crime, we need increased powers and effective and close cooperation between the supervisory authorities at Member State and Europol level. In addition to the pervasive threat of terrorism, serious crime and organised crime continue to increase in the European Union. I warmly welcome the strengthened role of the EP and the monitoring of Europol's activities by the Joint Parliamentary Control Committee.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP are against this report as we are principally against Europol and the extension of power of Europol. Even though this report does increase the potential to scrutinise Europol and hold the institution accountable we believe that the best way to increase safety is to remove Schengen and Europol, and instead have increased member state cooperation through institutions like INTERPOL.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to combat cross-border crimes and terrorist threats, responsible supervisory authorities, such as Europol, should be given the necessary expertise and resources. However, the fight against international terrorist crime must be balanced with the protection of personal data and the privacy of European citizens. Therefore, the European Data Protection Supervisor and national supervisory authorities should step up cooperation so as to ensure effectiveness and consistency in their work.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the compromise agreed by the European Parliament and the Council on 4 December 2015 must now be approved at second reading. The text deals with the regulation establishing the European Union Agency for the Cooperation and Training of Law Enforcement Authorities (Europol). Let us remember that Europol aims to improve the efficiency of the competent services of the Member States and their cooperation in areas such as the prevention and fight against terrorism, illicit drug trafficking, trafficking in human beings, illegal immigration networks, trafficking in human beings and money laundering of international criminal activities. In addition, the regulation will have to adapt Europol's external relations to the rules of the new Treaty. Europol must offer truly efficient support to states, especially in the fight against terrorism and crime. Given the importance of Europol's service, I believe that we need to have an aligned and dynamic system between the various Member States, which is why I am voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – We rejected the Council proposal on the new Regulation of EuroPol. We are against this agency being endowed with greater powers while maintaining significant opacity that leaves it completely out of public scrutiny. With this new regulation, the principle of subsidiarity disappears, leaving the agency responsible for all european policy issues, which would allow EuroPol to carry out its activities independently in addition to cross-border cooperation without cooperating with the security forces of the Member States. In addition, you will have the ability to collect and store data independently, which may conflict with the laws of different states regarding data protection.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that cooperation between national and European supervisory authorities is necessary to ensure the protection of the fundamental rights of EU citizens, including those of the protection of personal data, freedom and justice. I am convinced, in fact, that the protection of citizens' data must go hand in hand with careful sharing of information between the competent authorities, in order to intervene more effectively in the prevention of terrorist attacks and the fight against organised crime. The security of European citizens can only be guaranteed in the future through greater coordination and cooperation between the national police forces and Europol.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 After 3 years of negotiations, the European Parliament has finally reached an agreement with the Council on a new wording of the Regulation on Europol. Thanks to this regulation, the Effectiveness of the European Agency will be improved and it can take a tougher step against terrorism and organised crime.  Europol is an important agency of the Union which supports and promotes cooperation between national authorities. Thanks to the new regulation, Eurojust, another important agency of the Union in the field of terrorism and law enforcement, which is responsible for supporting and strengthening coordination and cooperation between national investigating authorities and public prosecutors, will also have access to data stored by Europol, so that the effectiveness of law enforcement will be greatly improved in the future. The recent terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels have shown that there are serious shortcomings in cooperation between Member States and that Europe's security is at stake. It is beyond dispute that we must ensure the protection of our citizens by all possible means. The new regulation, which I voted in favour of, is an important link in the complex solution.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This document creates a clear, extensive legal basis for Europol to enable it to address many of Europe's security challenges. The new draft regulation aims to bring the current Council Decision on Europol (Decision 2009/371/JHA) into alignment with the requirements of the Treaty of Lisbon by establishing a regulatory framework for Europol and by introducing a mechanism for the control of Europol's activities by the European Parliament and its national parliaments. The new Regulation will create a flexible and modern data management system for Europol and align Europol's management with the general guidelines applicable to agencies. As a result, Europol should become more effective in supporting Member States in the most effective fight against terrorism and other forms of serious crime. I fully agree with this proposal, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on an agreement between the European Parliament and the Council on new provisions to govern the European police agency, Europol. The agency aims to strengthen the fight against terrorism and cybercrime. The agreement strengthens Europol's mandate to ensure that the agency is able to combat the increase in cross-border offences and terrorist threats. Considering that the security of European citizens and the fight against terrorism require cooperation between national authorities and information exchange, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. By voting on this report, it is not so much a question of expanding Europol's powers as of strengthening the means at its disposal to complement the European arsenal in the fight against terrorism and organised crime. We need to ensure that this agency has the appropriate means to carry out its missions properly, including by allowing it to access the information it needs.  This agency has grown considerably in recent years. The European Counter-Terrorism Centre or the Internet Content Reporting Unit have their statutes clarified in this regulation. For example, it is claimed that Europol's Internet Content Reporting Unit could contact the companies of the Internet giants directly to ask them to remove content used by terrorists to recruit European citizens.  These are measures that I supported in my report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. The adoption of this text today is an important step forward in the fight against terrorism and a victory for our political group.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The strengthening of Europol's powers in European police cooperation will help to increase the effectiveness of the fight against terrorism in Europe. The European Police Office will now be able to set up specialist counter-terrorism units. It will be able to contact content providers directly on the internet, so as to react much more quickly to digital terrorist propaganda and to have any content deemed objectionable removed. This is a step in the right direction as part of a more comprehensive European strategy to deal with the terrorist threat.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In particular, it is timely to strengthen and endow the European Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation and Training (Europol) with all necessary means to take appropriate action in the fight against terrorism and in the prevention and combating of international organised crime. I therefore voted in favour of the report on Europol today. The Fidesz People's Party Delegation supports the Agency's strengthened mandate to effectively coordinate and strengthen the cooperation of national authorities in the prevention of organised crime and the fight against terrorism. We welcome this text, as we have managed to strike the right balance with the protection of personal data without compromising or hindering the success of investigations.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the new regulation to strengthen the mandate of Europol (the European Union Agency for the Cooperation of Law Enforcement) so that the agency is truly able to combat the increase in cross-border offences and terrorist threats.  Given the transnational nature of the threats facing Europe, particularly since the recent terrorist attacks in France and Belgium, it has become essential to strengthen cooperation between Member States, and contacts between law enforcement operational staff in Europe.  With this new regulation, Europol will be able to more easily create specialized units in order to respond immediately to emerging threats. The Agency will also be able to withdraw terrorist propaganda online more quickly because, from now on, Europol's Internet content reporting unit will be able to contact a social network service provider, such as Facebook, directly to request that it remove a web page run by the Islamic State. Finally, this future regulation provides that the activities of EUROPOL are subject to the democratic control of the European Parliament and national parliaments, which I have been arguing for a long time.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion to reject this text, which strengthens the European Union's agency for the cooperation of law enforcement agencies (Europol). The Council's position is to enable Europol to carry out future missions to report content on the internet and provides that the agency will now be able to receive personal data directly from private parties, following transfers, but with strict restrictions on the processing of data concerning particular categories of people. I remain in favour of cooperation between the police services of the Member States in the fight against terrorism and serious cross-border crime, but refuse to provide a European federal police force.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Diaz de Meera's report because I believe that the proposed regulation gives Europol a clear and deployed legal basis, expanding its competences and effectively enabling it to fight and deal more effectively with the challenges we face today.  I also support the proposal in the new regulation, which introduces a mechanism that provides for Europol to be subject to scrutiny by the European Parliament, together with national parliaments.   I believe that Europol needs to become more effective in supporting Member States in combating terrorism and tackling all forms of organised and serious crime.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Council proposal has many aspects that reduce efficiency and effectiveness and effectively limit EUROPOL's accountability in practice. Points of friction in the proposal are: 1. The proposal to merge EUROPOL and CEPOL. 2. The possibility for the online content reference unit to transmit publicly available personal data to private entities. 3. Governance provisions that deviate from the common approach for decentralised agencies. 4. EUROJUST shall have only indirect access to information stored by EUROPOL.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 In particular, it is timely to strengthen and empower the European Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation and Training (Europol) by all necessary means to take appropriate action in the fight against terrorism and in the prevention and combating of international organised crime. I therefore voted in favour of the report on Europol today. As a member of the Fidesz People's Party Delegation, I support the Agency's strengthened mandate to effectively coordinate and strengthen the cooperation of national authorities in the prevention of organised crime and the fight against terrorism. I welcome this text and therefore voted in favour, as we have managed to strike the right balance with regard to the protection of personal data without compromising or hindering the success of investigations.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Regulation determines the structure, functioning, area of action and functions of the EU agency for police cooperation. The aim is to improve Europol's governance and increase its effectiveness in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. Europol could more easily set up specialised units and centres to respond to terrorist threats and other forms of serious crime. The Regulation, already agreed between the European Parliament and national governments, reinforces the need for Member States to provide information to Europol and establishes a new framework for the processing of personal data.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. We are in favour of cooperation between Member States' police services in the fight against terrorism and serious cross-border crime, but we are wary of the gradual development of a kind of European federal police.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Joint Declaration of the Council and the European Parliament on Article 44 of this report seeks to deepen Europol's powers to "create a high harmonised level of data protection covering police and judicial activities in the Union as a means of respecting and safeguarding the fundamental rights of Union citizens", as read in the document. This proposal is a new step in which, on several occasions, we have already expressed our disagreement by extending the scope of Europol's powers, overriding them with the sovereignty of states and their competent authorities. By the objectives that we believe that Europol pursues – and which limit individual freedoms and guarantees – we voted against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the reform in question by the EU Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation. In the light of recent terrorist attacks, it is important that EUROPOL is able to respond more quickly and actively to terrorist threats. The safety of European citizens must come first. It is important that we start to control more intensively the internet threats that can lead to real crimes. It is important to improve cooperation between member countries and for EUROPOL investigators to be able to investigate across borders, for which they must be provided with adequate financial and material resources. This legislation does not in any way jeopardise the civil liberties of citizens of the Member States of the European Union. EUROPOL will be under the democratic control of the European Parliament and national parliaments.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Council proposal has many aspects that reduce efficiency and effectiveness and effectively limit EUROPOL's accountability in practice. Points of friction in the proposal are: 1. The proposal to merge EUROPOL and CEPOL. 2. The possibility for the online content reference unit to transmit publicly available personal data to private entities. 3. Governance provisions shall deviate from the common approach for decentralised agencies. 4. EUROJUST shall have only indirect access to information stored by EUROPOL. For the above reasons I am voting in favour of report A8-0164/2016.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Europol structure needed reforming, including its overall functioning, governance, supervision, data protection regime and its relations with third countries and international organisations. This so-called Lisbonisation process of Europol represents an important step for greater efficiency in EU-level cooperation of law-enforcement authorities. It also guarantees stronger oversight and a clearer data protection regime. I strongly support the call to push for a strong oversight and data protection regime and to streamline the Agency activities so it would contribute to a greater EU-level cooperation of law-enforcement authorities.
