A harmonised, high level of data protection covering police and judicial activities in the Union is crucial as a means of respecting and safeguarding the fundamental rights of Union citizens.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it provides for strengthening Europol's mandate and significantly improving the agency's levers to counter increasing cross-border crime and terrorist threat. I highly appreciate the fact that the new rules will allow Europol to respond more quickly and effectively to new security threats. For example, the agency will be able to exchange information directly with private entities such as companies or NGOs to quickly remove terrorist propaganda online. I welcome the agreement reached, as it will also help to avoid gaps in the information needed to ensure the security of European citizens. To this end, the new rules oblige EU Member States to provide Europol with the information the Agency needs to carry out the tasks assigned to it. At the same time, guarantees of enhanced data protection and parliamentary scrutiny are provided to go hand in hand with Europol's new powers. I consider it extremely democratic for europol's work to be monitored by the Joint Parliamentary Scrutiny Group composed of members of national parliaments and the European Parliament. There is also a clear procedure for citizens' complaints under EU law.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 In particular, it is timely to strengthen and empower the European Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation and Training (Europol) by all necessary means to take appropriate action in the fight against terrorism and in the prevention and combating of international organised crime. I therefore voted in favour of the report on Europol today. The Fidesz People's Party Delegation supports the Agency's strengthened mandate to effectively coordinate and strengthen the cooperation of national authorities in the prevention of organised crime and the fight against terrorism. We welcome this text, as we have managed to strike the right balance with the protection of personal data without compromising or hindering the success of investigations.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The fundamental rights of EU citizens can be adequately respected and protected by ensuring a high level of data protection cooperation within the Union, including police and judicial activities. Europol and other bodies play an important role as a result of rising terrorism and the migration crisis. Effective cooperation between supervisory authorities is vital as the Union and the Member States have shared competence in this area. I am convinced that linking Europol's knowledge of operational police cooperation with CEPOL's training and education expertise would strengthen links between the two areas and create synergies. This avoids unnecessary doubling of the support responsibilities of the two agencies and would result in the transfer of their savings. This is particularly important in the current economic situation. In agreement with the reporter Díaz de Mera García Consuegra, I voted in favour of the regulation establishing a European Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation and Training.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation with the firm conviction that further progress on common security and cooperation is essential. It is essential for member states' security forces to establish a common and harmonised system for the protection of dice, both to avoid cracks that harm citizens and to have a more efficient system in the face of potential threats. However, I believe it is necessary that good cooperation and cooperation should include the participation of all European police bodies, including those in the sub-state sphere.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report so that the European police agency Europol can intensify its efforts in the fight against terrorism and cybercrime, as well as respond faster to threats thanks to the new rules of operation adopted by Parliament. The new powers are accompanied by strict safeguards on data protection and democratic control tools.  The draft legislation, agreed by Parliament and Council negotiators in November 2015, strengthens Europol's powers to ensure that it has the necessary instruments in the face of the threat of cross-border crime and terrorism. Among other developments, the agency will have more facilities to create specialized units to respond to imminent threats.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the European police agency Europol will be able to intensify its efforts in the fight against terrorism and cybercrime and respond faster to threats thanks to the new rules of operation than the Parliament we have adopted. The new powers are accompanied by strict safeguards on data protection and democratic control tools.  The draft legislation, agreed by Parliament and Council negotiators in November 2015, strengthens Europol's powers to ensure that it has the necessary instruments in the face of the threat of cross-border crime and terrorism. Among other developments, the Agency will have more facilities to create specialized units to respond to imminent threats.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The threats arising from different forms of organised crime, such as, unfortunately, recently, those linked to terrorist attacks, show us how inevitable and urgent it is for the EU to invest more in security, strengthening the dynamics of cooperation between European and national supervisory authorities. That is why I fully agree with the proposal made in the recommendation on the EU Agency for Police Cooperation and Training, considering it essential, even more so today, to extend powers and instruments for Europol, in order to enable the Agency to become more efficient both in terms of supervision and control in the dynamics of cooperation with national police authorities. , as well as guarantees with regard to data protection and citizens' security.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) and, consequently, I voted against the amendment rejecting the proposal, because I consider it very important that Parliament supports the strengthening of Europol's mandate, given the current circumstances. The need to strengthen cooperation between national authorities in the fight against terrorism and organised crime is an absolutely essential necessity, as demonstrated by the attacks in Paris and Brussels and also by the recent police operations carried out in several Member States. I therefore wholeheartedly support the 'Lisbonisation' of Europol, with strengthened powers, more powers and a broader mandate. A broader mandate, however, means greater need for control, and I am therefore very much in favour of the introduction of parliamentary scrutiny and the establishment of a joint control group between the European Parliament and the national parliaments, which can convene representatives of the agency and the Commission. Finally, I believe that the provisions for the protection of personal data are important, given the amount of sensitive information available to the agency.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I ended up voting against the report on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). I welcome the strengthening of Europol and the creation of a genuine legal basis in the form of an agency. However, I believe that the idea of developing Europpol into a kind of European secret service is wrong and dangerous. Exchange of data - yes. But competence must remain with the member states.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I consider an extension of Europol's powers to be a long overdue and important step in view of the current developments in terrorism, cybercrime and other crimes in Europe. I consider the establishment of specialised units and the improvement of the exchange of information to be particularly important in relation to terrorism. I also support rules for the European Anti-Terrorism Centre and the extension of cooperation with NGOs and Facebook. We must do everything we can to protect the population from further attacks and to transfer those responsible.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal, which provides legal certainty for Europol activities and to contribute to further EU-level cooperation of law-enforcement authorities. The Regulation provides extensive rules and provisions for the processing of information by Europol and has been aligned with the recently adopted Data Protection Directive. It will also establish a specialised Joint Parliamentary Scrutiny Group to monitor Europol’s activities, including any potential impact on fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. During the passage of the European Commission's proposal on the European Police Office (EUROPOL) by the LIBE committee, a problematic text was improved thanks to the amendments of the left-wing groups. For example, through more stringent data protection, in line with the directive recently adopted in LIBE, a broader parliamentary control mechanism or a better definition of EUROPOL's limits of action. However, in its passage through the trilogue, the text has returned to swampy ground as it alters EUROPOL's original purpose of helping national police and judicial authorities combat international crime and terrorism by extending its scope of action to the point of compromising the principle of subsidiarity. The lack of a precise definition of the scope of action, the reduction of parliamentary control, the ability of the Internet Content Notification Unit to exchange data directly with individuals without the participation of Member States, inter alia, seriously calls into question a text which must regulate an agency whose action decisively affects civil liberties. That is why we voted in favour of rejecting the Council's position.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the new regulation for Europol. I believe that European citizens need a better legal framework for the fight against terrorism and their safety. The new regulation improves cross-border cooperation and anti-crime actions. It is important that this act emphasizes national parliaments and the European Parliament because it is the equivalent of an increase in democracy. Another positive aspect is that the new regulation also provides for data protection, but attention must be paid to the protection of personal data not to go so far as to affect security.  Improving Europol's governance will increase the safety of European citizens. The exchange of information between Member States must work and must no longer be the Achilles heel. We must avoid that after a terrorist act we consider the failure of the exchange of information to be guilty. People's lives are the most important thing and we must not discount anything that supports the safety of citizens.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In writing. Europol, which is celebrating its 17th anniversary this year, really needs more instruments and resources to enable it to improve cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and EU level. In 17 years, criminal groups and organisations have certainly developed their networks to the point where it is imperative that we consider their repression through a European or even a comprehensive approach.  Strengthening the agency's responsiveness by setting up specialized units, encouraging states to conduct cross-border investigations, monitoring and assessing the level of cooperation on terrorism and organised crime between Member States are all necessary measures to strengthen the fight against organised crime.  I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this regulation, but I deeply regret that this reform stopped halfway. I believe that we have missed the opportunity to create a 'European FBI', that is, a genuine European judicial police and internal intelligence service with a real capacity for criminal investigation and a real initiative in this area.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this proposal as it will provide the legal certainty for Europol’s activities which is essential for further EU-level cooperation of law-enforcement authorities. The regulation provides extensive rules and provisions for the processing of information by Europol and has been aligned with the recently—adopted Data Protection Directive. It will also establish a specialised Joint-Parliamentary Scrutiny Group to monitor Europol’s activities, including any potential impact on fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. On Wednesday 11 May, I voted in favour of the Diaz de Mera report to strengthen Europol's powers to better protect this police cooperation agency to combat terrorism, cybercrime and other forms of crime. This will allow it to quickly train specialized units to respond to emergencies, such as a terrorist threat.  Specifically, the agency will be able to exchange information directly with private entities such as companies or NGOs, in order to react more quickly. For example, Europol's Internet Content Reporting Unit will now be able to contact a social network service provider, such as Facebook, directly to request that it remove a web page run by the Islamic State (IS) in order to prevent the spread of terrorist propaganda more quickly. Member States will also be required to provide Europol with the necessary and sufficient information to ensure that the agency can do its job properly.  I welcome these new measures, which represent a powerful legislative tool to strengthen the security of European citizens. The regulation will come into force on the 20th day after its publication in the EU Official Journal and will be in force from 1 May 2017.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the European police agency Europol will be able to intensify its efforts in the fight against terrorism and cybercrime and respond faster to threats thanks to the new rules of operation than the Parliament we have adopted. The new powers are accompanied by strict safeguards on data protection and democratic control tools.  The draft legislation, agreed by Parliament and Council negotiators in November 2015, strengthens Europol's powers to ensure that it has the necessary instruments in the face of the threat of cross-border crime and terrorism. Among other developments, the Agency will have more facilities to create specialized units to respond to imminent threats.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. After three years of work and despite the reluctance of Member States to move towards more integration in police cooperation, I welcome the adoption, at second reading, of the Europol Regulation. Indeed, in the face of borderless threats, the European Union, through the Europol Agency, has an essential role to play.  This new regulation, which strengthens the Agency's competence and clarifies its functioning, will promote better cooperation between Member States and their police services at European level and increased information exchange. In the face of increasing crime, and in order to fight terrorism more effectively, the Socialists and Democrats have always defended a coordinated European response. My group played an important role in achieving this balanced agreement.  In particular, we have secured joint investigation teams, the establishment of national Europol units and the appointment of liaison officers. The Agency's new powers will be accompanied by strong data protection safeguards and tools to ensure democratic parliamentary oversight; this was one of the strong demands of the European Parliament. These are important advances and these are the reasons why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. Given the shared responsibilities of the Union and Member States in the area of freedom, security and justice, it is essential that there be close and effective cooperation among supervisory authorities at national and Union level which this regulation did not manage to cover.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the European police agency Europol will be able to intensify its efforts in the fight against terrorism and cybercrime and respond faster to threats thanks to the new rules of operation than the Parliament we have adopted. The new powers are accompanied by strict safeguards on data protection and democratic control tools.  The draft legislation, agreed by Parliament and Council negotiators in November 2015, strengthens Europol's powers to ensure that it has the necessary instruments in the face of the threat of cross-border crime and terrorism. Among other developments, the Agency will have more facilities to create specialized units to respond to imminent threats.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 In particular, it is timely to strengthen and endow the European Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation and Training (Europol) with all necessary means to take appropriate action in the fight against terrorism and in the prevention and combating of international organised crime.  The Fidesz people's party delegation supports the agency's strengthened mandate, which can effectively coordinate and strengthen the cooperation of national authorities in the prevention of organised crime and the fight against terrorism. We welcome this text, which has helped to strike the right balance with the protection of personal data without compromising or hindering the success of investigations.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) and replacing and repealing Council Decisions 2009/371/JHA, 2009/934/JHA, 2009/935/JHA, 2009/936/JHA and 2009/968/JHA. I believe that it is essential to create a harmonised, high level of data protection covering police and judicial activities in the Union as a means of respecting and safeguarding the fundamental rights of Union citizens. Such a regulation would ensure effectiveness and consistency in relation to the privacy rights of citizens, while simultaneously providing a high standard in judicial and policing affairs. Given that Ireland has an opt-out under Protocol 21 on Justice and Home Affairs, it is therefore up to the Irish government to choose if they participate or not. It is my understanding that the Irish government will participate.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The report calls for the existing Council decision of 2009, which established Europol as a regular EU agency based in The Hague, to be brought into line with the requirements of the Lisbon Treaty. This means that the legal framework for Europol will be improved in the form of an EU regulation. It also establishes the possibility of control on the part of the European Parliament and the national parliaments. It also takes into account data protection requirements and defines Europol's scope for intervention. The aim is to turn Europol into a more effective authority to support EU Member States in the fight against terrorism and other forms of organised or serious crime.  As the highest priority must be given to safeguarding internal security, I agree with this report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I am pleased that the Europol agency is finally equipped with the powers and structures necessary to carry out the tasks entrusted to it. With the increasing number of threats, including terrorism, organised crime, migrant trafficking and cybercrime, the agency's resources had to be strengthened and its mandate adapted to current circumstances. It is now done. Europol can now strengthen structures such as the internet referencing unit that tracks all sites promoting terrorism and the European counter-terrorism centre created last January. The agency can also exchange information directly with private interlocutors such as companies (Google, Twitter..) and NGOs while remaining concerned with ensuring the protection of personal data.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for high level data protection concerning police and judicial institutions in the Union which will lead to securing the fundamental rights of the Union’s citizen. This will also enhance the efficiency of EU-level law-enforcement agencies.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against amendments by the EFDD and Greens group to the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting parliament's and council's regulation on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) and on replacing and repealing council decisions 2009/371/PUP, 2009/934/PUP, 2009/935/PUP, 2009/936/PUP and 2099/968/PUP because I consider law enforcement cooperation to be essential to raise the level of security in the Union. Europol's new mandate must ensure a European approach in the fight against terrorism and transnational crime, and therefore strengthened cooperation at EU level is essential. Therefore, I do not support the amendments of the EFDD and Green group.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution continues to welcome the principle of thematic concentration and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which run counter to the interests of France and the poorest communities. It is for this reason that I objected to this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Diane James MEP and her fellow colleagues are against this report as we are principally against Europol and the extension of power of Europol. Even though this report does increase the potential to scrutinise Europol and hold the institution accountable we believe that the best way to increase safety is to remove Schengen and Europol, and instead have increased member state cooperation through institutions like INTERPOL.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Together with my colleagues from the ALDE Group, I welcomed the adoption of new legislation on Europol. I believe that, given the growing security threats in Europe, strengthening the mandate of this agency is a necessity. Indeed, EU Member States should strictly respect the commitment to cooperate with Europol and share information with each other, because only together can European states effectively fight terrorism. Of course, measures to protect personal data and oversee the Agency's actions by a joint group of representatives of the European Parliament and national parliaments are an important balance of europol's stronger mandate.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. The proposed regulation aims to increase the efficiency and accountability of Europol. The agency thus established will strengthen the actions and cooperation of Member States in order to better address the common challenges in terrorism and all forms of crime. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The present vote is a recommendation for second reading, in which two amendments will be put to the vote. I agree with the first amendment, which rejects the Council's position. I reject the second amendment calling for the creation of an Internet reporting centre to counter terrorism and extremism on the Internet.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the plenary session of the European Parliament, I supported the Council's position on the agreement reached by the European Parliament and the Council on a regulation that increases Europol's powers to fight terrorism. Security issues have become particularly topical in the European Union and, consequently, the need to increase the powers and rights of the EU security authorities in their work in the fight against terrorism and the security of EU citizens is also emphasised. This bill increases Europol's powers and ensures that data protection rules are strengthened by also involving European data protection supervisors in the transmission of data, who will have the power to control Europol's conduct on personal data. This report includes a provision that Member States will be obliged to provide Europol with the information it needs, but Europol will also have to report annually to the EU institutions on the information it has received. I supported this report because I believe that security for EU citizens needs to be improved and that the work of the EU institutions needs to be improved by providing them with clear rules and transparent powers.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – I voted in favour on the regulation on Europol. The interconnectedness of cross-border crimes, such as terrorism, organised crime, especially human trafficking and cyber crime/cyber threats, require a strong mandate for Europol. I welcome the fact that judicial cooperation between Europol and Eurojust, processing information from private parties will be enabled and better cooperation with Member States, with other EU bodies in general, and under special circumstances cooperation with private parties and third countries is made possible. Preventing crime and terrorism is only possible if different bodies and levels interact with each other. The new data protection package will provide for necessary guarantees to prevent data breaches. I especially welcome creating a new body within Europol – the Internet Referral Unit (IRU) to combat terrorist propaganda and violent extremism online. Most importantly, these changes need to be accompanied by adequate budgetary adjustments to meet the real needs to carry out the extensive tasks Europol is assigned to, that should also lead to increased number of staff. Finally, high level commitment and engagement by Member States in ensuring rapid response and information transfer and full operational cooperation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I support this proposal to provide legal certainty for Europol activities and to contribute to further EU-level cooperation of law-enforcement authorities. The Regulation provides extensive rules and provisions for the processing of information by Europol and has been aligned with the recently adopted Data Protection Directive. It will also establish a specialised Joint Parliamentary Scrutiny Group to monitor Europol’s activities, including any potential impact on fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The report calls for the existing Council decision of 2009, which established Europol as a regular EU agency based in The Hague, to be brought into line with the requirements of the Lisbon Treaty. This means that the legal framework for Europol will be improved in the form of an EU regulation. It also establishes the possibility of control on the part of the European Parliament and the national parliaments. It also takes into account data protection requirements and defines Europol's scope for intervention. The aim is to turn Europol into a more effective authority to support EU Member States in the fight against terrorism and other forms of organised or serious crime.  As the highest priority must be given to safeguarding internal security, I agree with this report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 For the European Parliament's legislative resolution of 11 May 2016 on the Council's position at first reading on the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol), I voted in favour of an amendment to reject the Council's position by the European Parliament. I had a similar problem here as with the legislative proposal on the use of passenger name record (EU PNR) data. I believe that we are putting too much emphasis on monitoring our citizens and getting as much information as possible about them. We often have more than enough information, but we are lagging far behind in their analysis. I did not want Europol (or one of its bodies – the IRU) to be able to identify illegal content and thus determine what you read in newspapers and on social networks. All without judicial or national control. It is indeed desirable that The Member States and their security authorities cooperate as much as possible, but it is not possible for Member States to be circumvented by becoming an untouchable body that collects information on innocent people and inbids private entities what information is to be provided to it.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 In particular, it is timely to strengthen and endow the European Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation and Training (Europol) with all necessary means to take appropriate action in the fight against terrorism and in the prevention and combating of international organised crime. I therefore voted in favour of the report on Europol today.  The Fidesz people's party delegation supports the Agency's strengthened mandate to effectively coordinate and strengthen the cooperation of national authorities in the prevention of organised crime and the fight against terrorism. We welcome this text, as we have managed to strike the right balance with the protection of personal data without compromising or hindering the success of investigations.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Who would not support any effort to combat terrorism, but let us also think about what led to the current situation, how EU citizens were allowed to take part in acts of war and then return to Europe to carry out terrorist acts. A balance must also be struck when checking content on the Internet, because it is not possible to build an Orwellian system at the expense of decent citizens of the EU, rather than the competent authorities doing their job on time. The subject is very important and further consultations are still needed within a short timeframes.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote gives strong evidence of its commitment to combating terrorism, cybercrime and other serious crimes. The text adopted strengthens the mandate of the European police agency Europol by making it able to respond even more quickly to threats operating across our borders.  We have given the agency new governance rules and given it new responsibilities so that it can provide more comprehensive support to member states' law enforcement authorities. Thanks to the changes made, Europol will now be able to support Member States' actions to prevent and combat forms of crime promoted or committed via the Internet, including the reporting to interested online service providers of the Internet content by which such forms of crime are facilitated.  The new powers conferred on Europol will not be at the expense of the data protection of European citizens. The European Data Protection Supervisor will monitor the agency's work and a joint parliamentary monitoring group will oversee its work.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I believe it is necessary to provide for the creation of a high level of data protection with regard to both judicial activities and police activities in the EU, in order to ensure and ensure respect for and safeguarding citizens' fundamental rights. The EP and the Council consider that close and effective cooperation between the various supervisory authorities, both at national and Union level, is essential in order to guarantee this process of protection. In difficult times such as those we are experiencing, action against the threat of terrorism must be at the heart of our political action. And in this context, the sharing of information between Member States and the consequent possible identification of 'foreign fighters', are fundamental tools in the fight against terrorism. I am therefore voting in favour of the new rules on Europol, in order to give concrete answers to the terrorist threat.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the EFDD group's motion to reject the European Union Agency for the Cooperation of Law Enforcement (Europol), because I oppose the progressive and surreptitious development of some kind of European federal police. Member States must of course cooperate in the fight against terrorism and major cross-border crime, but this can be done perfectly without Europol.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: in writing. ‒ A harmonised high level of data protection remains crucial in the times of massive development of advanced technology. EU citizens and in particular their fundamental rights need to be provided with appropriate safeguards. Therefore, the soon to be created European Data Protection Board is another necessary step towards improving these safeguards. The work on this subject should however not be stopped and sustainable and gradual development of safety measures could come up regularly on the Commission agenda.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted FOR the rejection proposal in the form of an amendment, which rejects the words made by the text. It plans to strengthen cooperation between the police services of the Member States in order to combat terrorism, but it takes the opportunity to increase the prerogatives of Europol (European Union Agency for the Cooperation of Law Enforcement). The very existence of this agency is questionable, because by its very nature it infringes on the sovereignty of states.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the European police agency Europol will be able to intensify its efforts in the fight against terrorism and cybercrime and respond faster to threats thanks to the new rules of operation than the Parliament we have adopted. The new powers are accompanied by strict safeguards on data protection and democratic control tools.  The draft legislation, agreed by Parliament and Council negotiators in November 2015, strengthens Europol's powers to ensure that it has the necessary instruments in the face of the threat of cross-border crime and terrorism. Among other developments, the Agency will have more facilities to create specialized units to respond to imminent threats.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the European police agency Europol will be able to intensify its efforts in the fight against terrorism and cybercrime and respond faster to threats thanks to the new rules of operation than the Parliament we have adopted. The new powers are accompanied by strict safeguards on data protection and democratic control tools.  The draft legislation, agreed by Parliament and Council negotiators in November 2015, strengthens Europol's powers to ensure that it has the necessary instruments in the face of the threat of cross-border crime and terrorism. Among other developments, the Agency will have more facilities to create specialized units to respond to imminent threats.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. We rejected the Council's proposal for the new Regulation of EuroPol. We are against this agency being endowed with greater powers while maintaining significant opacity that leaves it completely out of public scrutiny. With this new regulation, the principle of subsidiarity disappears, leaving the agency responsible for all european policy issues, which would allow EuroPol to carry out its activities independently in addition to cross-border cooperation without cooperating with the security forces of the Member States. In addition, you will have the ability to collect and store data independently, which may conflict with the laws of different states regarding data protection.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This report, the result of several years of hard work, aims to intensify the provision of Member States' information to Europol so that Europol can provide broad support to the coercive services of the Member States.  That is why it is given greater responsibilities such as the creation of a new department that will be responsible for supporting and coordinating the training of actors with coercive functions at the strategic level.  In addition, this report also establishes a robust data protection regime, introducing joint monitoring elements of the data transferred to Europol. Similarly, Europol takes responsibility for periodically re-examining the need to retain personal data.  Finally, it is also intended to introduce a mechanism for monitoring Europol's activities by the European Parliament and national parliaments to ensure democratic legitimacy.  In my view, the adoption of this report is crucial as it will serve to adapt Europol to the requirements of the Lisbon Treaty, as well as ensuring greater protection of data that will help prevent crime.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The report calls for the existing Council decision of 2009, which established Europol as a regular EU agency based in The Hague, to be brought into line with the requirements of the Lisbon Treaty. This means that the legal framework for Europol will be improved in the form of an EU regulation. It also establishes the possibility of control on the part of the European Parliament and the national parliaments. It also takes into account data protection requirements and defines Europol's scope for intervention. The aim is to turn Europol into a more effective authority to support EU Member States in the fight against terrorism and other forms of organised or serious crime.  As the highest priority must be given to safeguarding internal security, I agree with this report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my own proposal to reject the regulation on the creation of a new Europol. As Members, we did not have the opportunity to table amendments, and if I did not table a motion to reject it, it would become a regulation in force without a vote. The commission's original proposal to merge Europol with cepol police academy became something completely different. The original intergovernmental service organisation of the national police forces is abolished and is created under the same name Europol as the police agency subordinate to the European Union. It will collect a huge amount of data, account numbers, addresses, names and other data not only from national police, but also client data directly from private entities, e.g. airlines. Europol will be able to transmit them to third States and international organisations on the basis of a Commission decision. It will even be able to pass the data on to private companies. Europol will become a dangerous Big Brother who will know all about us. A poor cover is the supervision of the European Data Protection Supervisor. The Management Board, where there will be representatives of the Member States, has only limited supervisory powers and the only thing that the rapporteurs say is important is that there should be a balanced number of men and women. It's not about fighting the terrorism that everyone is now fighting. We have the police and Interpol to fight crime. It's about setting up a dangerous Big Brother, and I'm afraid of misuse and leaks of such a huge amount of data.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Achieving a high level of personal data protection covering judicial and police activities in the European Union is of utmost importance and serves as a key indicator of respect and protection of the fundamental rights of all Citizens of the Union. Given that there is a shared responsibility between Member States and the Union in ensuring justice, security and freedom, close and effective cooperation between supervisors at national and supranational level is very important. Cooperation within the EU is achieved through Europol, the main agency whose role is clear law enforcement, as well as contributing to greater security and other accompanying agencies specializing in consolidating legislation and enforcing justice. I consider Europol's role to be crucial in the area of data protection, ensuring justice and strengthening security within the Union's borders. For this reason, I did not support the proposal to reject the Council's position on the adoption of a regulation on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol).

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 There is a general feeling that the European Union needs measures to ensure the security of its citizens. Strengthening Europol's mandate is a step in this direction. The texts adopted increase the capacity of the agency to counter terrorism and serious organised crime.  The Regulation also improves Europol's accountability to the European Parliament and the parliaments of the Member States and lays down clear rules for the exchange of information between services and measures to protect personal data. The new legal framework will allow Europol to respond more quickly to modern threats, with tools to remove terrorist propaganda online as an example.  We are seeing a new momentum in European integration for ever closer and more effective cooperation in the field of policing. I do not hide my support for the establishment of strong European institutions in the so-called security and justice of the European Union.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Serious and organised cross-border crime, crime and terrorism have increased substantially over the last decade, affecting and impairing the life, security and freedom of the union's population, harming their property, the economy and the economy of the whole Community. This situation requires the active strengthening of Europol's powers. The mutual exchange of information with Member States' authorities to combat crime and terrorism, coordination of activities, improving the management and strengthening of training of law enforcement officers will help prevent cross-border crime more effectively. In order to increase the protection of personal data, Europol is strictly and precisely defined the data it may disclose. Competences are allocated between Europol and member states' law enforcement authorities. The merger of CEPOL and Europol will increase efficiency while achieving savings of EUR 17.2 million in the period 2015-2020.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. The increase in serious and organised crime in the European Union calls for a strengthening of the Europol agency, a body with a key role in cooperating between Member States and their police services at European level.  The regulation passed today aims to establish a legal framework necessary for the creation of a "new Europol" whose powers will be strengthened and governance improved. This regulation, which has been the subject of lengthy negotiations, preserves the right balance between facilitating exchanges between national police services and sufficient guarantees for our personal data.  I am voting in favour of this regulation, which strengthens Europol's competences, thus enabling joint work between member states, which is necessary for the construction of a genuine European area of freedom, security and justice.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading on the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Union Agency for Cooperation in Law Enforcement (Europol) and the replacement and repeal of Decisions 2009/371/JHA, 2009/934/JHA, 2009/935/JHA, 2009/936/JHA and 2009/968/JHA of the Council, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/5/2016 and because this Recommendation is not comprehensive and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. This Council text reforms the governance and responsibilities of Europol. In terms of governance, the text establishes a monitoring group established by national parliaments and parliamentarians of the competent committee of the European Parliament. Nevertheless, the powers of the European Parliament remain tightly limited. This is evidenced by the method of appointing the Executive Director of Europol: by the Council from a nominative list drawn up by the Member States. His appointment is subject only to an advisory opinion of the European Parliament. When it comes to internet surveillance and the processing of personal data, this text formalises and clarifies Europol's competences. It can now receive and transfer personal data from private individuals. It can also conduct analyses based on ongoing investigations under the "integrated data management" system. However, Europol is subject to the control of a data protection delegate and, outside, the European Data Protection Supervisor. The processing of certain categories of data is also strictly regulated.  The fight against organised crime is a priority. However, we do not condone the extensive powers granted to this quasi-federal police force.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ The negative voting was taken in consequence of a common decision of the Italian delegation of the PPE.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we discussed the proposal for a revision of the Regulation concerning Europol. The proposal foresees an increase in powers for Europol, and in particular the establishment of a special specialised unit within europol to monitor and monitor the content of social networks. The rationale is the fight against terrorism. Since I am afraid that this is the first step towards the complete freedom of the Internet, this idea does not exactly excite me. Furthermore, the supervisory powers of national parliaments and the European Parliament are formulated highly vaguely, rather they are a kind of cosmetic adjustments. I have always supported the establishment of Europol and I understand its importance in exchanging information and experience of police forces across the EU, but I cannot agree with the proposed changes, which is why I voted against it in the final vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Europol's new regulation will provide a solid legal basis, along with increased powers to support national authorities. In addition, the new text includes the new legal basis for the web monitoring unit. This unit, launched in July last year, will have the fundamental task of reporting to national authorities suspicious web content related to terrorist activities and radicalization on the network. Europol is a key element in the European Union's strategy to combat terrorism and cross-border crime. The agency will, in the near future, have to support the national authorities in their daily fight against crime. In addition, Europol actively supports Member States in the management of illegal immigration and in the fight against human traffickers. His contribution translates into European personnel who support national authorities on the ground, especially in hot spots in Italy and Greece. Europol is one of the best responses that the European Union is giving in ensuring greater security for our citizens.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. My firm support for the report by my colleague Agustín Díaz de Mera for the final adoption of the new Europol Regulation, which will enable the European police agency to have more means and powers to combat terrorism, organised crime and other serious criminal activities. This is an important step forward for Europol, which will be able to better combat the different types of crime and advance the treatment of information to ensure more effective work in this area.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The permanence of the terrorist threat, symbolized by the attacks in Paris and Brussels, highlights the urgent need for better information sharing and cooperation in police and judicial matters. Indeed, terrorism and organized crime are challenges that, by their very nature, transcend borders. For this reason, the European Agency for the Cooperation of Law Enforcement (Europol) deserved to see its powers strengthened and its governance improved.  I fully support the objective of systematizing member states' participation in the Europol Agency when faced with transnational crimes, through the establishment of joint investigative teams or the appointment of liaison officers. In view of the legitimate debates that accompanied the debate around the Vote of the Passengers Name Record (PNR), it was also necessary that the mechanisms for sharing information be fully compatible with the new data protection rules. The challenge of this new regulation from now on will be to enable Member States to achieve such a level of confidence that it will encourage information sharing and joint work. Because they will not be able to hide their own flaws indefinitely, States must stop blaming each other and seize this new opportunity for cooperation.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to give new powers to Europol to facilitate the establishment of specialised units to help respond more quickly to emerging threats. I also support the newly proposed provisions to allow Europol to exchange information with private companies in certain cases – e.g. in the case of private companies. ask Facebook to remove isis-controlled pages and accounts. I believe that this will make a significant contribution to preventing, preventing criminal activity and will contribute more effectively to public safety.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This regulation aims to definitively communitize Europol, the European office for collaboration between criminal police, i.e. to give it more autonomy of operation vis-à-vis states. Although (for the time being) without its own means of coercion, it acquires new key skills such as training national police units. Under the pretext of fighting terrorism, he will have more access to personal data, notably by collaborating with the FBI or private parties such as Facebook.  The Luxembourg President of the Council of the European Union announced the final objective: "we must work on the interoperability of the various tools", i.e. the all-round cross-checking of data collected by various European bodies (Eurojust, Frontex...) and international. Big Brother, George Orwell's nightmare because what's more, legal guarantees are non-existent or unclear. The office preserves the right to deny citizens access to their own information or to respect the right to be forgotten. And the existing right-of-appeal mechanism will allow it to blame states. As in the first vote on this regulation, I stand against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The European Union agency is reinforced again in this report. Cooperation of our police forces may be desirable, especially against terrorism. However, I am afraid that a federal police force will eventually be brought in. I remain quite reserved on this issue.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. Europol's mission is to support national police services and their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating serious crime and terrorism. Europol facilitates the exchange of information between the competent authorities of the Member States and provides criminal analyses to assist national police forces in their transnational investigations. The proposal improves Europol's governance by trying to achieve efficiency gains by streamlining procedures, in particular with regard to the management board and executive director, and aligning Europol with the principles set out in the Common Approach on EU decentralised agencies. Thus, this proposal for a Regulation provides for a legal framework for a new Europol, succeeding and replacing Europol established by Council Decision 2009/371/JAI of 6 April 2009 establishing the European Police Office (Europol), as well as cepol established by Council Decision 2005/681/JAI establishing the European Police Academy (CEPOL). Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it includes further data protection safeguards for the Union’s citizens as well as enhancing Europol’s capacity to rapidly respond to terrorist threats and organised crime gangs. It is essential that we, as legislators, demonstrate our commitment to ensuring the security of the Union as well as protecting our freedoms.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The reform of Europol is a new step in the establishment of a Security Union. As we know, our security problems are partly related to the lack of Europe, the lack of cooperation and the exchange of information between the Member States. The Europol Agency has a vital role to play in this context. I am therefore pleased that the European Parliament and the Council have reached an agreement to strengthen the effectiveness of the European Centre for Combating Terrorism.  It is essential that Europol in practice become the place where information is not only exchanged effectively but also analysed. Europol needs to strengthen its role in coordinating national practices by, for example, establishing risk analyses.  But this is only the first step. Europol still does not have the authority to initiate criminal investigations. The agency also does not have a European intelligence service. Our security is undeniably through the Security Union. This is a construction site in which we must redouble our efforts.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Taking into account the increase in serious and organised crime in Europe in recent years, such as trafficking in human beings, drugs and arms, corruption, money laundering and cybercrime, I consider it absolutely essential to strengthen cooperation between Member States. Harmonisation of data protection relating to the activities of the police and judicial authorities in the Union is essential in order to respect and safeguard the fundamental rights of citizens of the European Union. In view of the shared competences of the Union and the Member States in the area of freedom, security and justice, close and effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and Union level is necessary. The proposed Data Protection Regulation and the Data Protection Directive will help to ensure efficiency and accessibility in the processing of data by the police and judicial authorities, including the new European Data Protection Board, thus avoiding unnecessary duplication. I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the final agreement reached on the Regulation ‘Lisbonises’ Europol, which should provide for a legal framework by replacing EUROPOL as established by the Council Decision 2009/371/JHA establishing the European Police Office (EUROPOL), and CEPOL as established by Council Decision 2005/681/JHA establishing the European Police College (CEPOL). In this process Cepol was separated and has now its own instrument. This Lisbonisation meant that the Europol structure needed reforming, including its overall functioning, governance, supervision, data protection regime and its relations with third countries and international organisations.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) and the 2009/371/IB, proposed to the European Parliament and the Council the adoption of a Regulation replacing and repealing Council Decisions 2009/934/IB, 2009/935/IB, 2009/936/IB and 2009/968/IB. The Council adopted its position on the proposal at first reading. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament agree at second reading with the Council's position at first reading and thus adopt the regulation in accordance with the Council's position. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Police Office (Europol) was first regulated by an intergovernmental body concluded between Member States and entered into operation in 1999. Under a Council decision adopted in 2009, Europol became an EU agency financed from the EU budget. The purpose of this proposal is to adapt Europol to the requirements of the Treaty of Lisbon, with the establishment of europol's legislative framework in the form of a Regulation and the introduction of a mechanism for monitoring Europol's activities by the European Parliament and national parliaments, thereby enhancing europol's democratic form, legitimacy and accountability. I support this proposal to provide Europol with better governance, more effectively, to ensure a sound data protection regime for Europol and, in chief, in view of the stockholm programme targets, by aiming to make Europol a vital body in the exchange of information between member states' police authorities.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text goes to second reading, so there is no final vote.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's proposal on this text on the European Union Agency for the Cooperation of Law Enforcement. In particular, this text aims to strengthen europol's powers, in particular so that the agency can better fight terrorism, cybercrime and more generally against all forms of crime. After the attacks that France experienced in 2015 and that Belgium experienced last March, we must welcome all the texts that aim to strengthen the security of European citizens.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I support europol, the EU's law enforcement authority, being able to combat terrorism more effectively. Today is an age of technical acquis and data communication, and we must constantly respond to these new acquis from both a fundamental and data protection perspective.  Online terrorist propaganda conquers on an unprecedented extent, think of the online content that showed the cruel crimes committed by terrorist organizations and traveled the world in no time.  The new rules will allow EUROPOL to remove online elements of terrorist propaganda more easily and efficiently by ensuring a rapid exchange of information.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ As a mean of respecting and safeguarding the fundamental rights of Union citizens, the creation of a harmonized, high level of data protection covering police and judicial activities in the Union is crucial. I have voted for this report on Law Enforcement Cooperation and the creation of such agencies across Member States.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 Merging Europol and CEPOL into a single Agency based in The Hague would generate important synergies and efficiency gains. Combining Europol's knowledge of operational police cooperation with CEPOL's expertise in training and education would strengthen links and create synergies between the two areas.  Collaboration between operational staff and training staff working within a single agency will help identify training needs, thereby increasing the relevance and orientation of training at EU level for the benefit of global police cooperation at EU level. This proposal for a regulation provides a legal framework for a new Europol that succeeds and replaces Europol and CEPOL as they have been established. The proposal also strengthens the data protection regime applicable to Europol's activities. Thus, greater efficiency in EU cooperation of law enforcement authorities will also guarantee stronger surveillance and a clear data protection regime.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the amendments to the Europol Regulation, which should bring about more effective cooperation between police forces and thus ensure greater security in the EU. Thanks to the changes adopted, Europol should get a more complete picture of serious crime in the EU, including terrorism, gain the ability to quickly identify trends and threats in all areas of crime and produce better intelligence documents. Simplifying the establishment of specialised centres will also make it easier for Europol to support Member States' activities in the fight against so-called foreign fighters, terrorist financing or the illegal trafficking of firearms.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion as I consider Europol's work in the field of law enforcement to be worthy of support in principle. At the same time, however, I would like to stress that the support of Europol must not lead to a further curtailment of Member State rights, in particular by establishing a super-prosecutor's office through the back door.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is a second reading, aimed at uniting Europol and CEPOL.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I support the recommendation made. In view of the current threat of terrorism and cyber attacks, it is necessary to strengthen europol's role and empower it. The updated rules for the police office's activities will ensure that greater attention is paid to the fight against terrorism and cybercrime. Europol must be prepared to respond adequately to potential threats. The EU response must be comprehensive and based on coherent action. In addition, it is essential to ensure that Member States provide all necessary information in a timely manner relating to organised terrorism or criminal activities and to strengthen cooperation between them. Harmonised rules will facilitate the establishment of autonomous europol units necessary to combat new threats. There is also greater parliamentary control and supervision of the office's conduct, which will make Europol more effective and accountable.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report which provides for new governance rules of the EU police service, Europol, so that it can increase efforts to combat terrorism, cybercrime and other criminal offences and be able to respond more quickly to threats. The most important thing in the report is that the agency's new powers and responsibilities are accompanied by strong safeguards for data protection and democratic surveillance tools.  Europol is now receiving an enhanced mandate to ensure that it is fully equipped to cope with the increase in cross-border crimes and terrorist threats. The new Europol rules are a strong answer we can give to the threat of terrorism.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP are against this report as we are principally against Europol and the extension of power of Europol. Even though this report does increase the potential to scrutinise Europol and hold the institution accountable we believe that the best way to increase safety is to remove Schengen and Europol, and instead have increased member state cooperation through institutions like INTERPOL.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the importance of the work shared by the European Union and the Member States on the protection of fundamental rights, it is essential that there is effective cooperation between the authorities with regard to the creation of a high level of data protection in judicial and police activities. I believe that this proposal, as approved by the Council at first reading, is in line with the security objectives pursued by the European Union, and I therefore do not believe that I support the findings that are being voted on. I am therefore voting against.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The European Police Office (Europol) is the EU’s law enforcement agency, whose remit is to help make Europe safer by assisting law enforcement authorities in EU member countries. Creating harmonized, high level of data protection covering police and judicial activities in the Union is crucial as a mean of respecting and safeguarding the fundamental rights of EU citizens. Therefore I vote for the the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol).

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Establishing a European Law Enforcement Cooperation Agency would maximise the effectiveness of the work of the two U.N. agencies, EUROPOL and CEPOL, by joining them together in one body. In addition, the European and national parliaments, through the obligation to lay down the final accounts and annual reports of that body, would exercise control over its work. Repeated data storage would be avoided and strict protection of data would be developed, the practice of ordering damages in the event of the contrary to the Regulation would be established, the training of law enforcement officers was developed, the autonomy of the agency strengthened, which are all positive newspapers provided for in the Regulation.  For this reason, I supported the Recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol).

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The reform of the mandate of the Europol Agency, which we approved today, will ensure the allocation of additional resources and powers, which are urgently needed in the fight against the most serious forms of organised crime. At the same time, a more democratic and transparent system of monitoring its operation is being set up. The main lesson we must learn from the horrific attacks in Paris and Brussels is that, even when important information is needed to prevent and prevent terrorist activities, the national police services are not able to share this information effectively. The reform of Europol's mandate will help to fill this gap. In parallel with the increase in powers, however, the level of responsibility in charge of the Agency is being increased. Europol will have to show greater responsibility for the management of personal data - with tough new data protection provisions that will ensure the security of data concerning European citizens. It will also be subject to greater parliamentary control, thanks to the monitoring of its actions by a body composed of both European and national Parliamentarians. Europol now has both the powers and the legal framework it needs to effectively combat cross-border crime in the twenty-first century.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the adoption of a joint declaration by the Council and the European Parliament on Article 44 of the European Union. The creation of a harmonised, high level of data protection covering police and judicial activities in the Union is essential as a means of respecting and protecting the fundamental rights of Union citizens. Given the shared responsibilities of the Union and the Member States in the area of freedom, security and justice, it is of u importance that there is close and effective cooperation between supervisors at national and Union level. I agree with my colleagues from the European Parliament and with the Council's view that, following the adoption of the proposed GDPR and the proposed Data Protection Directive on data processing in the police and justice sectors, including the new one, The soon-to-be-established European Data Protection Committee, and given the announced review of Regulation (EC) No.45/2001, the various mechanisms for cooperation between the European Data Protection Supervisor and national supervisory authorities in this area, including the Cooperation Committee established in this Regulation, should be reorganisation in the future to ensure effectiveness and consistency and avoid unnecessary duplication, without prejudice to the Commission's right to initiative.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Joint Declaration of the Council and the European Parliament on Article 44 of this report seeks to deepen Europol's powers to "create a high harmonised level of data protection covering police and judicial activities in the Union as a means of respecting and safeguarding the fundamental rights of Union citizens", as read in the document. This proposal is a new step that highlights the undemocratic nature of this structure, increasingly overriding the sovereignty of states and their competent authorities. A deepening of powers which, seeking to justify itself also in the name of combating terrorism, extends the scope, inter alia, to crimes that act against the interests of Union policies, making room for an interventionist stance in any area and sector, in particular in the restriction of freedoms of civic and political intervention. Together with other policies, mechanisms and infrastructure that already exist or have been created, the strengthening of their funding and the extension of the scope of intervention affirms and continues the security posture of this European Union, which imposes control and restrictions on the freedoms and fundamental rights of citizens, which we reject. Sufficient reasons to vote in favour of the rejection proposal put forward.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. Europol assists national police services in the fight against international crimes and terrorism and has a central position in the European security structure. In light of recent terrorist attacks and threats and the rise of organised crime, Member States should receive support for operational and crime-fighting activities. As several participants are involved in the data processing process, it is important to use capacities reasonably and efficiently and respect the fundamental rights of Union citizens.  Due to the consequences of terrorist attacks, we need more intensive cooperation between intelligence, justice and law enforcement in data sharing and cooperation. I supported a recommendation giving Europol greater powers to prevent terrorist organisations, in particular online terrorist activities. While cooperation between European and national legislative bodies is of great importance, the protection of privacy and personal data is a relevant european security policy issue.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly support the strengthening of Europol's powers, especially in the current security situation in the EU. I believe that without coordination at European level, we cannot effectively face the growing threat of terrorism, but also other forms of international crime. Europol has been given more powers, with which there is also more responsibility. I am glad that supervision by the European Parliament and also by national parliaments has been strengthened, particularly with regard to the protection of personal data. For the above reasons, I voted against the amendments that called for further amendments to the text or for the entire legislative proposal to be repealed.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is the cornerstone of the European Europol Agency and, as a result, it is also the tool that enables coordinated action between the police forces of the various Member States to be strengthened in the fight and prevention of major crime and terrorism. The aim of this proposal is, at operational and functional levels, to promote greater efficiency of the agency's activities and, at hierarchical level, to promote the conditions of democratic scrutiny by democratically elected representatives, ensuring that the obligations in terms of accountability laid down by the Treaty of Lisbon are met in this way. Among the innovations introduced are the creation of a representative of the Commission and the Member States in the framework of europol's management, the establishment of a Joint Parliamentary Group consisting of MEPs and their national counterparts, and the appointment of an Executive Director of the Agency. Finally, the Regulation defines the reciprocal obligations of the above-mentioned actors. As for the efficiency of the agency's activities, the new system for the processing of information and data protection stands out, which ensures an increase in data protection standards, without prejudice to the sharing of information, whenever it is proportional to the exercise of the agency's functions. I voted in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. – UKIP are against this report as we are principally against Europol and the extension of power of Europol. Even though this report does increase the potential to scrutinise Europol and hold the institution accountable we believe that the best way to increase safety is to remove Schengen and Europol, and instead have increased member state cooperation through institutions like INTERPOL.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. In the face of the increase in serious and organised crime, and in order to fight terrorism more effectively, MEPs have always advocated better cooperation between Member States at European level. I therefore fully support this new regulation on Europol, which strengthens the Agency's competence and clarifies its operation, as it will promote information exchange and joint work between national police services. Europol's activities will be further monitored, in accordance with the provisions of the new data protection package. This is particularly essential with regard to the transfer of data to third countries. I also welcome the creation of a specialised group for parliamentary control, which will in particular monitor the impact of the Agency's operation on fundamental rights and individual freedoms. While we can only welcome these advances, this regulation is only the first step towards greater European integration in police cooperation. All this is based on a high degree of trust that is not reached today, and that is why the creation of a "European FBI" should be considered. This will be the next unavoidable step in the construction of a genuine European area of freedom, security and justice.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted in favour of the reform of the Europol agency proposed by the European Commission. This initiative dates back to 2013, before the attacks in France and Belgium. Attacks that demonstrated serious failures, particularly in terms of cooperation between European police forces. With this reform, the European Parliament and national parliaments will be able to control the activities of EUROPOL.  Better data protection is also provided thanks to the independence of EUROPOL's Data Protection Controller. Finally, this new legislation should also improve police cooperation and information exchange. Two absolutely crucial elements in the fight against terrorism and organised crime. Member States must join forces and coordinate their police services, otherwise we will not be able to prevent attacks and arrest perpetrators before they take action.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which gives new powers to the Europol agency, whose role is to help our national police authorities combat organised crime and terrorism. This text is not perfect, especially on the agency's means of action. It would have been desirable for the agency to be able to conduct criminal investigations on its own initiative, such as a genuine European FBI.  However, much progress has been made and a positive step has been taken. With this text, the agency's task and the functioning of cooperation between Europol and the Member States are formalised, providing more legal certainty to the agency's activities and enabling better European cooperation between the police authorities.  In addition, this new mandate given to the agency will improve the fight against terrorism, against transnational crimes or against cybercrime. For example, Member States will have to provide Europol with the data the agency needs to carry out its actions. In addition, provisions have been inserted to ensure strong data protection and democratic control by Parliaments.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The new system of rules and functions of Europol will provide it with better responsiveness to combat crime and terrorism by intensifying the exchange of information between Member States.  The new Regulation also introduces a europol control mechanism by Parliament and national parliaments, as well as a more effective data processing and protection system.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the European police agency Europol will be able to intensify its efforts in the fight against terrorism and cybercrime and respond faster to threats thanks to the new rules of operation than the Parliament we have adopted. The new powers are accompanied by strict safeguards on data protection and democratic control tools.  The draft legislation, agreed by Parliament and Council negotiators in November 2015, strengthens Europol's powers to ensure that it has the necessary instruments in the face of the threat of cross-border crime and terrorism. Among other developments, the Agency will have more facilities to create specialized units to respond to imminent threats.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Police Office, Europol, will soon be able to strengthen its efforts to combat terrorism, cybercrime and other criminal offences, and respond more quickly to threats, thanks to new governance rules that we adopted on Wednesday lunchtime. The new powers will be accompanied by strong data protection safeguards and tools for democratic control. To avoid information gaps in the fight against organised crime and terrorism, the new rules stipulate that Member States should provide Europol with the data the Office needs. Europol will also have to submit an annual report to the European Parliament, the Council, the Commission and national parliaments on the information provided by Member States, with a view to encouraging information sharing.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Union and the Member States are jointly responsible for the area of freedom, security and justice, and it is therefore essential to ensure close and effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and Union level. Their joint activities must lead to the emergence of a harmonised, high-level data protection system involving the activities of the police and judicial authorities. For its part, the efficient and confidential processing of personal data in the Union is a fundamental means of protecting and safeguarding the fundamental rights of Union citizens. The document under discussion is an important step in this direction. I believe that the small comments made by Europol's activities must not constitute an obstacle to the effective reorganisation of the mechanisms for cooperation between the European Data Protection Supervisor and the national supervisory authorities in this field in such a way as to ensure efficiency and consistency and avoid unnecessary duplication of activities, without prejudice to the Commission's right of initiative. I am convinced that the adoption of the general data protection regulation and the Data Protection Directive under consideration and the establishment of a Cooperation Board will speed up these processes.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
