text: In writing. I voted against the motion to reject this text. Indeed, the adoption of this regulation is crucial to enable Europe to effectively combat organised crime and terrorism. In the face of increasing these phenomena, a coordinated response that requires greater cooperation is needed. The new Europol agency, set up by this regulation, will enable this cooperation to be implemented.  State participation will become systematic and codified through joint teams, national Europol units or the appointment of liaison officers. The agency's governance will also be strengthened, while its powers will be governed by strong data protection safeguards and joint parliamentary oversight. This strengthening of Europol must mark a first step towards greater cooperation and integration to build a genuine area of freedom, security and justice.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation underlying this report provides for a legal framework for a new Europol, succeeding and replacing the former European Police Office (Europol) and the former European Police Academy (CEPOL). In 2009, Europol became an EU agency, with the role of providing support for the action of national law enforcement agencies and their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating serious crime and terrorism. Since 2005, the European Police Academy has been an EU agency responsible for activities related to the training of police officers, with the aim of facilitating cooperation between national police forces. I believe that this merger, in addition to aligning Europol with the requirements of the Treaty of Lisbon, strengthening its transparency and accountability, will also create important synergies and efficiency gains in the fight against terrorism and in strengthening the security of European citizens, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report refers to the European Council's proposal to establish the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) as a new step towards cooperation between judicial and police activities within the Union. Data control and protection are of crucial importance in prevention and security action, which is why I voted in favour of the report by rejecting the amendments tabled to the text proposed by the committee responsible.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. During the passage of the European Commission's proposal on the European Police Office (EUROPOL) by the LIBE committee, a problematic text was improved thanks to the amendments of the left-wing groups. For example, through more stringent data protection, in line with the directive recently adopted in LIBE, a broader parliamentary control mechanism or a better definition of EUROPOL's limits of action. However, in its passage through the trilogue, the text has returned to swampy ground as it alters EUROPOL's original purpose of helping national police and judicial authorities combat international crime and terrorism by extending its scope of action to the point of compromising the principle of subsidiarity. The lack of a precise definition of the scope of action, the reduction of parliamentary control, the ability of the Internet Content Notification Unit to exchange data directly with individuals without the participation of Member States, inter alia, seriously calls into question a text which must regulate an agency whose action decisively affects civil liberties. That is why we voted in favour of rejecting the Council's position.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. We rejected the Council's proposal for the new Regulation of EuroPol. We are against this agency being endowed with greater powers while maintaining significant opacity that leaves it completely out of public scrutiny. With this new regulation, the principle of subsidiarity disappears, leaving the agency responsible for all european policy issues, which would allow EuroPol to carry out its activities independently in addition to cross-border cooperation without cooperating with the security forces of the Member States. In addition, you will have the ability to collect and store data independently, which may conflict with the laws of different states regarding data protection.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to the compromise reached, Europol will be given the opportunity to set up specialised units to combat certain types of crime or acts of terrorism. The new regulation provides for the full independence of the Agency, greater guarantees of data protection and adds detailed rules on control by the European Parliament and national parliamentarians. In the light of what happened recently in Brussels and Paris, I believe that Europol must be able to do its utmost to combat and prevent crimes and acts of terrorism effectively and efficiently. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation on the functioning and functions of the European Agency responsible for police cooperation (Europol) aims to ensure more effective action by the agency in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. This Regulation provides for the fight against crime and terrorism to be done by intensifying the exchange of information between Member States in order to improve Europol's reaction, and presents new valences facilitating Europol's operation and can more easily set up specialised units and centres aimed at combating terrorism and other forms of serious crime. With this regulation, direct exchanges of information with private bodies and non-governmental organisations increase. Eurojust and OLAF agencies will have access to data stored by Europol, which will facilitate the exchange of data between the different agencies. The Regulation also ensures the safeguarding of the personal data of European citizens. I voted in favour because the proposal points to greater European integration through greater cooperation between national governments and their security actors with Europol. It also recognises that the agency is instrumental in combating organised crime and is now operating in a more transparent framework.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this proposal as it will provide the legal certainty for Europol’s activities so that it can contribute to further EU-level cooperation of law-enforcement authorities. The regulation provides extensive rules and provisions for the processing of information by Europol and has been aligned with the recently—adopted Data Protection Directive. It will also establish a specialised Joint-Parliamentary Scrutiny Group to monitor Europol’s activities, including any potential impact on fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ Europol exists to help share information amongst law enforcement agencies to make Europe safer. This smart cooperation has to keep evolving as new challenges are presented from organised crime, terrorist networks and traffickers in human beings. I was pleased to reject alternative amendment that would have stopped this development, and I am glad that this second reading agreement was approved.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. The Recommendation considers that, given the shared responsibilities of the Union and the Member States in the area of freedom, security and justice, the existence of close and effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and Union level is of u unathase. It also considers that the various cooperation mechanisms between the European Data Protection Supervisor and national supervisory authorities in this area, including the Cooperation Committee established in this Regulation, should be reorganisation in the future to ensure effectiveness and consistency and avoid unnecessary duplication, without prejudice to the Commission's right to initiative. It is also unacceptable that possible conflicts between Member States or Member States and Europol cannot be brought before the European Court of Justice. This is contrary to democratic principles, in particular as regards human rights, and is very dangerous given the fact that Europol is being given more and more responsibility. In view of the above, I did not support the Recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the European Union Agency for law enforcement cooperation (Europol) and on the replacement and repeal of Council decisions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The current period shows that transnational crime is very flexible and can adapt quickly to new conditions so that its networks are difficult to detect. I therefore supported the proposal to strengthen Europol's powers. The Agency will be expanded in the fight against terrorism, cybercrime or other current threats. Within the framework of this Regulation, Europol shall be arm-tied in situations requiring the establishment of specialised units intervening in urgent cases. In addition, in certain circumstances, Europol will also be authorised to exchange the necessary information with private undertakings or non-governmental organisations, thereby speeding up its work. An important measure is also the possibility to contact the social network operator directly. We know that radicalisation and extremist speech are spreading uncontrollably online. It is therefore essential that the security forces have the opportunity to enter into such radical manifestations in their germ. In addition, democratic control of Europol itself has also been strengthened, which will now be obliged to report regularly every year not only to the European institutions, such as the European Parliament, but also to national parliaments. This will contribute to better control of the information exchanged between Member States. These measures are part of the pressure that the European Parliament is now trying to exert on national authorities, which must increase their cooperation with each other for European security.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation to approve at second reading the Council's position on the proposal for a Regulation on Europol. The Regulation further strengthens and streamlines this existing police cooperation organisation for combating terrorism and serious cross-border crime. It thus helps to better combat the threats that EU countries face together today. Europol is already making the EU safer by operating in cooperation with national police authorities and by collecting, exchanging (including with partners outside the EU) and processing data on suspects. Once this regulation is adopted, it will be able to do even better. The regulation adopted also fundamentally strengthens the role of the European Parliament and national parliaments, i.e. directly elected representatives of EU citizens, in monitoring Europol's activities, which I rate very positively. In addition, the Regulation provides a robust framework for the protection of personal data that Europol works with in its databases, which also requires our support.  At the same time, the Regulation does not give Europol 'agents' enforceable powers, which belong exclusively to the police of the Member States, thus not restricting member countries' sovereignty in the sensitive area of internal security.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Terrorism and organised crime call for strong cooperation between police representatives in Europe, which is particularly evident in the recent events in Paris and Brussels. The exchange of information between Member States is essential for achieving security, and Europol plays an important role in providing support to Member States in the fight against cross-border organised crime.  Accordingly, Europol needs to further strengthen and increase its investigative capacity. At the same time, there is a need for better parliamentary scrutiny of its work, as well as a clear legal basis for its action. Only in this way can a disproportionate and unnecessary exchange of information be prevented, contrary to fundamental human rights.  Despite certain shortcomings, such as the trend towards the privatisation of policing, the regulation contributes to better and more effective cross-border cooperation in the fight against organised crime within the EU between law enforcement authorities and the intelligence services of EU Member States.  At the same time, it also improves the conditions for eu Member States' cooperation with third countries and international organisations, which is particularly important in the fight against organised crime that knows no borders. For the reasons set out above, I support the new regulation and voted against the amendment which proposed rejection.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The report calls for the existing Council decision of 2009, which established Europol as a regular EU agency based in The Hague, to be brought into line with the requirements of the Lisbon Treaty. This means that the legal framework for Europol will be improved in the form of an EU regulation. It also establishes the possibility of control on the part of the European Parliament and the national parliaments. It also takes into account data protection requirements and defines Europol's scope for intervention. The aim is to turn Europol into a more effective authority to support EU Member States in the fight against terrorism and other forms of organised or serious crime.  As the highest priority must be given to safeguarding internal security, I agree with this report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Police forces are the key to our own freedom, and institutions such as Europol need new tools to face new, modern challenges. The regulation adapts to the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon, but also brings about increased security security for Europe's citizens, reduces the bureaucratic burden on cross-border cooperation and allows for a more effective fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the revision of the regulation strengthening the powers of the European Agency Europol. The Agency is one of the largest analysis centres for serious crime and terrorism in the EU. It participates in more than 18,000 cross-border investigations every year.  Europol has recently focused, among other things, on combating relatively new and serious threats such as internet propaganda and people smuggling. It is on the Internet environment associated with terrorist propaganda mainly by the Islamic State that europol's specialized centre, which has been operating since July 2015, the so-called Internet Referral Unit, is targeted.  This unit systematically combats hateful content on the Internet and removes harmful content in cooperation with Internet providers. This activity is to prevent the radicalisation and recruitment of young people into the ranks of terrorist organisations. Since the unit was started, more than 1,700 decisions have been made, in 90% of cases malicious content has been deleted in cooperation with specific Internet providers. In January 2016, the new European Counter-Terrorism Centre was launched.  The aim of the revision is to improve and extend the exchange of information between Member States, to enable the Agency to operate more easily and effectively and, above all, to simplify the creation of specialised units to combat specific threats. The revision also remembers sufficient safeguards for the protection of personal data and provides for democratic oversight.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The main task of the European Police Office (Europol) is to assist national law enforcement authorities in the fight against serious international crimes and terrorism, thus making the Office a major contribution to Europe's security. Due to its central position in the European security structure, Europol must be efficient and carry out its duties in the best possible way, and this is only possible if there is close and effective cooperation between supervisors at national and Union level. It is also important that the fundamental rights of Union citizens are respected and protected, which is achieved through a harmonised, high level of data protection, including police and judicial activities in the Union.  In my view, for europol's effectiveness, various cooperation mechanisms between the European Data Protection Supervisor and national data processing supervisors in the police and justice sectors need to be reorganisation in the future so that effectiveness and consistency can be ensured and unnecessary duplication avoided.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support this proposal to provide legal certainty for Europol activities and to contribute to further EU-level cooperation of law-enforcement authorities. The Regulation provides extensive rules and provisions for the processing of information by Europol and has been aligned with the recently adopted Data Protection Directive. It will also establish a specialised Joint Parliamentary Scrutiny Group to monitor Europol’s activities, including any potential impact on fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The main task of the European Police Office (Europol) is to assist national law enforcement authorities in the fight against serious international crimes and terrorism, thus making the Office a major contribution to Europe's security. Due to its central position in the European security structure, Europol must be efficient and carry out its duties in the best possible way, and this is only possible if there is close and effective cooperation between supervisors at national and Union level. It is also important that the fundamental rights of Union citizens are respected and protected, which is achieved through a harmonised, high level of data protection, including police and judicial activities in the Union. I do not support the proposal to reject the Council's position, as I believe that different cooperation mechanisms between the European Data Protection Supervisor and national data processing supervisors in the police and justice sectors need to be reorganisation in the future so that effectiveness and consistency can be ensured and unnecessary duplication avoided.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) and replacing and repealing Council decisions. When we talk about european police office and law enforcement, we must not forget the respect and protection of the fundamental rights of EU citizens.  Close and effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at Member State and European Union level is crucial in this regard. With good cooperation, we will achieve efficiency and avoid duplication of activities.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to reform the EU Law Enforcement Cooperation Agency (EUROPOL) because I believe it will contribute to the effective fight against terrorism or internet crime of all kinds. Organised crime in particular is now a transnational issue, and it is therefore natural that coordinated international cooperation needs to be deployed to combat it, while at the same time being able to deploy adequate resources quickly in crisis situations. In order to promote information sharing between Member States, europol is required to inform the EP, the EC and the Council of the state and quality of information sharing between States. It is clear that the protection of personal data is guaranteed in a sufficient way. As at national level, access to this data is limited to authorised persons and this information is transmitted in coded form. The handling of personal data by Europol is subject to all standard EU rules, including the possibility of a complaint being lodged by individual citizens.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Our group generally disagrees with the increase in policing through Europol, but also with the powers that Brussels receives through it. However, the report appeared to have positive elements following pressure from Parliament's progressive forces. Such elements are the increase in the protection of personal data, and the prioritisation of Europol's jurisdiction under the security forces of each Member State. Negative elements are, inter alia, the extension of Europol's competence in matters of terrorism and organised crime. For the above reasons we voted abstention.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Council proposal has many aspects that reduce efficiency and effectiveness and effectively limit EUROPOL's accountability in practice. Points of friction in the proposal are: 1. The proposal to merge EUROPOL and CEPOL. 2. The possibility for the online content reference unit to transmit publicly available personal data to private entities. 3. Governance provisions that deviate from the common approach for decentralised agencies. 4. EUROJUST shall have only indirect access to information stored by EUROPOL.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 In particular, it is timely to strengthen and endow the European Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation and Training (Europol) with all necessary means to take appropriate action in the fight against terrorism and in the prevention and combating of international organised crime. I therefore voted in favour of the report on Europol today.  The Fidesz people's party delegation supports the Agency's strengthened mandate to effectively coordinate and strengthen the cooperation of national authorities in the prevention of organised crime and the fight against terrorism. We welcome this text, as we have managed to strike the right balance with the protection of personal data without compromising or hindering the success of investigations.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of a proposal to increase europol's powers and effectiveness, convinced that this office is only one but a key element in the fight against terrorism in Europe. Nevertheless, I regret that the political consensus already in place last November between the Council and Parliament has only now reached a real recognition of the need for urgent legislation in the wake of the tragic terrorist attack in Brussels on 22 March. The implementation of the proposed powers and organisational amendments, including a wider and coherent exchange of information and analysis, the European Counter-Terrorism Centre or rapid response units, coupled with the reassuring oversight of the Data Protection Supervisor, is long overdue and has been on the agenda of the EU institutions for some time.  That is why I think it is important to keep in mind that the success of the effort set out in the proposal and the effectiveness of europol with enhanced powers will continue to depend essentially on the willingness and capacity of the governments, law enforcement agencies and authorities of the Member States to cooperate. As a Hungarian MEMBER, I regret to say that, in particular, because of the insufficient attitude of the government of some Member States towards a single EU counter-terrorism and migration policy, I believe that, in addition to our current legislation, the Council is also waiting for serious political work to ensure a stable background for Europol in the Member States.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted against the amendments because cooperation on the implementation of laws is important and must be directed specifically at security challenges at EU level. The new mandate for Europol will ensure that terrorism and serious transnational crimes are combated at European level, which is the most appropriate level for combating serious crimes. In addition, Europol will have to equip itself with concrete European investigative capacity in the near future.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the regulation establishing Eu ropean Union law enforcement agencies (Europol). The aim of the regulation is to bring Europol into line with the requirements of the Treaty of Lisbon and to introduce a mechanism for monitoring Europol's activities by the European Parliament together with the national parliaments. We voted in favour of this regulation because it will be able to guarantee a robust data protection regime applicable to Europol to ensure that the data protection supervisor is independent and can act effectively. We therefore welcome the Europol regulation, which we believe can provide more efficient support to Member States in the fight against terrorism.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Council proposal aims to strengthen the level of data protection targeting police and judicial activities in the European Union. In view of the common responsibilities of the Union and the Member States in terms of security and justice, it is important to have close and effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and European level.  The new measures will enable Europol to respond to threats more quickly and to set up specialised units more easily.  I believe that this is an important step towards greater efficiency in the cooperation at EU level of law enforcement authorities. That is why, in my vote, I support the Council's position.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for the text. The establishment of a high harmonised level of data protection covering police and judicial activities in the EU is crucial to respecting and guaranteeing the fundamental rights of EU citizens. Given the shared responsibilities of the Union and The Member States in the area of freedom, security and justice, it is essential that there is close and effective cooperation between the supervisory authorities at national and EU level. We believe that, following the adoption of the proposals for a general data protection regulation and data protection directive for data processing in the police and justice sector, including the new European Data Protection Committee which will soon be established, and in view of the announced review of the Regulation , the various mechanisms for cooperation between the European Data Protection Supervisor and national data protection authorities, including the cooperation committee set up by this Regulation, should in future be reorganised to ensure efficiency and coherence and avoid unnecessary duplication, without prejudice to the Commission's right of initiative.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a regulation on the EU Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol), as it will make EUROPOL a stronger player in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. Concretely, the regulation will increase effective cooperation between supervisory authorities, increase the democratic control of national and European Parliament over EUROPOL, and clarify EUROPOLs access to and responsibilities regarding data. I particular welcome the fact that it will allow for better information exchange between Member States, as this has, unfortunately, proven a crucial point in the last terrorist attacks in Europe. However, I wish the reform had been even more ambitious in terms of cooperation between EU and national level, which would ensure even more effectiveness and avoid unnecessary duplication of tasks. This is however a major step.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report mentioned in the vote, because the functioning of Europol in the context of the emergency situation that Europe is now experiencing following the influx of refugees requires greater cooperation between the supervisory authorities. Member States' supervisory authorities should exchange information effectively in order to achieve better screening for those who enter the EU and those who commit crimes on EU territory. It is also clear that such cooperation, which is designed to protect citizens of EU countries, must also involve Eurojust. Only then will we be able to talk about a comprehensive approach to the problem that the report is referring to.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. Rejection of a legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) and replacing and repealing Council Decisions 2009/371/JHA, 2009/934/JHA, 2009/935/JHA, I rejected it in 2009/936/JHA and 2009/968/JHA (14957/2/2015 – C8-0130/2016 – 2013/0091(COD)) as it is essential to ensure harmonised high-level data protection covering police and judicial activities in order to respect and protect the fundamental rights of Union citizens.  Europol's wider powers are aimed at preventing cross-border crime and terrorist threats, which will contribute to increasing the security of European citizens. By providing data, Member States will contribute to meeting the agency's objectives, while europol will also be able to obtain data from companies and NGOs within certain diameters.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. During the passage of the European Commission's proposal on the European Police Office (EUROPOL) by the LIBE committee, a problematic text was improved thanks to the amendments of the left-wing groups. For example, through more stringent data protection, in line with the directive recently adopted in LIBE, a broader parliamentary control mechanism or a better definition of EUROPOL's limits of action. However, in its passage through the trilogue, the text has returned to swampy ground as it alters EUROPOL's original purpose of helping national police and judicial authorities combat international crime and terrorism by extending its scope of action to the point of compromising the principle of subsidiarity. The lack of a precise definition of the scope of action, the reduction of parliamentary control, the ability of the Internet Content Notification Unit to exchange data directly with individuals without the participation of Member States, inter alia, seriously calls into question a text which must regulate an agency whose action decisively affects civil liberties. That is why we voted in favour of rejecting the Council's position.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The agency comes out even stronger. I am in favour of cooperation between Member States' police services in the fight against terrorism and major cross-border crime, but I am wary of the gradual development of a kind of European federal police. I therefore voted in favour of the rejection amendment tabled by the EFDD group.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to increase Europol's effectiveness and accountability, with a view to stepping up efforts in the fight against terrorism, cybercrime and other crimes. Europol should thus strengthen actions and cooperation between Member States aimed at preventing and combating serious forms of crime affecting Member States as well as the interests of the EU. In addition to strengthening Europol's mandate, the new regulation aims to facilitate the creation of specialised units to fight against forms of crime or terrorism. It shall also define clearer rules for existing centres and contain new rules aimed at strengthening the Agency's data management and protection regime by establishing a mechanism for monitoring its activities by the European Parliament in cooperation with national parliaments and a complaint procedure for citizens. This new data management and protection system makes it possible to link the different investigations. Furthermore, information exchange agreements with third countries will be part of the scope of the Regulation. In some cases, Europol will also be able to exchange information with private parties. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation setting out new powers for the EU Europol Agency.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The fundamental rights of EU citizens can be adequately respected and protected by ensuring a harmonised and high level of data protection within the Union, including police and judicial activities. As the Union and the Member States have shared competences in the area of freedom, security and justice, it is essential to ensure close and effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and Union level. With my vote, I followed the position of the S&D group and did not support the proposals of the Greens and the EFDD.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. During the passage of the European Commission's proposal on the European Police Office (EUROPOL) by the LIBE committee, a problematic text was improved thanks to the amendments of the left-wing groups. For example, through more stringent data protection, in line with the directive recently adopted in LIBE, a broader parliamentary control mechanism or a better definition of EUROPOL's limits of action. However, in its passage through the trilogue, the text has returned to swampy ground as it alters EUROPOL's original purpose of helping national police and judicial authorities combat international crime and terrorism by extending its scope of action to the point of compromising the principle of subsidiarity. The lack of a precise definition of the scope of action, the reduction of parliamentary control, the ability of the Internet Content Notification Unit to exchange data directly with individuals without the participation of Member States, inter alia, seriously calls into question a text which must regulate an agency whose action decisively affects civil liberties. That is why we voted in favour of rejecting the Council's position.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as Terrorism and organised crime require a strong cooperation between Europe’s police officers and a coordinated response. It is necessary to equip Europol to support Member States more in Union-wide crime prevention, analyses and investigations. However the more Europol develops its own investigative capacities, the more parliamentary scrutiny is needed and, at the same time, more legal clarity is necessary and essential in the fight against radical content online. It is also essential to have cooperation initiatives with non-EU countries and international organisations as long as this cooperation doesn’t entail mass surveillance or a systematic and indiscriminate exchange for storage and analysis of data that might be disproportionate, unnecessary and contrary to fundamental rights.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a text which has been agreed in a very successful way by the rapporteur and which will strengthen Europol's mandate to ensure that Europol has the necessary instruments in the face of increased threats of cross-border criminality and terrorists. This new legislation will enable terrorist propaganda to be withdrawn more quickly on the internet, information coordination between EEMM and Europol can be promoted, or progress in data protection and democratic control. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the European police agency Europol will be able to intensify its efforts in the fight against terrorism and cybercrime and respond faster to threats thanks to the new rules of operation than the Parliament we have adopted. The new powers are accompanied by strict safeguards on data protection and democratic control tools.  The draft legislation, agreed by Parliament and Council negotiators in November 2015, strengthens Europol's powers to ensure that it has the necessary instruments in the face of the threat of cross-border crime and terrorism. Among other developments, the Agency will have more facilities to create specialized units to respond to imminent threats.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this proposal, which will provide greater legal certainty for Europol's activities, so that it can contribute even better to more cooperation at European level between the various law enforcement agencies. This proposal also includes the creation of a specialised Joint Parliamentary Monitoring Group, which will monitor Europol's activities in order to ensure the protection of our fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal is a new step that highlights the undemocratic nature of this structure, increasingly overriding the sovereignty of states and their competent authorities.  It should be recalled, as an example of the dismantling of national structures for the concentration of competences at Europol, the announced decision on 4 April 2016 to withdraw the judicial police from the national offices of Interpol and Europol in Portugal, which, under the pretext of combating terrorism, has actually resulted in a drift of fundamental rights and guarantees of citizens and the sovereignty of states.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. As this vote is a recommendation for second reading, there will be no final vote. Instead, however, the EFDD has tabled an amendment that the Council's position should not be adopted. I supported this amendment with my vote, as I reject the Council's planned project. Among other things, an Internet Referral Unit will be set up to counter terrorism and extremism on the Internet, but will in fact prove to be a further attack on the freedom of expression of the righteous citizen.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – the European Parliament's recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Union Agency for Cooperation and Training in The Field of Law Enforcement (Europol) and the replacement and repeal of Decisions 2009/371/JHA, 2009/934/JI, 2009/935/JI, 2009/936/JI and 2009/968/JI I rejected. Europol is allegedly used for European police cooperation. However, the new powers will make Europol more of a monitoring agency than a law enforcement coordination agency. Instead of repressive tasks, it receives preventive tasks. This legislative tendency – admittedly not only at EU level – is, in my view, dangerous. Freedoms are affected. In particular, I reject the Internet surveillance unit. I also reject the comprehensive powers to collect, store and process data.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support this proposal to provide legal certainty for Europol activities and to contribute to further EU-level cooperation of law-enforcement authorities. The Regulation provides extensive rules and provisions for the processing of information by Europol and has been aligned with the recently adopted Data Protection Directive. It will also establish a specialised Joint Parliamentary Scrutiny Group to monitor Europol’s activities, including any potential impact on fundamental rights and freedoms. I have a particular interest in Europol’s vital work tackling sex trafficking and the sexual abuse of children and young people, including online abuse. The agency’s partnership with Missing Children Europe and the Member States’ ‘safer children’ centres, such as the Cambridge-based UK’s Internet Watch Foundation, is an excellent example of why our membership of the EU contributes to our safety and security and improves the lives of women, children and vulnerable people. Exiting the EU would increase the risk of predatory behaviour going undetected resulting in more victims and fewer prosecutions. This is not a risk I am prepared to take in the forthcoming UK referendum.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Written. I supported the Council's position by voting against the amendments to its position. The reason why I support a stronger Europol is in line with what is stated in the joint statement. In summary, it says that the basic rights of European citizens can only be guaranteed if there is a proper functioning of the police and judicial services.  It is my belief that increased harmonisation and better data protection can ensure more effective cooperation between the national competent authorities of the various Member States. In addition, I also support the call to extend this efficient and effective cooperation to the national competent authorities, the Data Protection Supervisor and the European Data Protection Board.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – Given the shared responsibility of the Union and the Member States in the area of freedom, security and justice, I believe that it is essential that there should be effective cooperation between supervisory authorities at national and Union level. Following the adoption of the proposed GENERAL Data Protection Regulation and the Directive on the protection of personal data for the processing of data in the justice and police sectors, including the new European Data Protection Committee, which will soon be set up, I believe that the various mechanisms for cooperation between the European data protection controller and national supervisory authorities in this area should be simplified in order to ensure efficiency and coherence and avoid unnecessary duplication. Thanks to this new framework, Europol will now be able to create more specialised units in response to new threats. These new powers go hand in hand with guarantees on data protection and democratic control instruments.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 This resolution strengthens data protection in the field of police and judicial activities in the Union, while contributing to respect for and defence of the rights of the European citizen. The adoption of the Council's position at first reading was also supported by my vote.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. U2012 I am fully confident in the need to strengthen Europol's powers, as it is a means of increasing the chances of obtaining information on trends in organised crime and thereby one more step towards combating terrorism. With regard to this information, I think it is important to stress that its exchange must follow strict criteria, so that it is uniform and correctly proven. All this, through the cooperation of all EU members, would result in increased security in the European Union. That is why I am in favour of this report.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported europol's new rules of operation. As the threat of terrorism and foreign crimes is constantly increasing at present, I believe that Europol should have the powers to meet these challenges quickly and effectively. That is why, in the regulation, we approved an extended possibility for Europol to exchange data, including with some private entities, as well as to facilitate the establishment of special forces. On the other hand, however, we have also not forgotten that the data that Europol operates with are sensitive, and therefore the regulation contains their increased protection. Of the control elements, I agree with the introduction of democratic control of Europol through the approved obligation to report annually to the European Parliament and through a clearly defined complaints mechanism for citizens of the European Union. I hope that, thanks to this clear legal framework, Europol will also be able to better prevent security threats that threaten the European Union.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. The safety of European citizens is under greatest test since the end of the Cold War. It is therefore of the utmost importance that the European Parliament and the Council have finally reached an agreement on Europol, which will now have more powers in the fight against terrorism, cyber and organised crime and other serious criminal phenomena.  It will have the possibility to create specialised rapid intervention units, and the exchange of information between Member States and Europol will be better. For the reasons set out above, I support the new regulation and voted against the amendment which proposed rejection.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, the author's name rings familiar to many Hungarians, it was Mrs Wikström who, without giving reasons, rejected the petition of the disenfranchiseed Hungarian victims with foreign currency loans, so I read her report with suspicion as a Hungarian. And to put it this way, let some quotes support this: "Immigration from outside the EU is one of the sources of supply for highly skilled workers, and there is a growing demand for groups of third-country nationals and researchers." 'Students and researchers of third-country nationality may form the reserve of highly qualified potential workers and human capital that the European Union needs to overcome these challenges.' Dear Mrs Wikström, ask hungarian researchers, Hungarian university students, Hungarian unemployed people, for example, before you write such repugnant texts in a report.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, research, exchange of pupils and exchange of students, paid or not traineeships, volunteering, all of this prepares the younger generation for the historic leap that we have to make and that we are already doing - maybe some are not aware of it, but many are.  The mobility of the young generation is very important both for increasing competitiveness and for raising the qualification of the workforce, the more competitively competitive we will have, the more skilled the workforce will be and the better the outcome of the work and society will evolve. With this openness of Europe to students and pupils from third countries, we must, of course, be careful to take effective measures to prevent those entering the Union, under the pretext of study or volunteering or work, from bringing extremism with them.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I support this proposal on the grounds that I think it is right to promote the principles of mobility of young people, students and researchers. I consider it extremely right that we are trying to put uniform rules in place so that students and scientists from third countries can study and research scientifically on the territory of the European Union. In short, the influx of quality brains into the European Union is clearly a positive trend, it strengthens the quality of European research, the quality of European education and, of course, subsequently, if these people remain in the European Union, it affects the quality of European industry and other sectors where these educated, qualified people can take up and thus increase the competitiveness of Europe as such in relation to other powers such as the United States of America, Japan and so on.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, what we are seeing with the migration crisis is the tragedy of the Commons. By dismantling national frontiers and focusing only on an external one, we have incentivised – and thereby greatly exacerbated – the net influx of illicit migrants into the EU. Of course, if your starting point is that the EU should be a single country and should therefore just have a single border and not have what are called internal frontiers, that may be a price worth paying. But we should be very clear that this is the elevation of the dogma of closer amalgamation over any practical consequences, in the same way that the euro is now about preserving closer integration despite the immiseration being inflicted on tens of millions of people who have to use the euro. In a way, the choice that Britain faces on 23 June is whether to make those problems our problems. Because we kept our passport checks and because we kept our currency, we have other options. We can reorient back to the rest of the world the bits of the world that are still growing.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Every year, millions of third-country nationals, as we know, enter the territory of the European Union to study, study, do research, volunteer, and that is great. The aim of the new directive is to improve the relevant legal framework. According to the Council's proposal, Member States will unequivocally retain both their fundamental right to control the entry of aliens into their territory as a whole and to require all necessary documentation in any of the official languages of the Union, which is a good thing. It should also be noted that the Council modified the Commission's offer to allow students to work at least fifteen hours per week. In the case of researchers, the minimum legal duration will be one year or another contractually stated period. Trainees, by the way, will have a maximum period of six months, although countries will also be able to extend it on the basis of their own laws. In short, it is a very timely and good document, and of course I voted in favour.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, of course, strengthening the mobility of young people, exchanging trainees, people who are educated in their field, I think that is indeed the right way, and I support it. Of course, they cannot be underestimated when it comes to security-related issues. There can be no answer as to whether there is adequate scrutiny of those people who will be coming here. However, I think that security issues cannot completely prevent such an exchange of young people. Of course, I can also find a risk for them, but we cannot think that we will prevent everything, and on the basis of this, to make a sacrifice even the highest in terms of preventing any contact between universities and scientific institutes is certainly not the right way to go. I think this will strengthen the quality of education, the quality of science. Not only will some labour reserves be created, but it will indeed bring new life to our European science. That, I think, is the right way, which I, I have repeatedly said, support.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís is dóigh liom gur moltaí an-mhaith iad seo agus ní féidir leo aon rud ach maitheas a dhéanamh, ní hamháin don Eoraip ach go háirithe do na tíortha seo atá with forbairt.  Dar ndóigh, tá an chuid déanta with an Aontas le blianta fada do na tíortha atá with forbairt trí chabhair de gach sórt a thabhairt dóibh. Ach is dóigh liom gur ceart dúinn anois na moltaí seo and chur i bhfeidhm i dtreo is gur féidir leis na daoine go bhfuil and lán tallainne acu – ach nach bhfuil an seans acu ina dtíortha féin an tallann a úsáid – teacht go dtí an tAontas chun gur féidir leo taighde, staidéar, traenáil agus obair dheonach and dhéanamh.  Agus má fhanann siad san Aontas, cabhróidh sé go mór leis an Aontas amach anseo; ach má théann siad on ais go dtína dtíortha féin, beidh siad with tabhairt an taithí sin go léir leo agus beidh siad in ann gnónna a bhunú agus mar sin de. Sub iontach an moladh é.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 With Council Directive 2004/114/EC, the European Union has prepared a first harmonisation of national legislation on the conditions of entry and residence for students, pupils, trainees and volunteers from third countries. The current proposal to amend the directive aims to extend the legal avenues of access, as well as to simplify conditions and procedures, proposing significant changes in terms of entry into the world of work and mobility between Member States. I voted against the rejection amendment, because I believe that facilitating the exchange and mobility of students, researchers and volunteers can make a major contribution to the cultural, economic and social enrichment of the Union.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this early first-reading agreement on a Directive covering the categories referred to in the title and which takes the form of a consolidated text in which several directives are encompassed in a new one which jointly addresses issues which were previously regulated through differentiated legal acts. The aim of the new Directive is to extend the material scope of the pre-existing Directives, to provide greater legal certainity to different groups of third-country nationals coming to the EU in order to carry out activities within the categories envisaged.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. In the current situation where the European authorities are implementing migration policies of such an aggressive nature at our borders, they present at the same time this directive of a marked elitist character for the migration of members with the highest academic qualifications. Throughout the negotiation, our proposal to make this administrative category extensive to hugely discriminated sectors such as au pairs has been ignored, as well as maintaining the possibility that states may not accept a candidate without giving any explanation, which could lead to discrimination on the source. Even so, we voted against the rejection amendment which was being raised as we understand that despite these important weaknesses, any legislation that favours freedom of movement and migration with rights is positive.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal to reject the text on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, education, training, volunteering, student exchange and au pair work.  The aim of this text is to improve the existing legal framework and to extend the scope to new categories of third-country nationals (paid trainees and au pairs).  It therefore undermines the sovereignty of member countries, which should be able to have its own policy in this area. In addition, it supports measures that promote immigration (family reunification) and promotes brain drain at the expense of developing countries.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this report was to relax entry requirements for students who are travelling, training, volunteering etc. and therefore to improve the right for students to move around the EU. I voted in favour of this report, but I was disappointed that the Irish Government chose to opt out of this Directive, which sets out common rights and procedural guarantees for job-seeking students and researchers. (Which dealt with The Students Directive and the Researchers Directive from 2004 and 2005 respectively)

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of harmonised entry and residence rules at European level for students, researchers, trainees, volunteers and au pairs from third countries. All too often, students and researchers from third countries face unnecessary administrative barriers to studying or doing research in the EU, which ultimately deters them. These rules will strengthen Europe's position on the world stage in the areas of research and innovation, and respond to the demographic and economic challenges we face, while strengthening the rights of young people on the move.  In addition to harmonized and simplified provisions, this framework will effectively combat the risks of exploitation and unfair competition in the labour market, which all too often confront these people. The next step should be to propose a comprehensive framework for the stay of third-country nationals in the EU, in order to be able to fully meet the needs of the European labour market.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the amendment tabled by the EFDD and the ENF on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purpose of research, study, traineeship, voluntary service, student exchanges or educational programmes and the employment of au pair, because I am in favour of recommending a second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council. Given the negative situation at European level with regard to immigration, this directive is an important step in legal migration and, by extension, in exploiting its positive consequences.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The text lists, in addition to valid travel documents, all documents that may be required for entry, depending on the particular national regime or the specific situation of the third country national. All this undermines the sovereignty of the Member States, which should be able to carry out their own policy in this area. This text is also immigrationist (family reunification, right to stay to look for work or start a business), and favours the "brain drain" at the expense of developing countries. I therefore voted in favour of the motion to reject the Council's position.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the rejection of the Council position. Whilst the UK has an opt-out in this area, there are no guarantees that: 1. The current British government, or any subsequent government, will not concede this opt-out permanently and irrevocably. 2. This will not impact the UK through citizenship being granted to non-EU nationals in EU countries, who would then gain the right to live and work in the UK.  The legislation itself harmonises matters which are best dealt with by Member States.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, because the cohesion policy, with a budget of more than 350 billion euros planned until 2020, is the instrument by which the Union is getting closer to its citizens and the main investment and development policy of Europe. Nevertheless, I believe it is essential that Member States meet the ex ante conditions by the end of 2016 in order to ensure the proper implementation of the programmes. In addition, I call for simplifying the administrative burden, which leads to slow and cumbersome approval of major projects.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to facilitate the entry of third-country students and researchers into the EU. The proposal lays down conditions for the entry and residence of third-country national researchers, students, pupils, remunerated and unremunerated trainees, volunteers and au pairs on the territory of the Member States for a period exceeding three months. It lays down reception conditions for two groups of third-country nationals that are currently not subject to a legally binding EU legal framework– au pairs of nannies and remunerated trainees – to guarantee their rights and protection. In the case of third-country national researchers, their families, access to employment and their mobility within the EU are facilitated. The proposal also provides that an applicant who fulfils all the conditions for admission in one Member State is to be granted a long-stay visa or residence permit. The proposal facilitates and facilitates the mobility of students and researchers (in particular those participating in the Erasmus Mundus and Marie Curie programmes) within the EU. As a result of the proposal, students receive more rights to work part-time and enable students and researchers to stay in the area for 12 months after completing their studies and/or research so that they can find out their employability.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 Quote from the recommendation of the legislative proposal: "Globalisation makes it urgent to strengthen relations between EU businesses and foreign markets, and the mobility of trainees and au pairs contributes to the development of human capital, which in turn enriches migrants, the country of origin and the host country and creates a process to better understand each other's cultures." The proposal is in response to the need for cheap labour for multinationals and also aims to create a Europe of mixed ethnic composition, while the quality of life of indigenous European communities is declining due to high unemployment and increasing emigration. On this basis, I supported the motion of the EFDD and ENF factions to reject the Council proposal.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. As the text went to second reading, I did not have to comment on the text itself; I did, however, vote in favour of the proposal to reject the Council's position, which defends an immigrationist regulation which we have seen has so far only served the interests of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have approved this text because the agreement reached is probably a maximum result in the current context. Some positive points should be highlighted, such as the extension of visas of more than three months to trainees, volunteers and, in optional form, to au pairs. Similarly, the mobility of students and researchers on long-term visas is simplified and extended within the UNION and family members of researchers are now included in the directive with the right to work and move within the UNION. Finally, after completing their studies or research, students and researchers can stay in the EU for a period of 12 months to find a job or start their activity.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Attracting talent and people with high skills is a priority for the European Union, especially at a time of history such as this characterised by strong international competition, a shortage of skills within the EU and a high rate of ageing among its population. I voted in favour of the Wikström report because I believe that the solutions proposed are equal to the challenges we face. With the new directive, which will unifies and replace the provisions now laid down in the Students Directive and the Researchers Directive, it will be simplified and made more attractive for researchers and students and workers to study and do research in the EU. The new legislation will allow third-country nationals to stay in the Union for nine months after completing their studies and research to look for work or set up a business; it will allow them to be joined by their families and to move more easily within European borders during their stay.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted against the two amendments to the whole tabled by two political groups, which would have led to the rejection of the Council's position and, consequently, the decay of the legislative proposal.  We understand that this report contains very positive aspects for people wishing to carry out their higher education or research in the EU.  This is a second reading and was approved in the committee and there was no vote in plenary.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Opposing the proposal for a directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, education, training and volunteering, I voted in favour of the motion of rejection tabled by our group. This new directive will be just another gateway to mass immigration, under the most misleading pretexts. The explanatory statement estimates that the research and development sector will require an additional one million jobs in the coming years; yet, rather than reserving these jobs for our 12% unemployed, the Council and Parliament consider it necessary to bring to the EU a 'reservoir of highly skilled potential workers and human capital that the EU needs'. A double contempt, towards European workers as well as students from third countries, reduced to a mere uprooted resource of economic adjustment. Apart from the fact that this directive is a real lever for social dumping, I am surprised that Parliament and the Council, seeing the brain drain of our best researchers, are taking immigration as a solution rather than making europe more favourable.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 This directive would like to justify the entry of third-country nationals for the purposes of study, research, traineeships and other training programmes to encourage immigration to Europe. Once again, an attempt is being made to put forward the idea that the only way to save europe's economic and demographic growth lies through the mass immigration of non-EU citizens into the EU. On the contrary, I believe that Europe must first concern itself with the millions of European citizens who are out of work, mainly because of the EU's crazy choices. I therefore voted to call for the rejection of this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive to recast several Directives on the entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, studies, internships, volunteering, student exchange and au pair placement, bringing them into new regulation. The aim of this legislation is to give greater security to third-country nationals who come to the Union to carry out any of the activities envisaged, as well as to achieve a totally homogeneous system. Thanks to Parliament's requirements, both volunteers and trainees will fall within the scope of the Directive on a mandatory way, eliminating the possibility of optionally including au pair workers. In addition, intra-Community mobility of students and researchers has been improved and the minimum number of hours students can work part-time has been expanded, and the period during which students and researchers can remain in the Union after the end of the study or research period has been set at twelve months. The Union must continue to make progress on legal migration.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation because the Council position was adopted at first reading with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, studies, training, voluntary service, pupil exchange programmes or educational projects and the conditions for participation in the Au pair programme. As the European Parliament and the Commission understand, the provisions of this Directive allow Member States to reject an application only on a case-by-case basis and taking into account the specific circumstances of the third-country national and the principle of proportionality and on the basis of evidence or serious and objective reasons. The Commission will ensure that Member States implement this provision in accordance with this interpretation when transposing the Directive and will inform the European Parliament and the Council in fulfilling their obligations. The European Parliament and the Commission consider that the inclusion of this provision in this Directive should not be considered as a precedent for the establishment of measures for legal migration in the future.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I did not support the proposal to reject the Council's positions at first reading with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, study, pupil exchange, paid and unpaid training, voluntary work and the work of nannies. The Council's positions contain provisions to clarify and improve the conditions for exchanges between non-EU third-country nationals, trainees, volunteers, students and nannies. I had no reason not to accept these provisions.  The proposed directive also proposes to simplify the possibility of moving the aforementioned categories of people within the European Union, which further improves their mobility in finding work in the EU.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcomed the text adopted today at the end of a long legislative process, which aims at the revision and greater harmonisation of the legislation on entry and residence in the European Union by third-country nationals for the purposes of study, research, traineeship and other forms of exchange or placement. At a time when the issue of immigration is on the agenda, together with all the issues and challenges associated with it, strengthening the channels of legal entry into the EU and the conditions for staying within it, for the benefit in particular of qualified and willing young people, is an important step towards promoting the cultural exchange and skills that should undersoe the European spirit and the development of our societies.  Focusing on human capital and promoting its mobility is not only at the heart of our strategies, but also of our values, and we must remember this in these difficult times, even when we are dealing with third countries or immigration.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This text infringes on the sovereignty of Member States and is pro-immigration (family reunification, the right to stay to look for work or start a business). This text promotes brain drain at the expense of developing countries, which I am fighting hard.  I voted to reject this proposal.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – The aim of this report was to relax entry requirements for students who are travelling, training, volunteering etc. and therefore to improve the right for students to move around the EU. I voted in favour of this report, but I was disappointed that the Irish Government chose to opt out of this Directive, which sets out common rights and procedural guarantees for job-seeking students and researchers. (Which dealt with The Students Directive and the Researchers Directive from 2004 and 2005 respectively)

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is facing major structural changes of both demographic and economic nature. The working-age population has practically stopped growing and will begin to decline over the next two years. For both economic and demographic reasons, the current patterns of employment growth centred on qualified personnel will remain valid for the next decade. The Union is also facing an 'innovation emergency' situation: every year Europe spends 0.8% less GDP on research and development than the UNITED States and 1.5% less than Japan. In this context, it is important to maintain a framework of rules relating to the residence of third-country nationals that is consistent with the founding values of the EU, with the guiding principles of its action and with the economic and demographic interests of the Union.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The European Commission directive on which we must vote is supposed to facilitate the arrival of foreign students in the European Union so that they can train and use their skills in their country of origin. In reality, it will help to create new channels of legal immigration. These nationals are in fact called to stay in Europe, to make up for a shortage of skilled labour.  This directive will thus strengthen competition in the labour market between candidates who have just graduated, much to the delight of large groups who will have at their disposal a trained and low-demand workforce on their wage claims. That is why I opposed this text by voting for the rejection proposal.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this Directive is to authorise Member States to reject an application only on a case-by-case basis, but taking into account both the specific circumstances of each third-country national and the principle of proportionality, but only on the basis of serious and objective evidence or reasons. At the same time, it is necessary to monitor and ensure that Member States implement that provision in accordance with that interpretation when transposing the Directive and informing the European Parliament and the Council thereof, within the framework of their obligations under Article 39. I voted in favour of this resolution on the entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, studies, vocational training, volunteering, exchange of pupils and au pair work, considering it essential to encourage education, research and training, because this exchange only supports the Member States, but also the European Union as a whole.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The directive would like to make it easier for the categories mentioned above to access the Union through leaner bureaucratic procedures. All this, however, is justified by the political message that in short supports the need for more immigration into Europe. Let us remember that at first reading this text was justified by: 'Estimates of the immigration needed to maintain the ratio of the working population to the total population at 2010 levels indicate that the EU as a whole would need 11 million incoming workers in the period 2010-2020'; or: 'Europe will increasingly depend on immigration to fill vacancies and ensure economic growth'. I voted in favour of rejecting the proposal.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation of third-country nationals arriving in the Union for studies, research, training through paid or non-paid traineeships, but also for volunteering or au pair work is characterised by two aspects which I consider important. Firstly, this mobility creates a transfer between the European labour market, i.e. the research field and these young people in order to provide a framework conducive to completing their educational and professional development at a high quality level, and for the EU it would be noted that competitiveness in the market will be increased. Secondly, which this recommendation for second reading itself highlighted, Member States should not neglect the profile of any of the young third-country nationals coming into the EU, and the rejection of their application should be carried out only on the basis of evidence or serious reasons which would render their presence inappropriate. Here I am referring, of course, to the possibility of a transfer of extremism from the outside to the Union. I therefore support this recommendation for second reading on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, studies, training, voluntary services and student exchange programmes, educational projects and au pair work.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because I believe that the establishment of a single instrument, applicable to all these groups of third-country nationals, is crucial for the EU. Simplifying and improving their conditions of entry and residence is, at the same time, both a duty and a moral obligation. The EU faces major demographic and economic challenges. Enabling third-country nationals to acquire skills and knowledge during a training period in Europe can therefore help to form a pool of potential workers and encourage the circulation of brains. However, the rules in force governing access for some of these groups are not yet sufficiently clear and therefore do not make it possible to resolve the practical difficulties encountered by those concerned.  Promoting people-to-people contacts and mobility are essential elements of the Union's policy. Migration is a form of mutual enrichment for the state of origin and the host State. Global thinking is the new challenge facing the future of our young people.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which concerns the consolidation of two existing Directives – The Students Directive and the Researchers Directive from 2004 and 2005 respectively. The report seeks to relax entry requirements for the above categories in doing so, and improve the right for students to move around the EU. I was disappointed that the Irish Government chose to opt out of this Directive, which sets out common rights and procedural guarantees for job-seeking students and researchers.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEP’s have voted in favour of our group’s rejection amendment which calls for the council position to be rejected and the procedure to be closed. UKIP believes that it is not the competency of the European Union to create and manage entry requirements for third country nationals into the Union. We believe that this is a decision that sovereign national governments should have the ability to decide.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for educational purposes. I am confident that whilst the proposal clarifies and improves the rules for entry of such individuals, it will help young people come to Europe to discover our culture and gain valuable experiences.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament is called upon to approve at second reading the text of the revision of the Directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, study, traineeships, volunteering, pupil exchange programmes or educational projects, and au pair placement. The revision is in fact aimed at extending and facilitating legal avenues of access to the EU for certain categories of subjects. The text provides for the harmonisation of the conditions of entry and residence in the EU for researchers, students, trainees and volunteers participating in the European Voluntary Service from third countries. For other categories of subjects (such as third-country nationals applying to participate in a pupil exchange programme or educational project, volunteers other than those participating in the European Voluntary Service and persons placed on an equal footing), Member States would retain the option of applying the conditions laid down in the amended Directive. The vote is certainly positive.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which merges the current guidelines on the conditions for entry of students and researchers into the EU, and includes paid trainees and au pairs within the scope of the common directive.  This report clarifies the conditions for these people to enter the European area, with the aim of strengthening access to the labour market for students and filling the skills gaps that affect so many specific sectors in Europe. It is a matter of our Union's competitiveness in the global market. In particular, I welcome the fact that students and researchers can stay at least nine months after completing their studies or research in order to find a job or start a business. I congratulate my colleague Cecilia Wikstrom for her excellent work in the negotiations of these texts with the Commission and the Council.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Written. We Danish Social Democrats have abstained from voting in favour of this directive. On the one hand, the directive is subject to the Danish opt-out and, on the other hand, we do not agree with the whole content. There's b.la. challenges in relation to the way Denmark has set up its welfare society.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report as we believe it brings about improvements in particular with regard to admission procedures, equal treatment rights, students' rights to access the labour market during studies, mobility within the EU and procedural guarantees.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I could only speak in favour (technically: against rejection) of the Council proposal because I agree with the objectives and modalities of the report.
