The aim of the document is to simplify the possibility of movement for third-country nationals by giving them the opportunity to acquire skills and knowledge through a period of training in Europe. It also encourages the 'circulation of brains' and supports cooperation with other states. These are all laudable aims, and that is why I voted against the rejection of this proposal. Indeed, I am bitter to see that the mere obstructionism of certain political parties, such as EFDD, all too often poses a serious threat to the formation of good initiatives such as this.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union’s working age population has practically stopped growing and over the next couple of years it will start shrinking. The EU is also facing a situation of ‘innovation emergency’. Europe is spending 0.8% of GDP less than the US and 1.5% less than Japan every year on Research & Development (R&D). In addition, thousands of the best researchers and innovators have moved to countries where conditions are more favourable. To counterbalance this lack of manpower, immigration from outside the EU is one source of highly skilled people, and third-country national students and researchers in particular are groups which are increasingly sought after and which the EU needs to actively attract. Allowing third-country nationals to acquire skills and knowledge through a period of training in Europe encourages ‘brain circulation’ and supports cooperation with third countries.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The current multipolar world, with diverse focuses of power, also has expression in research and innovation. We are not alone in the world; we need to attract third-country nationals. Therefore, two directives were recast and merging, focusing mainly, but not exclusively, on the beneficiaries of these two: students and researchers. On the one hand, it facilitates the entry of researchers, students and their families, as well as their permanence after the completion of their studies. In this way, it is intended that these third-country nationals can develop, in Europe, the skills also acquired here.  On the other hand, the Directive facilitates intracontinental mobility. In other words, since these visas remain territorially limited, although we live in an area without borders, the procedure for movements within the Union is facilitated. For all this, I am voting in favour of this directive.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because the new rules make the rules more practicable for third-country nationals coming to Europe for research and study purposes. On the one hand, we in Europe are increasingly dependent on immigrants to fill vacancies. On the other hand, economic powers in other parts of the world today have far greater success in recruiting skilled workers. We must act here so that we can consolidate the EU's reputation as an attractive location for science and innovation, thereby contributing to a strengthening of overall competitiveness. The EU must be competitive and unbureaucratic on the world market, while ensuring security and equal treatment.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP MEP’s have voted in favour of our group’s rejection amendment which calls for the council position to be rejected and the procedure to be closed. UKIP believes that it is not the competency of the European Union to create and manage entry requirements for third country nationals into the Union. We believe that this is a decision that sovereign national governments should have the ability to decide.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report because I believe that allowing Member States to reject an application only on a case-by-case basis and taking into account the specific circumstances of the third-country national and the principle of proportionality on the basis of evidence or serious objective reasons is appropriate, however, such should nonetheless be regulated within a general framework of harmonised rules.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's working-age population has practically ceased to grow and is likely to start to decline over the next few years, while thousands of top researchers and innovators move to countries where conditions are most favourable. Enabling third-country nationals to acquire skills and knowledge during a training period in Europe can help to form a pool of highly qualified potential workers and encourage the circulation of brains, supporting cooperation with third countries. However, the rules in force governing access for some of these groups are not sufficiently clear and do not resolve some of the practical difficulties encountered by those concerned. For this reason, Parliament is called upon to approve at second reading the text of the compromise agreed with the Council, concerning the revision of the directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, study, traineeships, volunteering, pupil exchange programmes or educational projects, and au pair placement. The revision of this directive actuallyes the legal avenues of access to the EU for certain categories of subjects and facilitates their entry. Because of the many problems facing Europe in recent years, I am voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – In the current situation where the European authorities are implementing migration policies of such an aggressive nature at our borders, they present at the same time this directive of a marked elitist character for the migration of members with the highest academic qualifications. Throughout the negotiation, our proposal to make this administrative category extensive to hugely discriminated sectors such as au pairs has been ignored, as well as maintaining the possibility that states may not accept a candidate without giving any explanation, which could lead to discrimination on the source. Even so, we voted against the rejection amendment which was being raised as we understand that despite these important weaknesses, any legislation that favours freedom of movement and migration with rights is positive.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this legislative resolution by voting in favour, because I believe that the residence of third-country nationals within the EU, in order to carry out training projects, must be regulated in such a way as to safeguard the free movement of persons, knowledge and competences within the territory of the Union. I therefore support the joint position of the European Parliament and the European Commission on the reasons for refusing to enter Europe for third-country nationals. Such citizens must not be hindered in the implementation of their study or work project in one or more Member States and their application should be rejected only on serious and objective evidence or grounds and, in any event, taking into account the specific circumstances of the third-country national and the principle of proportionality.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. – The European Parliament supports the Council's position at first reading on the adoption of a Directive on the conditions of entry and residence of persons arriving from third countries to the EU for research, learning, volunteering or au pairing activities. The precise definition of the conditions for residence in the Union linked to the activities listed and defined in the Directive will make the system more transparent and clarify the category of applications covered, all of which is important during this period significantly defined by migration. The annex to the report contains a joint statement by Parliament and the Commission clarifying the reasons for rejecting the application provided for in the Directive, including taking into account the principle of proportionality and factual evidence. Member States will have to transpose the Directive in accordance with the attached interpretation.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of this directive is to improve global competition for talent and to promote Europe as a centre of excellence in studies and training. Improving competitiveness, stimulating growth and job creation. The draft directive provides for common conditions of arrival and residence within the EU for researchers, students, apprentices and volunteers from third countries participating in the European Voluntary Service. The new rules cover third-country nationals working as researchers or wishing to study in one of the Member States. The mobility period of researchers has been increased to six months, making the European Union a more attractive place for third-country nationals. In addition, students from third countries will be entitled to work at least 15 hours per week (outside study time) so that they can cover part of their study costs. On the basis of the above arguments, I voted in favour.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote because it is my view that immigration policies are a national competency for the UK to decide. The British Government has also opted-out of this mechanism.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report focuses on the entry and residence conditions of third-country nationals in the European Union with the aim of research, studies, training, volunteering, student exchange and au pair work. The aim is to simplify the mobility of third-country nationals in order to promote cultural exchanges.  This report proposes that students and researchers should be able to stay at least nine months after the end of their activities and promote their mobility in the European territory during their stay. Considering that the mobility of European students and researchers promotes the development of a European identity and contributes to the achievement of the single European area, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The revision of the directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, study, training, volunteering and student exchange programmes or au pairs and work programmes improves the legal framework applicable to the different categories of third-country nationals and facilitates their travel within the European Union. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which extends the scope of the previous directives.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Europe must continue to attract students, academics and researchers from third countries to its universities.  It is therefore necessary to improve their reception and stay conditions. This is the purpose of this new legislation which will allow, for example, students or researchers to stay at least 9 more months in Europe to work, or set up a business there, and which will promote student exchange programmes.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. To live up to its ambition, the Eu must invest heavily in innovation, to boost growth and create jobs, while maintaining and solidifying its social model. It is in the light of his demands that I support this proposal. It aims to welcome highly qualified people into the Union. Tomorrow a student will have the opportunity to come to Europe more easily, to have greater mobility in the Union and he will be offered the opportunity to stay 12 months in the Union in order to find a job in the territory that welcomed him.  The more favourable conditions available to researchers, in terms of family reunification and which allow them to continue their research in other Member States than the one that provided them with their residence permit, should encourage the arrival of new scientists. I welcome the promotion of the European social model with the status offered to au pairs and unpaid trainees, a fragile and exploitable category. The EU is true to its model, both in its economic ambition and its social vocation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion to reject this European and immigrationist regulation on family reunification, the right to stay to look for a job or to start a business, for researchers and students. In addition, the "brain drain" is encouraged at the expense of developing countries that suffer from it. More generally, this text undermines the sovereignty of Member States, which should be able to conduct their own policy on these fundamental issues.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided not to support this report and vote against it. A stronger and clearer framework of rules and requirements must work effectively both ways to allow for some academic exchanges and not undermine the opportunities of EU citizens to compete across the EU.  The effect of too high inflow can be seen most strongly in countries with the lowest development indicators, where students still do not have enough opportunities to benefit from stock and other academic programs. We must focus first on improving the EU's existing internal challenges before we think globally. I feel that some concerns have not yet been addressed strongly enough in this Directive.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a mockery that migration from outside the Union is a source of influx of highly skilled people. Young people in the Member States face serious problems of unemployment and access to the specialised labour market. Especially in Greece and the countries of the South, undergraduate and postgraduate graduates are forced either to flee their home countries or to work undeclared, uninsured and uncertain about the future. Illegal immigrants are already a time bomb for Europe and a direct threat to the national security and social cohesion of the states. It is not necessary for scientists to be burdened with their families, as is put forward in the report for a vote.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. "To this report, the EFDD and the ENF tabled amendments to reject the report, thereby dismissing the Council's position and concluding the procedure by facilitating the entry of third-country nationals to the EU for study, research, volunteering, student exchange and as an au pair. The Centre Party and I stand for openness both within and to the EU, and that is why it is obvious to support these opportunities.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Directive provides for the possibility for students to remain at least nine months after the completion of research or studies in order to seek employment or set up a business. The new Directive also lays down the conditions for entry and residence in EU Member States and the rights of third-country nationals for research, studies, training or voluntary activities in the European Voluntary Service. The new Directive also includes provisions on mobility within the EU in order to facilitate the completion of part of research or studies in another Member State, and on the right of family members to accompany researchers.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. It undermines the sovereignty of Member States, which should be able to carry out their own policy in this area. This text is also immigrationist (family reunification, right to stay to look for work or start a business), and favours the "brain drain" at the expense of developing countries.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 The opportunities and benefits offered by the research and innovation sectors need to be supported not only through investment but also through clear and binding rules governing the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, study, traineeship, volunteering, pupil exchange programmes or educational projects, and au pair placement. In ensuring fair and uniform treatment of these categories of persons by the Member States, the foundations are created for the promotion of social, cultural and economic relations which make it possible to circulate and transfer knowledge and skills. Certain rules for the formation of human capital must also aim at cooperation with third countries, benefit both the countries of departure and the countries of arrival and eliminate any risk linked to the generation of situations of exploitation and discrimination.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a second reading report on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, study, training, volunteering, student exchange programmes, educational projects and au pair placement. Although timidly, this report presents positive aspects. The provisions introduced improve the current situation. Examples include better job search conditions, improved mobility, the creation of a job seeker authorisation that extends the conditions of residence and entry into the European Union of members of the researchers' families. We support the possibility of third-country residents being able to enter, reside and work in the European Union, and we believe that they can do so with conditions of dignity.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The present Directive meets the needs identified in the reports on the implementation of the previous two Directives in order to remedy the shortcomings. It is also important to ensure legal certainty and, in particular, to provide a single legal framework for different groups of persons coming into the European Union from third countries. Existing provisions are important to be simplified and included in a single instrument, and the directive should also aim to strengthen people-to-people contacts, especially in relation to countries within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy or to the European Union's strategic partners. Migration for the purposes set out in this Directive will promote the creation and acquisition of knowledge and skills, and this Directive should also make the European Union more attractive as a place for research and innovation, thereby achieving EU progress in strengthening overall competitiveness and growth. The provisions of this Directive are without prejudice to the competence of Member States to regulate the scope of admission of third-country nationals for the purpose of carrying out work, but to achieve the best possible conditions at European Union level, in accordance with the principle of proportionality.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a mockery that migration from outside the Union is a source of influx of highly skilled people. Young people in the Member States face serious problems of unemployment and access to the specialised labour market. Especially in Greece and the countries of the South, undergraduate and postgraduate graduates are forced either to flee their home countries or to work undeclared, uninsured and uncertain about the future. Illegal immigrants are already a time bomb for Europe and a direct threat to the national security and social cohesion of the states. It is not necessary for scientists to be burdened with their families, as is put forward in the report for a vote. For the above reasons I am voting in favour of report A8-0166/2016.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is fundamental to make the conditions of entry of third-country nationals as simple and harmonised as possible, and to strengthen provisions on the right for students to work part-time while studying, and the right for students and researchers to remain after completing their studies for an 18 months period. At a time of negative news stories concerning migration, this Directive is a welcome step forward with regard to legal migration for students, researchers and other groups of young people. We need to see more legal migration instruments at EU level to tap into the great positive potential of migration. The broadening of the scope, the provisions on mobility, the provisions on working hours and allowing students and researchers to stay after completion of their studies or research are all elements which I support and will keep fighting for. I am satisfied with their inclusion in the final compromise text.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we regulate the conditions of entry and residence in the EU of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, studies, pupil exchange, remunerated and unremunerated training, voluntary service and au pairing. The document is balanced, allows third-country nationals to acquire skills and knowledge through a period of training in Europe and supports cooperation with third countries. It sets clear rights and duties for all people who wish to enter and study or train in the EU.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the second reading of the report in general. The UNION must be competitive on the world market, while at the same time ensuring safeguards and equal treatment for talented young people from third countries. Similar directives should lead to a strengthening of the Union's overall competitiveness and growth rate, while creating jobs that contribute more to GDP growth.  The proposal will facilitate and simplify mobility within the Union for students and researchers, in particular erasmus mundus or marie curie programme participants. These programmes are an important component of a responsible European education policy.  The proposal provides that a long-stay visa or residence permit should be issued to applicants who fulfil all reception conditions in one of the Member States. This should be reviewed in the light of these events. Furthermore, in the light of the current migratory pressures, I cannot support the statements that Europe increasingly needs to rely on immigration in order to fill jobs and ensure economic growth.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation as it is necessary to regulate the entry and residence of non-EU citizens who want to settle in the EU for reasons which can add significant value to European society. I believe that we must take into account and value the opportunities they can bring to our young people, which can be enriched by the experiences of other young people from third countries and the impetus that this can bring to the innovation of the European economy.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation on the directive "Conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for certain purposes", an important achievement that identifies the positive value of legal migration, giving students, researchers and other groups of young people arriving in Europe for exchange programmes between schools or educational projects, volunteering or training, greater legal certainty, expanding the scope of the existing directives. I believe that Europe must continue to give strong signals in this regard and to demonstrate a solid commitment to the protection of human rights.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement reached between Parliament and the Council on the adoption of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, study, traineeship, volunteering, pupil exchange programmes or educational projects and au pair placement. The European Parliament has today voted by a large majority for a measure with a great impact on the competitiveness of the European Union, providing not only an important opportunity for students and young professionals to better develop their professional and training skills and experiences, but also by placing immigration within a legal framework that fills a demographic and economic gap within the European labour market. I am sure that, thanks to this legislative result of the EP, European universities will be more attractive and able to develop even more ambitious plans and projects to ensure the highest quality of studies and research in Europe and in the world. Finally, I agree with the rapporteur, Mrs Wikstom, that this directive be transposed into the national laws of the Member States as soon as possible, so as to ensure that the rule is fully applicable throughout the EU and to preserve the spirit of the European legislator.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Directive on the entry and residence of third-country nationals for research or study purposes, for completing an internship, for participating in voluntary service or student exchange programmes and for the pursuit of an au pair activity – and rejected its rejection. The area is important, especially for young people. We need better cross-border rules to facilitate this.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Mobility scheme promotes the development of students and researchers. At the same time, these young, creative minds give the Union a decisive advantage in the areas of competitiveness, economic growth and the promotion of innovation and development. It also maintains the attractiveness of Europe's universities and universities and prevents students and researchers, as the top links in education policy, from transmitting their knowledge to other countries outside the EU.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ It is extremely important that the EU moves towards enhancing safer and legal routes to Europe; Labour MEPs support the text as it represents a great added value to managed migration particularly in context of the current migration crisis. However, it is important to remember that this report will not impact UK immigration policy concerning third-country nationals as the UK has an opt-out of EU Justice and Home Affairs measures.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against the two amendments to the whole tabled by two political groups, which would have led to the rejection of the Council's position and, consequently, the decay of the legislative proposal.  We understand that this report contains very positive aspects for people wishing to carry out their higher education or research in the EU.  This is a second reading and was approved in the committee and there was no vote in plenary.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this directive because there are obvious improvements in mobility in the EU and the working conditions of researchers, students and their families.  For the first time we have common rules for au pair work, and also volunteers are included in this directive. Students will be able to work 15 hours a week instead of 10 hours a week, as it was so far. Researchers can work for 6 months instead of 3 months. All citizens have the right to remain in an EU country for 9 months after the end of the activity for which they have come. The Directive provides for intra-mobility which prevents Member States from blocking it.  Au pair is a cultural exchange program that offers people the chance to do something new and at the same time remunerated.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In writing. I voted strongly in favour of this directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, education, training, volunteering and student exchange programmes. The reception of researchers, entrepreneurs, and students from third countries is an important factor in the competitiveness of member countries, and on a smaller scale, for the Union. Thanks to this directive, all these nationals will be able to stay an additional 9 months to apply for work or set up their business and their close family members will be able to benefit from freedom of movement and the right to work within the Community area. In other words, this directive makes the European Union more attractive to people whose contributions are fully involved in the development of our societies and economies.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it represents a great added value to managed migration particularly in context of the current migration crisis. This report will not impact UK immigration policy concerning third-country nationals as the UK has an opt-out of EU Justice and Home Affairs measures.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. The experience of implementing the current regulations reveals that all too often students and researchers from third countries face unnecessary administrative obstacles to attending school or doing research in the EU. I therefore voted in favour of a revision of the current rules. This redesign allows, first of all, to encompass a wider number of categories so far little or not framed. The new rules are also accompanied by a strengthening of rights, particularly in the area of employment and mobility.  For example, students and researchers will be able to stay in the host Member State at least 9 months after completing their studies or contracts, in order to look for work or start a business. In this way, we are strengthening the international openness and attractiveness of the European area of education and research. Our old continent needs youth and attractiveness... even if sometimes he ignores it. While there is still a long way to go for the adoption of a truly common and truly comprehensive migration policy, these new provisions send a positive signal in the current context of crisis. They are in line with the progressive vision that we Socialists and Democrats are advocating for the opening of legal and safe paths.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the recommendation of a directive. The European Parliament and the Commission consider that provisions of this directive regarding the right of every member state to reject the application should not be seen as setting a precedent for legal migration measures in the future.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, even though Ireland decided not to opt into the recast directive for a number of reasons. These reasons include that 1. The proposal conflicts with some national policies for example the internationalisation of education 2. The proposal has the potential to undermine the state immigration controls and 3. The UK is not participating in the proposal. There is a recital in the proposal that Ireland is not bound by the directive. However, I was happy to support the proposal as it provides volunteers, researchers and au pairs that have previously been open to exploitation in this area with legal protection. Furthermore, it allows us to foster instead of losing our most skilled, researchers and intellects who are responsible for attracting innovation and R&D investment, that can substantially contribute to the future growth of our economy.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote as Ireland will not opt in to this agreement.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The report aims to adopt a directive establishing study and research stays of third-country nationals in the EU in order to meet the overarching strategic objective of competitiveness, growth and the provision of employment opportunities. Specifically, it lays down general rules for researchers, students and volunteers from third countries in the EU. During the trial period, it was made clear that only highly qualified researchers and students with sufficient financial resources can benefit from this directive.  As this, as well as almost all the other concerns of the ECR Group, were taken into account in the trialogue negotiations between Parliament, the Council and the Commission, I agree with this report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I supported the agreement simplifying the admission requirements for researchers and students because I considered that guarantees were in place to encourage the attractiveness of "brains" in Europe while limiting the risks of illegal immigration. Thus, Member States retain control over their immigration since this directive does not affect the freedom of States to set the annual entry volume of foreign nationals into their territory. In addition, applicants, in order to benefit from the benefits of this directive, must be able to demonstrate that they have sufficient resources to do so as not to use the national social protection system. Finally, researchers and students are allowed to remain in the country of residence at the expiry of the study or research agreement for up to nine months provided they prove after three months that they have a real chance of finding a job or that they are starting a business. As a result of bureaucracy, French universities are losing a lot of talent to British and American universities. I believe that this directive is a tool for the development and visibility of our universities and research centres on the international stage.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report. The EU should offer more migration opportunities for young individuals, such as students or researchers. Migration can be a constructive tool as long as the security of the Union’s citizens is first considered.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against amendments by the EFDD and ENF group to the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a directive from Parliament and the Council on the conditions for entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purpose of research, study, student exchange, paid and unpaid training, volunteering and work for flat and food, as they would reject the Council's position. The existing rules for individual groups are not sufficiently clear, and there are some problems in resolving applicants' applications. I believe that the European Union faces serious demographic and economic challenges, and therefore it is necessary to improve the system and conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP MEP’s have voted in favour of our group’s rejection amendment which calls for the council position to be rejected and the procedure to be closed. UKIP believes that it is not the competency of the European Union to create and manage entry requirements for third country nationals into the Union. We believe that this is a decision that sovereign national governments should have the ability to decide.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 This Directive resonates with the EU's objective of attracting skilled and capable workers, researchers or students from third countries to its Member States who can benefit the European economy and fill labour market gaps. The text presents clearer and simpler conditions for both the entry of third-country nationals into the EU and their subsequent residence and constitutes a harmonised European system that will apply in all Member States. I believe that talented students or workers from outside the EU can help Member States improve their competitiveness on the world stage, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. The aim of the directive is to simplify administrative procedures and admission requirements for foreign researchers and students in order to attract these young talents to Europe. I therefore voted in favour of this text, which ensures the balance between the competences of the Member States and the simplification of the lives of these categories of nationals. Indeed, it is important for the EU to invest more in research and development in order to attract the best engineers and prevent them from going to Work Elsewhere after their training in European universities.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This vote is a recommendation for second reading. Instead of a final vote, identical amendments by the EFDD and the ENF are voted on, according to which the Council's position should not be adopted. I agree with these amendments.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ It is extremely important that the EU moves towards enhancing safer and legal routes to Europe. I therefore supported the text as it represents a great added value to managed migration particularly in context of the current migration crisis. This report will not impact UK immigration policy concerning third-country nationals as the UK has an opt-out of EU Justice and Home Affairs measures.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: Writing. \u2012 This Directive summarises the conditions for admission of third-country nationals in the EU for periods of more than 3 months for research, study, pupil exchanges, paid and unpaid training, voluntary services and au pair activities. For the first time, the Directive lays down the general principle that an applicant who fulfils both general and specific reception conditions must be accepted by the Member State where the application for residence or long-stay visa was lodged. The Directive also defines the mandatory and optional grounds for refusal, refusal or non-extension of a residence permit or long-stay visa. The Directive guarantees the right to work or study or otherwise be educated. At the end of the stay for the purpose for which the residence permit was issued, the applicant also has the opportunity to find a job for a specified period of time. For certain categories of third-country nationals, access to the labour market for family members is also provided for and mobility between EU Member States is addressed. I believe that the directive can make a significant contribution to the desired migration to EU countries, and I cannot help but remember the successful programmes of central and eastern European countries that have dealt with training, study and traineeship issues more than 50 years ago. If this directive results in an improvement in the status of desirable migrants in EU countries at least to the level reached in the 1970s in the socialist countries of the time, we can only welcome the proposal.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The report aims to adopt a directive establishing study and research stays of third-country nationals in the EU in order to meet the overarching strategic objective of competitiveness, growth and the provision of employment opportunities. Specifically, it lays down general rules for researchers, students and volunteers from third countries in the EU. During the trial period, it was made clear that only highly qualified researchers and students with sufficient financial resources can benefit from this directive.  As this, as well as almost all the other concerns of the ECR Group, were taken into account in the trialogue negotiations between Parliament, the Council and the Commission, I agree with this report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I am really very happy to be able to support the European Parliament's legislative resolution of 11 May 2016 on the Council's position at first reading on the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purpose of research, study, traineeship, voluntary service, pupil exchange programmes or educational projects and au pair activities. This legislation should prevent, for example, Czech au pairs from being perceived as second-class citizens in third countries and thus not having rights that fall to other foreign workers simply because their work is temporary.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – It is interesting that the EU leadership has no substantial results in solving the unemployment rate of young graduates in Europe of more than 20%, while enthusiastically importing additional graduates and graduates from third countries. It is impermissible to further disrupt the social fabric of EU countries, but it is also grossly unethical to accelerate the brain drain from third countries, so that only the remittance of the proposal is the viable option.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. We live in an continuously progressing world where borders are beginning to narrow. The recommendation to vote today aims to simplify and, at the same time, regulate the mobility of third-country nationals to European territory for the purposes of research, study, traineeship, volunteering, pupil exchange programmes and au pair placement. In so doing, the aim of the proposal is to encourage the circulation of brains and maintain cooperation with third countries. The directive involves a number of regulatory innovations which will undoubtedly lead to a better stay for the people concerned, and a more profitable European market, which will be able to enjoy the skills of these categories. For a more united Europe, and for the greater opportunities that will ensue, I am voting in favour of the proposal to simplify the method of mobility of the categories mentioned.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the ENL group's motion to reject the entry and residence requirements of third-country nationals for research, education, training, volunteering, student exchange and au pair work. It is a directive that undermines the sovereignty of member states, which should be able to carry out their own policy in this area. This text is also immigrationist: it encourages family reunification, the right to stay to look for work or start a business, and promotes a brain drain at the expense of developing countries, which will further amplify migration flows to Europe.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. My vote is on the proposal to reject it in the form of an amendment to the text. It proposes to extend the possibilities and conditions of residence to new categories of third-country nationals, including students and paid employees. In doing so, it creates all the necessary conditions for immigration (authorization of family reunification, right to start a business). It increases the risk of brain drain from developing countries to the EU. As a result, Member States are no longer in control of their immigration policy. I am therefore very much in favour of the vote to reject this text. That is why I voted for it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. In the current situation where the European authorities are implementing migration policies of such an aggressive nature at our borders, they present at the same time this directive of a marked elitist character for the migration of members with the highest academic qualifications. Throughout the negotiation, our proposal to make this administrative category extensive to hugely discriminated sectors such as au pairs has been ignored, as well as maintaining the possibility that states may not accept a candidate without giving any explanation, which could lead to discrimination on the source. Even so, we voted against the rejection amendment which was being raised as we understand that despite these important weaknesses, any legislation that favours freedom of movement and migration with rights is positive.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. In recent years there has been a large increase in the flow of qualified professionals who choose Europe as their destination to establish their training or professional activity. This report was born with the aim of expressly determining the entry and residency requirements of researchers and students. The main purpose of this directive is to facilitate and simplify mobility within the EU in such a way as to enhance the migration of talented people, harnessing the potential of such students and researchers once their studies or research projects in that third country have come to an end.  Among the different measures taken, we should highlight the fact that Member States will have the possibility of issuing visas for long-term stays or residence permits.   All the measures proposed in that report shall be carried out in compliance with the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity at all times.  In my view, this report must be adopted as it will increase the exercise of mobility within the EU and establish a clear and transparent framework for existing rules.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The report aims to adopt a directive establishing study and research stays of third-country nationals in the EU in order to meet the overarching strategic objective of competitiveness, growth and the provision of employment opportunities. Specifically, it lays down general rules for researchers, students and volunteers from third countries in the EU. During the trial period, it was made clear that only highly qualified researchers and students with sufficient financial resources can benefit from this directive.  As this, as well as almost all the other concerns of the ECR Group, were taken into account in the trialogue negotiations between Parliament, the Council and the Commission, I agree with this report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion to reject it. I am in support of flexible travel for traineeships, studies, research, etc., but I am against restricting member states' rights. I consider the restriction of the right of Member States not to allow entry to a third-country citizen to be an interference with the immigration policy of the Czech Republic.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. At first reading, the Council adopted a decision on the conditions for entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purpose of research, study, student exchange, paid and unpaid training, volunteering and work for flat and food.  According to the interpretation of the European Parliament and the Commission, Article 20(2) of that Directive allows Member States to reject applications only on a case-by-case basis and taking into account the specific circumstances in which a third-country national is located and the principle of proportionality, as well as on the basis of evidence or serious and objective reasons. Where Member States require third-country nationals to pay compensation, they should be proportionate to the purpose of residence and should not constitute an obstacle to the objectives of the Directive. Parliament also considers that when a third-country national pays this fee, he or she should be entitled to a refund. Third-country nationals should provide all information relating to the procedure, including general documentation of tests, research programmes and specific information on the rights and obligations of applicants. The Directive focuses on improving the legislative framework that will apply to third-country nationals and granting them residency for the purpose of studying, student exchange, practice, training, volunteering and scientific research, so I did not support the proposal to reject the Council's position on this Directive.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The unification of common principles of immigration policy for the purpose of work, research, voluntary service and education of persons from third countries will promote the circulation of experience, skills and education in the Union and can be an important factor in economic development and competitiveness. The establishment of clear and uniform rules and requirements for the granting of entry and residence will increase the legal protection of these persons, provide them with guarantees during their stay, which will be known to them in advance. This will simplify and simplify procedures and eliminate unnecessary administrative obstacles also between Member States and third countries. In a time of globalisation, we will thus promote the exchange and circulation of expertise, experience and skills, which will help the Union economy and economy.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. In recent years, Europe's working-age population has virtually ceased to grow. In this context, Europe needs to strengthen its position on the world stage in the fields of research and innovation, including by attracting new talent. The text presented to us today will allow an overhaul of the rules on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, study, training and volunteering, in particular, on European territory. To be more precise, the new rules proposed in this text also aim to simplify procedures for visa or residence permit applications, as well as to offer increased rights to researchers and trainees from third countries. The Union must give itself the means to be a magnet for research and innovation by acquiring a vast pool of talent from member countries but also from third countries; I therefore vote in favour of this text.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 Referring to my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/5/2016, I would point out that I abstained in voting on the amendment rejecting the Council's position of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purpose of research, studies, traineeships, voluntary service, exchanges of pupils or educational programmes and the employment of internal unpaid assistants, because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. This text, which passes at second reading, does not call for a final vote. Its aim is to strengthen existing provisions for new categories of third-country nationals. It lists the conditions of residence in the territory of Member States in these categories: limit to 15 hours of work allowed for students, nine months' residence permit for the search for jobs of students and researchers, etc. This text further strips Member States of their prerogatives in terms of migration flows. Member States will now only be able to reject an application on the following grounds: (i) if the host structure does not meet the conditions set out in the applicable law or convention; (ii) if the national concerned does not stay in the territory of the Member State in the framework described in his application for authorisation. In addition, Member States will only be able to restrict labour immigration to this category of nationals in exceptional circumstances.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. – The negative voting was taken in consideration with the Italian EPP Delegation and the position of the EPP Group.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe is lag behind in attracting young researchers and workers who could make a key contribution to growth. The report we have voted on today is a step in the right direction, facilitating the arrival and permanence of 'brains'. I would like the Member States to transpose the directive quickly, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the proposal to adopt the Directive on the entry and residence requirements of third-country nationals for research, studies, internships, volunteering, student exchange programmes or educational projects and au pair placement. I am sure that the new legislation will facilitate the steps to allow these exchanges, which will favour both people from third countries who come to the EU to improve their training, and the EU itself, which will be enriched by the arrival of people who are very talented to contribute to the European project.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the new directive will enable European businesses and society to benefit from the knowledge acquired by researchers and students. The new changes will make it easier for third-country students and researchers to stay for at least 9 months. after the completion of their studies or studies in order to find a job or set up a business. The new directive also provides for certain rules relating to the entry and stay of trainees, volunteers, pupils participating in exchange programmes and au pairs in EU Member States.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This directive aims to improve and facilitate the admission procedures of third-country nationals who come to do research, studies, internships or exchanges in the EU. It has already been voted on for the first time. It was then referred to the Council of the EU to renegotiate, among other things, the categories of foreign nationals that could be covered. The directive now includes unpaid trainees, to avoid the "real risk of exploitation". But not the au pairs. It offers the right to stay in the EU within 9 months of the end of research or studies. It allows the mobility of these nationals within the EU. But since this text does not guarantee quite the same rights in the labour market, it still allows social dumping and the plundering of brains. Under these conditions, I vote against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Entry requirements are extended to new categories. Member States must have the opportunity to decide for themselves on this subject. The text is immigrationist with, among other things, the mention of family reunification. The immediate consequence of implementing a program like this is above all the brain drain of developing countries. I am against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to improve the provisions applicable to third-country nationals who are researchers, higher education students, secondary school students, unpaid trainees and volunteers, as well as to apply common provisions to two new categories of third-country nationals, i.e. paid trainees and au pairs. Its overall objective is to support social, cultural and economic relations between the EU and third countries, promote the transfer of skills and skills and encourage competitiveness, and at the same time to establish safeguards to ensure fair treatment of these categories of third-country nationals.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, as it seeks to establish a clear set of rules for Member States when it comes to assessing applications for entry and residence of third-country nationals for purposes of research, studies, training, voluntary service, pupil exchange schemes or educational projects and au pairing.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this directive setting out new rules on the residence of third-country nationals wishing to travel to the EU for research, education, training, volunteering, student exchange and au pair work. The simplification and harmonisation of entry and residence rules for these categories of people brings real added value to European policy and the attractiveness of the Union for these third-country nationals.  Facilitating the rules governing their movement within the Union and extending the periods during which they can stay on European territory after their studies or research will enable them and the Union to make the most of the opportunities offered by their stay in Europe.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The working age in the European Union has practically stopped and the situation is even expected to deteriorate in the coming years. To counterbalance this labour shortage, immigration from third countries is one of the sources of skilled people. In particular, the European Union needs to attract students and researchers from non-member countries. The acquisition of the skills and knowledge of third-country nationals in the European Union also promotes economic, cultural and social relations with third countries. I consider it beneficial to promote the transfer of skills and know-how, as well as competitiveness. However, this has to do with the risk of abuse to which they may be subjected, as there is currently no clear legal framework to regulate the issue.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the report on the entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, studies, training, volunteering, pupil exchange and au paring because at a time of negative news stories concerning migration, this Directive is a welcome step forward with regard to legal migration for students, researchers and other groups of young people.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to the European Parliament and the Council a directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, studies, practice, voluntary service, student exchange programmes or educational projects and au pair activities. Parliament has established its position on the proposal at first reading. The Greek Parliament has tabled a reasoned opinion that the draft legislative act is incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. The Council subsequently established its position at first reading. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament agree at second reading with the Council's position at first reading and thus adopt the directive in accordance with the Council's position. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I endorse the joint position of the European Parliament and the Commission on the rejection of Article 20(2)(f) of this Directive by enabling Member States to reject a request only on a case-by-case basis and taking into account the specific circumstances of the third-country national and the principle of proportionality, on the basis of serious and objective evidence or grounds. It also provides that the Commission shall ensure that Member States apply this provision in accordance with that interpretation when transposition of the Directive, and shall thereby inform the European Parliament and the Council in the framework of their obligations under Article 39. I would argue, as the joint statement by the European Parliament and the Commission states, that the inclusion of this provision should not set a precedent for future mechanisms on legal migration.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text goes to second reading, so there is no final vote.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's proposal on this text on the revision of the "third country nationals" directives (conditions of entry and residence for research, study, student exchange, training, volunteering and au pair work). The aim of this text is to merge the directive on the reception of students and the directive on the reception of researchers in order to simplify administrative procedures. This text does not affect the sovereignty of Member States, which must take precedence over migration policy: I have notably supported the provision which guarantees Member States the right to set a volume of entry of foreign nationals into their territory.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has been facing major demographic and economic challenges in recent years, in particular growth and employment that are struggling to restart, an ageing population and significant migratory flows from Africa and the Middle East. With this directive, the European Union, through legal immigration channels, is stimulating the investment of resources and energy to attract the skills and knowledge of scholars and researchers from non-EU third countries, including trainees, volunteers and peers. Also from the perspective of the Europe 2020 strategy, it encourages the circulation of 'brains' and competences, in order to improve and strengthen the European socio-economic fabric as well: that is, the best response to stimulate the engine of growth and also to encourage our fellow researchers to remain in the EU. I therefore welcome the amendments made by Parliament at second reading and supported by the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Socialists, especially with regard to the allocation of ad hoc funds to support those who choose to come to Europe, as well as the extension to twelve months of the period granted at the end of the study experience for those who want to stay there to find work, to build a life and a family in Europe.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on the entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, study, internship, volunteering, pupil exchange programmes and au pair placement. The directive being studied by the Commission should reorder the existing directives in this field, harmonising them and improving the conditions of third-country nationals heading for the European Union. The report is interesting because it clarifies how the new directive expressly aims to strengthen the protection of students' right to part-time work during study visits and their right to remain on European soil until a further eighteen months after the end of their agreed period. This report is important because it has already seen broad convergence during the debate in committee thanks to its ambition to continue along the path of developing a central theme for the future of the Union: knowledge and cultural exchange. In this age of borders and walls being built, the European Union must show itself capable of promoting, today more than before, the cross-border mobility of people.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the legal certainty of talented young people and help them to continue their studies and research. It is important that European universities are attractive, that their quality and reputation are recognised in the world. The work of volunteers is of the utmost importance as they bring added value to society as a whole. It is important to ensure their legal situation with guarantee rules. However, this Directive should not be the subject of hidden and opposed migration policies.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission presented in March 2013 a legislative proposal for a directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purpose of research, studies, and training. I have voted for this report that will allow Member States to reject an application only on a case-by-case basis and taking into account the specific circumstances of the third-country national and the principle of proportionality and on the basis of evidence or serious and objective reasons.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Directive lays down the conditions for the admission, entry and residence of third-country nationals to the territory of the Member States for research, studies, exchange of pupils, vocational training, paid or unpaid, voluntary services or au pair work. Member States shall be authorised to reject an application only on a case-by-case basis and taking into account the specific circumstances of each third-country national and the principle of proportionality and on the basis of serious and objective evidence or reasons.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation approving the Council's position, thus concluding the procedure for adopting changes to the Directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, studies, training, voluntary services and student exchange programmes, educational projects and au pair work. I also support with today's vote the joint declaration of the European Parliament and of the Council attached to this recommendation, clarifying how and how to apply Article 20(2)(f) of that Directive, which clearly sets out the reasons for rejecting a request from a third-country national.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported an agreement with the Council that improves mobility conditions within the EU, including access to job search after completing studies or research projects, and extends the scope of the Directive to au pairs and paid trainees. I consider it beneficial that students will be given the right to work at least 20 hours a week from the first year of their stay and, once their studies/research have been completed, students and researchers should be allowed to remain in the territory for 12 months in order to find employment opportunities. As regards procedural safeguards, Member States will be obliged to decide on applications within 60 days and within 30 days respectively for Erasmus Mundus and Marie Curie participants.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I have spoken out against this report because it could lead to further unrelated immigration and also wants to promote family reunification for scientists, etc. At the same time, I do not see to what extent the increase in au pairs will have a positive impact on the EU's scientific location.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to improve conditions for the entry of students and researchers from third countries and to try to prevent their exploitation.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. I believe that each Member State must be able to decide for itself to reject or satisfy the application made by a third-country national for the purposes of entry and residence research, studies, pupil exchange, remunerated or unremunerated training, voluntary service and participation in the Au pair programme. Only the State itself, taking into account its current situation and national interest, can properly control the entry, residence and expulsion of aliens iš̌ its territory and prevent possible abuse. However, it is essential to ensure that the specific circumstances, the principle of proportionality and existing evidence are duly taken into account when examining applications on a case-by-case basis.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is facing major structural changes of a demographic nature. The working-age population has practically stopped growing. An immediate response to this crisis is certainly highly qualified migration, including students and researchers from countries outside the EU. I have chosen to vote in favour of the Council's position at second reading because I believe that action is urgently needed in this area in order to harmonise the legal framework in this area between the Member States and to extend this legislation to trainees from third countries.  Promoting contacts between peoples, mobility, in particular of students, trainees and researchers, leads to the transfer of knowledge, know-how and promotes competitiveness. Concrete action is therefore needed to fully implement Article 79 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which calls for a common immigration policy to ensure the effective management of migratory flows and the fair treatment of third-country nationals who are regularly resident in the Member States. We therefore call for greater commitment and coordination in the management of visas and on the issue of procedural rights and guarantees, because the rules in force are not clear enough and binding enough.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The fact that the EU's 'smart borders' are adapted according to the needs of monopolies for cheap labour comes to be confirmed by the directive adopted by the European Parliament. While Dublin is strengthening, thousands of stranded people remain in Greece and refugees face closed borders, deportations. The EU with this directive unsymed and opens borders according to the needs of business groups, choosing: researchers, students, i.e. tomorrow's skilled workers who need European monopolies to strengthen their position in competition with other American, Asian, etc. monopolies and those who will offer cheap work for capital, such as in the context of "unpaid and paid internships" , "voluntary service" and "internal unpaid assistants", in the name of "acquiring work experience" and "promoting contacts between peoples ... and the opportunity for third-country nationals to improve their language skills." As long as the economy is profit-based, workers will move inside and outside the EU for the interests of monopolies. The peoples have experience and must use it by overturning, through their struggle, the power of monopolies and by building a socialised economy that puts at the heart of meeting their needs and not profit.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEP’s have voted in favour of our group’s rejection amendment which calls for the council position to be rejected and the procedure to be closed. UKIP believes that it is not the competency of the European Union to create and manage entry requirements for third country nationals into the Union. We believe that this is a decision that sovereign national governments should have the ability to decide.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas Article 79 TFEI states that it is up to the Union to develop a common immigration policy capable of organising migratory flows by allowing regularly resident third-country nationals to enjoy fair treatment. Following this mandate, the proposal concerning the provisions relating to researchers, students, pupils, unpaid trainees and volunteers meets the needs created by the Europe 2020 programme. In view of this, I do not intend to support the positions taken by my fellow Members and therefore vote against it.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I strongly believe that education and R&D are of paramount importance for the development of every country within the EU, therefore, we need to be constantly sustaining and improving our relationships with all countries that are willing to work together. I vote for the entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, studies, training, volunteering, pupil exchange and au paring to further strengthen our international relationships.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒The Title Recommendation proposes that Member States abolish the obligation of third-country nationals to provide proof of the dismal means of living or, alternatively, that the funds requested be proportionate to the purpose of residence and do not constitute an obstacle to the achievement of the objectives agreed by the Directive. Furthermore, the Recommendation requires that Member States of the Union clearly inform of the rules applicable to third-country nationals. It also proposes to extend the application of certain provisions of the Directive to other categories of persons.  Since the Recommendation seeks to facilitate the entry and residence of persons whose protection of rights is governed, to ensure the transparency of the procedure and to strengthen legal certainty, to promote the mobility of third-country nationals within the Territory of the Union, and to the resulting number of other positive effects resulting from its application, I support this Recommendation.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a second reading report on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, study, training, volunteering, student exchange programmes, educational projects and au pair placement. Although timidly, this report presents comparatively better positive aspects in relation to the current situation, such as the right of students to work, from 10 to 15 hours per week, the improvement of the mobility regime, the creation of a job search authorisation allowing students and researchers to remain for at least 9 months and the entry into the European Union of the family members of researchers. We support the possibility that residents of third countries can enter, reside and work in the European Union, and we believe that they can do so with conditions of dignity.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒Increasing the educational, cultural and tourism mobility of young people and fostering their inclusion in international exchange is one of the EU's priorities, as confirmed by the Europe 2020 Strategy and other strategies aimed at tackling the pressing issue of high youth unemployment in the EU.  Ensuring opportunities for mobility and international cooperation in the fields of science, education and youth work training contributes to the overall strengthening of democratic potential, social cohesion and the competitiveness of society. The stay of young people from third countries creates opportunities for non-formal learning with a European dimension, while youth associations strengthen capacity and achieve international cooperation, and therefore I supported the recommendation of Wikström.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 At second reading, I rejected the EFDD proposal because I consider it unfounded, and I support the text in the original negotiated text.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of this directive is to improve global competition for talent and to promote Europe as a centre of excellence in studies and training. Improving competitiveness, stimulating growth and job creation. The draft directive provides for common conditions of arrival and residence within the EU for researchers, students, apprentices and volunteers from third countries participating in the European Voluntary Service. More favourable rules on the right to work while studying in the EU were removed during the negotiation process. In addition, clearer and stricter rules have been introduced on the need to provide evidence of qualifications and sufficient financial resources while still being in the EU. I hereby supported the report.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This Recommendation sets out the position of the European Parliament (EP) with a view to the adoption of the Directive on the conditions of entry and residence of foreign citizens, students or au pairs for research, studies and exchange purposes. The agreement between the different EP political groups was reflected in the unanimous adoption of the proposal amending the existing legislation, introducing clear and binding criteria, in particular as regards the definition of visa procedures, (mobility) rights and procedural guarantees. On another level, and despite the reservations and reticence sums up raised by Article 20, the EP and the Council have, on the other hand, reached an agreement on the basis of rejection of an application by a third-country national where this is justified on the basis of evidence or serious and objective reasons. I would like to see this legislative resolution, it follows an annex which safeguards the application of this provision, in accordance with the interpretation of Parliament and the Council. In the light of the provisions, and because I believe that the Directive satisfies the dual objective of recognising and safeguarding the rights of paid trainees and au pairs, on the one hand, and favouring the objectives of European action on education, on the other hand, I voted in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. – UKIP MEP’s have voted in favour of our group’s rejection amendment which calls for the council position to be rejected and the procedure to be closed. UKIP believes that it is not the competency of the European Union to create and manage entry requirements for third country nationals into the Union. We believe that this is a decision that sovereign national governments should have the ability to decide.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this directive, which opens up new safe and legal routes to Europe. It will provide more legal certainty as well as simplified and harmonised common rules to attract certain categories of citizens from third countries to the EU, namely researchers, students, trainees, volunteers and au pairs. This text will help to strengthen openness to the world of Europe, by removing unnecessary administrative obstacles that had previously discouraged so many young talents from joining our continent. Students will be able to work up to fifteen hours a week, and their mobility within the Union will be facilitated, as for researchers. They will be able to be accompanied by their relatives, who will also have the right to travel to Europe and work. Above all, students and researchers will have the opportunity to stay for several months in their host Member State, at the end of their studies or contracts, in order to look for a job or start a business. This directive represents a step towards the creation of a unified European area for legal economic migration. These provide a positive response to the demographic and economic challenges we face, as well as invaluable added value for the future of our societies.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This Directive concerns the conditions for the entry and residence of foreign researchers and students into the European Union. One of the objectives is to make Europe more attractive in the areas of research and innovation, training or volunteering. You have to capture talent to increase competitiveness. The Directive provides for the possibility of staying in the EU country which has given authorisation for a period of at least 9 months to enable job search or business creation. It also provides for greater mobility within the Union and family monitoring. Let us remember that Europe spends only less of GDP on R&D compared to the US or Japan. This is also good support for legal immigration.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive to recast several Directives on the entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, studies, internships, volunteering, student exchange and au pair placement, bringing them into new regulation. The aim of this legislation is to give greater security to third-country nationals who come to the Union to carry out any of the activities envisaged, as well as to achieve a totally homogeneous system. Thanks to Parliament's requirements, both volunteers and trainees will fall within the scope of the Directive on a mandatory way, eliminating the possibility of optionally including au pair workers. In addition, intra-Community mobility of students and researchers has been improved and the minimum number of hours students can work part-time has been expanded, and the period during which students and researchers can remain in the Union after the end of the study or research period has been set at twelve months. The Union must continue to make progress on legal migration.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted harmonised rules this lunchtime to encourage foreign researchers and students to stay in the EU. The legislation also improves conditions for trainees, volunteers, young students and au pairs from non-European countries. The new rules merge two existing guidelines to ensure that students and researchers can stay at least nine months after completing their studies or research to find a job or start a business, which should allow Europe to benefit from their skills. Students and researchers will also have the opportunity to move more easily within the EU during their stay. Thus, in the future, they will not need to reapply for a visa, but only to inform the Member State in which they are travelling. The revised directive also gives status to trainees (paid or unpaid), apprentices, volunteers participating in European service and au pairs from third countries, who have so far been excluded from it. What I'm looking forward to! It should be noted that Member States will have two years to transpose the provisions into national law, after they are published in the Official Journal of the Union.
