name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 Third-country nationals working and studying in the European Union make an important contribution to strengthening europe's economic, intellectual and cultural potential. It is therefore essential to ensure that there is an appropriate opportunity to do so for everyone coming to the EU for mutually beneficial purposes, from narrow specialised scientists to Aur Pair nannies.  At the same time, we cannot allow the openness of the European Union to become a threat to the world. I agree with the provisions set out in the document on the legal conditions for the residence of third-country nationals in the EU. At the same time, I would even suggest that both the EU and the world as a whole are currently facing various new security challenges and therefore additional security measures, additional checks, especially for risk groups, should be tightened up.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. The European Union faces a significant demographic challenge as its working-age population has virtually ceased to grow. At the same time, it needs to strengthen its position on the international stage in the field of research and innovation. This directive will make the Union more attractive. It concerns researchers, students and trainees as well as, for the first time in a European text, au pairs.  The rules of admission and movement are harmonised and simplified so as not to deter those who want to travel to Europe from doing so. In addition, guarantees are made to strengthen the rights of young people on the move: students will be allowed to work a maximum of 15 hours per week, students and researchers will be able to stay in the host Member State at least 9 months after completing their studies or contracts in order to look for work or start a business. Researchers will now be able to be accompanied by family members; they will also have the right to travel within the European Union and work there during their stay. I supported this text by voting against the motion to reject it.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Recommendation refers to the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and the Council on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals whose purpose is to carry out research, studies, traineeships or voluntary service, or who are involved in student exchange projects. This Directive redefines some aspects relating to the entry and residence of foreign nationals, in line with the principle of simplification on the movement of persons in/from the EU, only in the situations referred to. Enabling the acquisition of skills and knowledge through a period of traineeship and/or study in Europe by third-country nationals will not only encourage "brain circulation", but also supports and closely supports cooperation with the countries from which those citizens come from. This proposal for a Directive also aims to implement rules to ensure, for example, that the citizens concerned can remain at least nine months after they have finished their activities in order to seek a job or develop a business, which will ensure a benefit to the EU of the skills acquired by them.  As I said earlier, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report expresses its opinion on an important directive, fully in line with the spirit of free movement within the area of the Countries of the Union and in line with the objective of strengthening cooperation with third countries. The directive aims to simplify and therefore encourage the entry and residence of third-country nationals into the European Union for research, study, internship, volunteering and training exchanges. In support of the Council's original proposal, I voted in favour of the text of the report.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against the two amendments to the whole tabled by two political groups, which would have led to the rejection of the Council's position and, consequently, the decay of the legislative proposal.  We understand that this report contains very positive aspects for people wishing to carry out their higher education or research in the EU.  This is a second reading and was approved in the committee and there was no vote in plenary.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of re-regulating the entry and residence of third-country nationals for research or study purposes, completing an internship, participating in a voluntary service, student exchange programmes or educational projects, or exercising an au pair, as this will allow us to make better and easier use of and retain the knowledge of the people we have trained in Europe. This group of people now has permission to stay in the EU for another nine months even after completing their study/working time. This gives them the opportunity to find a job here or to start their own business. We also facilitate travel within the EU and we enable family reunification and work permits for families accompanying a researching family member. Students from non-European countries now also have the opportunity to take up work for at least 15 hours a week.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. In the current situation where the European authorities are implementing migration policies of such an aggressive nature at our borders, they present at the same time this directive of a marked elitist character for the migration of members with the highest academic qualifications. Throughout the negotiation, our proposal to make this administrative category extensive to hugely discriminated sectors such as au pairs has been ignored, as well as maintaining the possibility that states may not accept a candidate without giving any explanation, which could lead to discrimination on the source. Even so, we voted against the rejection amendment which was being raised as we understand that despite these important weaknesses, any legislation that favours freedom of movement and migration with rights is positive.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 As a scientist and leader of multidisciplinary and international research teams, I am very sensitive to this subject. I believe that the doors are open to establishing conditions for entry and residence in the EU Member States. The rights of third-country nationals for research, study, training or volunteeractivities in the European Voluntary Service are also defined. It is also important to note that, after the completion of research or studies, foreign researchers and higher education students will be able to stay in the EU country which granted them a residence permit or long-stay visa for a period of at least nine months in order to seek employment or set up a business. I agree with the enthusiasm for this directive and I hope that Portugal does not need the two years foreseen for its transposition. I voted positively.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that it is extremely important that the EU moves towards enhancing safer routes into Europe. I supported this text as it represents a great added value to managed migration, particularly in the context of the current migration crisis. This report will not impact UK immigration policy concerning third-country nationals, as the UK has an opt-out of EU Justice and Home Affairs measures.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of a resolution unifying the rules applicable to the entry and residence of people from third countries into the EU who have arrived here for the purpose of study or research, I voted in favour of adopting this directive, in line with the position of my EKR faction. I am pleased that this proposal clarifies the rules not only for the activities of students and researchers at universities, but also applies to trainees, volunteers and, overall, non-EU pupils. This Directive thus establishes a system of conditions for their adoption, rules applicable to the procedure for residence permits and long-stay visas. It also regulates the overall rights of these third-country nationals on EU territory, bringing significant added value to our society.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The directive governing the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals arriving in the EU has been discussed since 2013. As cultural exchange is one of the cornerstones of understanding between countries, I supported this position of the Council. I believe that we should not place unnecessary obstacles on foreigners interested in studying, carrying out research, voluntary service or au pair services in the EU. Moreover, it is apparent from the draft regulation that these are mainly technical and administrative details which have hitherto made it difficult for certain categories of third-country nationals to obtain a residence permit. In particular, this Directive aims to improve the legal framework applicable to third-country nationals and to introduce new categories of applicants. The directive will compulsorily include students, researchers, trainees and volunteers, to which each Member State will be able to introduce its own measures with regard to pupils or au pair workers. There will no longer be a distinction between rem rewarded and unpaid trainees, on the other hand, there will be advantaged volunteers using the European Voluntary Service. Students or researchers will also be able to remain in the territory of a Member State for a period of up to nine months so that they can look for work there if they comply with the conditions laid down in the Directive. I hope that this text will contribute to reducing bureaucracy and simplifying residence for those interested from third countries.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The recast proposal combined the EU Council Directive on the conditions of entry of third-country nationals for the purposes of study, training, voluntary work, pupil exchanges and the EU Council Directive on the conditions of entry of third-country nationals for research purposes. Satisfactorily, the entry conditions also apply to trainees and also to au pairs, which extends the legal framework for the entry and residence of third-country nationals into the EU.  Although these conditions do not cover volunteers outside the European Voluntary Service, this is still a step forward compared to the previous directive. The new conditions would also improve the mobility regime for students and researchers. The former could only be moved with a simple notice instead of submitting the full application, while for others short-term mobility would be extended from three months to 180 days.  A novelty that gives family members of researchers the right to enter the EU, including the right to work and mobility alongside a researcher, is also welcome. At the same time, it also allows graduates and researchers to find a job or a job after completing their education or research. The recast proposal thus represents a positive extension of the scope of the rights of these persons, which is why I support it and voted against the amendment which proposed rejecting the Council's position.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The report aims to adopt a directive establishing study and research stays of third-country nationals in the EU in order to meet the overarching strategic objective of competitiveness, growth and the provision of employment opportunities. Specifically, it lays down general rules for researchers, students and volunteers from third countries in the EU. During the trial period, it was made clear that only highly qualified researchers and students with sufficient financial resources can benefit from this directive.  As this, as well as almost all the other concerns of the ECR Group, were taken into account in the trialogue negotiations between Parliament, the Council and the Commission, I agree with this report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Education is one of the decisive factors of innovation potential. The economic level of the state and the growth in labour productivity depend to a large extent on the level of preparation and skilled power and on its rational use. The directive creates the conditions for positive synergy, through which we can improve general mobility on the basis of qualifications.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 Article 20(f) of the Directive on conditions for entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purpose of researching, studying, student exchange, paid and unpaid training, volunteering and carrying out work for flat and food, allows Member States to reject applications from third-country nationals only in individual cases, taking into account the specific circumstances in which a third-country national is located and the principle of proportionality , as well as on the basis of evidence or serious and objective reasons. It is important to ensure that Member States transpose this Directive in a quality way and that it is used as an instrument to better control the entry of third-country nationals into EU Member States.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ It is extremely important that the EU moves towards enhancing safer and legal routes to Europe; Labour MEPs support the text as it represents a great added value to managed migration particularly in context of the current migration crisis. This report will not impact UK immigration policy concerning third-country nationals as the UK has an opt-out from EU Justice and Home Affairs measures.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒The European Parliament accepts the Council's position at first reading as well as the joint declaration by Parliament and the Council. According to the interpretation of the European Parliament and the Commission, Article 20(2) of this Directive allows Member States to reject applications only on a case-by-case basis and taking into account the specific circumstances in which a third-country national is located and the principle of proportionality, as well as on the basis of evidence or serious and objective reasons. The Commission will ensure that Member States implement this provision accordingly when transposing the Directive. I do not support the proposal to reject the Council's position, as I consider it to be a good solution for better control of the entry of third-country nationals into the Member States of the European Union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, study, pupil exchange, paid and unpaid training, voluntary work and au pair work.  The European Union is not in the best shape right now. In addition to all the problems with terrorism and refugees, we still face a high unemployment rate in some countries. In particular, member states should improve the conditions for trainees, students, pupils and volunteers. With this report, we are providing access, but at the same time we are not doing enough to prevent abuse.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Despite the positive elements of the report, which gives young students and researchers a direct right to freedom of movement and an increase in the hours of work that these young people are entitled to in parallel with their studies, the rights of internal unpaid assistants are not sufficiently guaranteed; For these reasons we have observed an abstention attitude.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Young people in the Member States face serious problems of unemployment and access to the specialised labour market. Especially in Greece and the countries of the South, undergraduate and postgraduate graduates are forced either to flee their home countries or to work undeclared, uninsured and uncertain about the future. Illegal immigrants are already a time bomb for Europe and a direct threat to the national security and social cohesion of the states. It is not necessary for scientists to be burdened with their families, as is put forward in the report for a vote.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal, given that it is an important and particularly topical element of the migration package put forward by the European Commission three years ago, before the refugee crisis came to an end. As a left-wing politician, I believe that one of the main positives of the legislation put forward is that the intended European legislation also covers the social and labour protection of vulnerable groups of typically young workers, such as trainees, childcare workers and volunteers. For this reason, I would also like to pay particular attention to implementation, because under migratory pressure, in the current political and economic situation in Europe, professionals and workers from third countries can easily become targets for anti-foreigner, racist, undemocratic sentiment in some Member States.  Of course, the single European legislation should not detract from the interests of European workers, but in my view we cannot allow such demagogy (in some places infrocited by the government) to play the most obvious role in terms of regulation or admission at Member State level.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The revision of this Directive extends the legal avenues for access to the EU and facilitates the conditions of entry of third-country nationals who wish to come to Europe for the study, traineeship, voluntary, exchange and au pair placement programmes. The text provides for the harmonisation of the conditions of entry and residence within the Union for these categories. However, Member States retain the right and not the obligation to apply the rules of the directive. The directive provides for important measures for researchers: such as the possibility of moving to the EU with fewer restrictions for research reasons, family members will also be able to accompany them and move within the EU. Finally, it will be possible for students and researchers to stop for nine months after the end of their studies in order to seek employment in Europe. We believe that the right to study should not encounter any bureaucratic obstacles or restrictions, so we voted in favour of the directive.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal concerns the extension of the scope of existing directives, providing more legal certainty for different groups of third-country nationals arriving in the European Union. At the same time, the initiative aims to introduce special provisions on the mobility of these groups within the Union. I believe that this Directive is a welcome step forward with regard to legal migration for students, researchers and other groups of young people. We need more EU-wide legal instruments in the area of migration to realise its potential.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I supported the Council's position at first reading for the adoption of the European Parliament and Council directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research, study, training, volunteering and student exchange programmes or au pair education and work projects. I have followed the advice of my eminent colleagues and the recommendation for the second reading of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, studies, pupil exchange, remunerated and unremunerated training, voluntary service and au pairing, as it will facilitate the conditions for entry and residence in the EU of third country nationals looking to come to the EU for those purposes. This is a much needed measure to attract the most creative minds, entrepreneurs, and intellectuals from all over the world. I am convinced that they will contribute to making the EU more competitive, strengthen its social and cultural ties as well as promote its values beyond its borders. In midst of the debate on migration, I believe that it is particularly important to promote an ambitious legal migration system.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 I very much support this directive establishing new entry and residence rules, which are easier for people from third countries to study or research in European universities and is aimed at improving conditions for trainees, volunteers, pupils and peers from non-EU countries. I also believe it is necessary to attract highly qualified people within the EU and to facilitate their stay in the EU through a harmonised European system applicable in all Member States. With this simplification, European universities will be able to strengthen their competitiveness on the global stage.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because the conditions for the entry and residence of third-country nationals on EU territory should be clarified. At the same time, however, the EU institutions should not take over the prerogatives of the Member States in this regard. It is very well placed that the report highlights the points of the directive which allow Member States to reject requests on an individual basis and taking into account the specific circumstances of the third-country national. This is an important observation, since, in the case of entry into the territory of a particular EU Member State, it is first of all that country should decide on the criteria for authorising studying, research and training. Safety should be taken into account in the first place.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The rejection of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, study, pupil exchange, paid and unpaid training, voluntary and au pair work was rejected. The European economy is based on skills and a wide range of knowledge and skills of researchers and students must be provided for the further growth and development of the latter. Talented individuals need to be educated, developed and retained in Europe. This can meet both the needs of individuals and the needs of research institutions and European companies. The Directive makes it possible to simplify and unify the rules throughout the European Union. One of the main achievements is intra-EU mobility, which allows students and researchers to continue their activities in other Member States without the need to leave the EU and re-apply for entry. Students and researchers will have access to work, but labour market rules will remain within the remit of the Member States.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against the two amendments to the whole tabled by two political groups, which would have led to the rejection of the Council's position and, consequently, the decay of the legislative proposal.  We understand that this report contains very positive aspects for people wishing to carry out their higher education or research in the EU.  This is a second reading and was approved in the committee and there was no vote in plenary.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, studies, training, voluntary service, pupil exchange schemes or educational projects and au pairing. I think that these cultural and education exchanges, like the Erasmus studies exchange, are important to open minds and get people to know each other better. Living in other countries with different people and nationalities is an enriching experience. I support this programme fully and we should not be scared by populist propaganda on this.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. All the provisions of the text undermine the sovereignty of the Member States, which should be able to carry out their own policy on entry and stay in their territories. This text is also immigrationist (family reunification, right to stay to look for work or start a business), and favours the "brain drain" at the expense of developing countries. I voted in favour of the rejection amendment tabled by our ENF group with EFDD.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 This report has the central objective of establishing harmonised rules at European level for third-country nationals with a view to facilitating entry and stay into European territory for research, studies, training, volunteering, student exchange and au pair work. The new rules clarify and improve conditions for trainees, volunteers, students and au pairs from outside Europe. Thus, the new rules will allow students and researchers to stay in the EU for nine months after completing their studies or research in order to find a job or to develop a business. Mobility within the EU, from one Member State to another, is also facilitated, and only notification of the State of destination is required without applying for a new visa. Furthermore, researchers have the right to bring their family members with them and they have the right to work during their stay in the EU, and students have the right to work at least 15 hours a week. European universities will have the capacity to increase their competitiveness on the international stage and become more attractive to ambitious students who have received high education in other countries. I therefore voted in favour of the report setting out new rules for citizens of third countries on European territory.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I followed the position of the S&D Group and did not support the proposals of the EFDD and the ENF.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against the two amendments to the whole tabled by two political groups, which would have led to the rejection of the Council's position and, consequently, the decay of the legislative proposal.  We understand that this report contains very positive aspects for people wishing to carry out their higher education or research in the EU.  This is a second reading and was approved in the committee and there was no vote in plenary.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal that amends and brings together Council Directive 2004/114/EC (‘Students’ Directive’) and Council Directive 2005/71/EC (‘Researchers’ Directive’) as it proposes that the existing rules for students and researchers should also apply to trainees and, although only optionally, to au-pairs. These account for a much needed broadening of instruments establishing a legal framework for third country nationals to enter and reside in the EU under equal regulated conditions.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the creation of a working group in eight Member States to better implement the 2007-2013 programmes.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The new directive aims on the one hand to unite the directive of students and researchers from third countries and, on the other hand, to improve certain aspects of both groups such as granting them the right to remain at least 9 months after finishing their studies or research in order to be able to seek work, facilitate their movement in the European Union during their stay , having to notify only the Member State of destination, allow investigators to bring in their family members and allow students to work 15 hours a week. We are talking not only about simplifying legislation but also about improving the situation of regulated third-country nationals. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this text.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report, which regulates the conditions of entry and residence for third-country nationals for research, study, internships, volunteering, student exchange and au-pair activities. It is a well-considered document that allows third-country nationals to come to the European Union to acquire skills and knowledge through a period of training in our Member States.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This directive aims to promote the entry and residence conditions of people wishing to enter the EU in the context of research, studies, training or volunteering. It therefore targets only a limited number of people but can loosen the stranglehold of European migration policies. This directive will improve admission procedures by putting in place an obligation to decide on applications within 60 days. It creates a right of residence to find work for 9 months after school and will facilitate the right to family reunification for researchers. This will not solve everything, blockages remain: entry can always be refused on the basis of extremely vague criteria, the residence permits being not issued for the full duration of the diploma but on the basis of a renewable year. It is only a small element of breathing and always carries the same risk of choice of the most educated which participates in a certain logic of "brain plunder". But all the better for those who will benefit from it. It is indeed the whole migration policy that should be reviewed in particular in order to promote circular migration through more open policies in terms of the liberalisation of short-stay visas. I voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Although timidly, this report presents comparatively better positive aspects in relation to the current situation, such as the right of students to work, from 10 to 15 hours per week, the improvement of the mobility regime, the creation of a job search authorisation allowing students and researchers to stay for at least 9 months and the entry into the European Union of the family members of researchers. We support the possibility that residents of third countries can enter, reside and work in the European Union, and we believe that they can do so with conditions of dignity.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The aim of this Directive is to lay down the conditions for entry and permanent residence of third-country nationals for research, study, traineeships, voluntary work, student exchanges, educational projects and au pairs. The joint resolution of the EP and the Commission states that '[...] the inclusion of this provision in this Directive should not set a precedent for future legal instruments in the field of migration[...]'. This vote was a recommendation for second reading. The two groups, THE ENF and EFDD, have each tabled amendments stating that the Council's position should not be adopted. That is why I voted in favour of these amendments.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – With regard to the European Parliament's recommendation on the Council's position at first reading with regard to the adoption of the European Parliament and Council Directive on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for research or study purposes, for completing an internship, for participation in a voluntary service, for student exchange programmes or educational projects and for the exercise of an au pair (recast), I voted in favour of the request for rejection. The regulation of conditions of entry and residence is the responsibility of the Member States and not of the EU.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Facilitating access to research, further education and work in the European Union for talented young people from third countries is a significant factor in europe's increased competitiveness on the global market. It is necessary to give ambitious, innovative thinking, creative people the opportunity to further develop. The bureaucracy in the Member States has made it difficult for talented people to come and stay in the European Union. Their talent must be used correctly to maintain the growth and innovation of the European market. It should be noted that young Europeans also benefit from the arrival of people from abroad. This kind of action, working with people from other parts of the world, educates them on their views and way of thinking. Their minds become more open to the world. I am fully convinced that the decisions taken by the European Union at this time will contribute to improving the situation of all active, capable third-country nationals willing to develop their skills in Europe.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ It is extremely important that the EU moves towards enhancing safer and legal routes to Europe; Labour MEPs support the text as it represents a great added value to managed migration particularly in the context of the current migration crisis. It also contains measures to improve mobility of foreign students and researchers inside the EU. However, it is important to note that the report will not impact UK immigration policy concerning third-country nationals as the UK has an opt-out from EU Justice and Home Affairs measures.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Written. I fully support this resolution. I support the directive, which aims to create a more efficient, transparent and targeted legal framework for a targeted group of people. Specifically, it concerns people who want to stay temporarily in the EU in connection with study, research, training, au pair, etc. The ultimate aim of the proposed directive is to combat brain flight and the ageing of the European labour force. Europe will once again become more attractive to highly skilled workers. These are essential to safeguard the future of the European labour market and industry. In addition, the opportunity was taken to relax the rules on changing stays between different European Member States and to extend their duration for students and researchers to 6 months.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted for this text as it represents a great added value to managed migration, particularly in the context of the current migration crisis. This report will not impact UK immigration policy concerning third-country nationals as the UK has an opt-out from EU Justice and Home Affairs measures.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – This resolution helps to clarify and improve the conditions of entry and residence of researchers, volunteers, students, trainees and non-European pupils for the benefit of the Union and its Member States, as well as their countries of origin. It is about making the EU more attractive, more competitive and becoming a Europe of knowledge and research support with the human capital needed to achieve the objectives of the European 2020 strategy. Education, research and the promotion of cultural exchanges are objectives and means of building bridges between Europe and third countries. Furthermore, I welcome the more favourable conditions for researchers, both in terms of family reass and mobility, which will enable them to monitor their research in all Member States. Given its demographic situation, the European Union will certainly also need educated immigrants. However, this is only a secondary way of dealing with this bad situation in Europe. The role of population policies in the Member States is mainly to support the birth rate of its population, to create a legislative environment so that families who want to have children can develop and are not dependent on living in poverty. It is a task not only financial, but also cultural.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 This report, adopted by a large majority of colleagues in the committee responsible for Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, is the product of a broader consensus among political forces as, inter alia, it encourages the development of training as well as the EU's relations with third States.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the reception of students and researchers from third countries. As I learned in my city, Padua, characterized by the presence of one of the oldest and most prestigious universities in Italy, only an exchange of ideas from all over the world generates a fruitful and innovative scientific and academic debate. This is a consideration that can be extended at European level, all the more so since it is necessary to deal with the ageing of the population and the shortage of qualified personnel in many new areas of technology. I therefore fully agree with the proposal to unify the two previous European legislation on the reception of researchers from third countries and to increase the rights and protections for third-country researchers. I hope that this text will pav the way for greater integration of foreign researchers into European territory, favouring a fruitful discussion between the Member States on this issue.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The fact that the EU's 'smart borders' are adapted according to the needs of monopolies for cheap labour comes to be confirmed by the directive adopted by the European Parliament. While Dublin is strengthening, thousands of stranded people remain in Greece and refugees face closed borders, deportations. The EU with this directive unsymed and opens borders according to the needs of business groups, choosing: researchers, students, i.e. tomorrow's skilled workers who need European monopolies to strengthen their position in competition with other American, Asian, etc. monopolies and those who will offer cheap work for capital, such as in the context of "unpaid and paid internships" , "voluntary service" and "internal unpaid assistants", in the name of "acquiring work experience" and "promoting contacts between peoples ... and the opportunity for third-country nationals to improve their language skills." As long as the economy is profit-based, workers will move inside and outside the EU for the interests of monopolies. The peoples have experience and must use it by overturning, through their struggle, the power of monopolies and by building a socialised economy that puts at the heart of meeting their needs and not profit.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 Simplifying the conditions of entry into the EU and moving within for those third-country nationals who come to the EU for research, study, traineeship, voluntary services, pupil exchange programmes or educational projects and au pair activities is, in my view, right. That is why I voted in favour of this report. During their stay in the EU, these people acquire a unique opportunity to learn new skills and knowledge that they can apply directly in their country upon their return. This not only promotes the development of this country, but also helps to increase cooperation between the EU and third countries.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the vote, I proposed to the EP and the Council on the definition of conditions of entry and residence of citizens for research and study in the European Union. It should be emphasised that this legal solution will only apply to persons who will be legally present in the Member States of the Union. It will enable skills and knowledge to be acquired through training in Europe and will foster the so-called 'brain flow'. It should benefit the countries of origin of those persons as well as the countries that receive them. The legal movement of trainees and researchers should contribute to the development of human capital in Europe.  However, it is also worth taking into account in legal solutions that there is a risk of abuse of the law and attempting to work illegally on the basis of it. Therefore, the rules for the residence of researchers and trainees must be clear and the dates of their stay clearly defined, so that the desired exchange of young people is an organised process.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the directive concerning the entry and residence of third-country nationals who come to the European Union for the purpose of research, studies, traineeships or volunteering, or voted against the amendment that aimed at rejecting this whole directive. The proposal for a directive laid down uniform conditions for the entry and residence of these third-country nationals, introducing a number of innovations compared to the old regulation. These included, for example, the possibility to stay on the territory of the European Union for an extended period of time after study for the purpose of finding work, the possibility for students to work a limited number of hours in addition to their studies, or the possibility for family members of researchers to accompany them during research in the EU. I believe that the new regulation thus improved will help to make the European Union a centre of quality studies or practice under favourable conditions and will help to attract professionals who will be beneficial to the development of the European Union in the long term.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. The recast Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of research, study, pupil exchange, paid and unpaid training, voluntary work and au pair work is important mainly because it balances all interests. The unification of rules within the Framework of the European Union will enable young people to live better and work during their study and work mobility, while at the same time allowing member states which have reserved discretion the possibility of rejecting an application on the basis of individual treatment and taking into account the specific circumstances in which the third-country national, the principle of proportionality and on the basis of evidence or serious and objective reasons.  The renewed proposal thus presents new and balanced possibilities for obtaining human capital in the European Union, and I therefore support it and voted against the amendment which proposed rejecting the Council's position.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, this report is about the allocation of so-called cohesion funds, i.e. money to catch up with underdeveloped areas and underdeveloped countries, and contains some sensible ideas and proposals. Among other things, it is about looking at whether these funds could be used to create jobs. And I liked just as much the assessment and examination that potential beneficiaries might be insufficiently informed about these projects, about these support options. Well, it would be nice to see why. I have an idea because I read the paper. I think that because of the possible and actual supporters are given information, that is, the buddies. Everyone knows that political power and economic power are being built together, and most of the EU money is already distributed well in advance, between networks, networks, corrupt sidekkers. This should be changed and this would be one of the means of really eliminating or reducing these huge differences between countries.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, EU cohesion policy is all about contributing to the economic catch-up of poorer Member States. There are several reasons for this: in addition to meeting the social need for an increase in living standards, the aim is to create fairer competition in the market. After all, there are serious reservations about a common market, with huge differences in the income conditions of each Member State, in terms of infrastructure and in the quality of services. It is important to be aware that cohesion policy is not aid. Unfortunately, we can see that leading politicians often use that word, which is a complete misunderstanding of the situation.  Without a successful cohesion policy, the infrastructure and living standards of the former Socialist countries will approach the old Member States even more slowly, resulting in increased migration, dissatisfaction and disillusionment with the European project. It is therefore important that the same amount of resources are available in cohesion policy after 2020. It is therefore important to stress that the effectiveness of cohesion policy is also in the interest of the old Member States.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, I am sorry to abstain, but we cannot detach the debate on regional cohesion from building another economic model. We cannot ask for flexibility in public funds, recognise the burdens that the crisis and austerity have imposed, and at the same time insist on the implementation of new structural reforms, which are the main cause of growing inequality in Europe. Because we must not deceive ourselves, European funds are increasingly linked to encouraging the insertion of the European economy into the global market, without compensating for the effects of liberalisation and privatisation on workers in peripheral states. European policy can use the market, but not to replicate its priorities, the priorities of high capital. On the contrary, it must be a public pole for the definition of a different social and productive model. We must denounce how the right, as well as the Member States and regions, have managed the funds without having the social partners and favouring the cutting and disintegration of public investment at the hands of private interests.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, some EUR 360 billion is allocated to cohesion policy in the period 2014-2020, i.e. one third of the Union budget.  In 2007-2013, we had problems with the implementation of projects using this money, in some Member States, mainly because of the inability of some authorities, because of the lack of information for the beneficiaries of the funds, because of the cumbersome and lengthy process of approving projects or the complicated procurement and authorisation process, and also because of corruption or simply the incompetence of those who worked in this area. For this reason, I welcome the Commission's initiative to set up an independent expert group to monitor the simplification of procedures for access to these European funds, and the first condition is simplification, and the second, very important, is transparency: everyone needs to know who is asking for what, what they are asking for, how long, how much they cost and how they do their job on these projects.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Cohesion policy, as we know, constitutes one of the most important cornerstones of The European Union's policy. And there are countries, including my country, the Republic of Latvia, where not a small part of the resources available is simply not used every year. The difficulty of applying, the degree of birocragisation, the simple misunderstanding of procedures or, at all, the complete ignorance of existing options, are actually blocking the full development of several areas. I therefore join in calling on the Commission and the relevant authorities of the Member States themselves to inform potential beneficiaries of funds of such opportunities as actively and, for their part, to rationalise the functioning of the whole system. A fairly simple fact is that, during each programming period of the European Union budget, resources are allocated to each Member State, which can simply be received later than possible. I therefore support this document and consider it to be very timely and important.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, it is indeed true that cohesion policy suffers from certain ills, whether it is excessive bureaucracy, which is associated with the processing of applications and the submission of such applications at all. Certainly, cohesion policy is not sufficiently focused on the effect, it is often assessed very formally. However, all these ills are certainly balanced by the overall benefit. I believe that this policy is the most own thing europe can boast of. If the disadvantages, the differences between regions, are being erused against growth measures, then it must be said that this policy helps regions, despite all their ills, which they suffer from. A high group of experts has been set up to find a recipe for simplifying it in general, how to simplify the absorption of European funds. I will be watching very closely what proposals they will present, because I think this is the way to go. Not to abolish cohesion policy, but to reform it.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, we just had council elections in the UK. Labour and Conservative councils have been squealing, saying ‘we don’t have the money for libraries, museums, theatres, road safety measures’ and yet these same political parties support the spending of millions upon millions of pounds of UK tax payers’ money on closer EU governance and cohesion. This is a disgrace. These people squeal like babies at home that there’s no money, and yet send their money for redistribution across Europe. I stand against EU governance. I voted against this measure for more cohesion spending, and I will always – God willing – stand against the EU spending UK taxpayers’ money in this way.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar an mholta seo agus is dóigh liom gur polasaí iontach é, i ndáiríre, an beartas comhtháthaithe. Tá EUR 30 billiún ag dul dó sa tréimhse airgeadais seo agus tá súil agam tar éis 2020 go leanfar ar aghaidh leis. Taispeánann sé an mhaitheas is féidir leis an Aontas a dhéanamh agus freisin an dearcadh atá againn: na tíortha is saibhre ag cabhrú leis na tíortha agus na réigiúin is boichte.  Mo thír féin, nuair a chuamar isteach san Aontas bhíomar an-bhocht; ach fuaireamar airgead as an gciste seo agus de réir a chéile d’éiríomar níos saibhre. Anois táimid ar cheann de na tíortha is saibhre san Eoraip de bharr an airgid a fuaireamar saor in aisce ón Aontas.  Rud amháin a chonaic mé sa mholadh, agus aontaím leis: níl an t-eolas sin ag na saoránaigh agus caithfear i bhfad níos mó poiblíochta a dhéanamh faoin obair mhaith atá á déanamh ag an bpolasaí seo do na saoránaigh féin.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: And you still paid money to the EU? Written explanations of vote

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. Cohesion policy is currently the main form of investment and development that the European Union reserves for its regions. To this end, the strategies developed in this field aim not only to balance European objectives with the specific needs of the territories, but above all to enhance their peculiarities and riches. Looking at the previous programming period, however, the results achieved were not the best: too complex procedures, insufficient information, lack of adequate infrastructure, as well as difficulties in accessing finance. The resolution before us proposes a number of changes aimed at speeding up cohesion policy. I have, however, decided to abstain, believing that, in order to really encourage the development of these territories, it is essential to proceed with the drawing up of more significant action plans.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The aim of the resolution is to request from the European Parliament an acceleration of the implementation of cohesion policy funds, given the delays in payments that the European institutions have to beneficiaries (regions and sub-state entities). It therefore calls for the Commission to report to Parliament on the implementation and acceleration of the payment plan. It also requests an assessment of the impact of compliance with the preconditions for project financing, given the problems arising from confusing regulations and lack of information to interested public actors. Despite this, I cannot be in favour of this institution declaring itself in favour of "promoting structural reforms", the meaning of which is none other than the acceleration of the dismantling of public services and the reduction of public spending and investment, with fateful consequences in terms of social and territorial inequality, contrary to the Treaties. In short, I have opted for abstention in the vote on this resolution.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy.  The purpose of this text is to provide an overview of the implementation of the cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 and to make recommendations. With regard to regional policy, the topics discussed include late payments, administrative complexities in making a project eligible, lack of information and transparency for project owners and local authorities, and the use of regional policy to promote Euro-regionalism.  Despite some good positions of the REGI Committee (reducing payment deadlines, simplifying the whole process of engagement and monitoring of the Structural Funds), there is no question in this text of the holding of an urban agenda or the continuation of macro-regional strategies which are measures to strengthen EU cooperation with local authorities to the detriment of the national authorities of the Member States. Many other topics are not discussed, including the reprogramming of the Structural Funds to support migrant reception programmes. I therefore objected to this text.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution focuses on the need to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy, particularly the need for greater simplification, the strengthening of administrative capacity and encouraging greater subdelegation to local and regional actors via new tools like integrated territorial investments and community-led local development. It also calls for greater flexibility in the use of the investment clause, which could allow some Member States’ investments in development co-financed by the ESIF to be excluded from the calculation of national deficits. However, the resolution as a whole is still firmly couched in terms of advocating ‘structural reforms’, ‘investment-friendly policies’, and the use of a range of financial instruments as a precondition for meeting these growth and employment objectives. I therefore abstained on this vote.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which encourages Member States to use the instruments for projects aimed at creating quality jobs and opportunities for SMEs, boosting investment, sustainable and inclusive growth and social investment, and contributing to poverty reduction and social inclusion, particularly in regions and sub-regions where this is most needed.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the above proposal on speeding up the implementation of cohesion policy, which in some Member States is the main source of public investment. The purpose of the question tabled to the European Commission, which led to this motion for a resolution, is to highlight the number and type of measures envisaged by the European Commission to facilitate the implementation of operational programmes in order to avoid the release of funds, and how the European Commission and the Member States intend to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution on the acceleration of the implementation of cohesion policy is an exercise in which the Committee on Regional Development takes stock of the implementation of the cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 and makes recommendations following the tabling of an oral question addressed to the European Commission. The motion for a resolution does not call into question either the holding of an urban agenda or the continuation of macro-regional strategies. Furthermore, it continues to welcome the principle of thematic concentration and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy which run counter to the interests of France and the poorest communities. Communities that, let us remember, in times of economic crisis, need more flexibility in obtaining Structural Funds and better articulation with State/Region plan contracts. So I voted against the resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution contemplates the acceleration of the implementation of cohesion policy. In my view, the cohesion policy is a key plank of EU integration and the drive towards Euro-federalism. Whilst I would support genuine reform, I am far from convinced that genuine reform is on the table. Indeed, it appears that the suggestion of reform in this report in fact implies even greater European Union control. For these reasons I voted against the report.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy. I support the calls on the Commission to assess the use of the ESI Funds for the period 2014-2020. The Commission and the Member States must use all the potential of the ESI Funds to strengthen social and economic cohesion and reduce territorial disparities by making all regions more competitive and facilitating investment, including from private sources. Looking at the 2007-2013 programming period, the main obstacles were the lack of suitable projects, the slow and lengthy approval of major projects, as well as complex and time-consuming procurement procedures, complex State aid rules, complex authorisation procedures, unresolved property relations, the over-authorisation procedure and difficulties in obtaining funding. These problems need to be addressed as a matter of urgency.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution provides an overview of the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020: delays in payment, administrative complexities to make a project eligible, or the use of regional policy for the purpose of promoting Euro-regionalism: cohesion policy is not really a recipe. While some of the positions taken by the REGI Committee to improve the implementation of this policy are common sense (for example in favour of reducing payment deadlines), the motion for a resolution does not call into question the continuation of macro-regional strategies, and continues to welcome the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy which run counter to the interests of France and the poorest communities. Finally, it should be noted that the motion for a resolution does not address the thorny issue of the reprogramming of the Structural Funds in favour of migrant reception programmes.  So I voted against it.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. – This resolution aims to promote and improve Community cohesion policy by warning of its main shortcomings, urging the correct implementation of all programmes and instruments, and promoting better use and management of the European Structural and Investment Funds (EIE).   The EIE Funds are the main investment tool in European policy. For the period 2014-2020 they have an endowment of 454 billion euros. Its effectiveness and good management is essential to comply with the guidelines of the European Strategy 2020, to modernise our Union, and to facilitate entrepreneurship. Cohesion policy must make possible one of the EU's core values such as solidarity, ending territorial differences. Even more so in a time of economic crisis that has increased social inequalities and economic differences between Member States. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. Cohesion policy is the main source of public investment for many States and is, more generally, a crucial tool for bringing the Union closer to its citizens. The 2014-2020 regulations, with the changes introduced, have expanded their flexibility margins, allowing for a more coordinated use of EIS funds and an improvement in the links between the EU and regional realities. Despite the efforts made, however, the first two years of the new programming have seen the persistence of obstacles and problems, generated in large part by a lack of information and a lack of resources; two key elements to enable local and regional authorities to prepare project documentation. In this context, I have chosen to vote in favour of the motion for a resolution on speeding up the implementation of cohesion policy. The text, approved by Parliament, calls on the Commission to make efforts to ensure not only a simplification of procedures but also to support the strengthening of administrative capacity in the implementation and evaluation phases of the policy. The central point is the full use of the flexibility provided for in the Stability and Growth Pact. Only by this means will it be possible to increase investment in growth and employment.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The aim of the resolution is to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy in all EU regions and to improve its effectiveness, a key issue given that this instrument has a budget of more than EUR 350 billion by 2020 and that in several Member States it is the main source of public investment funding. We agree with many of the things that are proposed: recommendations for simplification of procedures, improvement of information, reduction of deadlines, implementation of tools for analysis and evaluation of the use of funds, etc. But there are references to the deepening of structural reforms and the use of Stability and Growth Pact mechanisms that we find problematic because they support the austerity policies we have been undergoing for years in Spain and other EU countries. For consistency with the denunciation position in the face of these instruments, we voted ABSTENTION.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this Resolution because, in addition to insisting on simplifying procedures and deepening the study of the problems caused, it has an impact on the problems that the crisis creates on the investment capacities of some States and the effects they have on the use or participation in these cohesion programmes. I also share that in some States local and regional authorities that often function much better than the States to which they belong are still considered 'minors'. The recommendation against centralism contained in the Resolution is very timely.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Despite some common-sense proposals in this resolution on the implementation of cohesion policy, I had to vote against it. Of course, the text has the merit of revisiting many dysfunctions in regional policy, and calls for, among other things, the reduction of payment deadlines or the simplification of the process of commitment and monitoring of the Structural Funds. However, as is customary in Parliament, the resolution does not go to the end of things. The Euro-regionalist logic of "going over" member states to better weaken them is in no way in question. Worse, the text takes pride in the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which, as we well know, are catastrophic for our country and our poorest local authorities, which need more flexibility in obtaining structural funds. Finally, the text misses a major problem, yet repeatedly mentioned by my colleague Steeve Briois in the REGI Committee: the reprogramming of the Structural Funds for migrant reception programmes, to the detriment of the development and economic and social stability of our regions and their inhabitants.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with what is contained in the resolution on the implementation of cohesion policy. With its crazy policies, the EU is increasing, rather than reducing, economic inequalities between Member States. That is why European funds, which should be a contribution to solving the problems of the territories, are also a form of eu control of these. We need a completely rethink of the Mechanism of European Funds, in order to make it an effective aid for our territories and our citizens. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. •u2012 Cohesion policy is the primary instrument with which the EU approaches citizens, as well as representing the Union's main investment and development policy, as well as the main source of public investment for some Member States. The objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy can be achieved through a coherent interaction between growth, development and structural reform policies. Cohesion policy therefore plays an essential role in the integration and development of these objectives. There is significant concern about the delay in the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, in view of what happened in the previous programming period, in which insufficient information, lack of administrative structures or complexity in procurement processes made it difficult to implement cohesion policy.  That is why this Resolution, which I have supported, calls for a proactive attitude by the Commission to facilitate the implementation and simplification of cohesion policy, as well as to maximise investment flexibility for growth and employment.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because cohesion policy is an instrument that brings the European Union closer to the people and is a key policy for investment and development covering all regions of the EU; whereas cohesion policy is the main source of public investment in some Member States. The 2014-2020 Regulations provide for a number of major reforms in cohesion policy, such as thematic concentration of support, which creates the flexibility needed to better address local needs, greater results orientation, better coordination with economic and social policies, better linking EU priorities to regional needs and a more coordinated use of the European Structural and Investment (ESI Funds) under the common strategic framework. Cohesion policy investments should be coordinated and coordinated in other EU policies, such as the Digital Single Market, the Energy Union, social policy, macro-regional strategies, the urban agenda, research and innovation, as well as transport policy, in order to contribute more to the europe 2020 objectives. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to assess the use of the ESI Funds for the period 2014-2020 and to prepare a detailed analysis of the risk of decommitment, indicating the amounts for each Member State and to carry out an analysis of the payment forecasts submitted by the Member States as soon as possible.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy expresses a number of very useful forward-looking ideas. The motion for a resolution outlines the problems that hampered the implementation of cohesion policy during the 2007-2013 programming period (e.g. insufficient information for potential beneficiaries, lengthy process of project approval, complex state aid and public procurement rules), stresses the need to strengthen administrative capacities, as this is a prerequisite for the effective and timely implementation of cohesion policy.  It underlines the importance of timely disbursement of cohesion funds, the pressing need to eliminate payment arrears and calls for better communication on cohesion policy and its results. As the motion for a resolution states, it is of the utmost importance that joint reflection on post-2020 cohesion policy begins as soon as possible. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the faster implementation of cohesion policy. Indeed, with the resolution, we called on the Commission to assess the state of play of the implementation of the European Structural and Investment Funds for the period 2014-2020 and to provide a detailed analysis of the risk of decomasing commitments, indicating the amounts per Member State, as well as an analysis of payment forecasts. I believe that, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, both the Commission and the Member States must make full use of the potential of the European Structural and Investment Funds in order to strengthen social and economic cohesion and reduce development disparities. This would enable all regions to develop competitiveness and stimulate investment, including private ones.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 In the face of the severe economic crisis, which has led to liquidity problems and major shortcomings in the availability of state funds, cohesion funds have become the main source of public investment in many Member States. Despite the absolute need for these funds, the capacity of many Member States to absorb funding remains surprisingly low. The main obstacles are the lack of information, the lack of transparency and the separate management of the various European funds. In order to fully exploit the potential of funding, effective structural reforms, investment policies and the full application of the flexibility provided for in the Stability Pact should be encouraged. This report, which I support, clarifies the main future challenges on the implementation of operational programmes, promoting cooperation, synergy and transparency in order to avoid the dispersion of funds and to help European regions become more competitive.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – This resolution focuses on the need to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy, particularly the need for greater simplification, the strengthening of administrative capacity and encouraging greater subdelegation to local and regional actors via new tools like integrated territorial investments and community-led local development. It also calls for greater flexibility in the use of the investment clause, which could allow some Member States’ investments in development co-financed by the ESIF to be excluded from the calculation of national deficits. However, the resolution as a whole is still firmly couched in terms of advocating ‘structural reforms’, ‘investment-friendly policies’, and the use of a range of financial instruments as a precondition for meeting these growth and employment objectives. I therefore abstained on this vote.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe it is important that the implementation of cohesion policy is made faster and more efficient because the financial instruments made available by the Structural Funds, if applied effectively on the basis of appropriate ex ante evaluation and in strategic combination with grants, can significantly increase the impact of funding , thus helping to offset the negative effects of public budget contractions and to develop revenue-generating projects.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to speed up the implementation of the cohesion policy to address the shortfalls in public investment in The Member States resulting from the austerity measures imposed by the European Commission.  On the one hand, the rapporteur promotes the implementation of macro-regional strategies and the creation of a European urban policy, even though it is an exclusive competence of the Member States. By strengthening the implementation of the cohesion policy, the European Union wishes to grant itself new prerogatives and to intensify its relations with local and regional executives at the expense of our national sovereignty.  On the other hand, this text approves the introduction of ex-ante conditions in the allocation of European structural funds. National governments will now be obliged to clean up their public accounts and implement the structural reforms recommended by the Commission to claim the benefit of these European funds, while they are abounded by the contributions of the Member States. For all these reasons, I objected to this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy is the most important investment and development policy in all regions of the European Union; it is the instrument by which the EU approaches its citizens, and at the same time is the main source of public investment in some countries. Cohesion policy is equipped with a budget of more than EUR 350 million, a budget valid until 2020. The objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy can only be achieved through a coherent interaction between development and growth policies, and where necessary through structural reforms, but also through the active involvement of cities and regions, because cohesion policy plays a crucial role in this. , so that there is the best possible rapprochement with citizens and that investment is as visible as possible to EU citizens and regions.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to the Eu ropean Union's unholy economic policies, cohesion between EU regions is being 19/7. Thus, implementing the Europe 2020 objectives means widening macroeconomic inequalities between Member States and within each of them (think of the gap between Padania and Italy which, due to the crisis and austerity policies, has never been wider). In other words, this paradox applies: the more European funding you use (so you are 'virtuous'), the more you need to increase public spending (co-financing) but, at the same time, cut services due to the constraints of the Stability Pact. It follows that it would be more effective and profitable if each Member State were to spend its own money, without passing it through Brussels; for Italy, which is the EU's net contributor, it would also be a significant saving. Union funds, although designed as an instrument for compensating for imbalances between Member States, are in practice a mechanism for amplifying these imbalances, which intervenes through the use of the two principles of cofinancing and conditionality; As a result, they are a particularly devious mechanism for monitoring Member States' spending policies by the EU. I voted against.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to bring about the desired change, the Europe 2020 strategy needs to be better targeted, to constantly pursue its transparent objectives and benchmarks for assessing progress. We need a strong governance framework as soon as possible, using all the development tools available to the Member States to ensure timely and most effective implementation. I support this draft EP resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy as I am concerned about the delay in the efficient allocation of EU budgetary resources in order to address the societal and employment challenges faced by all Member States and regions.   I believe that the EP plays an important role in the strategy, not only as a co-legislator, but also as a driving force for mobilising citizens and national parliaments. Greater visibility of the financing role of the European Union budget and a more direct link with European citizens could be ensured by promoting information campaigns.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Cohesion policy is an essential instrument of the European Union. It is the EU's main investment policy which enables European regions and cities to move towards the objectives of growth and job creation. Cohesion policy includes various structural funds: the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (FEADER) and the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries (FEAMP).  Cohesion policy also helps to restore equality between European regions by helping the most disadvantaged among them. This resolution notes the significant delays in the launch and implementation of the cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period. Cohesion policy for this period must be implemented quickly. We cannot leave projects without funding. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the Commission to put in place all the necessary measures to facilitate the acceleration of the implementation of cohesion policy 2014-2020. Due to delays in the approval of regulations, regional operational programmes (POR) did not see the light of day before 2015 and this led to a slippage and accumulation of funds to be spent. I agree with the request to the Commission to assess the progress of the implementation of the Cohesion Funds for the period 2014-2020 and to draw up a detailed analysis of the risks of decommitment, as well as to indicate the measures envisaged in order to avoid their decommitment as much as possible. It is also appropriate that the task force associated with the 2007-2013 programming should continue to support and accelerate the implementation of the 2014-2020 programmes in all Member States in order to catch up already accumulated, and that the European Parliament should be informed of the action plan on the activities of the task force. Member States are also invited to play their part by complying with ex-ante conditionalities by the end of 2016, in order to ensure smooth implementation of the programmes and avoid the possible suspension of interim payments.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ There were several positive aspects to this report, which focused on the need to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy, on the need for greater simplification, the strengthening of administrative capacity amongst relevant actors, and encouraging greater sub-delegation to local actors via integrated territorial investments and community-led local development. It also calls for greater flexibility in the use of the investment clause, which could allow Member States to see investments co-financed by the European Structural and Investment Fund excluded from the calculation of state deficits. However, it also strongly promotes structural reforms, policies that promote investment at the expense of workers, communities and the environment, and the use of a range of financial instruments as a precondition for meeting growth and employment objectives. On this basis I abstained.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because we feel EU regional funding is a propaganda tool and shamelessly wastes UK taxpayers’ money to fund it. The so-called ‘reforms’ are little more than EU attempts to cement control.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it outlines many relevant issues on the implementation of cohesion policy. In particular I believe that better use needs to be made of the Structural and Investment Funds and that the European Commission needs to pay greater attention to the assessment of their implementation.
