I also welcome the establishment of the Task Force for Better Implementation of the 2007-2013 programmes in some Member States and I hope it will help them significantly to increase the rate of absorption of funding.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report proposes a number of changes in the name of speeding up the EU's cohesion policy, which is currently the main form of investment and development that the European Union reserves for its regions. I have chosen to abstain from voting because I believe that, in order to really encourage the development of the Union's territories, it is essential to proceed with the drawing up of more significant action plans. In fact, looking at the previous programming period, the results obtained were not the best: too complex procedures, insufficient information, lack of adequate infrastructure, as well as difficulties in accessing finance.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Two years have passed since the start of the new programming period and the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, and there are already delays partly due to the late approval of operational programmes. The economic crisis is causing many liquidity problems for the Member States and consequently for the regions which, combined with the constraints of the Stability Pact, are in serious danger of jeopardising the implementation of the EIS funds and with them the benefits for businesses and territories. Cohesion policy funds are often the only source of public funding. That is why I believe it is necessary for the Commission to be more open to considering the use of flexibility if processes of development in our territories are to be engaged. With the resolution adopted today, on which I voted in favour, we wanted to call on the Commission to enter into a permanent dialogue with the Member States with a view to maximting flexibility in relation to investment in growth and employment.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Today's vote on speeding up the implementation of EU cohesion policy is a generally positive step towards speeding up and simplifying procedures for Europe's citizens. However, the references to the European Semester, as well as the forecasts for the use of financial instruments instead of public expenditure, find me to be opposed. That is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that we need to respond as soon as possible to the lack of cohesion between the various Member States that make up our European Union. We are talking about a very vast cultural, social and economic heritage, and although in many things we are really united, it is clear that there is still a lot of work to be done in this regard. Cohesion policies must therefore be speeded up in order to reduce territorial disparities as much as possible in order to enable all regions to become more competitive and to facilitate investment, including private investment. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which, in my opinion, expresses a clear political position, as it aims to direct part of the European Structural and Investment Funds in order to improve cohesion between the various Member States.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The Cohesion Fund is aimed at Member States whose Gross National Income (GNI) per inhabitant is less than 90% of the EU average. It aims to reduce economic and social disparities and to promote sustainable development. For the 2014-2020 period, the Cohesion Fund concerns Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Greece, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Cohesion policy contributes decisively to bringing the EU closer to citizens and investment and development policies for all regions, representing, in some Member States, the main source of public investment. To this end, the Commission and the Member States should exploit the full potential of the European Structural and Investment Funds, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, in order to strengthen economic and social cohesion and reduce territorial differences. I would stress the importance of making payments in a timely manner in order to ensure the correct and effective implementation and credibility of cohesion policy. At the same time, the Commission, The Member States and all stakeholders should ensure better coordination of initiatives and launch an effective communication policy in order to raise public awareness of the achievements of cohesion policy, thereby giving more visibility to this policy. For the above, I support this resolution.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We voted against this because we feel EU regional funding is a propaganda tool and shamelessly wastes UK taxpayers’ money to fund it. The so-called ‘reforms’ are little more than EU attempts to cement control.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – The aim of the resolution is to request from the European Parliament an acceleration in the implementation of cohesion policy funds, given the delays in payments that the European institutions have to beneficiaries (regions and sub-state entities). It therefore calls for the Commission to report to Parliament on the implementation and acceleration of the payment plan. It also requests an assessment of the impact of compliance with the preconditions for project financing, given the problems arising from confusing regulations and lack of information to interested public actors. Despite this, I cannot be in favour of this institution declaring itself in favour of "promoting structural reforms", the meaning of which is none other than the acceleration of the dismantling of public services and the reduction of public spending and investment, with fateful consequences in terms of social and territorial inequality, contrary to the Treaties. In short, I have opted for abstention in the vote on this resolution.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The progress of cohesion policy implementation in several Member States and regions for the period 2007-2013 has been partly hampered by some obstacles due to insufficient information available to potential beneficiaries, with the consequent submission of unsead projects, slow approval of projects, long and complex award procedures, difficulties of Member States and local authorities in meeting the requirements relating to the internal and external implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact. I therefore support, by voting in favour, the objective of this resolution to provide information for the period 2014-2020 on the obstacles already encountered and strategies to overcome them with a view to the effective implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 EU regional policy aims to promote job creation, business competitiveness, growth and sustainable development. These actions are carried out in order to achieve the overarching objective of this policy, which is greater territorial cohesion. Cohesion policy is implemented through three main funds: the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the Cohesion Fund and the European Social Fund (ESF), which are part of the European Structural and Investment Funds. With a budget of EUR 351.8 billion , representing almost a third of the EU's general budget, these funds for cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 are the EU's main investment tool. Without seeing any objections, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this oral question because I believe that it is important that process for absorbing regional development funds in the UK is simplified as much as possible, with many organisations in the UK stating that the process to access the funds is often highly complex and bureaucratic. Ensuring that there is less red tape and better value for money in these programmes is important for helping groups which wish to access these funds, so that they are not entangled by a process which they often find too difficult and time-consuming to complete.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. In the previous programming period, there were delays due, among other things, to insufficient information available to potential beneficiaries, slow approval of major projects, lack of administrative structures responsible for managing investments in major projects, complex and unclear award procedures, and difficulties in accessing finance. We cannot, because of the very credibility of cohesion policy, allow us to make up for delays, from the approval of the multiannual financial framework to the incredible case of some operational programmes approved only 6 months ago. We will also never agree on the link, introduced in this programming, between 'sound economic governance' and the Structural Funds (with possible suspension of these as provided for in the infamous Article 23) or on the assumption of the need to promote so-called 'structural reforms', according to some opinions even functional to a more effective cohesion policy. Unfortunately, the structural reforms proposed by the Italian Government to its citizens are all but in favour of transparency, participation, development and the fight against unemployment. For these reasons, I shall abstain in the vote on this resolution.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the implementation of cohesion policy. It calls on Member States to make full use of the European Structural Investment Funds to consolidate social and economic cohesion and welcomes the establishment of the task force promoting the implementation of programmes. Finally, the resolution recalls that administrative capacity is an essential precondition for the implementation of cohesion policy and that it must be strengthened for the implementation and evaluation stages of the policy.  Considering that the Union's cohesion policy, essential tools for the development and attractiveness of the territories, must be simple in its implementation by local actors and effective in its objectives, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy, the European Union's main investment and development policy covering all regions of the Union. I welcome the establishment of the task force on improving the implementation of programmes for the period 2007-2013 in eight Member States and encourage the Commission to extend it for the period 2014-2020 and extend it to all Member States.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In the period up to 2020, the European Union's cohesion policy has a budget of EUR 350 billion. Extending the N+2 rule of the 2014-2020 financial framework to N+3 can bring effectiveness, but the delay between 2014 and the end of 2015, in particular in the adoption of operational programmes, is worrying. The issue focuses on the following points: avoiding suspension of payments; for the period 2007-2013, is the Commission aware of the difficulties, hazards and repairs encountered in the implementation of the programmes; what it will focus on improving the impact in 2014-2020; supports, and if so, how to increase administrative capacity, as this has a fundamental impact on the success of cohesion policy; measures and reforms to encourage the use of resources; how do they allow payments to be made successfully from 2016 on?

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. With a budget of more than 350 billion euros until 2020, cohesion policy is the Main Investment and Development Policy of the European Union covering all regions of the Union. In some Member States, it is even the main source of public investment. It should be noted, however, that during the first two years of the new programming period, there were delays in implementing this policy.  Indeed, most operational programmes were approved at the end of 2014 and 2015 and a significant number of ex ante conditions have not yet been met. I therefore welcome the Commission's decision to set up a high-level group of independent experts to monitor simplification for beneficiaries of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI) in order to support economic, social and territorial cohesion and to achieve the objectives of the EU's Europe 2020 strategy.  For me, simplification is one of the prerequisites for accelerating implementation. It is therefore with conviction that I have supported this resolution.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text does not call into question either the holding of an urban agenda or the continuation of macro-regional strategies. Furthermore, it welcomes the principle of thematic concentration and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy which run counter to the interests of France and the poorest communities. However, the shortcomings of the regional cohesion policy persist: delays in payment, administrative complexity to make a project eligible, lack of information and transparency for project owners and local authorities, reprogramming of structural funds for migrants or even using regional policy to promote Euro-regionalism. Not to mention that support for improving the administrative capacity of some Member States and local authorities will go primarily to the Eastern countries. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the oral question to the Commission with a motion for a resolution on Speeding up the implementation of cohesion policy. Cohesion policy is part of EU regional policy and aims at creating new jobs, business competitiveness, economic growth and sustainable development. The funds earmarked for cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 represent one third of the EU budget, but its implementation, as well as the related operational programmes, is extremely slow. The Commission is invited to speed up the simplification process to help Member States improve the absorption of funds and improve their administrative capacity.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Greek economy, after so many years of implementation of the Memorandums of Understanding, needs immediate and effective solutions to strengthen it. The EU Structural and Investment Funds (ESI), although they provide a lot of money, do not really focus on creating permanent jobs but promote temporary solutions and half-measures, such as flexible forms of employment, and have the main objective of absorbing resources with beneficiaries of specific companies and NGOs. We are therefore voting against the motion for a resolution on cohesion policy since it is based almost exclusively on the EU's structural and investment funds.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy makes a number of very useful, forward-looking ideas, which is why I voted in favour of it in the plenary vote in Strasbourg in May.  The motion for a resolution outlines the problems that hampered the implementation of cohesion policy during the 2007-2013 programming period (e.g. insufficient information for potential beneficiaries, lengthy process of project approval, complex state aid and public procurement rules), stresses the need to strengthen administrative capacities, as this is a prerequisite for the effective and timely implementation of cohesion policy, highlights the importance of timely disbursement of cohesion funds , calls for the pressing need to eliminate the payment arrears and for better communication on cohesion policy and its results.  As the motion for a resolution states, it is of the utmost importance that joint reflection on post-2020 cohesion policy begins as soon as possible.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 The Centre Party identified cohesion policy as an important part of bringing together and closing gaps between EU countries and vulnerable regions. This report points to the good of cohesion policy, but also to what the Commission needs to do to ensure that the Member States receive better support, but also make greater use of the resources available. The report contains, among other things, letters on clld, which I see as an important part of integrating civil society into EU cohesion policy.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Cohesion policy, with a budget of more than €350 billion by 2020, is the instrument that helps bring the EU closer to citizens and the main investment and development policy for all EU regions and which in some Member States represents the main source of public investment. However, in view of such a budgetary volume, it is important to have a detailed analysis of the risks of decommitment, indicating the amounts per Member State, as well as an analysis of the payment forecasts submitted by the Member States as soon as possible, after the deadlines set.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: the motion for a resolution does not call into question either the holding of an urban agenda or the continuation of macro-regional strategies. Furthermore, it continues to welcome the principle of thematic concentration and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy which run counter to the interests of France and the poorest communities.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution aims to promote policies that, in the 2014-2020 programming period, accelerate the implementation of cohesion funds. The adopted text does not, however, advocate measures that were necessary and insists on negative measures: it sees it as essential for Member States to comply with and enforce all the policies that have departed them from this cohesion: to follow the line of the EU2020 strategy; involve and finance the private sector; comply with the requirements related to the internal and external implementation of the Stability Pact; harmonisation of the implementation of development funds with strategic investment funds and the single digital market; the need to encourage the implementation of these structural reforms and the importance of Member States complying with actions on so-called macroeconomic conditionality – which introduced unacceptable elements of blackmail and pressure in the implementation of the funds – by the end of 2016. We are talking about adding exclusion to exclusion, adding divergence to the divergence. These are logical that Portugal is particularly sensitive at the moment, with the threat of seeing EU funds suspended for non-compliance with an artificial deficit rule. We are strongly opposed to this policy. We advocate real cohesion, based on solidarity between peoples and the sovereign definition of development strategies.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic crisis has caused a lack of liquidity and available public finances in many Member States to make public investments, and cohesion policy funds have become the main source of public investment. Under the Stability and Growth Pact, the European Commission and the Member States must fully apply and make use of the existing flexibility. The European Commission should therefore continue to support the accelerating and implementation of cohesion policy programmes 2014-2020 in individual Member States. Excessive centralisation and a lack of trust can play a role in the implementation of the Structural Funds, as the willingness of some Member States and managing authorities to transfer greater responsibility for the management of European Union funds into the hands of local and regional authorities is diminishing. In future, the European Commission, the Member States and all stakeholders must work together to better coordinate and initiate effective communication policy initiatives in order to raise public awareness of the implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution which would only have the opposite effect, namely to widen macroeconomic inequalities between Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Greek economy, after so many years of implementation of the Memorandums of Understanding, needs immediate and effective solutions to strengthen it. The EU Structural and Investment Funds (ESI), although they provide a lot of money, do not really focus on creating permanent jobs, but rather promote temporary solutions and half-measures such as flexible forms of employment, and have the main objective of absorbing resources with beneficiaries of specific companies and NGOs. I am therefore voting against the motion for a resolution on cohesion policy since it is based almost exclusively on the EU's structural and investment funds.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ EU cohesion policy, with a budget of over EUR 350 billion until 2020, represents in some Member States the main source of public investments. Objectives of enhancing growth and job creation can be achieved through a coherent interaction within the EU economic policy mix of structural reforms and growth enhancing investment, all supported and accelerated by cohesion policy investments. It is positive that rule n+2 from perspective 2007-2013 is extended to n+3 for all Member States, but serious concern is expressed because of significant delay in the implementation of the cohesion policy 2014-2020, including the delay in adoption of operational programmes. The purpose of this Oral Question is to show which measures are envisaged by the European Commission to facilitate the implementation of the operational programmes in order to avoid decommitments of funds and how the Commission and Member States intend to accelerate implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I adopted the motion for a resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy. Cohesion policy is one of the Most Effective Tools of the European Union in the fight against inequalities, which extends to the whole Union and makes us united and equitable.  Cohesion policy and its support instruments are the most important safeguards for strengthening economic and social convergence at EU level. Let us not forget that drawing down cohesion funds is the primary source of public investment in most Member States. We therefore need a structured, transparent and simplified system so that we can make effective use of resources with a budget of EUR 350 billion by 2020.  The problem that often arises in the previous financial period was the lack of targeted activities and the lack of capacity building by local actors. In the hope of better use, we must focus on county development resources in the future, since our most important task is to revive the economy with the help of small and medium-sized enterprises. In line with this, the 2014-2020 provisions introduced the flexibility needed to take better account of local needs, increased focus on results and better coordinated use of investment funds. I particularly welcome this paragraph of the motion.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution with the firm conviction that cohesion policies are the necessary instrument to bring the European Union closer to the citizens. These represent the main investment and development policy in the EU as it covers all its regions. Further progress must be made in this area to reduce the economic and social differences that still exist within the countries and regions that make up the European Union.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as there has been significant delay in the implementation of the cohesion policy funds and EFSI funds for the 2014-2020 periods. At a time when parts of Europe are still experiencing significant economic problems and when there is urgent need for public investment in the economy, the funds available must be put to use as fast as possible. I hope the Commission will push forward with these implementations and provide technical assistance where local or regional governance capacity does not fit the set out criteria for receiving funds.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the non-legislative resolution on speeding up the implementation of cohesion policy because I believe that cohesion policy is one of the EU's most important investment instruments as it has enabled entire regions to converge economically, emerge from the crisis and revive growth in times of crisis. Therefore, an assessment of the same at this stage could provide the Commission with valid information to fuel the debate on future post-2020 cohesion policy. During the 2007-2013 programming period, major problems were encountered in the implementation of cohesion policy in several Member States; Very often this has been due to insufficient information available to potential beneficiaries, which has resulted in non-access to the relevant funds. I therefore believe that increasing the use of funds by the regions will also depend on administrative capacity at both national, regional and local level. Finally, I agree with the EP's position that strengthening administrative capacity for the implementation and political evaluation phases and good governance can help to improve absorption capacity, and I agree with the need to encourage relevant structural reforms in line with the objectives of territorial cohesion policy and sustainable growth and employment.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy. These EU funding is an important means of developing our regions. If they are paid out faster and easier, citizens will benefit.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. With a budget of more than EUR 215 billion and its structural and investment funds, cohesion policy is an important investment instrument for the Union. The priorities for funding have been divided into three pillars: the Europe 2020 targets, the country-specific recommendations and socio-economic analysis at national and regional level. I support the accelerated implementation of cohesion policy. There is still a great deal of support and solution to be done in this area, which should be tackled quickly in the various regions.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The aim of the resolution is to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy in all EU regions and to improve its effectiveness, a key issue given that this instrument has a budget of more than EUR 350 billion by 2020 and that in several Member States it is the main source of public investment funding. We agree with many of the things that are proposed: recommendations for simplification of procedures, improvement of information, reduction of deadlines, implementation of tools for analysis and evaluation of the use of funds, etc. But there are references to the deepening of structural reforms and the use of Stability and Growth Pact mechanisms that we find problematic because they support the austerity policies we have been undergoing for years in Spain and other EU countries. For consistency with the denunciation position in the face of these instruments, we voted ABSTENTION.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this resolution as the objectives of enhancing growth and job creation can be better achieved through a coherent interaction within the EU economic policy mix of structural reforms and growth enhancing investment, all supported and accelerated by cohesion policy investments. With a budget of over EUR 350 billion until 2020, cohesion funds represent the main source of public investment for some regions across Europe. It is concerning that the implementation of Cohesion Policy 2014-2020 has been significantly delayed and its operational programmes as well. With this vote, I hope that the Commission will commit itself further to implement the cohesion policy more effectively.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Nowadays, in a period of overcoming the consequences of the financial, economic and migratory crisis, the EU cohesion policy can help deliver more jobs, economic growth and energy efficiency. Almost a third of the total EU budget – EUR 351.8 billion – has been set aside for the Cohesion Policy in 2014-2020. To ensure maximum impact for these investments, more effective, efficient and timely use of cohesion policy support should be ensured.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy expresses a number of very useful forward-looking ideas. The motion for a resolution outlines the problems that hampered the implementation of cohesion policy during the 2007-2013 programming period. For example, insufficient information for potential beneficiaries, a lengthy process of project approval, complex State aid and public procurement rules.  It underlines the need to strengthen administrative capacities, as it is a prerequisite for the effective and timely implementation of cohesion policy, highlights the importance of timely disbursement of cohesion funds, the urgent need to eliminate payment arrears and calls for better communication on cohesion policy and its results. As the motion for a resolution states, it is of the utmost importance that joint reflection on post-2020 cohesion policy begins as soon as possible.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ The cohesion policy promotes balanced and sustainable development throughout the EU and I believe that its implementation should be expedited. The risk of decommitment with regard to the European Structural and Investment funds is of further concern. These funds should be used in line with the Europe 2020 policy throughout the Member States. Although the global economic downturn may have stunted the implementation of such funds, there should be a continuous dialogue between the Commission and the Member States seeking investments in order to harmonise the general cohesion policy over the European Union.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework set out principles and conditions for the so-called cohesion policy, which accounts for around 33% of the EU budget. Expenditure totals EUR 351.8 billion. This is about reducing economic and social inequalities and strengthening social cohesion in Europe. The fact that such large sums of money are paid out via Brussels and that structural policy is not primarily pursued in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity is critical of the nation states and regions. ALFA is considered to be even more problematic if the conditions laid down by all Member States to disburse funds for relevant programmes and projects are now to be questioned and, if necessary, repealed 'to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy'. Serious structural policy is not primarily characterised by the rapid disbout of funds, but by the high quality of measures. I reject this because of the considerable doubts about the demands mentioned in the motion for a resolution (e.g. 'decommitment'' and 'combination of the ESI Fund with EFSI'). Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ Accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy can only be a positive element for Member States. I firmly believe that investments under the cohesion policy – through its EUR 350 billion euro budget until 2020 – will aid Member States in enhancing growth and job creation.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted for the motion for a resolution submitted following a question for oral response B8-0364/2016 in accordance with Article 128(5) of the EIA. Rules of procedure on faster implementation of cohesion policy, since I know the issues well and have encountered problems of absorption of EU funds as prefect of Istria County.  There are many problems that have been correctly detected in the Resolution: complicated implementation system, insufficient engagement and insufficient competence with some national institutions in charge of cohesion policy, insufficient administrative capacity at national, local and regional level, late payment, etc.  I support the establishment of a working group on better implementation of the 2007-2013 programmes for countries where necessary, for which I have once launched the initiative myself. I also support the establishment of a high-level expert group to simplify the implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Diane James MEP voted against this because we feel EU regional funding is a propaganda tool and shamelessly wastes UK taxpayers’ money to fund it. The so-called ‘reforms’ are little more than EU attempts to cement control.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which regrets the delays in the launch and implementation of the cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period and calls on the Commission and the Member States to use the flexibility margins offered, to simplify cohesion policy and, more generally, to remove all the barriers that cause the delays. It also calls for improved administrative capacity to encourage the absorption of funds.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Cohesion policy with the relevant funds serves as an important source of investment for Member States and plays an important role in convergence. The rural areas of Austria, especially the Alpine region and Burgenland, have also benefited from this policy. However, some reservations remain with this resolution, such as the tendency to use the Cohesion Funds to implement a transfer union. For these reasons, I am abstaining on this resolution.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, as it calls on the Commission and the Member States to use the ESI Funds to their full potential and in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, in order to enhance social and economic cohesion and reduce territorial disparities by enabling all regions to become more competitive and to facilitate investment.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework set out principles and conditions for the so-called cohesion policy, which accounts for around 33% of the EU budget. Expenditure totals EUR 351.8 billion. This is about reducing economic and social inequalities and strengthening social cohesion in Europe. The fact that such large sums of money are paid out via Brussels and that structural policy is not primarily pursued in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity is critical of the nation states and regions. ALFA is considered to be even more problematic if the conditions laid down by all Member States to disburse funds for relevant programmes and projects are now to be questioned and, if necessary, repealed 'to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy'. Serious structural policy is not primarily characterised by the rapid disbout of funds, but by the high quality of measures. I reject this because of the considerable doubts about the demands mentioned in the motion for a resolution (e.g. 'decommitment'' and 'combination of the ESI Fund with EFSI').

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy makes a number of very useful, forward-looking ideas, which is why I voted in favour of it in the plenary vote in Strasbourg in May.  The motion for a resolution outlines the problems that hampered the implementation of cohesion policy during the 2007-2013 programming period (e.g. insufficient information for potential beneficiaries, lengthy process of project approval, complex state aid and public procurement rules), stresses the need to strengthen administrative capacities, as this is a prerequisite for the effective and timely implementation of cohesion policy, highlights the importance of timely disbursement of cohesion funds , calls for the pressing need to eliminate the payment arrears and for better communication on cohesion policy and its results.  As the motion for a resolution states, it is of the utmost importance that joint reflection on post-2020 cohesion policy begins as soon as possible.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The main objective of the resolution is to accelerate the effective implementation of cohesion policy in all regions of the EU. Although the report is positive, because it promotes a better cohesion policy with faster implementation, without delays in payments, more administrative capacity and sustainable development, it does not fully cover me. I voted to abstain because the report mentions specific structural reforms which I do not support.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Cohesion policy serves the interests of both the centre and the peripheral countries, if properly implemented. It is necessary to agree with the objective of the resolution, which, overall, can reduce obstacles and reduce administrative burdens. Accelerating implementation also helps to reduce unemployment and increase efficiency. It is also the responsibility of the Member States to allocate the resources available to their entrepreneurs, and there is room for improvement.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The cohesion policy is EU’s main investment and development policy that covers all EU regions. By enhancing social and economic cohesion it aims to bring the EU closer to its citizens. Having said that, in order for all regions to become competitive and to facilitate investment, we should accelerate the implementation of the cohesion policy. Timely implementation is the key not only for the successful fulfilment of the Europe 2020 strategy, in which the cohesion policy is a central pillar, but also to avoid Member States’ decommitment of funds. It is important to note that achieving timely implementation will require administrative capacity building both at national and regional level. Therefore, the Commission should support the strengthening of Member States’ administrative capacity. We should launch effective communication policy in order to raise public awareness of cohesion policy implementation so people to gain a better understanding of the results and impacts of cohesion policy.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy. While some positions are common sense, such as reducing payment deadlines, which should be a priority for the European Commission, or simplifying the whole process of committing and monitoring the Structural Funds, the motion for a resolution does not call into question either the holding of an urban agenda or the continuation of macro-regional strategies. Furthermore, it continues to welcome the principle of thematic concentration and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy which run counter to the interests of France and the poorest communities. Communities that, let us remember in times of economic crisis, need more flexibility in obtaining Structural Funds and better articulation with State/Region plan contracts. Finally, it should be noted that the motion for a resolution does not address the thorny issue of the reprogramming of the Structural Funds in favour of migrant reception programmes.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: in writing. ‒ The cohesion policy of the European Union is undoubtedly one of the most important instruments which bring ordinary citizens and the EU much closer to each other. Therefore, constant work on the improvement of this policy is not only crucial but also necessary to keep EU cohesion policy harmonised with other EU policies as well as providing an appropriate, sustainable improvement in the flexibility of mechanisms to better react to local needs and more effectively coordinate the use of EU programmes for citizens.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I spoke out against this text. Following the Committee on Regional Development's assessment of the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, it sets out a set of proposals. Indeed, many points have been raised during this review and call into question the effectiveness of cohesion policy. That is why the rapporteur recommends reducing payment times and simplifying the Structural Funds process. However, the text does not focus on the fundamental political problems of the Europe 2020 targets, which are destroying the poorest local authorities and the interests of the Member States.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of EU cohesion policy as the main source of public investment in some Member States. The objectives of growth promotion and job creation can be achieved through coherent interaction within the framework of the Union's combination of economic policies of structural reforms and investments in support of growth, all favoured and accelerated by cohesion policy investments. The fact that Rule 2 of the 2007-2013 perspective has been extended to n+3 for all Member States is positive. However, there is a clear concern about the significant delay in the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, including the deadline for the adoption of the Operational Programmes.  This resolution sets out how it intends to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy and what measures are envisaged to facilitate the implementation of the Operational Programmes and prevent the release of funds.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. U2012 Investment policy is regarded as the Union's main investment and development policy. This proposal arises because cohesion policy needs to be coordinated and harmonised with other Union policies, such as the digital single market or transport policy in order to meet the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy.  The report aims to bring about relevant structural reforms, including investment-friendly policies and the fight against fraud. It is also intended to reduce territorial differences by establishing a plan in which all regions are able to develop their competitiveness. I support this proposal as a good interaction between cohesion policy and growth and development policies would facilitate the path towards achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework set out principles and conditions for the so-called cohesion policy, which accounts for around 33% of the EU budget. Expenditure totals EUR 351.8 billion. This is about reducing economic and social inequalities and strengthening social cohesion in Europe. The fact that such large sums of money are paid out via Brussels and that structural policy is not primarily pursued in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity is critical of the nation states and regions. ALFA is considered to be even more problematic if the conditions laid down by all Member States to disburse funds for relevant programmes and projects are now to be questioned and, if necessary, repealed 'to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy'. Serious structural policy is not primarily characterised by the rapid disbout of funds, but by the high quality of measures. I reject this because of the considerable doubts about the demands mentioned in the motion for a resolution (including 'decommitment'' and 'combining the ESI Fund with EFSI').

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the European subsidy policy, I do not agree with the proposed increase in the administrative capacity to deal with subsidies, I do not agree with the involvement of the European Investment Bank in this EU policy, nor do I agree with the increase in EU promotion by informing the public about cohesion funds.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has allocated €350 billion to cohesion policy by 2020. In order to make efficient use of these resources, the Commission must respond flexibly to the actual state of management of these resources. I support the proposal that, after two years of the new programming period, the Commission should produce and present analyses as soon as possible that demonstrate the weaknesses in management and the current state of absorption of these resources, but also the actual payment discipline. The subsequent adoption of adequate measures can thus create scope for the swift removal of the obstacles identified and to fulfil the meaning and purpose of the resources allocated.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 Referring to my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/5/2016, I am voting against the motion for a resolution on speeding up the implementation of cohesion policy because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Although some provisions of the text are adequate, it does not call into question the holding of an urban agenda or the continuation of macro-regional strategies. We oppose the principle of thematic concentration and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which run counter to the interests of France and in particular to the poorest communities. Furthermore, the issue of reprogramming structural funds to support migrant reception programmes is not addressed. Finally, it should be stressed that support for improving the administrative capacity of some Member States and local authorities will, first of all, go to the Eastern countries which have the lowest absorption rates of structural funds.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on speeding up the implementation of cohesion policy. With a budget of over EUR 350 billion up to 2020, cohesion policy is the Union's main investment and development method for all its regions. For some Member States, this structural fund is the main source of public investment and the union's most closest approach to its citizens. The objectives of the 2020 Strategy are achieved through a coherent interaction between growth and development policies. This policy plays a key role and should be harmonised with other EU policies such as the macro-regional strategy, the digital single market, the Energy Union, research and innovation in order to contribute better to achieving its objectives. Implementation of cohesion policy has been delayed in view of the two years since the start of the new programming period. The Commission will submit an annual summary report on the fund programmes to the EP, a strategic report will be drawn up to monitor and summarise the progress report of the Member States.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 EP resolution gives an overview of the 2007-2013 programming period, highlighting the main obstacles and problems that have hampered the implementation of cohesion policy – insufficient information for potential beneficiaries, lack of suitable projects, slow and lengthy approval of major projects, as well as complex and time-consuming procurement procedures, complex State aid rules, complex authorisation procedures, unresolved property relations, over-authorisation procedure and difficulties in obtaining funding I agree with the provisions laid down in the resolution , in which the EP calls on the Commission to take concrete steps to avoid these problems for the 2014-2020 period by strengthening the capacity of national, regional and local authorities to prepare project documents in a timely and efficient manner.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This resolution calls for an acceleration of cohesion policy. With a budget of 350 billion euros until 2020, it is the main tool for regional development, through various envelopes such as the European Social Fund. This resolution calls for simplifying the administrative procedures for accessing these funds. But it still calls for a part of national and European public investment generated under this policy to be exempted from the calculation of the national deficit.  Yet the root of the problem remains. The text wants to subordinate this social policy to the economic demands of Brussels and in particular to the stability and growth pact and its remedies, "structural reforms" and "good governance". In the end, this is a disengagement of the state and additional budget cuts at the national level. The text leaves room only for the largest companies, in administrative capacity and expertise, to respond to European calls for tenders. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I note in this report the reduction of payment times or the simplification of the process of committing and monitoring of structural funds. On the other hand, the proposal is not critical of maintaining an urban agenda or pursuing macro-regional strategies. Moreover, it praises the Europe 2020 objectives or the thematic concentration principle, which are against the interests of France and the less wealthy communities. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. Cohesion policy, with a budget of more than €350 billion by 2020, is the instrument that helps bring the EU closer to citizens and the main investment and development policy for all EU regions and which in some Member States represents the main source of public investment. The regulation of the period 2014-2020 introduced several key reforms in cohesion policy, such as thematic concentration, which, through the necessary flexibility, has enabled better adaptation to local needs, better results-oriented, better coordination with economic and social policy, greater synergy between EU priorities and regional needs and better coordinated use of ESI Funds thanks to the common strategic framework. It is therefore necessary to coordinate policies to maximise cohesion policy funding. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it includes suggestions for the facilitation of the exchange of best practices amongst Member States regarding the decentralisation in the control of European structural and investment funds. This would improve the implementation of projects as well as improve regional and local actor interaction with the Union. It also calls for improved communication with citizens regarding the implementation of the cohesion policy in order to improve awareness of its significance and impact.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The biggest obstacles to the implementation of cohesion policy in 2007-2013 in some Member States were, in particular, the lack of information of potential beneficiaries, which led to a lack of eligible projects, slow and lengthy approval of major projects, along with a lack of administrative structures for managing investments for large projects, complicated and time-consuming procurement procedures, complex State aid rules and complicated authorisation procedures. Therefore, information should be provided on the obstacles faced by Member States in implementing cohesion policy in the 2014-2020 programming period. I believe that administrative capacity is an inevitable prerequisite for a well-timed and successful implementation of cohesion policy. Appropriate structural reforms should also be encouraged, in line with the objectives of territorial cohesion and sustainable growth and employment, as well as with investment promotion and anti-fraud policies. I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution on the acceleration of implementation of EU cohesion policy because the budget of over EUR 350 billion until 2020 represents in some Member States the main source of public investments. Objectives of enhancing growth and job creation can be achieved through a coherent interaction within the EU economic policy mix of structural reforms and growth enhancing investment, all supported and accelerated by cohesion policy investments.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Regional Development has proposed a resolution to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy. The draft seeks to face the main obstacles to the use of resources in each Member State during the 2007-2013 programming period, and urges the analysis of the lessons learnt from that period and their application in the current period. It highlights the importance of administrative capacity in terms of timely and successful implementation of cohesion policy. It criticises excessive centralisation and a lack of trust and stresses the importance of timely payments for the correct and effective implementation of cohesion policy and its credibility. I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Vote against it because the motion for a resolution does not call into question either the holding of an urban agenda or the continuation of macro-regional strategies. Furthermore, it continues to welcome the principle of thematic concentration and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy which run counter to the interests of France and the poorest communities. Communities that need more flexibility in obtaining Structural Funds and better articulation with State/Region plan contracts, especially in times of crisis.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. It should be noted that the motion for a resolution does not address the thorny issue of reprogramming the Structural Funds for migrant reception programmes at this time (it is necessary to wait for amendments to be tabled). Finally, it goes without saying that support for improving the administrative capacity of some Member States and local authorities will go first to the Eastern countries which have the lowest absorption rates from the Structural Funds. That's why I voted AGAINST.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. This text aims to accelerate the implementation of the cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, which has experienced significant delays. In particular, I support the call to the Member States for the simplification of this policy and for the removal of all the barriers that are causing delays. Indeed, the effectiveness of a policy depends above all on its legibility and accessibility. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. Thanks to cohesion policy, the European Union is able to lend a helping hand to regions that face serious challenges as a result of demographics or other adversity, such as globalisation and climate change. The effective implementation of cohesion policy delivers visible results that are directly experienced by the regions concerned and their inhabitants.  As with all instruments, effective implementation is essential for cohesion policy, which is why I consider it particularly important to speed up the implementation process. This idea is supported, among other things, by the motion for a resolution, which we managed to adopt today by a large majority.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that calls on Member States to use the ESI Funds to their full potential, in order to enhance social and economic cohesion and reduce territorial disparities by enabling all regions to become more competitive and to facilitate investment, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – Cohesion policy, with nearly EUR 350 billion planned by 2020, is an important mechanism for investment and development in the EU, and in some Member States it forms a major source of public investment. At the same time, however, the information shows that although two years have passed since the beginning of the current programming period, there are delays in the implementation of cohesion policy.  By supporting this resolution, I join the call on the European Commission to make full use of the opportunities offered by the ESI Funds in order to strengthen social cohesion between different European regions and reduce territorial disparities, for which delays in the Funds are detrimental.   An important finding from the previous period is that administrative capacity at national but also regional and local level is an essential precondition for successful implementation of cohesion policy and for increasing the competitiveness of regions. I therefore believe that the European Commission should support strengthening administrative capacity for policy implementation stages.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 During the 2007-2013 programming period, the main obstacles and problems that prevented the implementation of cohesion policy in several Member States and regions were insufficient information for potential beneficiaries, the cumbersome and lengthy process of approving major projects, complex and lengthy procurement procedures, complex State aid rules, complicated authorisation procedures, excessive duration of the authorisation procedure and difficult access to funding. We call on the Commission, for the 2014-2020 programming period, to provide, on the one hand, information on the obstacles that Member States face in implementing cohesion policy and, on the other hand, an assessment of the impact of the ex ante conditionalities exercise on the effective implementation of the policy. I welcome the establishment of a task force for better implementation of the programmes for the period 2007-2013 in eight Member States, and we call on the Commission to inform Parliament of the results achieved. The Commission should continue, together with this task force, to support and accelerate the implementation of the 2014-2020 programmes in all Member States and to submit to Parliament an action plan on the activities of the Task Force.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy, I consider it important that the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States and their local and regional authorities, find ways to effectively combine funds from the Structural Funds and the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Although they are two instruments of a different nature, they can complement each other and increase the leverage effect of investments. The Commission should also issue comprehensive guidelines on public procurement and the preventive measures necessary to avoid unnecessary errors and irregularities in the award process and, as a result, financial corrections and possible cancellation of EU financial contributions.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The resolution correctly mentions that cohesion policy is the main source of public investment in some Member States. This resolution does not change the financial disempowerment of the nation states by cohesion policy either. The resolution was therefore clearly to be rejected.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Cohesion policy can increase the number of jobs, growth and energy efficiency, so it needs to be used efficiently and in a timely manner.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I support the resolution that has been found. It is essential to ensure that greater attention is paid to the implementation of cohesion policy. It should be noted that European cohesion policy is more than a simple redistribution of funds. This is an improvement in efficiency in lagging regions, ensuring sustainable and sustainable development and the well-being of citizens living throughout the country. In addition, in order to reduce the gap and disparities between different regions more effectively, it is essential to assess the use of the ESI Funds for the period 2014-2020 and to harmonise ESI and EFSI funding. Targeted use of funds increases competitiveness and enables faster economic growth.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. Cohesion policy, with a budget of more than €350 billion, is for some Member States the only source of public investment. Cohesion policy has a strong impact in many areas. In particular, it provides the necessary investment framework and strategy for the implementation of the Europe 2020 Strategy. However, it has been two years since the start of the new programming period, and there have been delays in the implementation of cohesion policy. Most operational programmes were adopted at the end of 2014 and in 2015 and a significant number of the ex ante conditions have not yet been fulfilled. I therefore voted in favour of the report on speeding up the implementation of cohesion policy, which calls on the Commission, for the 2014-2020 programming period, to provide, on the one hand, information on the obstacles faced by Member States in implementing cohesion policy and, on the other hand, an assessment of the impact of the fulfilment of ex ante conditions on the effective implementation of the policy.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this because we feel EU regional funding is a propaganda tool and shamelessly wastes UK taxpayers’ money to fund it. The so-called ‘reforms’ are little more than EU attempts to cement control.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The correct link between growth and development policies and structural reforms is necessary to ensure full implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. With a budget of over EUR 350 billion, cohesion policy is the instrument through which the European Union invests in its regions and brings it closer to its citizens. I therefore believe that the call for the Commission to carry out detailed analyses and the call for greater coordination between the parties concerned can help to achieve the objectives set. I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Since the 2014-2020 regulations - 2020 introduced several key cohesion policy reforms such as a thematic concentration allowing for better adaptation to local conditions, a greater focus on results, better coordination with economic and social policy, better connectivity between EU priorities and regional needs, and a closer coordinated use of ESI Funds through a common strategic framework, it is clear that they will accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy itself. The Commission answered the question of what are the main obstacles and problems in the Member States in 2007-2013, citing insufficient information to beneficiaries, slow and long approval of large projects, lack of administrative structures for managing investments in large projects, complex and lengthy procurement procedures, complex State aid rules, complicated licensing procedures, unresolved ownership relationships, length of the authorisation process and difficult access to finance. This resolution supports the faster implementation of cohesion policy and that is why I supported its adoption.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union's cohesion policy, with a budget of over EUR 350 billion until 2020, is the main source of public investment in some Member States and therefore plays a key role in the growth and development of European regions and cities. The 2014-2020 regulations introduced important reforms in cohesion policy, such as focus by themes, greater focus on results and better coordination with economic and social policy. However, two years after the start of the new programming period, the implementation of cohesion policy continues to suffer from considerable delays. That is why we call on the Commission and the Member States to do more to make full use of the potential of the European Structural Funds, in accordance with the Europe 2020 strategy, to strengthen social and economic cohesion and to reduce territorial disparities. From the analysis of the period 2007-2013, it is clear that the main problems were due to insufficient information available to potential beneficiaries and long and complex award procedures. That is why it is very positive that the Commission has set up a high-level group to ensure greater transparency and simplify procedures.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the adoption of a resolution on the topic of faster implementation of cohesion policy. The amount of untapped potential of the European Structural and Investment Funds is worrying, so for example not a penny of assistance from EU funds has been withdrawn by as many as 85% of Croatian municipalities. I therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to make full use of the potential of the ESI Funds, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, in order to strengthen social and economic cohesion and reduce territorial disparities, enabling all regions to become more competitive and facilitate investment, including private ones. given that the economic crisis in many Member States has caused a lack of liquidity and available public funds for public investment, and as cohesion policy funds become the main source of public investment, I call on the Commission and the Member States to fully apply and take advantage of the existing flexibility under the Stability and Growth Pact, and I ask the Commission to maintain a permanent dialogue with Member States that have requested the application of the current investment clause , with a view to maximising the flexibility associated with investment in growth and jobs.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution aims to promote policies that, in the 2014-2020 programming period, accelerate the implementation of cohesion funds. The adopted text does not, however, advocate facilitating the financing to be allocated to Member States in this area. On the contrary, it sees it as essential for the fulfilment of cohesion that Member States comply with and enforce all policies that keep them from that same cohesion: following the line of the Europe 2020 strategy; involve and finance the private sector; comply with the requirements related to the internal and external implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact; harmonisation of the implementation of development funds with strategic investment funds and the single digital market; the need to encourage structural reforms and the importance of Member States complying with actions on ex ante conditionalities by the end of 2016. We are talking about adding exclusion to exclusion, adding divergence to the divergence. These are logical to which Portugal is particularly sensitive at the moment, with the very real threat of seeing development funds suspended for non-compliance with an artificial deficit rule. We are strongly opposed to this policy of liberalisation of cohesion. We advocate real cohesion, based on solidarity between peoples and the sovereign definition of development strategies.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒One of the most important reasons for reforming the EU's cohesion policy was to ensure faster access to funds that will serve national authorities and regions to finance projects of utmost importance for technological, economic and social development and the development of Member States' infrastructure. I supported the European Parliament's resolution calling for greater cooperation between the Commission and the Member States, faster implementation of cohesion policy in all Member States and the use of statistics that could be used as relevant in the adaptation and application of those parts of the fund that directly affect work, growth and employment. This ensures an acceptable and binding financial framework and encourages Member States to become more and more actively involved in the European Cohesion Policy Project 2014-2020.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion Policy is the European Union's strongest investment and development instrument, with more than EUR 350 billion earmarked until 2020. However, as this policy has been launched with considerable delay in the new programming period in many Member States and the speed of its implementation is still lagging behind, the threat of the impossibility of using all its instruments by the end of the period is more than real. It is for this reason that I supported the European Parliament's resolution, which encourages the European Commission to analyse and assess the state of play. I consider it extremely important that the analysis also includes a study of the obstacles that individual Member States face in drawing. I also voted in favour of strengthening administrative capacity at national, regional and local level, which should help implement cohesion policy in the future. Similarly, I supported new initiatives in the field of communication, as it is precisely the lack of public awareness that is one of the blocks negatively affecting not only the very implementation of policy, but also the scepticry that is oftenthe product of disinformation.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy plays an essential role in closing socio-economic disparities between EU Member States. A successful cohesion policy will increase the competitiveness of all European regions. However, the EU and the Member States show both long implementation delays and a lack of flexibility, which significantly limits the effectiveness of this policy. The full report proposes a number of recommendations for faster action in this area and for better implementation of the existing programmes for 2014-2020. Therefore, these two areas also need to be significantly strengthened. The potential of local and regional authorities, whose role in drawing on ESI Funds is crucial, is also far from being exploited.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to exploit the full potential of the European Structural Investment Funds (ESIF), noting that the economic crisis has caused liquidity problems and a lack of public funds available for investment. In the context of stagnation or recession of certain economies, it is essential to expand the absorption capacity of funds and ensure the effective application of financial instruments. Only the strategic implementation of resources can enhance the impact of funding and mitigate the negative effects of cuts in public budgets. However, the available strategic options and the maximisation of existing resources through alternative and creative solutions are, to this day, severely hampered by the complexity and slowness that characterise the implementation of cohesion policy. Having said the above, the rapporteur considers that an assessment of the implementation of cohesion policy could provide important learning elements with a view to the debate on future cohesion policy post-2020. I voted in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. – We voted against this because we feel EU regional funding is a propaganda tool and shamelessly wastes UK taxpayers’ money to fund it. The so-called ‘reforms’ are little more than EU attempts to cement control.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy. With a budget of 351.8 billion euros for the period 2014-2020, cohesion policy is the main investment policy of the European Union. It targets all EU cities and regions with the aim of supporting job creation, business competitiveness, economic growth, sustainable development and improving the quality of life of citizens. However, there have been delays in implementing the cohesion policy. We therefore call on the Commission to take a number of measures to speed up the process: informing of the obstacles in the Member States, supporting the strengthening of administrative capacity at national, regional and local levels, speeding up work to simplify procedures and maintaining a high degree of transparency, or encouraging EIB participation through increased technical and financial support.  Finally, it is important to raise public awareness and increase the visibility of the implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's cohesion policy, with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion by 2020, is the main source of public investment in some Member States. We all agree on the need to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy and to know the measures that are being considered to facilitate the implementation of operational programmes in order to avoid the cancellation of funds.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. •u2012 Cohesion policy is the primary instrument with which the EU approaches citizens, as well as representing the Union's main investment and development policy, as well as the main source of public investment for some Member States. The objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy can be achieved through a coherent interaction between growth, development and structural reform policies. Cohesion policy therefore plays an essential role in the integration and development of these objectives. There is a major concern about the delay in the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, so the Commission is asked how it intends to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy. I welcome the conduct of a joint debate in plenary on these issues. That is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In voting on the general delay in implementing the 2014-2020 Cohesion Policy, we called on the European Commission to take a series of actions to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy. In essence, the resolution calls on the Commission to carry out an assessment on the implementation of cohesion policy, in order to target, on the one hand, the ways to ensure its acceleration, and, on the other hand, to draw lessons in the context of the discussions on cohesion policy beyond 2020.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 In Mrs Mihailova's report, I see many very positive elements. The call already made in the first point to the Commission to assess EFSI funds that individual Member States may not absorb seems very good. However, as a practitioner who has repeatedly implemented Structural Funds projects, I would like to point out that such an aspiration seems good only in theory. In practice, this will, in particular, create an additional administrative burden for Member States' ministries, agencies and project implementers and certainly will not speed up the implementation of projects. I also regret that the rapporteur has found no place to record a call for the Commission to continue to actively combat the plundering of EU aid funds. The rapporteur rightly emphasises the relationship between administrative capacity, the principles of good governance and the absorption rates of EU support. The call to the Commission to ensure timely payment of support is also welcomed. I am not sure whether the call for a closer involvement of the European Investment Bank in the implementation of projects is a welcome step. Instead, it would be more necessary to invite the Commission to look for better mechanisms for interaction with the private sector. In view of the lack of funds in the public sector, I propose to include a call for the Commission to look for ways to combine funding for the same or similar projects from individual sources of EU support.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because cohesion policy, with a budget of more than EUR 350 million (2014–2020), is the main instrument for the investment and development of regions, being the most effective policy for promoting territorial development in the European Union (EU), setting populations to regions with the lowest economic/population density and stimulating the creation of comparative advantages for regions. The importance of Cohesion Policy is undeniable and, when we talk about the 'figures' of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) in the total Public Investment of our Member States (MS), we find that in 10 MS, more than 50% of public investment between 2014-2016 was made using the ESI Funds. Therefore, we demand its rapid and unbureaucratic implementation, bearing in mind that it is not long before the "plus 3" of the "n" of 2014... In prospection, more general, and as the European Parliament, we should pursue 3 key objectives: To strongly promote the implementation on the ground of the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF); Discuss the revision of the MFF and strive to achieve a joint position that is most widely supported by the different parliamentary groups; Start preparatory discussions on the MFF framework and the Union's long-term strategy post-2020.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for the implementation of cohesion policy to be implemented more quickly and effectively. The aim here is to raise the risk of release of unused funds. It is crucial to avoid such a situation. The Commission and Member States must use the flexibility margins available to them to remove all the barriers that cause payment and implementation delays. I supported this resolution because it also calls for full use of the administrative capacity of Member States and their local authorities to ensure greater absorption of funds. Cohesion policy is necessary to finance the development of our European territories; it is therefore necessary for the Union and the Member States to engage fully, more efficiently and more quickly in the implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to take action to fully implement the Union's cohesion policies. In particular, the report calls for the monitoring and relaunch of these policies through the exploitation of the potential represented by the Structural Funds and the European Investment Fund. Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The aim of the resolution is to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy in all EU regions and to improve its effectiveness, a key issue given that this instrument has a budget of more than EUR 350 billion by 2020 and that in several Member States it is the main source of public investment funding. We agree with many of the things that are proposed: recommendations for simplification of procedures, improvement of information, reduction of deadlines, implementation of tools for analysis and evaluation of the use of funds, etc. But there are references to the deepening of structural reforms and the use of Stability and Growth Pact mechanisms that we find problematic because they support the austerity policies we have been undergoing for years in Spain and other EU countries. For consistency with the denunciation position in the face of these instruments, we voted ABSTENTION.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The aim of the resolution is to request from the European Parliament an acceleration of the implementation of cohesion policy funds, given the delays in payments that the European institutions have to beneficiaries (regions and sub-state entities). It therefore calls for the Commission to report to Parliament on the implementation and acceleration of the payment plan.
