It also requests an assessment of the impact of compliance with the preconditions for project financing, given the problems arising from confusing regulations and lack of information to interested public actors. Despite this, I cannot be in favour of this institution declaring itself in favour of "promoting structural reforms", the meaning of which is none other than the acceleration of the dismantling of public services and the reduction of public spending and investment, with fateful consequences in terms of social and territorial inequality, contrary to the Treaties. In short, I have opted for abstention in the vote on this resolution.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union intends to achieve five concrete targets for employment, innovation, education, social integration and climate/energy by 2020. In order to achieve them and to address the different development needs of all European regions, €351.8 billion has been allocated to cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. Through this resolution, Parliament has called on the Commission to speed up activities linked to the introduction of simplified procedures in such a way as to strengthen social and economic cohesion and thus reduce territorial disparities in the European Union. To this end, administrative competence at both national, regional and local level becomes a fundamental prerequisite for achieving timely and positive results of cohesion policy. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ With a budget of over EUR 350 billion until 2020, Cohesion funds represent the main source of public investment for some regions across Europe. I have voted in favour of this resolution as the objectives of enhancing growth and job creation can be better achieved through a coherent interaction within the EU economic policy mix of structural reforms and growth enhancing investment, all supported and accelerated by Cohesion policy investments. It is concerning that the implementation of Cohesion Policy 2014-2020 has been significantly delayed and its operational programmes as well. With this vote, I hope that the Commission will commit itself further to implement the cohesion policy more effectively.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. – EU spending opportunities have long been burdened with excessive bureaucracy. Simplifying this process is one of the prerequisites for speeding up the implementation of the absorption of european Structural and Investment Funds. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the parliamentary question on the faster implementation of cohesion policy on the grounds that cohesion policy is an important instrument for achieving the EU's strategic objectives, providing a seven-year financial framework for projects contributing to the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Member States of the European Union.  The Republic of Croatia, as a full member of the European Union, has the right to compete with quality projects for the funds at its disposal under cohesion policy. For the period 2014-2020, we are talking about €8.6 billion, which would mean that it has the right to spend around €1.2 billion a year on various development activities with a particular focus on less developed areas.  The European Parliament asks the Commission to respond to a question on concrete measures it has planned to take to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy and facilitate the implementation of operational programmes. It also asks for justification on the main barriers in Member States that hindered absorption of funds. Finally, Parliament underlines the importance of a timely payment that contributes to the correct implementation and credibility of the policy and raises the question of the measures under consideration to ensure the full implementation of the payment plan in the context of the 2016 budget and for the coming years.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion by 2020 is a major investment and development policy, affects all regions and is the main source of public finance in some Member States. Two years have passed since the start of the new programming period and there are constant delays in the implementation of cohesion policy. It is necessary for the Commission to examine the state of play of the use of the European Structural Funds and to carry out a detailed analysis of decommitment risks, indicating the amount per Member State and an analysis of the forecasts of payments that hampered the absorption of the Structural Funds in the last programming period. In particular, it was a lack of information to potential beneficiaries, slow and lengthy approval of major projects, together with a lack of administrative structures for managing investments for large projects, complicated and time-consuming public procurement procedures, complex State aid rules, complicated authorisation procedures and difficult access to finance. In order to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy, the Commission has set up a high-level expert group to monitor simplification for beneficiaries, as it is one of the prerequisites for helping Member States to close regional disparities, create new jobs, support young people in the labour market, and promote large investments, but also support small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In some EU countries, cohesion policy with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion by 2020 represents the main source of public investment. Coordinated action of structural reforms, together with economic policy and investment, enables growth and job creation to be boosted.  The resolution raises an interesting question in relation to the risk of appropriations for appropriations in the third financial year (the so-called n+3 rule), which for the new programming period represents precisely 2016. The issue is particularly important because the implementation of operational programmes has been largely delayed in the current programming period, thus increasing the risk of the cancellation of appropriations for funds.  I support the request that the European Commission help EU Member States and their regions to reduce the risk of the suspension of appropriations for funds. I believe that the work already set up in the task force for better implementation of cohesion policy, which contributes, inter alia, to improving the capacity of the public administrations of the Member States, regions and cities. On the basis of the above, I also voted in favour of the resolution on the faster implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework set out principles and conditions for the so-called cohesion policy, which accounts for around 33% of the EU budget. Expenditure totals EUR 351.8 billion. This is about reducing economic and social inequalities and strengthening social cohesion in Europe. The fact that such large sums of money are paid out via Brussels and that structural policy is not primarily pursued in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity is critical of the nation states and regions. ALFA is considered to be even more problematic if the conditions laid down by all Member States to disburse funds for relevant programmes and projects are now to be questioned and, if necessary, repealed 'to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy'. Serious structural policy is not primarily characterised by the rapid disbout of funds, but by the high quality of measures. I reject this because of the considerable doubts about the demands mentioned in the motion for a resolution (e.g. 'decommitment'' and 'combination of the ESI Fund with EFSI').

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 EU cohesion policy is the main source of public investment in some countries. The interaction to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy within the EU's economic policy mix will allow positive linking of EU priorities to the needs of the regions, better coordination of the use of the European Structural and Investment Funds and better coordination with economic and social policy.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Cohesion Policy, with a budget of over €350 billion by 2020, is one of the most important instruments helping to bring the European Union closer to its citizens and is the European Union's main investment and development policy covering all REGIONS of the EU. In some Member States, such a policy forms the main source of public investment and is therefore of great importance. In order to achieve the objectives of Europe 2020, it is necessary to have a coherent interaction between growth and development policy and, where appropriate, structural reforms, as well as the active involvement of regions and cities in the implementation of these reforms. Without cohesion policy, it would not be possible to fully achieve these objectives. Its importance is reflected in many aspects of the European Union and I therefore support this proposal for a resolution on the faster implementation of cohesion policy. Administrative capacities at national, regional and local level are essential for its implementation, without which it is impossible to implement cohesion policy in a successful and timely manner. Also important is good rule that encourages relevant structural reforms in line with territorial cohesion, sustainable growth, employment goals and investment-oriented policies.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Cohesion Policy, with a budget of over €350 billion by 2020, is one of the most important instruments helping to bring the European Union closer to its citizens and is the European Union's main investment and development policy covering all REGIONS of the EU. In some Member States, such a policy forms the main source of public investment and is therefore of utmost importance. In order to achieve the objectives of Europe 2020, it is necessary to have a coherent interaction between growth and development policy and, where appropriate, structural reforms, as well as the active involvement of regions and cities in the implementation of these reforms. Without cohesion policy, it would not be possible to fully achieve these objectives. I support this proposal for a resolution on the faster implementation of cohesion policy, as its importance is reflected in many aspects of the European Union. Administrative capacities at national, regional and local level are essential for its implementation, without which it is impossible to implement cohesion policy in a successful and timely manner. Good rule that encourages relevant structural reforms in line with territorial cohesion, sustainable growth, employment objectives and investment-oriented policies is also essential.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution to the oral question on the faster implementation of cohesion policy. I support the Call on the Commission to assess the state of play of the implementation of the European Structural and Investment Funds for the period 2014-2020, while at the same time preparing a detailed analysis on the risk of decomasing commitments.  Cohesion policy investments must be coordinated and harmonised with other European Union policies. This is the only way to get closer to the Europe 2020 targets. The delay that has arisen in the last two years since the implementation of cohesion policy must encourage us to take measures to influence the faster implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ Cutting red tape and ensuring added value in EU programmes is key to ensuring that taxpayers’ money is well spent. I therefore welcome this broad call for better regulation and simplification across all of the EU’s regional development funds and I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In the resolution there are several positive elements in simplifying the procedures by which final beneficiaries (see Member States) receive grants from the Funds as well as in terms of further strengthening vulnerable economic areas. However, references are made to the promotion and implementation of structural reforms through policies and programmes (Task Force for better implementation, Better Regulation Strategy) which find us diametrically opposed. However, we could not vote against the proposal as a whole, since it is moving in positive currents and also the main beneficiaries of these funds are the peoples of the Mediterranean. As a result, we have kept an ATTITUDE.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU Structural and Investment Funds (ESI) do not really focus on creating permanent jobs, but promote temporary solutions and half-measures. Their main objective is to absorb resources with beneficiaries of certain large companies as well as NGOs.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy makes a number of very useful, forward-looking ideas, which is why I voted in favour of it in the plenary vote in Strasbourg in May.  The motion for a resolution outlines the problems that hampered the implementation of cohesion policy during the 2007-2013 programming period (e.g. insufficient information for potential beneficiaries, lengthy process of project approval, complex state aid and public procurement rules), stresses the need to strengthen administrative capacities, as this is a prerequisite for the effective and timely implementation of cohesion policy, highlights the importance of timely disbursement of cohesion funds , calls for the pressing need to eliminate the payment arrears and for better communication on cohesion policy and its results.  As the motion for a resolution states, it is of the utmost importance that joint reflection on post-2020 cohesion policy begins as soon as possible.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I agree that cohesion policy, with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion by 2020, is an instrument that helps bring the EU closer to its citizens. I also share the view that cohesion policy is one of the most important investment and development policies covering all EU regions, in many cases the primary source of public investment. I therefore consider it important to draw the attention of all stakeholders to the need for better coordination of implementation.  The resolution draws attention to the fact that the 2014-2020 provisions have introduced a number of key reforms in the area of cohesion policy. These are the "thematic concentrations" that allow local needs to be taken into account, greater focus on results, improved consistency with economic policy and social policy, closer links between EU priorities and regional needs, and better coordinated use of the European Structural and Investment Funds through the common strategic framework. I would also like to recommend to the Hungarian Government the finding that investments in cohesion policy should be coordinated and coordinated with other EU policies, such as the Digital Single Market, the Energy Union, social affairs, macro-regional strategy, urban agenda, research and innovation, and transport, in order to make a better contribution to achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 Cohesion policy will create more jobs and economic growth for the EU regions. Almost a third of the EU's total budget is earmarked for cohesion policy in 2014-2020. Right now, the EU needs investment. It is important for the realisation of investment that cohesion policy is speeded up, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's cohesion policy is an important resource for the development of disadvantaged regions in the Member States. The EUR 350 billion budget for 2014-2020 aims to support economic growth and create new jobs through the implementation of structural reforms and well-targeted investments. A positive development is the extension of the deadline for the expenditure of the funds available for the period 2007-2013 from two to three years as certain Member States need this respite in order to strengthen the necessary internal administrative procedures. This should not, however, affect the implementation of the Multiannual Cohesion Framework 2014-2020. In this respect, the Commission should speed up procedures to facilitate the implementation of operational programmes in order to avoid the decommitment of cohesion funds.  I fully support the adoption of this resolution by the European Parliament, the guarantor of the interests of European citizens.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy. I support the Commission's request to review the progress of the implementation of the ESI Funds over the 2014-2020 period and to conduct a detailed analysis of release risks, indicating the amounts per Member State, as well as an analysis of the payment forecasts submitted by the Member States as soon as possible after the expiry of the 31 January and 31 July deadlines set out in the regulation with common provisions. We also call on the Commission to clarify what measures are planned to avoid the release of the ESI Funds as much as possible.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Cohesion Policy is the EUs main tool to invest in and develop EU regions and cities, in order to promote job creation, business competitiveness, economic growth, sustainable development, and improve citizens’ quality of life.  Looking back at the period 2007-2013, the main obstacle to the better implementation of this policy has been the insufficient information available for potential beneficiaries. SMEs, start-ups and non-governmental organisations, which have the least administrative capacity, have particularly suffered much from this. This is why I welcome this resolution to accelerate the implementation of the cohesion policy, to find ways to speed up and improve the efficient implementation of the policy without losing the quality of the spending. Simplifying the policy, decreasing the administrative burdens it implies, and increasing its good governance, among other measures, could be helpful in that regard.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Given that in some Member States eu cohesion policy is the main source of public investment, I believe that the delay in implementing cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 is very worrying, as is the delay in the adoption of operational programmes. The objectives of increasing growth and jobs can be achieved through a coherent interaction between structural and growth-oriented investments under the European Union's economic policy mix.  I therefore support the Commission's call for ways to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy and assist Member States in addressing administrative problems in implementation, and for the Commission to find measures to facilitate the implementation of operational programmes with a view to avoiding revocation of funds.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on cohesion policy in the EU's mountainous regions. Mountain regions account for a significant proportion of EU territory (around 30%). The whole EU depends on the services of mountain ecosystems. Due to extreme conditions and remoteness, these regions are structurally disadvantaged to the point where many mountain regions are facing a decline and ageing population, which can disrupt the natural generation cycle and lead to a decline in social standards and quality of life. This often leads to higher unemployment rates, social exclusion and migration to cities. Mountain regions offer numerous opportunities to achieve the EU's objectives of employment, cohesion and environmental protection through the sustainable use of their natural resources.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The aim of the resolution is to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy in all EU regions and to improve its effectiveness, a key issue given that this instrument has a budget of more than EUR 350 billion by 2020 and that in several Member States it is the main source of public investment funding. We agree with many of the things that are proposed: recommendations for simplification of procedures, improvement of information, reduction of deadlines, implementation of tools for analysis and evaluation of the use of funds, etc. But there are references to the deepening of structural reforms and the use of Stability and Growth Pact mechanisms that we find problematic because they support the austerity policies we have been undergoing for years in Spain and other EU countries. For consistency with the denunciation position in the face of these instruments, we voted ABSTENTION.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework set out principles and conditions for the so-called cohesion policy, which accounts for around 33% of the EU budget. Expenditure totals EUR 351.8 billion. This is about reducing economic and social inequalities and strengthening social cohesion in Europe. The fact that such large sums of money are paid out via Brussels and that structural policy is not primarily pursued in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity is critical of the nation states and regions. ALFA is considered to be even more problematic if the conditions laid down by all Member States to disburse funds for relevant programmes and projects are now to be questioned and, if necessary, repealed 'to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy'. Serious structural policy is not primarily characterised by the rapid disbout of funds, but by the high quality of measures. I reject this because of the considerable doubts about the demands mentioned in the motion for a resolution (e.g. 'decommitment'' and 'combination of the ESI Fund with EFSI').

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Some of the positions taken by the REGI Committee are common sense, notably the one concerning the reduction of payment deadlines, which should be a priority for the European Commission, or the simplification of the whole process of commitment and monitoring of the Structural Funds. However, this motion for a resolution does not call into question either the holding of an urban agenda or the continuation of macro-regional strategies. Furthermore, it continues to welcome the principle of thematic concentration and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy which run counter to the interests of France and the poorest communities. Communities that, let us remember, in times of economic crisis, need more flexibility in obtaining Structural Funds and better articulation with State/Region Plan contracts. Finally, it should be noted that the motion for a resolution does not address the thorny issue of the reprogramming of the Structural Funds in favour of migrant reception programmes. Finally, it goes without saying that support for improving the administrative capacity of some Member States and local authorities will go first to the Eastern countries which have the lowest absorption rates from the Structural Funds. I voted against it.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that two years have already passed since the start of the new 2014-2020 programming period, the implementation of cohesion policy is lagging behind, with operational programmes largely approved as early as 2014-2015, however a significant number of ex-ante conditionalities have not been able to be met to date.  The 2014-2020 regulations have introduced several key reforms in the area of cohesion policy, but the investments related to this policy need to be aligned in other areas, such as the Digital Single Market, energy union, social policy, macro-regional strategies, urban agenda, research and innovation in the field of transport, in order for Member States to make the best contribution to the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. I voted for the motion for a resolution on speeding up the implementation of cohesion policy because I believe that the European Commission's annual assessment can benefit for a better coordinated use of the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy, with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion by 2020, is an instrument that helps bring the EU closer to its citizens and is the main investment and development policy covering all EU regions; whereas in some Member States cohesion policy is the primary source of public investment. With my vote, following the position of the S&D group, I supported it.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The aim of the resolution is to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy in all EU regions and to improve its effectiveness, a key issue given that this instrument has a budget of more than EUR 350 billion by 2020 and that in several Member States it is the main source of public investment funding. We agree with many of the things that are proposed: recommendations for simplification of procedures, improvement of information, reduction of deadlines, implementation of tools for analysis and evaluation of the use of funds, etc. But there are references to the deepening of structural reforms and the use of Stability and Growth Pact mechanisms that we find problematic because they support the austerity policies we have been undergoing for years in Spain and other EU countries. For consistency with the denunciation position in the face of these instruments, we voted ABSTENTION.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I abstained in this report because although the text calls for the fulfilment of investment content, there are parts of the text that refer to structural reforms and the so-called "better regulation" which I do not support.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the creation of a working group in eight Member States to better implement the 2007-2013 programmes.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This question is intended by Parliament to obtain certain clarifications to speed up the implementation of operational programmes, strengthen the administrative capacity and good governance of THEMs, ensure payments on time or request information on the main obstacles that the EEMM encountered in implementation, among other issues. We are therefore talking about an action necessary to be able to move forward with the correct use and proper management of funds and what I believe is necessary to vote in their favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'In the efficient and timely use of cohesion policy, we can increase economic growth more efficiently. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. With a budget of 350 billion for the period 2014-2020, cohesion policy is one of the main policies of the Union in terms of budget. In theory, cohesion policy is supposed to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities between regions and complement other European policies in the areas of education, employment, energy, environment, research and innovation. Unfortunately, the will of the European institutions is increasingly to make it a means of submitting it to the Economic Policies of the Union and in particular to structural reforms, to the application of the European Semester and thus in general to austerity. As a result, we are turning our backs more and more on the initial objectives. This resolution supports this drift and calls for speeding up its implementation while wishing to simplify it to take account of late payments and the slow pace of completion of current programmes. The GUE/NGL tried during the negotiations to challenge these harmful developments. I don't want to do it. In particular, the EPP and the S-D voted in particular on the amendment on structural reforms. I have chosen to abstain in order to take into account the need for such funding for projects, particularly regional ones, but by refusing to endorse this new direction.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. Cohesion policy, with a budget of more than €350 billion by 2020, is the instrument that helps bring the EU closer to citizens and the main investment and development policy for all EU regions and which in some Member States represents the main source of public investment. It has been two years since the start of the new programming period and there are delays in the implementation of cohesion policy. Although almost all operational programmes were approved at the end of 2014 and 2015, investments were dedued in reaching the ground. All kinds of obstacles, such as ex ante conditionality, macroeconomic conditionality and performance conditionality itself, which have complicated the processes and are the cause of many delays, will not be unrelated to this.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The resolution mentions that cohesion policy is the main source of public investment in some Member States. Nevertheless, this motion for a resolution does not alter the financial disempowerment of the nation states by cohesion policy.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on speeding up the implementation of cohesion policy. I am opposed to cohesion policy as a whole. It is not possible to align regions and Member States with centrally allocated funding. Europe should live and celebrate its regional and national differences, rather than wanting to make them equal through the EU.  I am certainly not in favour of speeding up the implementation of a policy that I reject. The resistance of various kinds to the implementation of cohesion policy is well reflected in the fact that the regions are opposed to central governance.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ My own region has recently experienced a very concrete example of the importance of EU assistance through regional funds. During December 2015 the UK was hit by the extra-tropical cyclone storm Desmond, followed by storms Eva and Frank, causing severe flooding in the North of England and Scotland well into January. Extensive damage was caused to homes, communities, and businesses. Following intense pressure from the Labour Party, the UK government eventually applied for EUSF in February 2016, on the eve of the deadline. We are now waiting for the first payments to be made in order to support reconstruction and re-development of the affected communities. Beyond this particular example, regular delays by the relevant authorities in implementing regional ‘operational programmes’, resulting in subsequent payment delays, are a barrier to the full implementation of the cohesion policy, which is so crucial for the sustainable development of EU regions. I therefore welcome this parliamentary question calling on the Commission and Member States to explore mechanisms to reduce administrative burdens and ensure a quick and efficient implementation of the cohesion policy, building on the lessons learned from the previous implementation period.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – This resolution stresses that continuous simplification is one of the basic conditions for speeding up cohesion policy. A high degree of transparency is also needed. I believe that evaluating the implementation of cohesion policy at this stage would provide the Commission with some important insights and lessons to discuss the future of cohesion policy after 2020. Furthermore, the resolution asks the European Commission to formulate key lessons and to start a dialogue with the European Parliament, Member States and other stakeholders on the future of SEEs after 2020 as soon as possible in order to use more targeted ways and better respect the deadlines for their implementation. Another very positive aspect of this resolution is the requirement for the Commission to develop detailed guidelines for public markets and for preventive measures, in order to avoid errors and irregularities and to make the procedures of standard contracts public for beneficiaries public, thus avoiding financial corrections and the possible cancellation of the Union contribution. I supported the report.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution which takes into account the crucial importance of cohesion policy in the Member States most affected by the crisis such as Greece. In this difficult period, in which liquidity is a huge issue for many Member States, we must make a major contribution to channelling the European resources which in many cases constitute the most important part of public investment.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Mihaylova resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy, because I agree that the European Commission should rapidly present measures to facilitate and accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy by Member States.  I regret that, given its importance, the process of implementing cohesion policy does not deserve particular attention from the EU. Delays in implementation and the difficulty in combining them with other tools to support development, growth, employment and investment are missed opportunities at a time when the EU is experiencing difficulties requiring the mobilisation of all available resources. I would stress that, having been designed to combat asymmetries and to break the gap between access to opportunities for European citizens by the volume of resources it mobilises (more than EUR 350 billion by 2020), cohesion policy is a key tool for reversing the cycle of stagnation in which the EU plunged after the financial crisis started in 2008.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 Cohesion policy, with a budget of more than EUR 350 billion to 2020, represents the main investment and development policy covering all EU regions. It is therefore necessary to implement, responsibly, efficiently and effectively, measures to promote appropriate structural reforms, as well as investment-friendly policies and the fight against fraud, in line with the objectives of territorial cohesion, sustainable growth and employment.   I supported the report on the faster implementation of cohesion policy because I believe that it gives a balanced assessment (of accelerating) the implementation of cohesion policy.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Ladies and gentlemen! As you will recall, during the sitting on 9 March 2016, the President applied an emergency measure under Rule 165(3) in conjunction with Rule 11 of the Rules of Procedure and expelled Mr Eleftherios Synadinos from the Chamber for his unacceptable remarks about the Turkish people for the rest of the sitting. On 9 May, after hearing From Mr Synadinos and in accordance with Rule 166 of the Rules of Procedure, the President decided to impose a penalty on Mr Synadinos for his conduct during the meeting on 9 March. The penalty consists in the cancellation of the entitlement to daily allowance for a period of ten days. The decision has been received by the honourable Member today.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the adopted decision on the reform of the Common European Asylum System (2016/2655(RSP)).

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, until we are able to build peace and prospects for war-ravaged and persecuted communities in our neighbourhood and beyond, people will continue to look to the EU for refuge. We need to make sure that people who need protection actually receive it. This is our moral duty as well as our legal responsibility. And we must find ways to help these people without them having to risk their lives on dangerous journeys. We need to take them out of the hands of smugglers by putting in place safe and legal ways to the EU for those in need of protection. Cooperation with third countries, protection in the region and resettlement from there to the EU should become the model for the future. We will come forward in June with proposals on how to work better with third countries as part of our work towards a more sustainable approach to managing migration. Recent experience also shows that we need a better approach to large-scale arrivals of people at our external borders. Those who do not seek protection should be returned. Those who do claim asylum should have their case processed efficiently and get a decent reception.  But we have seen how our existing European asylum rules are not doing that. We all know the weaknesses. In the past year a few Member States came under incredible strain. This results directly from the shortcomings of the Dublin System in its current form. Dublin was simply not designed to deal with situations such as these. It does not deliver effective solutions and it does not ensure solidarity and a sustainable sharing of responsibility. A month ago we presented options for reforming our Common European Asylum System and we heard your reactions as well as those of the Member States in the Council. The simple truth is that, if Member States do not find a common approach to sharing the responsibility in handling the refugee crisis, at the end of the day not a single Member State will be able to handle that responsibility on its own. We either face this challenge together, or we give up on facing it at all, with dire consequences for all and with unacceptable consequences for refugees who flee war and persecution.  If we take leave of our common responsibility, we will take leave of our common values and weaken the very fabric upon which our societies are built. That is why the Commission has presented a proposal that will make it possible for all Member States to take their responsibility. So we propose to introduce a corrective mechanism in our Dublin System. It will be triggered automatically so that, whenever a Member State has to face a disproportionate number of asylum applications, responsibility for new applicants – of all nationalities – will be transferred to other Member States. Once the pressure is relieved, that Member State will again take responsibility for new applicants. Each Member State’s share will be based on clear and simple criteria – population size and GDP. Their resettlement efforts will also be taken into account, in line with our objective to provide safe and legal pathways to Europe. All Member States will be required to contribute and show solidarity. This may, under conditions, also take the form of financial solidarity. If – temporarily – a Member State does not relocate asylum applicants, they will need to support those Member States which do. The new system will also be much more efficient and fairer with shorter processes for assigning responsibility and processing applications. It will discourage abuses, with clear obligations for applicants and safeguards against ‘asylum shopping’. At the same time, we will better protect the rights of those who seek refuge through better safeguards for unaccompanied minors and stronger guarantees that families will be kept together. I trust this House to examine our proposals with the urgency this issue merits. Mr President, if you agree, Commissioner Avramopoulos will continue.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I will go straight to the core of the issues. We know the weak points in our current asylum system, and the smugglers know them, too. To address them, we started last year to strengthen the control at our external borders with our proposal on the European Border and Coast Guard. I am glad that the discussion progresses well, but, as you have indicated in your report on the Holistic Approach to Migration, Europe also needs to set up a robust and effective Common European Asylum System. The reform of the Dublin Regulation, the reinforcement of Eurodac and the transformation of EASO into a true European Agency for Asylum, are the first major steps in this direction. These proposals are all based on the same principles: solidarity, responsibility and pragmatism. We cannot abandon any Member State to face a crisis alone. A country’s place on the map should not decide its share of the work. I am convinced that our proposal to reform the Dublin system strikes the right balance to achieve two objectives. First, our proposal will allow establishing a sustainable and fair system for determining the Member State responsible for asylum seekers. It is based on a European reference system, with an automatically—triggered corrective solidarity mechanism. Once the number of asylum applications in a Member State exceeds 150% of the allocated share based on GDP and population, the corrective mechanism will be automatically triggered. All new admissible applications will then be shared proportionately between the other Member States which are below their share, based on the reference key. The objective is to avoid that a Member State carries a disproportionate burden.  Second, the new Dublin Regulation will better prevent secondary movements within the European Union. The current shifts of responsibility between Member States will no longer be possible. It is important to see the Dublin Regulation as part of a package together with the reform of EASO and of Eurodac. Indeed, the existing European Asylum Support Office (EASO) will be transformed into a fully-fledged Asylum Agency.  The tasks of the Agency will be considerably expanded. One of its other essential tasks will be to ensure greater convergence in the assessment of applications for international protection across the Union. And, as we have proposed for the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, we see the clear need to strengthen its operational role when needed. Therefore, we suggest a reserve of 500 experts from Member States to be available when needed in urgencies, if a Member State is subject to disproportionate pressure and needs support. Finally, the reinforced Eurodac Regulation will continue to support the application of the Dublin system. The new regulation includes the possibility for Member States to store and search data belonging to third country nationals or stateless persons who are irregularly staying in the Union. This will facilitate their identification and therefore the enforcement of return decisions in line with data protection standards. These are only the first proposals for the reform of the Common European Asylum system. We are now working on a second stage of legislative proposals towards achieving more convergence in the asylum procedure and the rights we need to grant to those in need. In addition, we are working towards increasing the legal avenues to Europe, and we will come up soon with a structural resettlement scheme. As President Juncker said in this plenary in April, we want to build a Common European Asylum System that is the best in the world – and I have full confidence that this House will help us to build a fairer, more equitable and more sustainable system that Europe needs and will need in the future.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioners for their detailed presentations and for their constant leadership in trying to address the crisis in very tough circumstances. Your proposals, Commissioners, contain a number of very good elements and show some clear progress in addressing the issue. Strengthening the Malta—based EASO is essential and I am pleased that the proposals contain concrete measures in this regard which will see staff and resources increased. We need to keep proving to our citizens that there is an understanding among politicians in Brussels that Member States on the front line should not have to face disproportionate pressure on their systems alone. This is crucial, and any change to our systems must have this as its central theme.  The Commission’s idea for a corrective fairness mechanism is a good step in the right direction in addressing this concern and will go some way to pushing forward a sustainable solution to disproportionate pressures faced at the external borders. However, I think that the Commission’s idea for Member States to be able to pay their way out of the mechanism is provocative, and it does show just exactly how far away Member States still are from real sharing of responsibility. I can perhaps sympathise with the thinking behind the idea, but that some countries will be able to exonerate themselves from responsibility by payment is not, in my view, the best road towards effective solidarity. We need to do more to ensure that there is the political will to move forward.  Overhauling Dublin is essential. It is a system that has perpetuated a disproportionate responsibility on some Member States which feel left alone. It has poisoned the debate on migration and has allowed extremist elements to hijack the narrative. It must be changed. Solidarity must be part and parcel of being an EU Member State. It can never be a concept we can buy our way out of. The bottom line is this: we are either all in this together, or we are not.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, I will be frank: the Commission's proposal is not what we expected, and it is far below our expectations. A month ago, this Parliament voted by a large majority for the Kyenge-Metsola report, which called for Dublin to be overcome and for the unfair criterion of the first port state to be overcome and went further, to the point of calling for the centralisation of the examination of asylum applications, which would become European responsibility.  The message from this House was clear: Dublin must be overcome and it is absurd to keep it alive artificially. We were calling for a genuine ambitious and necessary reform, and unfortunately this has not been the case, the principle of the first country of arrival has remained intact and a decision has been taken on an emergency basis. When, for years, 6 out of 28 Member States alone deal with almost 80 % of asylum applications, it may no longer make sense to talk about an emergency, because it has become structural. The 150 % criterion triggering automatic distribution is strictly mathematical and abstract, and does not take into account the resilience of reception systems, some of which are already collapsing. With regard to financial solidarity, the frontline countries have already been financially supported, but this has not been enough. Are we sure that we can monetise the solidarity, rights and duties that also result from our treaties? It is a good thing, however, that the new mechanism applies to all asylum seekers, without creating discrimination on the basis of nationality, and also that we want to strengthen family reunification and protect children more. It is bad, however, that no account is taken of the preferences expressed by the applicants, as this Parliament had already requested. Commissioner, dear Commissioners, we will have a lot of work to do. I hope that together we will find together the bravest spirit of the European immigration agenda, isolating the selfishness of governments and aiming higher. My group and I are ready to work constructively with you and we will not stop until the joint response is up to scratch. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" question. Unfortunately, this solidarity is lacking. There is a large group of Member States that do not want to participate in a common concept. That is regrettable, but it is a realistic fact and we must find an answer to that. Now you can say that this solidarity must be achieved, but we must have a means of enforcing that solidarity. The drug that has now been chosen is far too heavy and out of proportion. How do you want to tap into this non-existent solidarity and yet ensure that care is taken together?

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: answer to a "blue card" question. My dear colleague, it seems to me that your question more than for me is for the governments that sit in the Council and that have not even started the relocations to which they committed themselves in September last year.  The figures are ridiculous: 160 000 commitments were made and 1 200 to 1 400 people were relocated. There is a problem of political will. In my opinion, we must remind european governments that Articles 78 and 80 of our Treaties already require full solidarity between Member States.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The Commission is proposing a reform of the Dublin system. That is the system that determines which Member State is responsible for applying for asylum. That remains the first Member State of entry and therefore, in fact, Greece, for example. Only if the tax becomes too high for that frontline member state on the basis of its size and economic strength can refugees be relocated. Only if Greece is no longer able to cope objectively will other Member States have to take in asylum seekers. And yes, there is provision for sanctions if Eastern Europe does not want to cooperate. The N-VA has always strongly pushed for this. The N-VA is a dispersal plan because Belgium already handles double the European average of asylum applications and thus benefits from a better distribution. But as in the past, the N-VA will not vote for a proposal that has not been sufficiently worked out. Relocation is just the last step. First, we need an adequate EU borders policy and an economic cap. Only then can we talk about spreading and integrating. There is no point in leaving the tap open and simply mopping up in a more efficient way.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I am very happy that we now have two packages of proposals from the Commission to tackle the situation with the refugees in a more determined and sustainable way. Let us hope that this will put an end to the era of panic—driven negotiations with Turkey to outsource our responsibilities to them, and instead focus on creating a robust European asylum system that can earn the respect of European citizens, while providing sanctuary for people fleeing war and persecution. As rapporteur for the Dublin Regulation, I can assure the Commission, Member States and this entire House that I, together with my negotiating team, will work in an effective, determined way to conclude in a good agreement. The Dublin Regulation is the cornerstone of the European asylum system and this is not the time for watered—down deals. This is the time to – once and for all – get it right. Out of respect for my team of shadow rapporteurs, I will not set out a specific approach here today. I believe it is important that we in this House work together and come up with a unified view on the Regulation and how it should look in the future. In order to do this, I intend to work closely with all groups that are interested in achieving a progressive European solution.  The Commission proposal is a good point of departure, but I am convinced that we are going to substantially strengthen the proposal in this House. However, I want to make it clear that I do not accept the approach by the Commission with regard to the Dublin transfer of unaccompanied minors. We have clear jurisprudence from the European Court of Justice that it is not in the best interest of children to be sent around Europe like ping pong balls or suitcases. On this I am convinced that I enjoy the full support of the House and so I am happy to work together with you on this.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would honestly like to meet those who have come up with this Commission proposal on Dublin. After all, it is actually arrogant to declare a dead hare alive! Because the Dublin system is dead, and now it is to be revived. The so-called corrective or fairness mechanism in the event of exceptional migratory pressure in the Member States does not change this. It is naive at best, because refugee admission is understood as an automated calculation example, as a calculation result, but it probably fits rather on completely different contexts.  For example, on items. items such as potato sacks. You have too many potato sacks somewhere and send them exactly where there aren't that many yet – nutritionally perfectly okay, I very much agree with that. But this principle cannot be applied to refugees, because they are not objects, but human beings. And then there is something else: if, for each refugee who has not been admitted, one can supposedly buy oneself free with EUR 250 000, then I think that is basically a distraction. After all, what will change? It is much more true that the unwilling Member States are very much in agreement with the obligation to examine first whether refugees can be deported to safe third countries. So the longer the list of so-called safe countries of origin and third countries, the fewer refugees you have. None of this changes the plight of refugees, nor does it help the overwhelmed Member States, and is therefore neither fair nor fair.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I want to say first of all to Cecilia Wikström that she has our Group’s full support in what she has been saying on unaccompanied minors and I think we would also agree with a number of the other criticisms that have been made.  I have worked on every Dublin Regulation that has been brought before this House; most of them have moved forward. I do not think this one is going to and I have to say I will try and keep my language parliamentary but it is going to be a real struggle. I understand that many NGOs and experts have been in discussions with the Commission and have basically been told that they need to ‘get real’; that they need to understand what is happening on the ground. These people do, and I think we have a duty to listen to them. UNHCR, Charter of Fundamental Rights, Jesuit Refugee Service, numerous others – we should be listening to these people. I would agree with what we have been told: Dublin does not work. We never thought it did. We would agree that it puts a huge responsibility on countries because of their geographical situation – that was always obvious, was it not? We also know that Member States need to show solidarity. We heard this from Malta many years ago; we are still waiting for it. Dublin is only going to have a chance of working if we also take into account asylum seekers themselves, because if you are looking at secondary movement, you need to think why do people move? Dublin fixes you; it gives you one chance. If that is going to be in a country where you think your claim will not be properly examined, where you will not be able to make the contacts with your community, use the language that you have to integrate as we want you to, would you not move? It is your one chance to actually develop your life in any sort of way. A key point that we made in the last Dublin revision was that the thorough examination of your case was also a foundation of Dublin. Yet, when I look at some of the proposals here – for people who dare to cross a border – that is now being thrown out of the window and the court cases that decided that go along with it. I think there are some really big amendments that need to be made to this proposal.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we do not like this dublin amendment proposal. We are talking about a reform, so something that should presuppose something new. So I ask myself: what is the alternative to the barges that this proposed amendment offers? How are the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities observed between Member States, which are principles enshrined in Article 80? How is the first country of entry protected, which still has the greatest burden in the responsibility and examination of asylum applications and in the management of landings? Why wait for a country to collapse, to be in extreme difficulty, and then trigger the automatic relocation mechanism? If this mechanism then works, because a Member State can decide to wash its hands of it, to pay the fine of EUR 250 000 and therefore not to accept any asylum seekers.  We have long been aware of the failure of this Dublin system. The 5 Star Movement loudly asked for its modification, but intended a strong, effective, true change. A change that unfortunately did not come. The Commission has in fact confined itself to proposing an implementation of the old Dublin system, maintaining the status quo, and so we are essentially continuing to make the same mistakes once again. Relocation on a voluntary basis, as we have seen, has not worked. We have seen that it has not worked and we must acknowledge that the Commission has tried to make an attempt to penalise Those Member States that are opposed to the relocation of migrants. Yet here too, instead of providing for a fine – which then falls on the pockets of the citizens, falls on the taxpayers – we foresee something stronger, something that really can act as a deterrent, we envisage the suspension of the right to vote for those countries that refuse to cooperate, for those countries that violate Article 80 of the Treaty.  We keep repeating it, we repeat it: to foresee once again an implementation of the old system does not work. We need a European management system for asylum applications, on the basis of common criteria that are applied by all Member States. Asylum seekers must be seen as people seeking help, who are asking for solidarity with the whole of the European Union, not with the individual Member State. We must implement a permanent relocation system that is truly compulsory, we must provide for a binding European resettlement programme, the creation of humanitarian corridors, those legal access routes that are still lacking today, which will allow applications for international protection to be submitted to the Embassies of the European Union of third countries, and thus guarantee legal and safe access routes to the European Union. The future common European asylum system cannot be reduced to a balance of interests between Member States.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We have to work on the correction mechanism for the Dublin rules. The Dublin rules, which have now ended up in the dustbin of history, because no one within the European Union is paying any attention to them, just as not only the Dublin rules, but also the Schengen Agreement and all sorts of other European treaties have been broken in recent years at the discretion of national governments. Simple rules, they say, are the ones we want to sell here. Why then has the Commissioner not managed to explain to us in two or three sentences in a comprehensible way what exactly these rules should look like? We can buy free from this European solidarity system! On the other hand, I would particularly like to thank the Commission. We now know the price of a migrant in the European Union: a quarter of a million euros. This attempt at correction reveals only one thing, namely the failure of all previous attempts. Mrs Merkel's break-up of Schengen and Dublin led to the attempted redistribution of 160,000 migrants in the European Union last autumn. Of these, not 1% has been implemented so far. We have seen the failure of the negotiations with Turkey. We have seen the European Union blackmail, public and humiliated. And we are not even talking about the problem of family reunification, which will increase the chaos that has been caused in the past.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, the Commission's communications are an even greater reinforcement of the reactionary Dublin Regulation. For asylum, the responsibility of the first host country, such as Greece, prevails, and refugees and migrants will now be trapped in it and "with the will". Your inhumane mechanisms with quotas, key numbers, your directions to prevent so-called secondary movement, border repression, fences, are all that feed the traffickers' circuits and create life-hell for refugees and migrants. Any refugee who does not comply with your reactive regulations is threatened with consequences and a fast-track rejection of their asylum claim. The people and refugees fight together to free themselves from the vise of imperialist wars, the treaties and mechanisms of the European Union and its governments that violate the Geneva Convention. Facilitate their safe movement to the countries of final destination and ensure humane and decent conditions of residence during their temporary accommodation in Greece.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Greek asylum service is currently trying, with only 280 staff, to manage asylum applications that have risen sharply since the European Union-Turkey refugee agreement, because everyone is asking to be recognised as refugees in Greece because they refuse to return to Turkey. However, the situation is not manageable, since only 89 applications out of a total of 6,605 submitted so far have been settled. The Commission's new proposal on reforms to the common European asylum system has considerable added value in de-escalating pressure on specific Member States, since the revision of the Dublin system is undoubtedly necessary. Since May 2015, when the Commission first announced the interim management measures, we have insisted that the new relocation and resettlement mechanisms be permanent and binding for all. A year later, given the failure of European solidarity in practice, the Commission's proposal to legislate an economic solidarity contribution for those Member States that refuse to accept refugees is more necessary than ever. This is a good measure for everyone to comply with, with the clarification that it is not a fine or penalty nor is it of a sanctioning nature, but it is a measure of balance aimed at proportionate and criteria-based distribution of the burdens of the refugee. Ladies and gentlemen, the European asylum system is not understood if it is not characterised by solidarity and justice.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – European asylum policy is not working. It does not work for Member States, it does not work for asylum seekers. The proposed package of measures and the amendment to the Dublin system is a step in the right direction, but it is not ambitious enough. It's like we want to heal superficial wounds, treat the symptoms, forgetting the original disease. I am afraid that the proposed reform will not prevent the emergence of situations similar to what we are seeing today in Greece. We need a truly common system of European asylum based on fairness and solidarity. The burden cannot and must not be borne solely by countries with an external border. Mechanisms for action against non-participating countries are urgently needed. But they're not enough. And they will not be enough until we know that this is a common European problem and that the only real solution is the cooperation of all. Dialogue with citizens is also important here. If we want a functioning and secure situation at our borders and in our countries, if we want to protect everyone's fundamental rights, we need better and all-enailing reform. And in doing so, dear colleagues, it's no longer about whether we can do it, it's whether we want to. That we have to, and we've known for too long.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: – Mr President, I welcome the presence here today of the First Vice-President and the Commissioner, as well as the Commission proposal to maintain the basic principles of Dublin. This is essential if we are going to combat irregular economic migration, sending a strong signal to human traffickers and allowing us to grant asylum to the most vulnerable.  As you are aware, my political group has always had serious reservations about a compulsory relocation scheme. It has had little success. Rarely does forcing someone to do something result in improved relations between the parties and the payment system suggestion of a fine of EUR 250 000 per individual who is not being relocated seems like a punishment for Member States, rather than a credible alternative.  I welcome the strengthening of important instruments such EASO and Eurodac. I believe that looking at how we can enhance what we already have, rather than reinventing the wheel, will always be the most effective way forward. But despite all this, my main message here today is a simple one. These revisions, these proposals, these enhancements will only work if we all stick to the rule book.  Commissioner, your institution is there to oversee compliance with the Treaties and with our laws, and what I have seen over the last 12 months is Member States believing they are all above the laws rather than pursuing the laws that they have negotiated and adopted. If we are creating real solidarity in a truly effective area of asylum, then the rules must be followed. This Parliament must not just be a talking shop, but a venue for building credible and effective solutions to gain back the trust and the confidence of the electorate.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the One thing is beyond dispute: Europe is facing a formidable challenge. However, it is feasible to deal with them, and not on the number of asylum seekers, but on our attitude, the concrete attitude of the Member States to the reform of the current European asylum system. The Commission's proposal is on the table and I think it is balanced. Member States cannot continue to turn a blind eye and hope that the influx of refugees will break down.  Let us be honest: compared to their population, economically weak countries such as Lebanon and Jordan are taking in a much higher number of refugees than we do. As long as we try to shift our responsibilities to other countries, the problem remains. There is no sustainable European solution outside our borders. The plan to resettle asylum seekers was a first attempt to get a grip on the situation – unfortunately, it has clearly failed. I hope that shortcomings caused by the lack of solidarity between the Member States and a lack of European responsibility will be addressed and resolved through negotiations on a European asylum system.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: – Refugees are forward-looking. They think of a safe place now, but they also think about their children and what kind of an existence that children will have in the future. Member States seem to be living mainly in the present: now fewer refugees in my country and we will see in the next government what that means for Europe, or what that means for the refugees, or what that means for stability in the Middle East.  The European Commission is generally forward-looking. Mr Avramopoulos, you are here for the future of Europe and of European citizens, and we want to work together to ensure stability in the region. The need must therefore be very high for you to make such a short-sighted proposal for the change of the Dublin system. My question to you is: What can we do to help you? For the future of Europe and for the future of these refugee children.  (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. You invite us to reflect on the future of children brought to Europe. I would like us to reflect on the present, what is actually happening at the moment, what we know about these 10 000 children who have gone missing in Europe. We don't know what happened to them. This is the reality of immigration policy, this is what it is like to look at this illegal human smuggling industry, which we do not know about, whether they were actually used to smuggle others, whether they are still alive or not victims of crime.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: "blue card" answer. – Thank you for raising awareness of the issue of missing children. If children could have come to Europe legally, they wouldn't be missing now, that's one. Secondly, I think that a lot of children who have arrived in Greece or in Italy have registered there. Then, like many refugees, they set off on foot on their way to see family elsewhere. And that is something we all allow because we have an asylum policy under the motto 'survival of the fittest'.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Ever since the late 1990s, the Commission has been trying to force a common European asylum policy. The aim is said to be to combat illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings by adopting a federalist plan for legal migration. The Commission calls its proposal a harmonised and effective asylum procedure. I'm amazed at the choice of words. Further measures are now being proposed to achieve the objectives of its plan. However, this involuntary solidarity contribution simply means resorting to additional coercive mechanisms to implement its policies. Those Member States that do not want to accept migrants should be fined, and no small sums either: EUR 250 000 per roaded migrant. Asylum should not, of course, be a lottery – an asylum seeker has the right to have his case heard, but not at the cost of loosening the conditions for the right of asylum in the way that is now happening. For how many of those who come are really asylum seekers? And for every so-called asylum seeker – how many relatives are the Member States forced to accept?  Europe cannot proceed with a common asylum policy; We must reject those who have no reason to come to Europe, and learn how to deal with all unfounded applications quickly and effectively already at the EU's external borders. We have to stop the terrorist journeys. We need to help people on the ground. We must safeguard the future of Europe. Thanks!

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: – First, bring unlimited fortune-seekers to Europe, push European countries into a huge crisis, and then propose more European Union as a solution: that is what the European Commission does time and time again, on the road to a European superstate. Same today. But it could be even crazier! For when a country declares that it can no longer cope with the influx, if it wants to defend itself against the asylum tsunami and additional Islamisation by closing its borders, it can expect a fine of as much as EUR 250 000 per asylum seeker. Solidarity is what Mr Timmermans calls it. I say, it's crazy.  The ruins of the European Union are not solving by more European Union. You don't solve them by blackmailing and threatening fines. You will not solve this by removing even more sovereignty from the Member States. I therefore call on you to take these plans off the table and let the countries take control of their own borders.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, you are constantly talking about solidarity between EU countries and constantly insulting my country, Hungary. Please, we've done our part in solidarity. We defended Europe's common borders with our own resources, for huge amounts of money and with enormous energy, just as we have done many times throughout history. We started from the principle of rule of law, which is one of the fundamental principles of the European Union, we did what European standards, European legislation, made mandatory: we defended the border. You, on the other hand, seem to have no idea of the principle of the rule of law, because you are doing something that is totally illegal. On the one hand, it is illegal under international law to exchange the population for what you wish to do, and on the other hand, the law requires that a penalty be imposed, which you now wish with this EUR 250 000, only if you have already said in advance what the illegal act for which you wish to impose a penalty, and only a court can do so, you cannot. Stop the law ...  (The President withdrew the floor from the Member.)

name: Frank ENGEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! If I see the matter correctly, it is a question of asylum. This is, after all, an internationally established right that can be limited in a relatively difficult quantitative way. In other words, we do not have any mechanisms in place to reliably say in the future that there must only be so many more. There will be as many as are theoretically entitled to asylum, and even those who have hope of being able to obtain asylum with us.  That is why I find it quite adventurous that the Commission is only presenting us with a text in the second attempt in which it says again: what one does not want is redistributed to others who perhaps do not want it at all, and they pay a quarter of a million per capita. A quarter of a million per capita means that four heads make one million, 4,000 heads make a billion! Take this into account in the event of a real onslaught of people arriving in any Member State that would not be willing or able to participate meaningfully in the pay-as-you-go process. I am not at all opposed to all this happening here. In fact, I believe that one of the most sensible things that President Juncker discreetly said to this House was that we should actually get someone to apply for asylum in the Union in the future and no longer in any Member State – so that would actually be the thrust. But in order to get there, I think we have to think about it at some point. And that means it doesn't help a fine – at least no head-to-head! It will only help in the future for us to inform those states that do not want to participate in solidarity policies that they will then have a problem with the functioning of the European Union.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the When we discussed the Commission communication on the revision of the Dublin system a month ago, there was a great deal of agreement. At last, someone had the courage to admit that there are alternatives to Dublin. The draft regulation is a disappointment to many of us because it clings to the illusion of Dublin. The first-country principle remains in place, and on this basis attempts are being made to remedy weaknesses, such as the distribution already quoted among all Member States. Some elements are quite right – a single European asylum procedure, the strengthening of EASO, the improvements to EURODAC – but in the end it remains to dowithce, and the risk of failure is very great, and there is also a risk of not being taken seriously. All of this is damaging Europe. We should really have the courage to create legal entry opportunities, to treat different systems differently, such as immigration and asylum, and to regulate the possibilities of applying in the regions of origin, whether in the embassy procedure or in specific contact points to be created. This is the only way to combat smuggling.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Mr President, I think we focus too much on how to manage and distribute the people who are coming, while the question we should be asking is how many people we can afford to take in socially or economically. What we should understand clearly is that there is now, and in the future, an endless number of people who want to come to Europe. Relocation has not worked and will not work and, even if it did work, it would only encourage more people to come. Many Member States have re—established border controls and that has significantly reduced secondary movement and asylum shopping. In the long run, it will likely also reduce the number of people crossing the Mediterranean because those people are not interested in staying in Greece or Italy. They all want to go to Germany, Sweden and some other countries. As for the external borders, I think we should look closely at what Australia has been doing successfully for the past few years.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card question. – I hear you say we should take as many people as we are able to take in, referring to a kind of absorption rate. So what are you going to say to the people who are fleeing a war situation, who come to Europe and who, according to your definitions, we cannot absorb any more? What are you going to say to them?  But my more important question is: do you not think that it is an absolute disgrace to have that kind of language in the richest, most prosperous, freest and safest continent in the world, to say that we actually do not have the capacity to take those people in?

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: blue-card answer. – Well, given the miserable integration rate that we have seen, even with much smaller numbers of humanitarian immigrants in Europe, I would say that we cannot afford even these kind of numbers. Most humanitarian immigrants concentrate in those Member States which have the most generous social security system; that is a fact. We should not be naive about the people who are now crossing the Mediterranean. The majority of them are economic migrants; they are not refugees from Syria.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Mr President, these reforms, if presented and adopted quickly, will finally enable - in any case, we hope - Europe, but especially those who have been placed at the External Borders of the Union, to manage and welcome in a responsible, solidarity, humane and dignified way, those fleeing war and violence. The first package of measures with the major reform of the Dublin Regulation is probably the most significant, and we have been calling for it for many months. Thus, if the Commission, in essence, has fulfilled an important part of the contract - with the caveat I bring, echoing Cecilia and other colleagues on the reception of unaccompanied minors, however, now is the time to make a clear appeal to States, because the blockade of States results in the final end of all the work on the "asylum" package, which took place and negotiated from 2008 to 2012, so unfinished that after only two years , we have to reform it. This constancy in blockades and procrastination is deadly for both refugees and citizens, our fellow citizens who expect something else from Europe.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, the Commissioner has been speaking about solidarity but if we look at the proposal, only those refugees will be transferred that are more than 150% of admissible applications. So the country of first entry would still have to check whether a refugee’s application is admissible or not. That means, Commissioner, that neither Greece nor Italy would actually benefit from that automatic solidarity scheme that you are proposing. So where in fact is that solidarity?
