This check on admissibility also leads to a situation where we are basically expanding the Turkey deal to all neighbouring countries. We are creating an invisible border region around Europe where all the neighbouring countries will be safe, and third countries will be first asylum countries, so we will send everyone back. That is what the proposal implies. Maybe you can tell me otherwise but that is what I read in this proposal and I am very worried about that.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: – Mr President, can I point out to this Chamber that an ISIS-linked terror cell was unearthed after three men were arrested in Italy only yesterday. The five suspects, including one who had been to London, had all been granted refugee status. They were free to take advantage of the EU’s internal borders, crossing between countries unchecked, just like the perpetrators of the Paris and the Brussels murders. The group had also photographed potential targets in London and one of the group was planning to move to Calais, raising the prospect of either using that as a base or else to help others enter the UK.  When will the EU learn and when will the UK Government learn? Of course we should give those in genuine need a safe haven using the Geneva Convention on Refugees. But that is not what this EU asylum system is about: it is about forcing countries to take on people who could well be terrorists and fining them if they do not. It is about Brussels forcing local services in Britain to a breaking point rather than face opposition to their project in other countries with external borders. It is another example of why our membership of the EU makes Britain less secure, and why we will be better out of the European Union. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – I can, of course, share many doubts about what you had, but you have certainly not read these Commission papers because they mention, for example, the reform of Eurodac. The Commission proposes to search asylum seekers more effectively for potential ISIS members through the collection of databases and fingerprints than hitherto. Read the Commission's proposal.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: blue-card answer. – Listen, I am not saying that I have not read the paper. I have read the paper. What I am saying is that fining will make absolutely no difference whatsoever to these people that are so determined to actually murder people.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: – No asylum system of this European Union can still be an acceptable asylum system for the citizens of Europe for the simple reason that you, the european Union's rulers, have exhausted all trust and all credibility altogether and completely. Your borders policy has become an open borders policy. You have made asylum a savage immigration, poisoned and tainted by deceit, materialism and human trafficking, and by the ideology of a multicultural delusion that destroys the foundation of Europe – unity in diversity. We no longer want your asylum policy, ladies and gentlemen of the European Commission. It is terrifying and it is no longer supported by the people of Europe.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the When I read about your proposals, the Commission's proposals, last week, I first thought it was an April Fool's joke. But since today we know it is true. The high values that you claim to defend here in this House – humanity, humanity – come at a price. This amounts to EUR 250 000 per person. That is the reality that we are looking at today. But what are you doing with the countries in which, unlike my country, Germany, referendums are possible? In Hungary, a vote will soon be taken on whether or not the people want immigration. Do you want to put pressure on such referendums with this price that the people should no longer vote as they feel afterwards, for fear of paying the country? What do you actually think of yourself at a time when you have so far done nothing to combat the causes of flight? Have you ever addressed those who are to blame for the fact that so many millions of refugees want to come to Europe who have bombed Iraq and Libya: the United States of America? Instead of applying coercive measures against Member States, we should instead implement the 'polluter pays' principle. We should combat the flow of refugees where they arise and help people where they come from, instead of imposing coercive measures on EUR 250 000 per person.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have finally arrived at a formal proposal to amend the Dublin 3 Regulation, which we broadly desired, called for and called for over the last two years, which is the real anomaly of the European reception system. That is why I very much welcome this proposal, even though – I must say this with great intellectual honesty – I would have preferred to have debated a text providing for a radical amendment to the Dublin 3 Regulation, removing the exclusive competence of the state of first port for the performance of applications for political asylum. But it is still a very important step forward, which establishes a concrete application of the principle of solidarity in the relocation of migrants should a Member State be the subject of a particularly significant flow. Unlike many of my colleagues, I also agree with the mechanism identified of a substantial penalty of EUR 250 000 per migrant, provided it is actually applied, which I believe could be an exceptional deterrent to Member States that do not wish to follow up relocation. I also agree with the strengthening of Eurodac, the transformation of EASO into a genuine European Asylum Agency, facilitating returns and combating irregular migration in a completely determined manner.  That is why I very much welcome this proposal. I hope that the Council will speak the same language as Parliament and the Commission.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if there is no solidarity on the management of migratory flows, there will be no solidarity in any other area. These are the words that you, Vice-President Timmermans, spoke a few weeks ago, words to which we thought ambitious and at the same time realistic proposals followed. Instead, we are faced with a 'creative reinterpretation' of the Dublin Regulation which can be summed up with the principle: 'those who do not accept pay'. A mere calculation of figures of people to be transferred from one Member State to another with a bureaucratic approach that does not take into account other factors.  The proposal before us is nothing more than a palliative for first-port states. Yet, not even a month ago, this House voted in favour of a fundamental revision of the Dublin Regulation in favour of a centralised European system of asylum applications. We have asked to go beyond the criterion of the Member State of first entry and to abandon the emergency approach once and for all. Solidarity is a key principle of our system and not a mechanism to be triggered when a Member State is overwhelmed.  For our part, Mr President, we will fight to amend this proposal and carry out a reform that will rebuild a climate of trust and cooperation between the Member States, asylum seekers, the European institutions and all the various actors involved.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Solidarity is not about shed responsibility on others for their own political iliability. In fact, a huge part of the responsibility for the current immigration crisis falls on the European Commission, the authors of these irresponsible calls, led by President Juncker, who announced the opening of ways to legalise illegal immigration. This, of course, also includes the failure to do so by the European Council decision of April last year, which referred to the vigorous fight against the illegal immigration industry. At the moment, we are watching as we try to blame those countries that have the courage to oppose it for the consequences of this policy. No, gentlemen, you really should be politically responsible for this policy. The foundation of democracy is political responsibility. It is the authors of this policy, led by President Juncker, who should leave.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: – Mr President, the events of the past months have shown that, in its current form, the European asylum system cannot cope. Europe was facing an unprecedented crisis that placed a disproportionate burden on several countries. It turned out that the Temporary Protection Directive, created precisely to deal with a sudden migratory flow, could not be implemented as it does not provide for a mechanism for mandatory sharing of responsibility.  From this experience, we need to learn the right lessons. We need a comprehensive reform of the system that provides true European solidarity, not measures unable to deal with problems in the long term. While the Commission's proposal does not provide for a centralised European system, the automatic implementation of an corrective mechanism for the distribution of asylum seekers is a step in the right direction.  I therefore call on the Council to support the proposed amendment in the name of finding a longer-term solution.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr When we started the legislature, President Juncker said that there would not be a lot of new legislation. Then came terrorist attacks and a massive influx of refugees that changed everything. And the result we are seeing is a battle of proposals, all of which have in common that they have been urgently needed, and that, in principle, there is a lack of impact assessments. We put out fires but do not think about how to prevent them, or whether our decisions really solve the problems. It is not enough simply to change the asylum system. It is not only asylum seekers who risk their lives on the way here. There are many economic migrants and they will continue to cross the sea even on the day the wars in our neighbourhood have ended. The only way to reduce deaths in the Mediterranean is to create legal routes for both refugees and other migrants. In my language, this does not mean that you are trading in the trade that you are talking about. These include humanitarian visas and labour migration rules for both the high- and low-skilled, and it is about working on the root causes of migration, not just poor conditions in the refugee camps in Turkey.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: – First of all, let us answer honestly whether we are trying to solve the problems facing Migration in Europe, or whether we want to address the problems of migrants who have flooded Europe at the expense of the people of all the countries of the European Union. And if we choose the first version of the answer, neither the revision of the Dublin Treaty, nor the newly established European Union Asylum Agency, nor the computerised resettlement mechanism, basically solve it. The Dublin Treaty has sufficient leverage to properly regulate migration flows in Europe. But this requires one essential and fulfilling condition. This is a strict and professional control of the European Union's external borders. Admittedly, if no transfer mechanisms have been properly done, there will be no new king's clothing or a newly invented bicycle. Even despite the fact that we will encourage Turkey with six billion euros, we will try to punish countries that do not want to share migrants by a quarter of a million euros for one un-adopted refugee.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are at the usual: the usual lies, the usual useless words. Today, the Commission is presenting the reform of the European asylum system. But what reform are we talking about? If asylum seekers have to apply in the first country of entry, then Italy and Greece, and not directly to the EU, why do you call it European asylum? Do not play on words, do not make press releases – as you did last week – two pages long to say that everything has changed when nothing has changed, do not come and tell those who live in Italy like me that we must control borders, because we have been saying this for years, but it has never been done. Meanwhile, there will be 300 000 illegal immigrants arriving and in Italy in 2016, and as Europol says there are also potential terrorists among them. Don't talk about reollocateing migrants who have arrived in Italy, because I've heard this story before. From September 2015 to April 2016, only 1 145 people were relocated. Nothing but 160,000 as you promised. A failure! European immigration policy is a great failure and you have not yet understood it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, after a year of discussions, I expect the European Commission to be able to change the asylum system so that it is better functioning from the point of view of migrants and to ensure greater security for the citizens of the European Union. Therefore, this measure cannot be separated from better external border control, which should be ensured as soon as possible. From this point of view, I welcome the extension of the Eurodac database for better identification of persons and the exchange of information between States, as well as the strengthening of the European Asylum Office for the Enforcement of Asylum Law by all participants. However, I consider the introduction of automatic redistribution of refugees to be a mistake that is no longer working today and will not work, even if this measure is enforced again. The reception of asylum seekers is the exclusive competence of the Member States and if we do not respect this, we will not build a prospective Union.  I want to say to my colleagues from Greece, Italy, Malta that we, the citizens of Central Europe, are in solidarity, that we know that we are in the same boat. And we also know that no one wants to be an asylum seeker, no one wants to leave their home. That is why we consider crisis management to be a solution where it arises. The asylum system is just a solution to the consequences, not a solution to the causes.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S&D). Mr President, Commissioner, there is no better proof of the validity of a law, of its quality, of its validity in time, and Dublin proved to us, when necessary, that it was not sufficient. Looking at the Commission's proposal, I have only one criterion. If it had been implemented since the beginning of the refugee crisis, would we have been better off? And the answer is certainly, yes, we would have been even better off if Frontex II.0 had been implemented and implemented, which we are preparing. This proposal, with all the additions it will receive from Parliament, can be a clear better intermediate stage until we reach a truly European response that can meet all the needs, but is not in the interests of the Member States as I understand it. And one question, since we have you here: we have read that there is a 'plan B': if the agreement with Turkey collapses, the Greek islands will become places of concentration for refugees. Does this have anything to do with reality?

name: Richard SULÍK
text: – The Commission's proposal to fine EUR 250 000 for each unseen migrant with an overview wins the prize for the most ridiculous proposal in the commission's history. The gentlemen and ladies in the Commission seem to have forgotten that the citizens of Eastern Europe do not yet have sufficiently brainwashed and not only do they not think that multi-cults do not work, but they do not even think that Islam belongs to Europe. Or perhaps only the Commission has said that it has still not tasted enough for the citizens of Europe to think enough about a common Europe. For the citizens of Slovakia and other Eastern European countries, I say, in any case, that any fines for the disregarded migrants and the redistribution of migrants across Europe fully ignore their will. It is important to protect borders in order to deal with the migrant crisis, not to make absurd proposals.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the honourable President for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I strongly support the proposals made by the European Commission, because the Commission has initiated the process of reforming the European asylum system. Let us be honest: the Dublin rules in their present form have been and are no longer up-to-date, they overwhelm a few Member States and ultimately promote irregular migration. In my view, for a humane and effective European asylum policy and for better managed immigration, we need a uniform EU asylum law, a fair and solidarity-based distribution of the burden and safe legal routes for people from third countries to enter the EU. In fact, those in need of protection must be distributed fairly among the Member States. The unilateral burden on a few states is unacceptable. Only through a common procedure can we in future prevent national solo actions and be a community of solidarity that actually deserves the name. That is why I support this proposal from the European Commission. Let us argue calmly and in the necessary objectivity about the details! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. " You are talking about a just solution. Do you not think that if children are taken on buses less for a ticket, maybe there would be a lower penalty for refugee children?

name: David McALLISTER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I am sorry, I have only been a little late in translating your speech, hopefully now correctly. I do not think it is worth going into detail about your proposals, because you probably do not expect an answer at all. I believe that you, too, would be well advised to look in detail at the Commission's proposals, both on the proposals on how to enter the European Union on safe and legal migration routes, but also to deal specifically with the proposals on what it means to pursue a fair and sustainable common asylum policy, from the introduction of a sound and fair system for determining the Member States responsible for examining asylum applications to the member states responsible for examining asylum applications. strengthening the EURODAC system. Please let us argue on the matter and not become polemical.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr President, the loopholes in the Dublin Regulation are not new. We know that this system is inefficient, unfair and expensive. The current crisis stigmatizes these dysfunctions and reminds us that it is urgent to rethink it. However, the Commission did not make that choice. I understand why, but I don't share it.  Two expressions come to mind to describe this proposal: tinkering and red rag. Why patching up? The foundations of the Dublin system had to be pushed together, they will be maintained. The Commission adds a touch of solidarity, providing a one-off relocation mechanism in the event of a crisis. However, the basic mechanism - distribution - is the same, and it is flawed.  Of course, the Commission provides for significant financial penalties for recalcitrants, but if this fine is intended as a deterrent, one can legitimately think that this financial solidarity is realistic. Unless the amount of financial penalties also serves as a red rag and proves useful in diverting the spotlight from certain provisions criticised in the new regulation. I am thinking in particular of the quasi-punitive measures envisaged to combat the secondary movements of applicants.  I am also thinking of the primacy of the concepts of 'safe third country' and 'first country of asylum' before any designation of the Member State responsible for the review. The golden rule of the Dublin system of the first country of entry is not only maintained but strengthened. This mechanism will therefore continue to pose a large number of logistical challenges in front-line countries to ensure individual review, redress and a dignified reception of these populations.  There is no easy solution to this problem, but I am frankly not sure that the proposed calculation is the right one. The risk is that we end up with a Dublin system unchanged, or worse, diminished rights for applicants and even less readable devices for states.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: – All Member States must contribute to solutions for the reception of refugees. Unfortunately, a mandatory distribution of refugees among the Member States is impossible, but from this political reality we have to come up with alternatives. A fine of a quarter of a million euros per rejected asylum seeker, that puts bad blood. In this way, the Commission is really imposing a huge dictation on the Member States. This proposal will split Europe, and that is grist to the mill for Geert Wilders and his European political friends.  My counter-proposal is to free up 5 billion a year within the Structural Funds to support Member States hosting asylum seekers. Half of this money comes from the Cohesion Fund, the fund which mainly benefits countries that have so far failed to cooperate. I believe that this is a fair, budget-neutral solution that will, above all, prevent further European divisions.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that the proposal on the reform of Dublin is more than welcome. We do have common asylum rules; the problem is that Member States are not implementing them fully. It is time for an obligatory emergency mechanism for distribution of asylum seekers.  The criteria should also include population and the number of refugees received, including children. When so many are coming at the same time the issue remains how to create the political will for Member States to take shared responsibility. I believe more in carrots than sticks and that means: more support for countries facing disproportionate pressure, strengthening Frontex, the Asylum Office, Eurodac and the hot spots. But the EU’s assistance should not be a disincentive for Member States to build reception capacity.  The solidarity pillars should be: resettlement – countries must speed up procedures and increase their quotas; relocation – Member States must take asylum seekers from Italy and Greece, as agreed; and return – we should save all, but we cannot take all in Europe. The EU has to negotiate more readmission agreements and fast adopt the list of safe countries of return, including Turkey. More humanitarian aid to assist refugees in Lebanon and Jordan and the EUR 3 billion for refugees in Turkey are urgent.  I conclude by saying that building bridges and dialogue with Turkey is crucial in any EU migration policy now, and in the future.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Honourable Member, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I very much appreciate your rationalism and we had a common position on sweden's proposal. I would like to ask you if you are not afraid that relocation in centralist and bureaucratic terms will lead to refugees, immigrants against their will, being in countries that do not provide sufficient economic cover and will want to leave? Does it not pose a threat, also from the point of view of international law, to place people where they do not want to be?

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the first question. My understanding of the proposal is that the final decision whether to accept a refugee or not still remains with the Member States because we have to work in respect of solidarity but based on a mechanism that we have to agree to, which I would call obligatory. The second thing is that secondary movements are not part of this. You cannot choose where to go once you are in Europe. In my view, giving international protection does not mean that you can choose which of the 28 Member States you can go to.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the Socialists have said many times in this European Parliament that the Dublin Regulation is obsolete and clamorously unfulfilled and, therefore, we have demanded its overcoming and substitution by a true European mechanism, a European system that deserves that name, a European system that honours the Lisbon Treaty's commitment to a common European Asylum System.  And, for exactly the same reason, we are now critics and deeply disappointed with the unshrunk shortcomings of the Commission's proposal, which hardly offers creative make-up of the current Dublin Regulation rather than establishing a truly binding mechanism governed by the principle of solidarity, reception and registration of asylum seekers on European soil. What does he do? A corrective mechanism exclusively designed for emergency situations or extraordinary flows, and economic sanctions that are not enough deterrent mechanism to force States to fulfil their obligations under humanitarian law. Clamorous case of Spain; unfortunately, my own country, which is said not to be a country for refugees because it is blamorously in breach of the agreements adopted by the Council, but which would be prepared to pay the fines proposed by the Commission.  No, it's not enough. It takes not only economic mechanisms, but also political mechanisms and, where appropriate, legal sanctions. That is why we say very clearly that we must move towards a European asylum system governed by dignity in reception and registration, by decent reception and by sufficient resources to honour the European vocation of the asylum system.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr I am not surprised by the Commission's proposal. This is, as always, based on opportunities to trade, including at a price. During the year, the Commission maintained the principles of solidarity, responsibility, justice, which is beautiful, but the only real migration measure was the realpolitik-based Treaty between the European Union and Turkey. The Commission is also introducing a justice mechanism that will also judge the particular asylum seeker who has paid the smuggler for getting into Germany, but this justice mechanism will send him to Latvia. What will this unfortunate man who has been sent to Latvia? He will, of course, go to Germany, but then there will be a secondary ban on movement, which in turn will force this man to catch, take his fingerprints again, compare and sentence him back to Latvia.  And finally, above all, the European Commission has set the price of one migrant integration by two hundred and fifty thousand euros. This is a lifelong dream for one pensioner in many European countries. Not luxembourg, of course.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – I welcome the Commission's proposal to establish a collective safety mechanism. It is a realistic set of measures that should have been taken even with the collapse of the Dublin Asylum Regulation. Allow me a few more comments.  Firstly, the fact is that only reforming the asylum system will not put an end to the migrant crisis. The new asylum system is only one of the key parts of an integrated approach to tackling the crisis, and the main pillars are the protection of external borders and the effective and rapid return of migrants to the countries of origin. If these principles had been adhered to since last year, only a third of the newcomers who are here would enter Europe.  Secondly, while the European Commission has maintained the rule of the first country or country of entry in its proposal, it has added a new corrective mechanism for justice to ensure that, if there is a disproportionate number of asylum applications, a Member State on the so-called first front, including my Slovenia, does not be left to its own. That's correct. I also welcome the view that asylum seekers do not have the right to choose a state. When it comes to life or death, all that matters is that the country you come into is safe. In this context, it is of paramount importance to prevent so-called secondary migration of refugees... (speech interrupted due to time overrun).

name: Kati PIRI
text: It is disappointing to see that there is insufficient support and political courage among our governments in Europe to thoroughly review the Dublin agreements and therefore there is no willingness to work on a genuine common European asylum policy with solidarity and shared responsibility as a starting point. That is why we must do it with this proposal from the European Commission. Not a big leap forward, just a small step in the right direction. For example, the proposed distribution key prevents Member States from having to sit down again and again to argue about which country to take over how many people if another Member State is temporarily unable to cope with the influx. The proposed fines for countries that refuse to honour previous agreements do not merit the beauty price. It is actually too bizarre to say that we must enforce solidarity within the EU, but unfortunately the current situation, in which a number of countries are scrambling to take in refugees at all, leaves the Commission no choice. I would urge European governments to speed up this decision. Thousands of people in Italy and Greece are still waiting for the previously promised redistribution. We must not allow the countries on the edge of Europe to pay for this humanitarian crisis. Let us therefore at least implement this proposal quickly and pave the way for a real overhaul of the bankrupt Dublin system.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Mr. President, I would like to recall at the outset that recently Mr Juncker said in this house that every European in the last 100 years has once been a refugee. Therefore, this motivates me to support any change, any improvement, including this improvement of the new common asylum policy. The fact is that the Dublin rule did not work and therefore we need to improve it. So I'm committed to advancing this rule, but we're also seeing the weak spots that have been so far. Smugglers were aware of this, we are aware of this, so from day one we call for solidarity and responsibility. Today the word solidarity is mentioned again and I hope that it is the main backbone of this common asylum policy. When it comes to fines, I am not in the place to impose fines and I do not agree with this solution, although I see that unfortunately this may be the only solution. But personally, I'm not up for that kind of solution. I want to remind you of the large number of unaccompanied minors, and there are 10,000 minors who are not only a statistical figure but a fact, and it is up to us to imagine ourselves over this data. Therefore, I think any innovation is welcome, so I am committed to making these changes to the Dublin rule and the overall common asylum policy.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Commission is trying to respond to the lack of solidarity, European responsibility and capacity to act. I welcome that. The problem is not the Commission's proposals, but the breaches of the law in the Member States, the lack of solidarity, the growing nationalism, the failure to implement the decisions and enforce the proposals. Let me be quite frank: democracy also has its limits. We do not have to vote on fundamental rights, human rights and solidarity, but to live them and to stick to them. We will not be able to cope with these proposals either. We need a pan-European asylum and migration policy, a common foreign, security, defence and development policy, common external border protection, legal migration policy, new approaches to integration policy and a coordinated investment policy in Africa. We must tackle all of this. Without solidarity and political will, no proposal will help us.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: - Mr. Vice-President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, I thank Mr Timmermans for presenting the European Commission's proposal to reform the Common European Asylum System. It is obvious that the refugee crisis and migrant movements over the past year have put to light all the shortcomings and difficulties we have in the current system regulated, in part, by dublin regulation which has now proved insufficient for the specific shape and intensity of the migration wave we have experienced. That is why, in parallel with what we are doing on the foreign policy security front, and in the context of the European Agenda on Migration, this reform proposal in several segments of the current legal system is heading towards a good objective of sharing responsibility, in a fair way showing the true solidarity of all Member States, with corrective mechanisms going towards ensuring a long-term acceptable solution and a genuine European policy. I also advocate strengthening the European Asylum Support Office, the EU Asylum Agency and the EURODAC system.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Colleagues! The EU is entering a dead end, where we are going to remove international asylum law and closing the door to people on the run. It's deadly, and dangerous. But it also does something to us who are inside europe's borders. We are shrinking, our humanity is peeling off, we are becoming crueler and crueler. It is enough to listen to what the extreme right's policy sounds like. We must be able to adapt to the policies of the extreme right. You in the Commission are doing what they want to do at European level instead of nationally. The new Dublin proposals do not change that. On the contrary, I fear that they are strengthening Fortress Europe, and perhaps the worst is the proposed rule, which seeks to force Member States to direct the resettlement of refugees to countries in the EU's neighbourhood. A kind of extension of the shameful agreement with Turkey, as my colleague Mr Keller also highlighted. Colleagues! It is time we take the fight for a more open Europe, otherwise the future will be cruel – for all of us.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the common European asylum system has shown in recent years all its shortcomings and complete non-compliance with the new circumstances, so it is clear that it needs an upgrade. However, the model proposed by the Commission again camouflages the problem and does not address it. The Problem of the European Union is that it has preliberal asylum policies and avoids addressing illegal migration. We need to reduce the number of people trying to come to Europe illegally, not deal with mere redistribution. Asylum seekers are free people and should choose their own destiny, just as EU Member States are free and can choose who they want to receive. The Commission's new measures only lead to complete absurdity and send asylum seekers to countries where they do not want to go, who are forced to take them beyond the will of their citizens. It's hard to limit freedom and put it in completely the wrong direction.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, let me get involved and say very clearly that after the dysfunction of "Dublin" it finally needed both a Commission solution and a Commission proposal. This is a step forward, but I'm afraid this doesn't include everything that should be included: more European togetherness and more European solidarity. I fear that the way the mechanism of "punishing" countries that do not want to take in asylum seekers is envisaged will lead to additional conflict within the European Union. Perhaps a mechanism for the use of cohesion funds and other European funds, in support of those countries receiving asylum seekers receiving asylum seekers in the European Union, would be a better model. I think that in this context, if European unity does not prove to be fully successful, we risk another serious and very big crisis because the asylum issue will not stop tomorrow but will last over the coming decades.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Timmermans said that the asylum request can be examined on the islands, I suppose, when refugees leave Turkey. This cannot be done when the applicants are tens of thousands, to be honest. There is no possibility from either the European Union or Greece. There is a common agreement on netting by some Member States, i.e. those who agree to take some of these asylum seekers. Those who have agreed to this proportionality should not take advantage of the fact that others have not agreed and should not apply it themselves. I close with this: we must have a 'plan B' in relation to refugees and it can only be reconstruction, in parallel with aid to Turkey, of one or two cities within Syria, so that when people are ready, they will return. There's no other way beyond that.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – The asylum policy reforms will signal what Europe will look like in the future. Will it be a community that is founded on values, solidarity, cooperation, respect for human rights and human dignity, or we will lock in internal fences and borders and wonder who will close our doors in the next crisis.  The question is whether we are really threatened by refugees, or whether we can be more concerned about our response to the crisis and the inability to respond effectively. Asylum reform is therefore no longer just a political and also a mathematical issue and a challenge, but, of course, a civilisational test of Europe's future.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to address Commissioner Avramopoulos. Commissioner, I ask you: but if you come here – and I counted that you touched the phone and looked at it at least thirty times, or your iPad – do you give a damn what you say in this House or do your cabbage and just come here to be here? Because if we only talk here to play, then there's no point in him coming or taking a 20th-century put himself back there, sleep, and then when he's done, he says his message that he's already written and it's all over.  What do we want to understand that it is full of people who come and who have no right to come to Europe? Instead of going around Europe and going to the refugee camps or going to Catania, doing the good thing in Sicily, to say that everything is fine, that the Sicilians are good and that the Italians are all happy! False, false and false!  We do not want the supposed refugees because they are not refugees, only 5 % are fleeing the war, all the others come to Italy only to be kept and the Italians are fed up with this situation. The same applies to Greece. And the rest of Europe, what does it do? He comes here to whining and then nothing changes. Thank you, Commissioner.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, the uncontrolled and uncontrolled invasion of hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants into Europe has proved once again that the European Union has also failed in its handling of the asylum issue and has left this handling, and of course all the problems, to the countries of first reception, namely Italy and Greece. But who should we protect, who should we grant asylum to? First, those whose lives and security are at risk in the country they come from and, secondly, those who are persecuted for their political beliefs by undemocratic governments. But how do we know which of all those who are asylum seekers are law-abiding citizens and are not terrorists or other criminals? Turkey, for example, grants hundreds of thousands of fake passports to those who come to Greece illegally. Who will tell us who these people are, when they themselves lie when and if they are recorded at some point. And finally, we make one more mistake. We give asylum to those who ask for work. And I ask my compatriot, Mr Avramopoulos, what are we going to say to the Greek unemployed who are about 30% of the population, that you are useless and we take foreigners from third countries to do our job?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the Dublin asylum system has failed, as it has turned Greece and Italy into warehouses of souls. But instead of abolishing Dublin, and in particular the criterion of the country of first entry, it is ultimately maintained. Mr. Avramopoule, Greece cannot afford any more refugees and illegal immigrants, and you know that very well. The people trapped in our country are over 54,000. What about the famous relocation? Of the 66,400 refugees who should have relocated from Greece to other European Union countries, only 869 have been relocated. This means that if you calculate the numbers, it will take a hundred years for the 66,400 relocations to take place. That's what the Bruegel Foundation said. We therefore need a mandatory relocation system. Also, the re-launches from Greece to Turkey are progressing at a turtle pace. Only 386 people have been re-launched. What about the experts you said would come from the European Union to examine the thousands of asylum applications?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, first of all we must all admit what all the citizens of the Union are saying, but the political leaders continue to say that they do not understand it. Europe's asylum and immigration policy has failed, because from the outset it has been based on the wrong foundations, on the wrong foundations. Europe does not have the capacity, nor will its peoples, to welcome all those who wish to come here, expecting a better life, taking advantage of the absurd provision of allowances, at a time when our continent is experiencing a very important economic crisis. We are already experiencing the social upheaval that has come from the policies you are implementing and our future holds even greater problems. Especially as you choose to close your eyes to peoples' reactions or, even worse, when you try to describe those who react as 'misanthropes'. If we really want to solve this great problem, first of all we need to redefine who is really entitled to asylum, since we all know that it has been abused by people who have never been in any real danger and, most importantly, western countries must stop constantly interfering in the internal affairs of third states. It is the countries of the West that have bombed, overthrown, or tried to overthrow, and invaded any country that did not agree with their interests, following a clearly neo-colonial policy.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you above all for your speeches. Today's debate has made it clear that the status quo is not an option. It has also shown that there is a wide range of opinions on how to improve the functioning of our common European asylum system. Judging by your interventions, the Commission's proposal seems to me to be balanced. An approach to greater integration of our asylum systems may be desirable.  If you ask me if I'm happy, I'll tell you I'm satisfied. Our proposal today is both balanced and realistic. It is also ambitious because we propose to go beyond the current Dublin Regulation by introducing a fundamental change, an automatic redistribution mechanism. It is realistic because we are proposing the changes needed to create a system that will be sustainable and equitable. Indeed, our reform simplifies the rules for determining the responsible state. The basic principle is that only one Member State will be responsible for the examination of an asylum application. At the same time, we propose an automatic mechanism for distributing new asylum seekers when a Member State is faced with a disproportionate number of asylum applications.  This is a strong expression of the solidarity that must exist between the Member States. This solidarity can take various forms, including financial ones. The important thing is that it speaks out. With the support of the European Funds and the new European Union Asylum Agency, each Member State must develop its capacity to manage a fair number of asylum applications, which can be up to 150% of its reference value. The threshold has been set to allow intervention before a state is facing a crisis. To do this, the possibility of triggering the mechanisms will be examined weekly.  Secondly, let me clarify what we are proposing to adapt the rules that apply to unaccompanied minors to the new logic of the Dublin Regulation. Our proposal specifies that the responsible Member State will be the one where the minor files his first application for international protection. This Member State is not necessarily the first country of entry. In any case, Member States will have to ensure that it is in the best interests of the minor. The new regulations provide safeguards to ensure that this review is carried out.  Finally, we propose stricter rules to deter secondary movements that call into question the functioning of our asylum system. Strengthening EASO's expertise, human and financial resources, and strengthening Eurodac will facilitate the implementation of the Dublin system.  I really want to work closely with you on our proposals without wasting time. Too many parameters depend on it. An effective common European asylum system is the prerequisite for a borderless European area. The experience we had over the past year has made us more determined, not only to manage the migration crisis in the immediate future but to create a functioning and just system for the future. Let me respond now in Greek to Mr Kyrkos.  Κύριε Κύρκο, δεν υπάρχει σχέδιο Β. Υπάρχει μόνο ένα σχέδιο και αυτό στηρίζεται στην αρχή της αλληλεγγύης, γι̕ αυτό εξάλλου προτείναμε και αλλαγή του Δουβλίνου. Αλλά βασίζεται επίσης και σε έναν στόχο: να καταπολεμηθούν τα δίκτυα των διακινητών και βέβαια να εφαρμοστεί η συνεργασία που έχουμε αποφασίσει με την Τουρκία. Και θέλω να τονίσω ότι αυτή η στρατηγική έχει αρχίσει ήδη να δίνει αποτελέσματα. Γνωρίζετε πολύ καλά ότι οι αφίξεις στα ελληνικά νησιά έχουν μειωθεί θεαματικά. Επομένως, οι φήμες και η παραφιλολογία περί σχεδίου Β δεν ευσταθούν και σας ευχαριστώ πραγματικά που θέσατε αυτό το ζήτημα και μου δώσατε την ευκαιρία να το ξεκαθαρίσω.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. – The Commission has proposed revisions to the regulations governing the European Asylum System. The Socialists have long denounced the inoperability of the current Dublin System and emphasizing the need for an in-depth reform of it that will lead to a true European Asylum System worthy of that name. A system based on solidarity between Member States in addressing the challenges posed by the current dynamics of asylum and refuge. A system that includes a mandatory compliance-sharing key, with corrective mechanisms that take into account the particularities of each State in terms of size, GDP and absorption capacity. We Socialists have managed to get the Commission involved in reform and from today we will work hard to improve the proposals put forward as we believe that what the Commission has raised does not meet our expectations. We welcome the initiative to impose sanctions on insolidary countries that fail to meet their asylum obligations or do not agree to assume their share of responsibility for the receipt and management of asylum applications that correspond to them in accordance with the key of decisive distribution.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The Commission has proposed the revision of the regulations governing the European Asylum System. The Socialists have long denounced the inoperability of the current Dublin System and emphasizing the need for an in-depth reform of it that will lead to a true European Asylum System worthy of that name. A system based on solidarity between Member States in addressing the challenges posed by the current dynamics of asylum and refuge. A system that includes a mandatory compliance-sharing key, with corrective mechanisms that take into account the particularities of each State in terms of size, GDP and absorption capacity. We Socialists have managed to get the Commission involved in reform and from today we will work hard to improve the proposals put forward since what the Commission has raised does not meet our expectations. We welcome the initiative to impose sanctions on insolidary countries that fail to meet their asylum obligations or do not agree to assume their share of responsibility for the receipt and management of asylum applications that correspond to them in accordance with the key of decisive distribution.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The submission of the European Commission's proposal for a revision of the common European asylum system is in itself positive, as it shows that the inadequacy of the current Dublin Regulation is now widely understood. The main direction of the proposal for a fairer system based on solidarity between Member States, with the redistribution of asylum seekers from the Member State of first entry, if this is disproportionately weighted, to the other Member States is also correct. There are, of course, a number of individual issues which need clarification in the context of the dialogue now under way between the Institutions of the Union. But in addition to managing refugee flows, the European Union needs to take their causes more seriously. Refugeeisation is not a natural phenomenon. It is the result of wars waged by some states in our wider geographical region against ethnic minorities on their territory, such as the war of the semi-authoritarian Erdogan regime against the Kurdish minority, or even the consequence of the action of criminal organisations such as the "Islamic State". We therefore need a new, common European foreign policy geared to the common European interest, that is to say to the interest of peace. We must do everything possible to enable refugees to return to their homes.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – The Commission's proposals are divisive and do not help to solve the real problem in Europe. They go against the clearly stated will of some Member States, ignoring the subsidiarity requirement on a number of points. It is divisive and inciting tensions with the public, because it proposes a mechanism with which a significant part of the European public disagrees. An EU citizen may feel that the state spends more on a refugee than on its own citizen. Costing a Member State EUR 250 000 per refugee leads to social tensions, as the value of EU citizens' GDP per capita is far below that in many Member States. The Commission's interpretation of European solidarity is a one-sided approach, and solidarity cannot be enforced with sanctions. Instead, the definition of solidarity already formulated by the BIÜT in 2012 should be enforced.  Therefore, the People's Party's desire to interpret this concept of solidarity more broadly, including efforts to protect the external borders together, is to be welcomed. This proposal shows that if some Member States do not comply with the rules, for example at the external borders, the answer will be to create new rules instead of enforcing existing ones. The Commission's proposals should have been aimed at reducing the total burden on Europe. It would have been important to address the external dimension, the causes of becoming a refugee, the selection of actual refugees – not to mix the refugee issue with general migration.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – The asylum reform is lagging behind reality. The new EC proposal does not amount to a comprehensive solution. Probably quite some Member States and MEPs will not agree with the proposed corrective allocation mechanism in cases of disproportionate number of asylum applications, foreseeing also a payment of EUR 250 000 per refused applicant. Solidarity cannot be enforced by disciplinary measures, it shouldn’t put the validity of subsidiarity principle under doubt. The proposed mechanism will enable a MS to buy itself free from solidarity. I am afraid that instead of contributing to more solidarity this will create more tension and induce new cracks in EU unity. The EC proposal doesn´t address one of the major problems – the massive, organised human trafficking by criminal gangs. According to Europol 90% of asylum seekers in 2015 had used the services of human traffickers, thus creating them a profit between EUR 3-6 billion. This extorted money flows mostly to organised crime and Islamic extremists. EU needs a rapid and comprehensive solution to clamp down on international criminal networks. Lastly, return of people who do not qualify for admission seems not to work. Only 1/3 of those who were refused asylum have been actually sent back, leaving 2/3 to hover in unknown.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: Writing. – The European Commission sometimes suffers from the impression that the European Union is equal to Europe. Therefore, the name of this point is also wrong, because I do not expect that the proposed reform of the common asylum system of EU states will be discussed with the states of Eastern Europe and the Balkans. I find it particularly comical at present to have the idea of such a common system between the EU and Belarus, Russia, Moldova, Turkey, Kazakhstan and the Caucasus Republics. The European Union's asylum system really needs reform. However, the European Commission's efforts to command participants in asylum procedures in which country specific persons can find asylum and in which they cannot must be refused must be fundamentally rejected. What is also strange is the sudden declaration of "safe" by some countries. I consider it an absolutely outrageous attempt to order EU states how many refugees and from which countries they must accept on their territory. Similar efforts by colonial powers in the 20th century led to tragic consequences. And their result in the current implementation may be a threat to EU cohesion. The adoption of such a Regulation may result in the formal fulfilment of the obligation to exote the parties to the asylum procedure in the event of non-compliance with the conditions of residence. Indeed, this is already the case in eu target countries that are attractive to migrants, such as Germany. The whole issue is closely linked to the future of the Schengen system. Eu legislation must respond to the refugee crisis, but quotas are certainly not the solution.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. – The current Dublin mechanism needs to be amended to ensure a fair distribution of responsibilities between Member States. Front-line countries must not bear a disproportionate burden, putting significant resources in and bearing extreme responsibility for the security of the EU's external border. A new mechanism must be operational in the long term, not just serve to overcome the current crisis. It is very important to take into account the lessons learned from the implementation of relocation and resettlement mechanisms. The right to protection must be ensured, but at the same time opportunities for abuse should be avoided. This means clearly distinguishing those fleeing war from those who illegally enter eu territory. All common actions in the field of migration policy must be based on the principle of solidarity and a fair distribution of responsibilities.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The Commission has proposed revisions to the regulations governing the European Asylum System. The Socialists have long denounced the inoperability of the current Dublin System and emphasizing the need for an in-depth reform of it that will lead to a true European Asylum System worthy of that name. A system based on solidarity between Member States in addressing the challenges posed by the current dynamics of asylum and refuge. A system that includes a mandatory compliance-sharing key, with corrective mechanisms that take into account the particularities of each State in terms of size, GDP and absorption capacity. We Socialists have managed to get the Commission involved in reform and from today we will work hard to improve the proposals put forward as we believe that what the Commission has raised does not meet our expectations. We welcome the initiative to impose sanctions on insolidary countries that fail to meet their asylum obligations or do not agree to assume their share of responsibility for the receipt and management of asylum applications that correspond to them in accordance with the key of decisive distribution.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. The Commission's decision is a first step towards a European right of asylum, although not sufficient with a view to the necessary review of the entire Dublin system. It is no coincidence that Pope Francis recently highlighted: "I dream of a Europe in which being a migrant is not a crime, but an invitation to greater commitment, with the dignity of the whole human being". It is morally right not to turn our backs on the tens of thousands of women, men and children knocking on our door. Only a shared solution, which does not give rise to nationalistic selfishness, is equal to Europe. In this respect, Europe's commitment to human rights must not fail, we must not fail to involve respect for fundamental freedoms in agreements with third countries and their economic contributions. A common legal immigration policy is a condition for preventing migrants and refugees from falling into the straits of lawlessness and remaining at the mercy of degradation and crime in order to survive. Let us therefore renounce the closure of borders and the anachronistic suspensions of Schengen and regain confidence in ourselves and between the Member States.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. – Today we discussed for the first time the panic-driven reform proposal for the Commission's refugee distribution system in Dublin. Unfortunately, the proposal is flawed and hasty in many points. Why? Because until there is a common external border guard and the collection camps outside the EU's borders are not operating until there is deportation, this could be the EU's rustiest coffin angle, let alone its saviour.  And the €250,000 fine is a political mistake, with all extremist parties asking for something like this for Christmas. The disproportionality is inexplicable not only to the electorate, but also to me: eur 6 000 would be given to the Member State if it undertakes, but to pay EUR 250 000 if it is unable to undertake the integration of a person. I ask the Commissioner not to force the proposal before the permanent stabilisation of uncontrolled immigration.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. The Commission is finally proposing a proposal to revise Dublin. Unfortunately, this is just a tinkering, which does not call into question the foundations of the current system. We cannot accept that the irregular entry test remains applicable. First-entry countries must become only registered countries, so that they no longer have to process asylum applications from all persons arriving on their territory. Also, the "equity mechanism" should apply not only in an emergency, but permanently.  Finally, if the proposal to punish countries that refuse solidarity is to be welcomed, there must still be guarantees on the effective application of these sanctions. What is needed is harmonisation and Europeanisation of asylum procedures at European level, in order to create a unified and effective European asylum system. We must also defend the creation of a genuine European Asylum Agency to oversee this new system and to deal with asylum applications centrally. The Commission proposes the creation of such an agency, of course, but not within the same framework and not with the same powers. We will fight throughout the parliamentary process to improve this proposal, which does not meet our expectations.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – The current crisis has shown that the EU needs a coherent asylum policy. However, there is still a long way to go, because the most acute problem remains the reluctance of the Member States to implement the decisions that have already been taken. The refugee crisis can only be solved together and requires the commitment of all 28 Member States.  I support the Commission's proposal for an automatically activated mechanism for distributing migrants more evenly to different Member States in a situation where an individual Member State is overburdened. Greece and Italy in particular have been under undue pressure for a long time. This distribution must be fair and take into account the real absorption capacity of the Member States.  All Member States must assume their responsibilities. Particular pressure must now be put on countries that have not taken joint decisions. The Commission's proposal for a fine fee understandably raises objections and is not necessarily feasible as such, but some type of sanctions are needed unless there is now a boost to implementation.  Once again, I would like to highlight the importance of external border control. This is of paramount importance in order to properly identify and register migrants. The EU's involvement in border controls in frontline countries must be increased.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. – In my opinion, reform of the asylum system is inevitable. The EU cannot operate according to the old rules and is also able to face new challenges, which undoubtedly include the migration crisis. I am strongly in support of harmonising asylum procedures across the EU, ing reliable registration systems and access to them. However, it is not possible for us to include quota-based redistribution in the reform of the asylum system. This is not, in my opinion, a solution. It is far more important to establish an effective registration and screening mechanism for all asylum seekers in the EU.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me be clear, the creation of the Schengen Area, in which the free movement of persons across internal borders is ensured, is one of the greatest achievements of the Union. Without any doubt, it has brought important benefits to European citizens and businesses alike. Yet over the past months, the system has been severely tested by the migration crisis, leading several Member States to reintroduce internal border controls. Now as you all know, the aim is to ensure that any and all remaining obstacles are removed by the end of the year at the latest, for the costs of losing free movement within the Schengen Area would be huge. Now to overcome what emerged originally as a patchwork of unilateral decisions, we are developing a coordinated European approach, within the framework of the Schengen rules of course, and let me also underline that the practice of waving through has now ended.  Clearly, securing the EU’s external borders, ensuring efficient border controls and improving the functioning of the asylum system are prerequisites for restoring normal free movement within the Schengen Area. This is a shared responsibility involving all our institutions as well as the Member States. In other words, proper control at our external borders is our common responsibility, hence the need to reinforce our collective ownership over that common good.  Now, as we all know, last December the Commission presented a proposal for a European border and coast guard. It is imperative that we adopt this proposal as soon as possible so that it becomes operational and it is therefore of great importance to work together in order to start trilogues in June and strike a political agreement soon thereafter. In February, the European Council made itself very clear. Member States must grant access to asylum procedures for all applications made at their borders. At the same time they should refuse entry to third country nationals who do not satisfy the entry conditions of the Schengen border code and who have not submitted an application for asylum despite having had the opportunity to do so. The European Council also underlined the importance of restoring the normal functioning of the Schengen Area in a concerted manner while giving full support to Member States facing difficult circumstances. I am of course referring to Greece, whose external border has been under immense pressure.  Now fortunately this pressure has, since the EU—Turkey statements of 18 March, significantly reduced. However, serious deficiencies in external border control persist today – even if many of them have been, and are being, tackled by Greece. That is why the Commission presented on 4 May a proposal on Article 29 of the Schengen Borders Code, a proposal recommending a coherent EU approach to the reinstatement of internal border controls until the structural deficiencies are remedied, as well as proposing border controls only at the sections of the border where they are necessary and proportionate.  Now in closing, the effective application of all these policies and measures taken together, and the effective application by all of us, should contribute to fully reinstating free movement within the Schengen Area and I sincerely hope that we will succeed before the end of the year.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Schengen Area, as you know, is an area of free movement without internal borders. We have repeatedly said here that it is maybe the most tangible achievement of the European integration. This Commission, from the very beginning, has done everything in its power to make sure that we preserve it in accordance with the steps set out in our Back to Schengen roadmap.  Our objective is to return to a normal functioning of the Schengen Area with no internal border controls as soon as possible and within six months at the latest because the costs of internal border controls are already visible. We see transporters complaining about increasing delays and costs and we see the tourism industry in some Member States suffering and this is only a small part – a fraction – of what would happen if border controls were systematically re—established. But the political cost of non—Schengen would be much greater still. It would be a highly symbolic reversal of a major achievement of European integration. This is why we need to take coordinated action at European level, making use of the tools that the same Schengen Borders Code provides us with so as to allow Member States to do what is necessary in the current circumstances, while preserving Schengen as a whole. This is what our proposal under Article 29 of the Schengen Borders Code is meant to achieve. Let me first acknowledge that Greece has made significant progress in the last few months. However, not all deficiencies identified in the management of external borders control have been remedied. This concerns in particular sea border surveillance, reception capacities and registration on the mainland of migrants who were not registered upon arrival in the islands.  Despite the reduction in the flows due to our cooperation with Turkey, the sustainability of this reduction still has to be confirmed. Moreover, a number of these unregistered migrants remain in Greece or in other countries of the Western Balkans. They may seek to move irregularly to other Member States. In other words, the reasons that led several states to unilaterally introduce temporary border controls still exist. The persistent threat of secondary movements puts at risk the overall functioning of the Schengen Area. Therefore a coherent, coordinated and sustainable common approach to temporary internal border controls, as foreseen in Article 29 of the Schengen Borders Code, is needed at EU level. Article 29 is a tool to safeguard the functioning of the whole Schengen Area and this is the first time that the Commission has made use of it.  As a result, we propose that the Council recommend that Austria, Germany, Sweden, Denmark and Norway maintain their internal border controls at specific border-crossing points for up to six months. Controls will be regularly reviewed by the Schengen states concerned and adjusted to the level of the security threat addressed. The states concerned will also report to the Commission every two months. Let me be clear about two things. Article 29 is not a sanction against a Member State nor a means to expel it from the Schengen Area. I want to be very clear on that. We do not propose the introduction of border controls at Greece’s Schengen border, namely at airports and ports. In addition, we clearly state that the controls introduced should be proportionate and limited to what is strictly necessary to respond to the serious threat and safeguard public policy and internal security. They should impede border crossing for the general public as little as possible.   The Commission will continuously monitor the situation and will report to this Parliament and the Council, after four months, on the possible need to adapt the application of its initial recommendation. The principles of necessity and proportionality are the guiding principles for this and any future decision. Let me therefore reiterate that our proposal is an exceptional – temporary – measure to ultimately allow for the safeguarding and return to a normally functioning Schengen Area as soon as possible. It is expected that, by the end of the six—month period at the latest, the implementation of other tools will allow the lifting of all internal border controls and a return to a normally functioning Schengen. I refer in particular to the European border and coast guard, to the further sustained implementation of the EU—Turkey statement, and the full application of EU asylum rules, as well as the swift agreement by the co-legislators on the recently presented proposals for reforming parts of the Common European Asylum System, in particular the Dublin System. We look forward to the Council adopting the proposed recommendation tomorrow.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – I join all those who welcome the European Commission's efforts to restore the Schengen system. I am even convinced that this is one of the european Union's key tasks in the months to the end of the year. It is clear – the more the external borders are 'Schengen', the more freedom will be inward. The creation of 'Schengen' was one of the biggest experiments in the history of the Union in the 1980s, but it can only flourish if there is a proper climate in the area, especially trust and security. Today, we know what beneficial economic effects the Schengen system has brought. However, we also know that failure would cost us tens of billions of euros a year. Dear. I am convinced that the end of Schengen could also mean the end of the European Union, which was created at the heart of The Second World War with a view to maintaining lasting peace. Today, neither the European Union nor peace is taken for granted. That's why we have to work every day to preserve them. Protectionism is re-awakening in Europe, even under the influence of various destabilising factors. Protectionism! In the early 1960s, the first half of the two-century world war, two great seas, led to the first half of the two-century world war. Let history be our teacher. Let us work on concepts that will consolidate the values on which the Union is founded. A fully functioning Schengen system is one of them.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. The fact is that, in light of past developments, COREPER has today adopted the European Commission's proposal for a semi-annual extension of border checks at internal Schengen borders. It is true that in some places these boundaries are still sensitive, that the situation has not yet been fully and definitively stabilised. However, it is far from alarming. Rather, the reasons for this extension appear to be questionable. We must not agree on the principle of prolonging internal controls as far as "in stock" and at the will of individual members.  This creates further internal tightening, including between the new and old members of the Union, which is absolutely not needed at the moment. Nor do we need to use changes in border control for political campaigns, as Austria recently afforded when it sent an army to an otherwise empty burden.  This kind of creation of some frightening situation and the apparent fight against an invisible enemy is a very bad signal for European citizens. However, we must insist that the Commission prepare a report as soon as possible after the introduction of the extension of internal border controls, whether and to what extent this measure is proportional. It must also do so in the light of the fact that the introduction of border controls in some Member States has paralysed the transport and logistics sector of the whole of Europe and that the consequences of this control will result in between €5 billion and €18 billion in direct costs per year, in particular in road and freight transport, as well as in tourism and cross-border mobility. Instead of iso -- which will not prevent internal terrorist attacks caused by European citizens — we must focus our forces and resources on ensuring the effective functioning of the external Schengen border and helping countries that are still facing significant migratory pressure.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR group. – Mr President, unfortunately terrorist organisations have been underestimated, radicalisation has been underestimated. European citizens who have sided with Jihad have been underestimated. The time has come, in the twelfth hour, to show lucidity and act. Since September 2015, several Schengen Member States have reintroduced internal controls. I have been and remain a supporter of the Schengen area, it is one of the Union's most important achievements for citizens and business.  It is time for Romania to enter Schengen. We have been using the Schengen Information System successfully for several years. As a state on the External Border of the Union, Romania wants to enter Schengen and take its share of responsibility in the field of European security. As the Commissioner for Migration has said, an internal area without border controls is only possible if we have solid protection of the Union's external borders. Securing the Union's external borders is a mandatory condition for maintaining freedom of movement within the Schengen area and beyond.  We need to identify who and why crosses the union's borders, this can be done by introducing controls at the Union's external borders for both European and third-country citizens, by checking in databases, but the condition for any verification is that the databases be updated with real-time information by all Member States. Today we have twenty-three Member States that have not updated the Schengen databases.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, on behalf of the ALDE Group I am very glad that we are having this debate. We requested it because we welcome the roadmap that was presented by the Commission for restoring a fully-functioning Schengen system. However, in practice we do not see much progress. We see more, rather than less, border controls. We see walls being put up, not broken down, and a couple of days ago we even heard about a violent incident on the border of one of the Schengen countries with refugees being shot at, so the situation is actually getting worse, not better. Maybe Schengen is not yet dead but it is certainly on life support.  What I would like to know from the Commission is how strictly are you applying the criteria, because you keep saying it has to be necessary and proportionate, but that seems to have become a bit of a mantra because we do not see border controls disappearing. I do not see any steps in the direction of abolishing them. We seem to think that it is a kind of replacement for a fully-fledged refugee and security policy or a replacement for a European border and coast guard, but this is in the hands of the Member States. The Member States should take their responsibility and no longer hesitate about a common asylum policy, the common security policy and a border and coast guard, rather than reinstating border controls.  I think it has been said by others that Schengen is a great achievement and the current border controls come at a huge economic cost, so we have every interest in abolishing the border controls as quickly as possible.  I would really like to know from the Commission: how do you assess the recurrent requests from the Member States for authorising border checks? Quite frankly I have not seen many cases where the Commission has said: sorry, this is simply not justified. When we say it has to be ‘exceptional and temporary’ we are talking about, I believe, six Schengen countries now, or eight, for a very extended period of time. That does not sound like exceptional and temporary. I understand that you are under a lot of pressure from the Member States who want the Commission to actually clean up the mess left by the Member States, but I really hope that you will resist the pressures.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the free movement of people is one of the cornerstones of the European Union and the creation of the Schengen area has contributed to a more effective exercise of this freedom. However, the pressure created at the external borders due to the influx of migrants and refugees has led seven Member States to reintroduce controls at certain internal borders within this area. Since then, however, conditions have changed radically and, in particular, with regard to Greece, the country has taken decisive steps to control its external borders. The future of Europe without Schengen is at least in doubt. The reintroduction of borders between Member States would cost European economies many billions of euros a year, with heavy implications, particularly in the transport sectors of trade and tourism. Furthermore, there are disadvantages that are not costed, such as the decline in the quality of life for the approximately two million European citizens who cross borders every day in order to get to work. However, regardless of the economic results, the abolition of the Schengen area would be a setback on the road to European integration. We therefore need the abolition of internal border controls, the sooner the better.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, overcoming borders, it has been said, is at the heart of the European idea. Borders that used to be once the cause of war could be crossed easily in the past, and I believe it is really at the borders where European citizens can see and experience the true value of the European idea and what Europe really means. But the fences and the borders that have been erected in the past month destroy pretty much all of that. They divide people, it is harmful to the economy and it destroys the fundaments of Europe. Just look at the Brenner Pass, look at Malmö and Copenhagen.
