Then look at the French-German border, and look at how all these border regions have integrated and how we are trying to do that much more to the East, and all of that is being disrupted – if not completely destroyed. That is why I believe, and that is why we believe, that this closing of borders has to end immediately and not just in a couple of months, at the end of the year, or whenever. And our internal borders are on the way to be coming as deadly as our external borders are. Slovak border guards have been shooting at refugees; a boat sank just yesterday in the sea between Denmark and Sweden. This is the situation we are in right now. Do we want the Øresund to become the new Aegean in this respect? Closing borders does not stop people from coming; it only makes their journey more distressful and increases the death toll. Fences are not a solution for anything, neither at the internal borders nor at the external borders. This Schengen debate really is a debate about the future of the European Union; about where we will stand tomorrow, but this future starts today. Whatever we do wrong right now cannot be mended tomorrow. This is why we need to pull down the fences and to overcome the borders once again, because this is what Europe is for. Let us not destroy this fundament, this stuff that Europe is really built on.  (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question by Korwin-Mikke under Rule 162(8))

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the EFDD Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The Schengen Agreement guarantees travel without border controls at internal borders, but the abandonment of border controls requires secure external borders. These external borders were already rotten, and then Mrs Merkel came and completely demolished them. Schengen is dead. Anyone who wants to have Schengen back must secure the external borders of the Schengen area, and not build a wall or fence in the non-Schengen state of Macedonia, or demand that a despot protect the Turkish-Syrian border. We need an Australian solution before the refugees make their way back to Lampedusa. We must consistently close the sea route across the Mediterranean, and we need reception camps for refugees and more money for refugees in order to be able to help outside Europe. Anyone who is responsible, but unwilling or unable to protect the Schengen borders, must leave the Schengen area.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Once again, we are discussing Schengen, and this debate today shows that Schengen in this form is a very central conceptual flaw on the part of the European Union: well-intentioned, but very, very poorly implemented accordingly. In principle, you do not have to have anything against the principle of open borders, you just have to adapt all the environmental conditions according to that, you have to feel safe. That is not the case at the moment. You could compare it to his apartment or garden. If I can leave the door open, i don't have to build a fence, it's a very safe situation, and anyone who comes to me will be welcome. But – the situation at the moment is different, because no one has an overview of who is coming to Europe, who is moving through the various countries, how many criminals are involved, how many terrorists are involved. That is why, for my country – for Austria – I am calling for us to regain control of our borders, including all other countries, until it is ensured that no criminals, terrorists, or persons whose whereabouts and their origin cannot be precisely determined, enter our country and our continent.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). – In fact the question today should be whether we really want to restore the functioning of Schengen. Given the Structural Weaknesses of the Union, this Treaty has been shown to serve to a large extent various illegal trafficking rings for arms, drugs, people and, more generally, smuggling. To date, the movement of extremist or terrorist groups from one Member State of the Union to another cannot be controlled in any way in order to escape the attention of the authorities. In addition to the security reasons which really call into question the need for Schengen, we must take into account the role played by this Treaty and the weakening of the weaker economic states by a valuable scientific or skilled workforce which, with almost no obstacle, moves to Northern and Western Europe condemning the countries of origin to permanent recession or even to a long delay in development. So before there is a debate on how to restore the Treaty, it would be better and much more useful to decide whether it really should exist. It would be very good to hear convincing arguments in favour of it, arguments really, not sentimentalities and ideologies.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Mr President, the events of 2015, namely the unprecedented number of migrants and the terrorist attacks in Paris, have shown that the actions taken so far to manage the European Union's external borders are not effective in addressing today's challenges. More importantly, events have proved the constant link between the need to protect the european Union's external borders and the preservation of the free movement of persons within the European Union and in Schengen.  I believe that the legislative proposals currently under discussion, such as the European Border Office, will lead to better and more effective management of the external borders, the most important being to ensure a pan-European approach, not a one-off action by Member States. Only in this way will it also be possible to ensure the integrity and future of the Schengen area.  Here I want to highlight the fact that the European Union and Schengen will be safer if Bulgaria is accepted as a member of Schengen as soon as possible. As an external European border, we are responsible for ensuring the security not only of Bulgarian citizens, but also of all over 500 million Europeans.  The work of the Bulgarian border police in the fight against foreign fighters and illegal crossing of European borders by migrants has proven to be extremely successful and is often set as an example. I can boldly argue that Bulgaria protects borders better than some members of Schengen.  Taking the country into Schengen and providing full access to the relevant information systems will inevitably contribute to more European security. The future of Schengen depends on our readiness for more European action and this includes Bulgaria's accession to Schengen.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which It is not about ideology, as you have just said. It is also a bit about emotions, but first and foremost it is about what this European Union actually is all about. The free movement of people in the EU is one of the few truly visible, tangible experiences, and especially for young people who see the EU as an advantage for their personal lives.  The free movement of goods is an important part of the internal market. And business circles have calculated that it would cost us well over EUR 40 billion each year if these borders were tight. It is utter nonsense to erect fences, because in reality they are not intended to protect them, but only to shift a problem – the so-called refugee problem – to the neighbour. And these fences and border controls are intended to deceive us into some form of security that does not exist to this extent and through these measures.  I was able to celebrate Europe Day for two hours on Monday. That is, from Offenburg to Strasbourg, because three police officers who were instructed – who did not do so voluntarily – told each other jokes and the road was narrowed to one lane. Where there should be more security, they will not be able to explain to any person in Germany or to anyone here in Alsace. In this respect, Commissioner, I am very unhappy with her proposal. She's lukewarm! By saying: let us continue this nonsensical game for six months, and we report every two months. You don't need to report every two months. You can finish the report tomorrow morning when you start now. It is nonsense, it pretends to be security that does not exist, and it damages and damages our European Union as a whole.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I believe that one aspect of Schengen cooperation that we should pay much more attention to is the economic consequences of disintegration. Companies that depend on deliveries at exact time will have problems and lose competitiveness. The time delays that everyone who commutes to another EU country will have is estimated at between EUR 1.3 billion and EUR 5.2 billion. The tourism industry is expected to lose around EUR 1.2 billion a year, and border controls will require staff who are expected to cost away upwards of EUR 6 billion a year. And taxpayers will have to foot the bill. The result of all this is more expensive prices for consumers, less competitive companies, smaller margins for employing people and ultimately less growth and deteriorating welfare across the EU. Reintroduced border controls are perhaps the most effective way in which we can kill off our economic prosperity, and I ask myself why some politicians are so obsessed with sawing off the branch on which we are all sitting.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: – Mr President, in the wake of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels it was understandable that national governments would reinstate border controls to increase security and try to monitor who was coming in and out of a country. An alleged plot was uncovered yesterday by Italian police revealing that an ISIS-linked group was using migrant routes and open borders to plan terror attacks in Britain, Italy, France and Belgium. Just like this latest plot, the perpetrators of the Paris and Brussels murders crossed internal EU borders unchecked, including between France, Belgium and Hungary. Some of them had even been to Syria and returned. In calling for borders to once again become a terrorist’s dream, the EU has shown it puts its diehard dogma of a European superstate above the safety of the European people whom it is supposed to represent and who pay for it – in the case of Britain, to the tune of GBP 8 billion net. And ‘die’ is a pertinent word, for the EU has blood on its hands. Schengen is not only the free movement of people: it is also the free movement of terrorists and Kalashnikovs. I question the principles of all those urging the UK to vote to remain in the EU. I also question the principles of those senior British military personnel who, like me, swore an oath of allegiance to Her Majesty The Queen, but who have been telling voters we are safer in the EU. It is my sincere belief that the British people are safer outside of this leaking terrorist haven of a political union. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I wanted to ask you if you do not find it strange that here on the left side of the chamber everyone is saying that you have to leave the borders open, that no walls will help, and no one will say that the bait for these immigrants, namely social benefits, must be removed. The only way out, if we want to preserve the Schengen area, is to abolish socialism, to abolish the benefits that attract these people to us. Do you agree with me?

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I do agree with you, but as I say, to me this is a matter of safety and security for the people of Europe. Open borders is perpetuating the ISIS and the Daesh to come into Europe and kill and murder wholesale. We have to put back up the borders.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Mr President, Schengen is a failed project – I do not know why we are even discussing it. I really do not buy the economic argument; it is security that matters. What price do we put on our security?  Schengen’s open borders have allowed thousands of illegal migrants to camp at Calais for onward illegal entry into the UK. The French authorities have even given them safe passage via trains to Calais.  Dublin is being dumped, not because it did not work, but because the State has turned a blind eye. Now nation states are putting up borders – borders work, that works. I was in Calais again last week; five and a half thousand migrants are camped there, all waiting illegally to break into my country. I have been there quite a lot of times, I have spoken to the various nations represented there, and I have asked them: are you refugees? But they are not refugees, they are economic migrants. Because I go there and ask them – I do not listen to the Commission, I do not listen to the left and the human rights industry that are promoting this – I go there and listen to them myself.  When I was there last week, they were deciding they were refugees because the human rights industry was telling them they were. Real refugees do not pick and choose the borders where they want to stay. That is Schengen. That is allowed, and that is why it has failed.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Schengen area is not only the foundation of the great idea of the European Union, proof of the existence of a genuine community, but also a key element of the EU economy. For these reasons, we should take care of its inviolability. On the other hand, however, we must have the ability to act in crisis situations, including the migration crisis and the terrorist threat in Europe. For these reasons, it seems that it is possible to accept, but only in certain situations and only for a limited period of time, the suspension of the Schengen area and only in certain places. At the same time, it should be remembered that such solutions do not tolerate the risks that I mentioned and protect us only to a limited extent. Europeans, on the other hand, are waiting for effective and definitive solutions, and restrictions on the schengen area are not among them. Similarly, penalties imposed on states even if they break out of the principle of solidarity. I therefore hope that this year we will free the Schengen area from restrictions and thus find solutions to restore freedom and freedom of movement in the European Union.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, the Commission and the Council want to make it clear that we are on the path to the Schengen restoration, discovering significant progress, look at the situation in Greece, where thousands of refugees are shamefully blocked, arrested and threatened with deportation, while on the border between Hungary and Slovakia police and military forces are shooting refugees. At the same time, the Commission recommends that Member States such as Austria, Germany, Denmark and Sweden keep their borders closed as a threat to public order and internal security. The denial of reality even hurts. But it is temporary, the Commission says, by legitimising member states to join in to violate Austria-led Schengen but remotely controlled by the German government, which, without proclaiming it, suddenly closed the door open to refugees, announced by the chancellor last summer.  The Commission and the Council have, in the schengen breach, heavy responsibilities for not acting against Prime Minister Orbán when he challenged the Union, refusing to share the relocation and beginning to build walls and attack refugees. The Council and the Commission have made things worse with the dirty deal with Erdogan, which, in addition to being immoral and illegal, is also impractical, as developments in Turkey itself prove; and it is ineffective, it only diverts refugees and the networks of dowees to other stops. The Commission's proposal on the revision of the Dublin Regulation, which has long been called for in this Parliament, is based on sharing responsibilities and solidarity between Member States. The Council and the Commission must see this problem as European from now on. We desperately need more Europe, and more Europe is Schengen. And we also need strategic leadership, which we unfortunately don't have today.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the Schengen area has been abolished in practice for months. Germany, France, Austria, Denmark, Sweden have suspended Schengen. Today's decision - a recommendation by the Commission - now legitimises the formal suspension of Schengen for two years which will lead to closed borders and turn Greece into a vast refugee camp. So instead of relocating thousands of refugees from Greece to the European Union, Greece is finally turning into a vast refugee Dachau. Greece's participation in Schengen has turned it into a magnet for the thousands of refugees in Turkey who prefer to risk drowning in the Aegean Sea to reach Greece rather than go safely to Bulgaria, which is not a Schengen country. They therefore prefer Greece, as a Schengen country, which grants Schengen travel documents and allows them to travel to Germany. So the only solution now for Greece is to leave Schengen here and now, to stop being a magnet for refugees. That is what I proposed as early as 11 December and it is time to implement it.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: Madam President, I would like to make a point of the regulation, because this is not the first time that Mr Marias has compared the refugee camps, or what can happen in Greece, to what happened in the concentration camps. I heard, according to tradition, that he was comparing this to the Dachau camp.  I would like to point out that in France - and Parliament is located in Strasbourg, France - the law punishes any attempt at denialism. Comparing to Dachau what is happening today is a way of denying the genocide that took place during the Second World War. I believe that, as President, you should object to such remarks being made in our Chamber.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, I am asking for the floor on a personal matter, because my colleague has referred to me personally. So I explain to my colleague that I am one of those who have condemned both Dachau and the concentration camps, I am one of those who clearly in my political life I have condemned these acts and that is why I have also asked Germany for compensation for the Greeks who died in the Nazi camps. So my position is clear. What I said, for my colleague to understand, is that when thousands of refugees are trapped in Greece, they will be trapped...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Madam President, to return to Schengen, I would say that the term has become a 'paradox', a kind of living paradox. Today, it is used by some who, to suppress freedom of movement, use it as a scapegoat for all our ills and evils. For others, of which I am still a part with - I wish and feel it - many European citizens, this is the most concrete element that Europe brings, it is - as the Commissioner has pointed out - the most tangible achievement. In this respect, if I may, in my constituency, which is close to three European countries - Luxembourg, the German states and Belgium - Schengen is part of the daily lives of these men and women who work on the other side, in one Member State. Behind Schengen, there are men, women, activities, trade, the economy. In addition, there are 1.250 billion trips to the European area, not counting students. Of course, there are improvements that can and must be made to strengthen the agreement, notably through the communication of the "Back to Schengen" Commission, but there are many answers. One of them, which we have already debated, will be put to Parliament's vote: that of external borders, of a European body - which is fully European - of border guards and coastguards. Schengen is also about helping countries that are at external borders and face difficulties. It is an excellent intelligence cooperation. It is our common interest, but it is above all our European responsibility, and it must be shared.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, the Council and the Brussels Commission announce their desire to restore a fully functioning Schengen system. In Eurocratic jargon, this means that "we must save the Schengen soldier". This fad will cost us dearly: 6 billion euros given to Turkey and promises of visas for 78 million Turks. Why all this? To persuade her to take back 72,000 migrants, not one more! The other migrants, which number in the millions, will be relocated to the Member States. Woe to states that will want to resist. It will cost them 250,000 euros per rejected migrant.  It's time to face reality. Schengen is a total failure, a sieve whose holes cannot be plugged. The people of Europe don't want it anymore. The European Union will have to listen to them or it will disappear.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I believe that the erosion of freedom of movement is one of the most visible threats to the rights acquired by citizens of the European Union. The effects on the competitiveness of our businesses, entrepreneurs, have already been mentioned in the debate. I think that if there has been talk in the debate that this may be an economic collapse, that may be somewhat excessive. However, the costs, which are quantified precisely in relation to the threat to the Schengen area and freedom of movement, are indeed alarming. This clearly provides a political task for the Commission and, of course, for the Council to work with full force to restore the Schengen area. However, the costs that we can measure in the negative figures on the economic level are immeasurable on a political level. How will it really affect the mindset of the citizens of the European Union if it loses one of the most visible features of European integration? I don't think anyone can even predict enough of this future vision today.  There's a lot of talk about safety. Of course, the clear political task of national governments is to ensure the security of their citizens. But it is not possible to sacrifice one of these main visible freedoms on the altar of security, and that is freedom of movement. In my opinion, the political task of all, both the Member States and the Institutions of the European Union, is to apply the return policy consistently in order to be effective and effective. This will ensure that the Schengen area works for us.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: – Madam President, Schengen is perhaps the most significant achievement of the European Union, which is also tangible and tangible to citizens. Not only does it make everyday life a great ease, but its economic importance is enormous. Schengen is also a great symbol of freedom, unity and a common Europe. It is therefore disappointing to see national governments giving up lightly on what has been fought so much for. It is fooling ourselves to think that locking up, foreclosure, ever-tighter controls, suspending Schengen borders will somehow solve the difficulties caused by migration. It doesn't solve, it only exacerbates conflicts. After all, it gives the impression that there is a separate solution in the Member States, even though we know that there is none.  The pointless "law and order" policy only strengthens the far right. The extent to which this is the case is illustrated by what has happened in Austria in recent days. It must finally be understood that it is not possible to catch the wind from the sails of demagogokers by taking over the assets of the far right. The really heavy price, however, is once again paid by those fleeing war. A 26-year-old Syrian woman was seriously injured on the Hungarian-Slovak border this week when border guards opened fire on her. Is this Europe today? Is that where we're going to get? We all have a common responsibility to protect Schengen. National selfishness, populist far-right politics cannot be sedented. It is not refugees who are threatening Europe and Schengen, it is the incarceration, the nationalist selfishness, the stupid populism.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A key part of our discussion on Schengen is devoted to Greece. It is true that Greece is currently at the centre of attention. But arewe not just looking at a small part of the problem here? If the route shifts, we will find, to our surprise, that there are equally large deficits at the other external borders. We must recognise that saving Schengen is not a real question that can be answered with yes or no. In reality, it is a moral obligation to protect our external borders with common border management in order to keep internal borders open. This border security must be based on trust, solidarity and fairness towards third-country nationals. The European Parliament and the Commission have already taken steps in the right direction. As is so often the case, however, it seems that the Member States are failing. We must be honest with ourselves and with our people: Schengen is more than the removal of passport control, Schengen is a European achievement, the core of the Union and a necessary condition for prosperity and growth.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Madam President, Madam Minister, it is good to see you representing the Council, Commissioner, we do not support those who want to destroy Schengen. We criticise inaction, lack of solidarity, the setback in Europe's achievements. Internal border checks can be an analgesic to buy time to stop the disease. But we must continue to solve long-term problems while responding to short-term ones. We must immediately be sympathetic to Greece and ask the Greek Government for more determination and effectiveness. The commission's proposal for a decision to extend internal border controls is a foreseeable step. It does not destroy Schengen, but prolongs a chaotic period of transition in which Member States have used this prerogative in a totally uncoordinated manner. And while some, like Germany, have tried to better welcome asylum seekers, others have only done so to fuel populist discourse. The Commission's proposal at least mitigates this problem. But this decision should not serve to justify the irrationalities and national selfishness that we have seen.  Moreover, this proposal for a decision is the result of the assessment of Greece's external borders, the shortcomings of which have not yet been recsised. Greece will never be able to do it on its own. As the Commission acknowledges. On the other hand, if there are certainly problems in border management, it is agreed that it is in the field of asylum, which is not part of the Schengen assessments, that the real source of the problem is!

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The renewed extension of border controls is a serious intervention. It provokes the danger that we will get used to it and that the Europe we know will be decisively changed, to the point of being unrecognisable. Many now see the reintroduction of border controls as a panacea of domestic policy, such as the Brenner. It is positive that the Commission and the Council see the problem, but I do not agree with the solutions. This is also due to the poor quality of the discussion. Such serious measures should actually be discussed intensively and transparently, and not only at ambassadorial level and in a Development Assistance Council, as is happening now. The European Parliament should be involved and not just informed. I would remind you that three years ago, as the European Parliament, we asked for participation in the Schengen evaluation mechanism. At the time, the Council gave us the cold shoulder. That was a very bad decision.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like also to reiterate that Schengen is just unprecedented; its value cannot be matched and we need to maintain it and of course develop it, but in order to do that, we really need to safeguard the external borders. The Commissioner has identified the deficiencies but I think, Commissioner, that any Member State will always have a difficulty and I think this is just yet one more argument for having a European coast and border guard – a European one, an efficient one, with all the capacities.  If we have that, and if we also reform the asylum system but with a strict return policy, and if we are efficient with it and if we will really identify the key issue, which is the real refugees, then we will also have solidarity. We need solidarity and unity in order to perform and to deliver. The 250 000 is going in the opposite direction; I am sorry to say so but that is killing unity. Otherwise if we work on these aspects then we will achieve it for sure. One final remark. There were some views from the left of the Hemicycle, saying that Schengen is basically contributing to terrorism. With that logic we would have to build borders in London, in Paris and between the States. That is just a stupidity and a nonsense.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, the Schengen agreement is one of the most important achievements of European integration. The current migrant crisis, however, has severely damaged the possibility of Schengen’s further unaltered functioning. Every state has the right to promote its security by whatever legal means available, but the introduction of internal border controls within Schengen takes place mostly unilaterally, without any serious assessment of the underlining systemic consequences. As a result, should the border controls ever be fully re-established, the EU economy, cooperation and development across many areas shall severely suffer. That, quite frankly, makes the estimated yearly costs of EUR 5 to 18 billion a serious understatement. Ensuring better protection of the external borders and assisting the Member States that suffer the most is absolutely necessary. However, since one of the main reasons for reintroduction of border controls was and still is their thoroughness, revision of internal cross-border security measures is highly warranted. The only one who can fix this situation are the Europeans themselves, no deals with rather untrustworthy and unpredictable neighbours will ever do that for us.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D). Madam President, Commissioner, we all understand that you have one of the most complex portfolios and this extraordinary situation, although temporary, is difficult to assess when it will be brought under control in every dimension. I would ask you to make a few clarifications, as all countries should respect the agreements, but above all Greece is going through dramatic and continuous austerity. What will be the cost of protecting its external maritime borders and how much is Europe prepared to bear? Could you also give us a timetable for Frontex and NATO action and tell us what the plan is for next? Also, if Turkey's demands are not met, what are basically your concerns and what do you think will become of the people who are already trapped in Greece? And one final question: can we also have a timetable for what will be the immediate restoration of Schengen and the improvement of its functioning, as well as your assurance that there will be no exit of any country from Schengen?

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Madam President, Respected Commissioner, by giving up Schengen we would accept the fear that terrorists want to impose on us. The cost of not functioning Schengen is huge and amounts to between €15 billion and €18 billion a year as estimated by the European Commission. It is much better to invest these funds in strengthening the common external border, in strengthening Frontex and European guard teams. That is why I certainly support the European Commission Action Plan. It was made together with the Member States and it is important that they feel ownership of the plan and the responsibility for implementing it.  I have heard in speeches by some MPs that they see no improvement in the return of Schengen. I have a completely different experience. Now you can drive from Croatia via Slovenia, Austria, Germany to France without wasting hours at every border. Finally, one message for the Commissioner: I ask that Croatia, which is outside Schengen and wants to enter as soon as possible, support and speed up the entry process along the way.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the end of Schengen would mean the beginning of the end of the European project. The harmful consequences would be incalculable for all European citizens, who would suddenly find themselves in a Europe fragmented into small states, prey to national self-interest. We would lose the great achievement of the ease of moving from one point to another in Europe: damage to our economy, to our tourism and also to our transport. If I think of my own country, Italy would be alone in managing the migratory flow. Schengen can and must be saved for the future of a real Europe, with a global and holistic approach to the whole migration phenomenon, together with an ambitious dublin amendment, to establish humanitarian corridors, visas and humanitarian admissions, to strengthen legal immigration channels, to intervene in the root causes that move people from their lands. And finally, for a strong foreign and development cooperation policy.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Colleagues, freedom of movement within the Schengen area is certainly a very symbolic advantage of European integration. But freedom is only possible if it is accompanied by responsibility. In this case, the responsibility for the safe external border of the Schengen area. The external border is not sufficiently protected and I fully understand citizens' concerns about security, which is why I also understand the temporary measures that some countries have simply taken within the Schengen area at their borders. Moreover, the Commission is not proposing anything else at the moment. Therefore, until the external border is adequately protected, there will be illegal migration, then these temporary controls will also be necessary. I would reiterate once again that freedom without responsibility is simply not possible and is not sustainable.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, the Schengen area is one of the most significant achievements of modern Europe. It guarantees the free movement of hundreds of millions of European Union citizens. However, in the past year, six Schengen members have re-introduced controls at their internal borders for reasons related to the refugee crisis. This temporary introduction of border controls negatively affects trade, but above all has important implications for the European project, expressed in Euroscepticism, anti-immigrant and populist rhetoric.  I therefore believe that we must restore the normal functioning of the Schengen area by the end of this year at the latest. To this end, we must ensure the protection of the European Union's external borders, and this can be achieved with the newly established European Border and Coast Guard Service. It must be based on joint responsibility and solidarity, and Member States that are not yet part of the Schengen area, such as Bulgaria and Romania, should also participate in it.  I believe that a return to the normal functioning of the Schengen area is a return to the foundations of European integration.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, restoring the full operation of the Schengen system is the sine qua non for the creation of a real Europe. Never before have we defended the Schengen Treaty with all our might, putting an end to myopic and sterile nationalism. The free movement of persons was already one of the objectives of the Single European Act and Schengen is to be regarded as one of the most concrete advances made by the European Union.  Closing borders to stem migratory flows is tantamount to turning the clock back on integration. The suspension of the Schengen Treaty can only immediately plug the security emergency, but it cannot make up for the absence of a common immigration and asylum policy in all Member States and the lack of a concretely integrated and functioning system of police and external border control. It is a common responsibility and a duty to history to ensure that solidarity prevails over scepticism and fear.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, dear colleagues, first of all, I would like to express my thanks for your interventions and your contributions. Ms in ‘t Veld and Ms Fajon, I will answer your concerns. What prevailed is the need to ensure a coordinated and coherent European approach. We have set a timetable; a roadmap, and we implement it. We clearly state that we will be monitoring the application of our recommendations. Member States are expected to adjust the controls to the level of the threat. And yes, some Member States have stopped the controls when they were not necessary.  And yes, on a different case, on the Brenner for instance, I have sent a very clear letter that we do not agree with the reintroduction of border controls and border checks as the situation currently stands. Our very constructive discussion gives me confidence that most of us in this House believe in, work for and support the need for more Europe. The message is clear: we will walk this way together – together and united with a spirit of true solidarity and responsibility as our Treaties expressly stipulate. Going back to Schengen will allow the reorientation of our common European endeavour towards a deeper and more integrated Union – an achievement with tangible important benefits in the everyday life of the citizens of Europe and businesses. May I now draw attention to those who are in favour of building walls, erecting fences and fortresses, afraid of outside enemies. Beware of the Trojan horse carrying xenophobia, racism, populism and extremism. Europe has suffered in the past from elements like this. Border controls should take place only as long as required to address the threat to public policy and internal security. It is an exceptional measure to be used only in exceptional circumstances; it should not obey myopic, short-term domestic policy and tactics. Since you asked me about Greece, allow me to answer as well in Greek now.  Ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Kailis, you have raised very important issues with me. The European Commission is putting an end to the scenarios and paraphilia, which it is paradoxically still holding, for expelling Member States from the Schengen Treaty and imposing so-called penalties. Article 29, which we are triggering for the first time, is intended not to punish, but to ensure the protection of the proper and safe functioning of the Schengen area. There are no controls imposed at airports and ports. With the full support and support of the European Commission, as I had the opportunity to say in my protology, Greece has made considerable progress in recent months in the area of effective management of our common external borders. Certainly, we do not overlook weaknesses and shortcomings, because, yes, they still exist. But we do not overlook the fact that Greece has had to deal with migration and refugee flows of unprecedented intensity. It is on the right track, but it must complete the effective response to all the issues that have been highlighted to it. We activate every available financial resource. We mobilise all available technical assistance, we have a concrete and coherent plan, implementing a holistic strategy, the first results of which have already begun to be felt In this context, the initial implementation of the European Union Turkey Agreement as well as the ongoing operations of FRODEX and NATO, particularly in the Aegean, have contributed to a drastic reduction in the number of irregular migrants and asylum seekers. Honourable Members, the European example shows that through crises Europe is coming out even stronger, even stronger and, of course, this will happen now.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I think that Mr Zver touched upon the essence of what we are discussing when he said that the better the control of our external borders, the more freedom we can allow within our borders. I agree with all of you –or most of you, I have to say – that it is of the greatest importance to restore full freedom of movement in the Schengen area as soon as possible and as soon as the circumstances allow us to act accordingly. Some of you remarked that things are getting worse rather than better. I beg to differ. The utter chaos that we experienced at our borders earlier this year is disappearing. We are regaining control. But it is true that we need to further stabilise the situation, and this further stabilisation of the situation is necessary before we can lift all controls and return to normal again. I agree with all who have said that the controls need to be exceptional, temporary and proportionate. That is exactly what the Commission proposal aims to do and that is why we hope to adopt a decision tomorrow at the Foreign Affairs Council. Of course Mrs in ‘t Veld is totally right when she says that Schengen is one of the greatest European achievements – I totally agree with her – and Mrs Fajon and others are right in pointing out the economic consequences if the Schengen area were to fall apart. We have heard things like ‘I don’t buy the economic argument’ or ‘I do buy it’. It is of great importance for all our citizens and businesses alike. So, as I said earlier, the aim is to ensure that any and all remaining obstacles are removed by the end of the year at the latest, and I sincerely hope that we will collectively succeed soon.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. – The full functioning of the Schengen area is something that I believe is fundamental to the European project and I regret its partial suspension, as it is one of the most negative consequences of the refugee crisis we are facing. The behaviour of some Member States which violate the spirit underlying our union must be highlighted negatively. There are governments in Europe that promote an ultra-nationalist and xenophobic discourse of exclusion, with very negative consequences, such as the aforementioned suspension of the Schengen area. One of the pillars of the European project is the principle of free movement and, before an analysis of the negative economic impact of these measures, it is important to conclude that the European project is being called into question by these attitudes. I hope that the European Commission will continue its efforts to draw the attention of the Member States to remain faithful to the European spirit.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I support the resolution. Although I welcome the possibility of temporary border controls within the framework of the legislation, these measures must only be temporary. Schengen is the heart of the EU, the cornerstone of the free movement of goods, services and people. But Schengen stands for much more than being able to cross a border without control. Schengen is a symbol of the european Union's growing together. We must not give up this symbol lightly. We must protect our external borders effectively and we must not shake schengen!

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. Overcoming the Schengen system could have very serious repercussions in the transport and tourism sector and could jeopardise the survival of the internal market, at an estimated cost of between EUR 5 billion and EUR 18 billion per year for the European economy. These huge costs in economic terms would be the invaluable political costs, the consequences of which could be much more lasting and costly. That is why we have a duty to save Schengen, not only to guarantee our citizens and workers their right to free movement and movement, but above all in the name of the far-sighted political project of European integration, as the founding fathers of the Union had imagined. In order to achieve this objective, I hope that the timetable laid down in the Commission's roadmap for a return to normal operation of the Schengen area, which provides for the elimination of all internal border controls by the end of this year, to modify the European asylum system and to strengthen the control of the external borders, will be strictly respected. I hope that much faster progress will be made by the Member States in implementing the Commission's Roadmap, before it is too late to safeguard one of the main achievements of the European Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - The space of free movement of the so-called Schengen between European countries is the highest value of European unity. That is why this system needs to preserve and create effective control at the external borders of the European Union. It is essential to establish full cooperation between all Member States on all matters that threaten the functioning of the Schengen area. The loss of freedom of movement of people and goods in the Schengen area is unacceptable and therefore all necessary efforts should be made to restore a normal regime between Member States by the end of the year.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The establishment of the Schengen system has brought a new breath to European freedoms, taking a huge step towards the creation of a true single market. By eliminating customs controls, interminable queues at the borders between states have been lost and time and prosperity have been gained for citizens. However, amid the current migration crisis, some states have decided to close their borders in the hope that this will protect them from the wave of refugees. This is a wrong measure, devoid of vision and against everything that the European Union stands for. On a problem of this magnitude we need a European solution, not a patchwork of divergent reactions. That is why I believe that a strong Schengen area can be part of the solution we are looking for and in no way the source of the problems. An effective Schengen must include all Member States, including Romania and Bulgaria, which have already shown that they meet all the required criteria. Beyond the fact that their acceptance would signal that all states are equal to each other, we could finally focus on strengthening European borders. We must therefore prove that we are united inside, but also that we can protect ourselves from the problems that come from beyond the EU's borders.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me start by saying that I consider this debate as a truly useful opportunity to hear the views of this House on the issue. From the outset I must however underline that my own comments will be preliminary. The Council has just started examining the report presented by the Commission; in other words there is no Council position yet.  First of all I would like to stress that visa liberalisation for Turkey is a long-standing commitment. It was decided to start this process back in 2011. The roadmap was adopted already in 2013 and what did the EU-Turkey statement do on 18 March? It accelerated the existing process. Secondly, I would like to stress that visa freedom for Turkey is something that benefits, at the very end, all parties concerned. Not only can Turkish citizens travel to Europe more easily, but the millions of Europeans visiting Turkey for holidays or business, for example, can also do so more easily. It will facilitate people-to-people contact. It was, I believe, one of your MEPs, Judith Sargentini – I do not know whether she is in the Chamber today – who said it is also about the Turkish human rights defenders who will be able to travel to Europe freely to tell their story. In other words this is not just a present for President Erdoğan, neither should it be seen as just a concession by Europe to Turkey. It is something from which we all, at the very end, benefit. Now in the Commission’s third report it is concluded that Turkey has achieved remarkable progress. However it also becomes abundantly clear that Turkey has not yet managed to fulfil all 72 benchmarks. Seven benchmarks remain unfulfilled. Regarding two of these seven outstanding requirements, the Commission has noted that for practical and procedural reasons, Turkey needs a longer timeline for implementation.  With regard to the biometric passports, the practical solution consists of limiting visa freedom to the holders of the latest generation of biometric passports. When it comes to Turkey’s obligation to build up a track record under the EU-Turkey Readmission Agreement, we simply need a bit more time as this agreement only becomes effective next month. For the other five requirements, the Commission has invited the Turkish authorities to undertake urgently the measures that are necessary to fulfil these benchmarks. In other words, Turkey has a lot of homework to do and I also, from this chair, urge the Turkish Government to intensify its efforts. Now as you know, we have, besides Turkey, visa freedom proposals also on the table for Georgia, Ukraine and Kosovo. At the same time the Commission has presented a proposal to amend Regulation 539 with a view to revising the current suspension mechanism.  The main objective is to strengthen this mechanism by making it easier for Member States to notify circumstances leading to a possible suspension, and by enabling the Commission to trigger the mechanism on its own initiative, and yes, at a time when we are considering granting visa liberalisation to a 130 million citizens, it is only natural to look again at the current suspension mechanism.  The Commission’s proposal responds to a broadly-felt need in the Council to have a more effective mechanism and we are grateful to the Commission for this proposal. It will undoubtedly facilitate decision-making. It is now up to us, Parliament and the Council, as co-legislators, to start working on the different proposals and as I said work in the Council has started. The Council’s Visa Working Party met this morning and if one thing becomes clear from the initial discussions, it is that this is by no means an easy decision.  What also came out of the discussions is the firm determination of all Member States to stick to a merit-based approach. We will not take a decision based on political expediency. Turkey needs to fulfil the benchmarks and I do trust that this House shares that conviction. There is broad consensus within Council to advance quickly on the revision of the suspension and monitoring mechanism with the aim of agreeing a position at the Justice and Home Affairs Council of 20 May. That is the good news. In closing, the Presidency will take the necessary measures to make sure that all proposals are discussed in a timely manner in the Council and that talks with Parliament are started as soon as you are in a position to do so.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on 4 May the Commission presented its third report on Turkey’s progress in fulfilling the requirements of its visa liberalisation roadmap dating from 2013, in parallel to comply with the strict timeframe set by the EU Member States Heads of State and Government and on the understanding that the Turkish authorities will take the necessary measures to fulfil all the outstanding benchmarks. On 4 May the Commission also presented a proposal to transfer Turkey to the list of visa-free countries. The Commission’s proposal opens the way for the European Parliament and the Member States to decide to lift Turkish citizens’ visa requirements once the benchmarks have been met. It also gives – and it is equally important – adequate time for consulting the national parliaments on this issue. Let me underline that in the last months, the Turkish authorities have made really substantial progress in fulfilling the visa liberalisation roadmap, with a further acceleration since the 18 March EU-Turkey Summit. As a result of this, for example, they are now fully cooperating with Greece on readmission. We see a clear reduction of the number of irregular arrivals in Greece from 6 000 a day in October 2015 to around 140 with a continuing downward trend. We also have to commend Turkey for hosting around 2.7 million Syrian refugees and more than 200 000 non-Syrian asylum seekers and refugees, granting to all of them free access to healthcare and education, and now also to legal employment. Meanwhile, they are also improving the asylum procedures. They have ratified all international conventions and protocols and judicial cooperation indicated by the visa liberalisation roadmap, and as requested by the roadmap they have also adopted several pieces of legislation, for instance on trafficking in human beings and on judicial cooperation and on equality and anti-discrimination, and action plans on social inclusion of citizens with a Roma background, on corruption , in the fight against drugs trafficking, in the fight against organised crime which they are starting to implement. But let me be clear as well that there is still progress to be made. This implies for Turkey to take the following steps: to adopt measures to fight against corruption in line with the recommendations of the Council of Europe; to align its legislation on personal data protection with EU standards; to conclude an operational cooperation agreement with Europol; to offer effective judicial cooperation in criminal matters to all Member States; and last but not least, the need to better align with the European standards its legislation and practices on terrorism. In the EU-Turkey statement of 18 March, the Turkish authorities expressed their determination to fulfil all benchmarks of the visa liberalisation roadmap by June. I am confident they remain committed to implement all aspects of that statement. In any case, the Commission will continue to monitor closely the fulfilling of these benchmarks, and naturally I and my services will ensure that you are regularly updated. We have to remain optimistic that the Turkish authorities will give that final push before the end of June. I want to be clear: this agreement is beneficial for both sides. We are not watering down our standards in order to provide visa-free, but we are doing everything we can to provide support and expertise to the Turkish authorities to accelerate what are also quite important reforms in their own right. What is also important in their path towards the European Union? The implementation of visa reforms will not only contribute to the internal welfare of Turkey but will also help the EU and Turkey to develop effective cooperation within the framework of the global strategy that we are building with this key neighbour. We are confronted with the same challenges. Cooperation is necessary. I will give an example. Only yesterday Turkey was hit by another terrorist attack. I take this opportunity to express my thoughts for those injured, and my indignation. Terrorism must be condemned in every form and everywhere. And we know how sensitive the issue of terrorism is for Turkey. But this proves how beneficial the close cooperation with Europol is for both sides. For this to be achieved, Turkey needs to further align its data protection standards to the European ones. Not just because this is required by the roadmap, but because the reforms required by the roadmap are the basis for an even stronger cooperation on both security and migration, with sensitive data exchanges that need adequate protection. It is true that Turkey is considering this cooperation as a catalyst, I would say, to reenergise our relations as well as its European perspective. Indeed, it is an opportunity for Turkey to come closer to the European standards on all issues. The fulfilment of the visa liberalisation roadmap is an important step towards this direction. I would now like to mention another element of the package, adopted on 4 March. The Commission also proposed to revise the existing suspension mechanism of the visa-free regime. I want to be very clear on this. The suspension mechanism is not about Turkey. It is a horizontal provision which will apply to all visa-free countries and not only Turkey. I hope that the co-legislators will look favourably at this proposal, although it should not delay the deliberations and the adoption of the visa liberalisation proposal.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, we have heard clearly – important and accelerated steps have been identified on the progress of the visa liberalisation roadmap with Turkey.  We support the agreement between the European Union and Turkey, but we also have a very clear position on visa liberalisation. In this context, I draw attention to three aspects: First, support for visa liberalisation with Turkey can only be given if all the criteria are met. It is the Commission's responsibility to formally confirm that all the requirements have been met by Turkey and not to have only a time frame in which we expect this to be done. The implementation of all indicators will ensure the reliability of the process. In one sentence: in the European Parliament, we cannot vote on such liberalisation until the criteria are met and before the Council has given its consent.  Secondly, I welcome the Commission for linking visa liberalisation to the implementation and proper implementation of the Agreement between the European Union and Turkey. This means a steady small number of migrants coming from Turkey and effective readmission.  Thirdly, I congratulate the Commission on the proposal to revise and optimise the safeguard mechanism for visa waiver. Our efforts must be aimed at creating an efficient, including emergency brake. The mechanism should also be introduced in parallel with the possible adoption of the visa liberalisation decision and not there after.  Finally, relations between the European Union and Turkey are at a key stage. A clear sign of efforts to change legislation where necessary is needed to meet the criteria and effectively and sustainably implement what has already been adopted. Sustainability and dialogue are key to our partnership with Turkey.  Finally, I believe in our constructive role as a European Parliament, in which as co-legislator we will take the necessary time to analyse all the details thoroughly and thus make our decision.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group.  I could be sure of how very tangible the measure is, how it has a strong, direct and two-way impact on political and social dynamics. That is why I have considerable reservations in supporting the visa waiver for Turkey at the moment.  Whatever conditions, whether economic or political, which we place at any time in the European Union, are not intended to develop the imagination of politicians, but are created on the basis of half-century of development of integration and are intended to advance and develop for the common good. The European Union's relationship with Turkey is very important in order to resolve the migrant crisis at the moment, but that does not in itself mean that Turkey is granted benefits without all the conditions being met. Turkey has been placed on visa waivers with 72 measures, which it has so far failed to fully comply with.  This is a simple fact that we cannot and must not overlook. I am concerned that, for example, legislation in the fight against terrorism and data protection are not met – in my opinion very crucial conditions– in the fight against terrorism and data protection. Turkey will have to address this and the remaining unresolved areas very seriously before we are able and willing to initiate the legislative procedure in the committee responsible.  The abolition of visas is a process that requires not only a strong commitment in principle to meet the criteria, but also actual fulfilment. We simply cannot allow exceptions, because this will give rise to a boomerang effect and the effect of a snowball that will end up burying us all.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – From June, the European Commission intends to grant visa-free travel to 80 million Turkish citizens. This is really incomprehensible. The asylum agreement with Turkey clearly states that there will be no special visa conditions for Turkey. The Commission itself recognises that Turkey does not meet all 72 conditions, but wants to push this forward. But Turkey is not fulfilling its part of the agreements. For example, Turkey has still not implemented the requested anti-terror regulations and anti-corruption measures. Especially in these times of terror threat, seizures of critical newspapers and the arbitrary arrests of journalists, these are not futility. It is sufficient to refer to the newspaper Zaman, the German stand-up comedian Jan Böhmermann and the Dutch-Turkish journalist Ebru Umar.  Instead of making sweet buns with Erdogan, the European Commission would rather stress turkey's failing and worsening policy on, among other things, freedom of expression. No two sizes and two weights, please. May I just remind you that the conditions for Turkey need to be filled in extra strictly now that it is a candidate country? As Members of Parliament, we cannot participate in the sale of European values. In fact, there should be no substantive debate here as long as Turkey has not fulfilled all the visa conditions. I feel vicarious shame here about the Commission's submissive attitude towards a dictator.  (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: "blue card" question. A press release from the European Parliament dated 4 May announced that all parliamentary work in committee would be suspended on Turkey until it met the 72 criteria. However, last Monday, in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, we nevertheless worked on Turkey. Do you not think, Mrs Stevens, that this proves that the Commission is determined to give everything to Turkey?

name: Helga STEVENS
text: "blue card" answer. I cannot reply on behalf of the Commission. I can only say what happened in the LIBE committee. There has been criticism. In the LIBE committee, we said that we would only like to continue to talk if Turkey fulfils all the conditions. What the Commission is doing is its business. But first Turkey must meet all the conditions and only then will we talk further.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, firstly let me make very clear that my Group, in principle, is in favor of visa liberalisation for the reasons set out by Minister Hennis. Yet I am unhappy with the debate we are having because, quite frankly, I have great personal respect and appreciation both for Minister Hennis and Commissioner Avramopoulos, and I realise that you have to represent the official view of the Council and the Commission. But we should really be having this debate with the architects of this unsavoury deal with Turkey, where they made a trade-off between the reception of refugees and granting of visa liberalisation. We want to judge Turkey on its merits and not because there has been a sell-out by, amongst other people, Mr Timmermans. The criteria must be fulfilled, and, if I listen to the presentation – also on Monday in LIBE by the Commission, who says: well, we are nearly there, there are just a few little details to be concluded here and there – they are not details: we can all see what is happening in Turkey. So what you are saying, on behalf of your institutions, is simply not reality. Anybody who watches television or reads a newspaper knows that that is not the case. Just today we hear that, through his office’s advisers, Mr Erdoğan makes it known to the European Parliament that, if the European Parliament takes the wrong decision, he will let the refugees travel to Europe.  That is blackmail in my book – and why is Europe open to blackmail? Because we are weak and divided. Why are we weak and divided? Because the national government leaders fail to agree on a common EU refugee policy. That is why they find it easier to make deals with a dictator like Mr Erdoğan than to agree amongst themselves – leaders of EU countries on a proper EU common refugee policy. Now Council, go home and do your homework. Get us the refugee policy; get us the border and coastguard, and do not make us vulnerable to blackmail by people like Erdoğan. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" question. Yes, Madam in 't Veld says here that we should judge Turkey on its actions, but these actions have been perfectly clear for months, if not years. Journalists disappear in prison, refugees are treated badly in the camps, there is now even shooting at refugees. You don't expect Mr. Erdogan to suddenly turn over like a leaf on the tree tomorrow and say, "Oh sorry, I'm going to do better now"? So my question to you is: when will your group pull the plug? Cut out this deal and start working on a plan B!

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: "blue card" answer. – Mr. Van Dalen, for your information, we have strongly criticized this deal. We didn't close it either. That was the Commission and the Member States and also the Dutch Presidency. For me, that deal didn't have to happen. But unplug? Turkey is more than just Mr. Erdogan and his government, and you never slam the door completely. And yes, we want to work with the Turkish people. Yes, we want people to person to person contact and you always look to the future. But it is crystal clear that at the moment, with Mr. Erdogan, we will not achieve visa liberalisation or, indeed, rapprochement in the context of membership.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, I am pleased that we have this debate, being the source of the request. This is a key point of the EU-Turkey agreement, the agreement which we learned on Monday in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs that it was not one of them and therefore would not be subject to the approval of this Parliament. This is a key point for Mr Erdogan, the only real issue for him, as he visibly prepares for a new election campaign to seek, once again, the majority needed to change the country's constitution.  As the European Union is obsessed with migrant issues, Mr Erdogan is holding his tool of blackmail. No matter what happens in Turkey, it does not matter if the Kurds are slaughtered when the United Nations has just drawn our attention to this point, once again. It does not matter that their elected representatives are sent to prison, like all those who dare to denounce these facts and that democracy is increasingly called into question in this country. Worse, next week, Turkey's national assembly is expected to amend its constitution to collectively lift the parliamentary immunity of some 130 deputies. A detail!  And you are telling us that human rights are respected in Turkey. You tell us that the criteria for migrants and refugees are met, including criteria 14, 24 to 28 and 62. You are telling us that there is no violation of the freedom of movement of citizens in Turkey or discrimination in this regard - criterion 57.  I am generally in favour of visa liberalisation agreements but not in any way, not in any condition, not by turning a blind eye to what is happening in Turkey today.  I am therefore waiting for you to tell us, Commissioner, how Turkey meets the various criteria that I have mentioned and which are supposedly respected? These are not details.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam Presidents, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for her excellent work and for her excellent work. The escalation against every opposition in Turkey, against every critic of President Erdogan last week, was truly of new quality. When I observe this, it is becoming increasingly clear to me that President Erdogan is dividing his country ever more deeply. The preparation for waiving the immunity of more than 100 Members of the Turkish Parliament, supported also by the chairman of the opposition GROUP CHP, shows this very clearly. We have seen the shooting of Can Dündar, we have seen the incredibly high penalties against Dündar and Gül, the forced resignation of Davutoglu and, in the end, shots fired at refugees on the border with Syria. That's the incomplete list last week. My group is aware that nothing should be imposed on Turkey. However, we also know that the European Union must not become an actor who simply overlooks these systematic violations of the rule of law. The conditions for visa liberalisation that we are talking about are so important because they affect social development in Turkey for better or worse. And as much as we want freedom of travel, we cannot give freedom of travel in support of President Erdogan's authoritarian path. The events of the last few days, which I have described, are actually an appeal to the European Union to shape its policy on Turkey much more carefully. Turkey, like turkey, is an indispensable partner for us if we are to achieve security and stability in this region beyond Turkey. We have known this for a long time. However, I think in recent days that we are learning that we are making a mistake if we improperly mix up the European refugee strategy and our necessary positive policy towards Turkey, our efforts towards Turkey. We urgently need – and this was long overdue – this deliberate strategy towards Turkey in terms of visa liberalisation negotiations. But the European Union must not rely centrally on Turkey in its refugee strategy. We must shape our refugee strategy independently. Nor must we base the design of our management of the external borders on Turkey. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), a question with a 'blue card'. – With all that is being said today with regard to Turkey, is it possible to continue today to consider Turkey to be a reliable and indispensable partner in the European Union? Here I would remind you that the European Union, a large, structured and powerful Union, cannot be held hostage to any Turkey and be blackmailed and, in fact, tolerate Turkey flattening everyone and everything! And the most basic and important element, which must be made clear here: can we continue to treat Turkey in this way at a time when it does not respect either the institutions, the principles or the agreements of the European Union? And I will challenge you by asking us to mention at least one agreement that Turkey has respected with the European Union, and if you believe that it can also respect the agreement that has to do with the criteria for the release of rapes.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The fulfilment of the criteria of agreements can be discussed in many contexts, but I am of the opinion that we should not be dependent on Turkey in the design of our policy. On the contrary, I strongly believe that, in the refugee crisis, together with the United Nations Refugee Agency, we must take direct responsibility for the refugees from Turkey.  Generous resettlement quotas are the better answer than the deals we've done so far. And, precisely because you are from Greece, a management, a European management of the external borders beyond the eternal sovereignty debates, would help us much more than the dispute that will lead to this with Erdogan. But – and I remain so – we need good relations, functioning relations with Turkey. Turkey is not just President Erdogan. Many people in Turkey are pinning their hopes on the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the EU-Turkey agreement/non-agreement is illegal, and we all know that. Today we are talking about visa liberalisation, and now I am going to tell you what you would like to do: you would like to water down the 72 requirements for blanding Erdoğan, to conceal the glaring failure of quota distribution. You want to hide our European dust under a Turkish carpet. You would like a hypocritical and hasty yes, and I am sorry for the Turkish people, who are mine and our friend and have done a great deal for the Syrian refugees. But the truth is that these rulers, who criminalise press freedom and social media, who close their eyes to the borders while the jihadists do the dirty work against Assad, who with the anti-terrorism law (untouchable, for Erdoğan) persecute the Kurds and political opponents, no, are not and can never be our friends. That is why I am now telling you what we would like to do: we would like to reject the blackmail of those who use despair as a weapon, of those in Syria who are part of the problem and not of the solution; to impose severe sanctions, including the suspension of all European funds on those countries that care about solidarity and would gladly reduce Greece and Italy to two refugee camps. And yes, those 6 billion tip to Erdoğan would give them to Greece to help it rise again after the bloodletting suffered in the name of your austerity. And yet even today you are presenting us parliamentarians with a complete fact, powerless spectators of an illegal and immoral democracy. This agreement must be challenged before the Court of Justice. Parliament must vote on our legitimate request, Mr President! Have the courage to put your face on it, you can't keep lying to us saying everything's under control. Because if there's a check, it's definitely not ours.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are living in a time of confession. Once is not customary, I wanted to thank Mr Schulz for recognising that the European dream was turning short. "Europe is a promise, but a promise that has not been kept," he said a week ago. He's right. Many Europeans believed in good faith in the dream of the European Union that had been skilfully sold to them. Today, this project has become the nightmare of the European peoples. Today we have another example of this with this bad agreement with Turkey, which you are imposing on the peoples of Europe in the wake of President Erdogan's coup. The latter exerts a real migratory diktat through a terrible blackmail where, in exchange for illusory protection against the migratory surge, Turkey demands 6 billion euros. With this blackmail, Mr Erdogan has also secured from you the relaunch of Turkey's accession negotiations to the European Union. It now orders you to grant its nationals free access to the territory of our nations, with the abolition of short-stay visas. Who knows if, tomorrow, it will not be tens of millions of Turks from Turkey, but also Turks from the Caucasus and Central Asia, who, thanks to the Turkish passport which can be granted to them, will be entitled to a one-way ticket to Europe. You disarm the states and peoples of Europe by going so far as to demand their financial participation in the migration submersion through this delusional european Commission project of a fine of 250,000 euros per rejected migrant. You have decreed the lands of our peoples "land open to mass immigration and Turkish influence". President Erdogan is just playing with the cards you left him. He intends to dominate the region through a policy of destabilization in Syria, he intends to make Europe give way with the weapon of migration and, as in any racketeering, he promises to protect you from the threat he himself has created. Today, you pretend to fight on some convergence criteria, they are just smoke screens to mask your rout. We patriots intend to defend our nations offered by your betrayals to migratory submersion. You wished to submit to us, you will have to resign one day. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I understood that you spoke out massively against the EU-Turkey agreement: that is wrong, it should not have been done. I now interpret this as saying that you believe that the mass influx of refugees into the EU should have been allowed to continue. Or what other solution would you have proposed? I see no other interpretation of your speech at all. Do you not think that this cooperation with Turkey has, of course, been needed – no matter where we are now, what we are now debating – in order to slow down the mass influx and steer it in order?

name: Marine LE PEN
text: "blue card" answer. Madam, you consider that we need Turkey to solve a problem that you have created, which is the removal of the internal borders of the European Union, the abolition of national borders. If we had national borders, we could put in place policies to protect our peoples precisely from this migratory submersion.  Therefore, you create a problem by removing national borders and then subject the peoples of the Union to a shameful agreement with someone who is blackmailing us. I would like to point out that it was an agreement that was reached, not by the Commission or even, of course, by the European Parliament, but, in fact, by Mrs Merkel, who had absolutely no mandate, in this case, to negotiate it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, in a recent speech I referred to Turkey, wanting to draw your attention to a single fact: Turkey has not respected, and will never respect, any international agreement. I was accused of racism and aggressive behavior. I was sanctioned by Schulz because I was against Davutoğlu, the leader of a neighbouring and acceding state in the Union, and against the Turkish nation and his religion. So I ask, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Schulz, where is Davutoğlu now? Your other privileged interlocutor Erdogan deposed him by authoritarian procedures. Who are the Turks and how do they treat their neighbours? Ask the millions of massacred Greeks, Armenians, Kurds, Syrians and, above all, Greek-Cypriots who since 1974 half their homeland has been illegally occupied by Turkey with the tolerance of the Union. How do Sunni Turks behave in other religions? The closed Theological School of Halki, the persecuted Shiites, Alevites and Christians give the answer. Do we want Turkey in the Union? Are we sure we want the Turks to move freely within the Schengen zone? No, I don't. Like many of you. I say it openly. You do it, too. Schulz cannot expel the whole Parliament!

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you very much. Normally I am obviously available for all debates, but I will have to leave a bit earlier, so I would like to make just a few remarks in response to the contributions. Firstly, I heard a number of negative comments about the EU-Turkey statement of March 18.
