I understand, and I am the first one to admit that this agreement is by no means perfect, but let us also remind ourselves of the positive effects that this agreement has yielded so far. The vast and uncontrollable flows of irregular migration across the Eastern Mediterranean have been brought to a halt. The tragic loss of life has dramatically reduced. We have started an orderly process of resettlement and readmission. We are not there yet, but we have started it. The smugglers have been increasingly put out of business. We are regaining control over our eastern borders, so it might not be a perfect agreement, I agree, but it was and is the very first effective response to the migration crisis. Secondly, let us not forget that the use of biometric passports by Turkey will allow us to better control who enters the EU. It will contribute to our safety. The UNHCR has obtained better access to refugee facilities in Turkey. Refugees have obtained the right to work in Turkey and have gained better access to Turkish social facilities such as schooling and health care. These are just a few examples. But what I would like to underline is let us not lose sight of also the positive developments. Thirdly, a lot has been said today about the human rights situation in Turkey, and I agree with everybody in this House who says that the situation is far from perfect. I also worry about the freedom of speech in Turkey – and let me stress every human rights violation is one too many – so we will need to continue to engage with Turkey on human rights issues, because only through engagement will we be able to achieve improvements. At the same time, I would like to remind you that Turkey is hosting around 3 million refugees, so the efforts of the Turkish Government to provide a safe shelter for all these people fleeing war and conflict is impressive at the very end, and Turkey deserves our support in coping with this enormous challenge. Finally, as I said before, it is difficult for me to communicate at this stage a Council position, since our work has just begun but, as I said at the beginning, it was important for me to hear your views and your concerns. Let me stress once more that visa freedom can only take place once the Commission has reported that it is satisfied with the efforts of Turkey to meet the required benchmarks. So in response to many of you, let me be clear: we will judge Turkey on its merits.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: – We are watching with great concern the developments surrounding the Turkey deal. The point of contact for Europe in Ankara, Prime Minister Davutoglu, has been pushed aside. President Erdogan criticizes Europe every day, he refuses to revise anti-terror legislation and his advisers are now threatening to send refugees to Europe. A low point has been reached and we cannot afford to remain dependent on the whims of the Turkish President. Europe must be able to control its own borders and control the flow of refugees. This requires a European plan and that plan, which is apparently being worked on. Can the Commission confirm this?  In the meantime, we must remain very clear: 72 conditions are 72 conditions, period. I would also like to ask Minister Hennis to ensure here that this item will not be placed on the Council's agenda until all those 72 conditions are met. This is not just about anti-terror legislation. We have seen examples of criminals convicted in European countries who sit in their swimming trunks on a Turkish beach and are not extradited (condition 47). We have seen examples of refugees being shot at, while the Commission claims that Turkey complies with international refugee law (condition 14). The Commission would like a response from the Commission on these two points.  And, last but not least, how is the European Commission going to ensure that the reforms that Turkey is implementing are more than a paper reality and are actually being implemented in practice? Would it not be very wise to also ask for an external review of, for example, the Venice Commission on this point?

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, the time when Turkish people feel least European is when they wait in line for a visa. This statement was made by a former Turkish EU Minister some years ago, and I believe it is still valid today. The lengthy and bureaucratic procedure to obtain a visa is of great nuisance for Turkish citizens who want to travel to the EU for business, studies or simply for enjoying their holidays. It is therefore good that the EU and Turkey started negotiations two years ago in order to lift this visa requirement. As part of the EU—Turkey deal on refugees, it was agreed that the EU is willing to accelerate that process if and when Turkey meets all 72 criteria. But while accelerating that process was part of the deal, lowering our standards certainly was not. Let us be honest: Turkey over the last few months has come much closer to meeting the set of technical standards than any of us would have thought possible, but the Commission has also made it clear that there are still five criteria where Turkey does not fulfil the benchmarks. Among these are the fight against corruption, an independent data protection authority and, most importantly, Turkey’s very broadly defined anti-terror legislation – the same anti-terror legislation which has been criticised for many years by us here in Parliament, not because Turkey does not have the right to fight against Islamic State, PKK or other terrorist groups, but because this law is used to jail journalists and silence academics. Labelling all voices of dissent as terrorists is what makes this law unacceptable. Just like the current attempt to lift the immunity of 129 Members of Parliament, including almost the entire HDP parliamentary faction, this will certainly not bring Turkey closer to European standards nor bring it closer to restarting their much needed peace process. We must not undermine our own values by being lenient and give Turkey a free ride on some crucial benchmarks that still need to be fulfilled, just for the sake of keeping an EU—Turkey deal alive.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – We can discuss visa liberalisation with a country that has a fair relationship with us, I think where law and law are respected, where there are no security risks. My question is: why are we even opening up this visa liberalisation for Turkey? Does Turkey respect fundamental rights? Not. They imprison journalists, confiscate churches and impose Islam on other religious minorities. Do they have an orderly border with the EU? Not. They face the biggest immigrant wave, where real refugees mix with illegal and economic migrants who cross the border uncontrollably at the risk of drowning or being abused by smugglers. Have they met all our criteria? Not! The real reason for liberalisation is that the billions spent on refugee camps in Turkey may be threatened by inhumane blackmail by the Turkish Government in the form of a new wave of migrants. This is an unacceptable dictatorship on the part of the country applying for EU membership. The above requirements must be met. The visa requirement cannot be the subject of trade. This is about our future security and the protection of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Mr President, when you read the progress report on Turkey, you can get the impression that all is well. Has the Commission missed completely the fact that the repression of basically everyone opposing Erdoğan’s totalitarian regime has increased dramatically? On fundamental rights, the Commission concludes (in what I would like to label as the understatement of this century): “further progress is needed on some outstanding requirements”. On migration management, the report does not contain one single hint about inconvenient facts such as the shooting to death of refugees at the borders. Once Turkey fulfils the conditions that apply to every other country, they should obtain visa-free status. In other words: when the fundamental rights are granted and all the academics, journalists, authors and everyone else that has used the right to freedom of speech are released from prison and everybody freely can also practise free speech in the streets and cities of Turkey. Clearly we are not there any more. The Commission is clear: Turkey does not fulfil all the 72 criteria. Erdoğan is equally clear when he is stating that Turkey does not intend to fulfil the criteria, especially those relating to terrorism legislation. This is the problem, and we should not engage in this completely immoral agreement, or statement, or trade-off or whatever it is called. Something is rotten in this as long as we continue.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, perhaps contrary to the view that many here may have, I believe that Mr Erdogan will change the law on terrorism, but will change it when this law exhausts its purpose. When, using this law, he will expel Kurdish MPs from parliament in order to change the Constitution and get the power he needs. And he's going to change the law when this law exhausts his purpose and when he throws in the prisons those he still hasn't been able to put in place. We are in favour of the 72 criteria being implemented, but we will not turn a blind start. I do not believe that any of these criteria can, under any circumstances, be implemented for Cyprus without solving the Cyprus problem. Without differentiating GUE from our position on the readmission agreement, we would like to know if there are any assurances that Turkey will also implement this agreement with Cyprus. I conclude by saying that we differentiate our attitude towards Turkish politics from our attitude towards Turkish citizens! The rights of Turkish citizens are what we defend!

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr As a Green Member, I am always in principle in favour of facilitating freedom of movement across borders. I want to see a world where everyone can legally enter and exit a country and with as few obstacles as possible. And that regardless of whether there are biometric passports and return agreements in place. But the problem That I have with the visa facilitation for Turkey today, it is that they are linked to what I see as an extremely dirty game about people fleeing, among other things, the Syria of war. Turkey is also a country that is becoming increasingly authoritarian, that is shooting at refugees, imprisoning journalists under terrorist laws, where corruption is rampant high in the dwellings of power, and where a war is taking place with the Kurds. There is a road map with 72 criteria to meet. A few of them have not been met, two of them not at all: number 42 on corruption and number 65 on terrorism. The last thing, Erdoğan has expressly said that he does not intend to comply. It is a very remarkable statement by a man who has entered into an agreement with us, knowing that all the criteria will be met. For me, it is difficult to give Erdoğan such a victory as visa facilitation means, unless the terrorism criterion is also met, and it is far from being met and will be difficult to meet. But on the day That I vote 'yes' to visa facilitation for Turkey, it will be for the sake of turkish citizens, and not to give Erdoğan some feathers in his hat. It will be for all the journalists, but also the Kurds, who may need to flee Turkey in a future. Thanks!

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: – Mr President, in its desperation to put in place at least one measure to tackle the ever-deepening migrant crisis, the European Commission is willing to stoop to any depths. Instead of scrapping the Schengen Agreement, reinstating proper border controls and putting in place measures to sort true asylum seekers from economic migrants, the Commission is instead bowing to Turkey’s demands for admission to the EU. This is despite the Erdoğan regime being accused of a catalogue of human rights abuses: air strikes against Kurds fighting Daesh, a clampdown on the freedom of the press, and a highly controversial anti-terror policy. But any EU opposition to these totalitarian measures has crumbled in its haste to ease the migrant crisis while still maintaining Schengen, despite these terrible acts being directly opposed to its own principles. The fact is, President Erdoğan has realised he is now in a position to hold the entire block to ransom and make demands of the EU that even two years ago would have been unthinkable. And to understand just what a stranglehold Erdoğan has achieved, consider his ‘we’re going our way, you go yours’ outburst in rejecting EU demands for changes to Turkey’s anti-terror laws. This is a law that is more often than not used on opponents of Erdoğan’s regime, yet it is a law that the Commission has chosen to give way on as it pushes ahead with giving Turkey visa-free EU travel as a reward for their cooperation. This once again demonstrates how the EU’s principles have the same attributes as toilet tissue: strong to start with, but simply dissolves when the right conditions are met. It seems to me that, as long as the EU gets to keep its core principles of free movement, they do not care how many other principles are cast aside.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the watered-down version that we heard at the beginning of this debate by Commissioner Avramopoulos contrasts, unfortunately for him and for the intelligence of those who have listened to him, with the reality that has emerged from almost all the speeches, which is the reality of a police state, which imprisons journalists, who are even persecuting abroad, in European countries. , the authors of political satire – to tell the truth this, on some occasions, also takes place in our territory. But it is a very serious matter: it is a police state in the hands of an autocrat who is still blackmailing Europe at this time, while we are debating the issue of visas. So I say: a jolt of dignity on the part of this European Union, which is being blackmailed by a tipaccio like Erdoğan. To deal with these delicate things would be like getting on the table with a declared baro, a professional specialized in the subject.  Contrary to what we would have us believe, this is not a formal issue, it is a substantive issue, it is a turning point of a historical and political nature, in the face of which, from a historical and political point of view, a total revirement of Europe's position is required, which makes us ashamed in the face of schuman's memory and paintings. , by De Gasperi, by Franz Josef Strauss. The German lords in charge in this Europe have forgotten their founding fathers, who are certainly turning their graves to the idea of this sell-off of Europe, of the founding principles of this Europe, which you are betraying in order to hand over the poor immigrants in these hands.  I would remind you how many times in the last parliamentary term the LIBE Committee went to check how we Italians kept poor migrants in reception centres in Lampedusa. But why is It that Europe, which wants to make Turkey welcome others, does not go to check how turkey is guarding asylum seekers and immigrants? Entrusting them to these is an act of hypocrisy in comparison to which even Trump would seem Mother Teresa of Calcutta. It's a disgrace! It's a disgrace!

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, it is important to remember that the debate on visa liberalisation for Turks predates the beginning of this migration crisis. Therefore, I understand that some of our colleagues, especially extremists, want to erase this and use the issue of migrants against Turks who, on the other hand, welcome migrants very well, better than some European countries. They are also cooperating very well with Europe to reduce the flow of these migrants to Greece. It's a factual truth.  The fact that the Turks have put the issue of liberalisation back on the agenda does not erase the fact that we have always asked them to meet 72 criteria. Five of these criteria are not met, and of course we have to wait until they are met to really work on this issue. I draw your attention to the fact that, for example, Georgia, concerned with this same debate on visa liberalisation, has met all the criteria. Therefore, we must be fair and not put this theme in the mouths of extremists. This never solves a problem.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which The Commission did the right thing when it sat down with Turkey and negotiated this deal, whatever we want to call it. The premise was that a number of Member States had refused to share the burdens that have come to us.  And now I say something to you, dear colleague from the Nea Dimokratia: I find it a bit tragicomic that you, of all people, are swearing so much here. If this Commission had not acted, your beautiful country would be a single refugee camp with an acropolis in the middle, and I think we are grateful to you for acting for Greece. Secondly, I have nothing against visa-free travel. I am happy for my Turkish friends in Hamburg that their families will finally be able to visit them soon – hopefully soon – without a huge amount of bureaucracy. But it is also true that we have said that only if the 72 conditions are met. No one of us, the Commission, the Council, of here, says that they no longer need to be met – that is why we now have the problem. And in this respect, there is nothing here with blackmail: either they fulfill it, or they do not. And, of course, the Turkish Government has the right and the duty to protect itself against terrorists.  That they have the right and the duty to stand up to those who are also clear and, if they are to, militarily with police means that threaten their people. But to put a lot of journalists in prison, to waive the immunity of Members and to shell entire neighbourhoods with artillery, because there are some fighters in there, for me this is not a fight against terrorism – this is war against a part of our own people, and we have to take that into account. That is why we need to talk about it, and I am glad that the Turkish Minister for Europe is here. And if all this doesn't work out, then this deal won't happen and then you get the visit you seem to want so much. (The speaker refused to answer a question about the procedure for Mr Epitideios' 'blue card')

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Werner Faymann resigned at the weekend. It became known that he was present shortly before at a high-level meeting of the Social Democrats in Stockholm, which was probably also about his future. He is said to be a candidate for the post of EU Council President in place of Donald Tusk. If he were to do this work, the S&D would have to relinquish the office of President of Parliament. Do you think that Mr Schulz will succeed Mr Sigmar Gabriel in Germany? Is this to be understood in his criticism of the disgraceful Turkey trade of Angela Merkel, who has so far been supported by the SPD? Does he really want to do something for the people of Germany and Europe? He is probably beginning to realise what an imminent visa-free regime would mean for Turkish citizens, for the EU and for potential German voters.  After all, Mr Juncker has clearly indicated that he does not want to take all 72 points so precisely. Trade with Erdogan is likely to fail, which is good news. Relations with Turkey have been unnecessarily damaged. What both Angela Merkel and Jean-Claude Juncker are responsible for.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to President Erdogan wags the yellow card and whistles for commitments and criteria for visa liberalisation, especially on data protection and the rule of law against anti-terrorism legislation.  But no one in the EU should exploit the legitimate needs of the Turkish people to be part of a cosmopolitan Europe, or squeeze them into a indulgence trade at the expense of refugees, Kurds, political opposition and freedom of the press.  Those who still believe that the EU-Turkey deal is putting a stop to smugglers have hidden the causes of flight and real movements of refugees and abandoned a common EU refugee policy. At the moment, Parliament must not agree to visa liberalisation outside the criteria, but it should also call on the Council and the Commission to finally tackle a common eu-wide refugee policy. It is implausible, on the one hand, to praise the EU's values in ceremonial speeches and, on the other, to rip them off and sacrifice them in everyday political life. Listen to Amnesty International and other organisations that provide us with the bitter facts on a daily basis.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, Turkish citizens must see their right to travel, study and work for and in the European Union recognised. We've owed him for years. Welcome the progress they explain to us, but we are no less attentive to the flagrant contradictions we continue to observe on a daily basis. The facts, apart from the famous seventy-two criteria, are clear. The anti-terrorism law draws an inadmissible environment, and the D'ndar and Gul cases are just terrible evidence. Data protection law departs ostensibly from our standards. The lifting of parliamentary immunity to 25% of Turkish Members is more than just an indicator of democratic alertness and Turkish behaviour on the Syrian border is entirely condemnable. Do you know the Human Rights Watch report on these actions? It doesn't look like it. Or do you consider it a good example of external border control?  Therefore: release of visas by Turkish citizens, yes; under these conditions, no. We will say 'yes' to Turkey and its citizens, say 'no' to impositions and threats like the ones we have recorded today about the mass sending of refugees to Europe. This Parliament, this is certain, will vote against any agreement which does not meet these criteria, which we are expressing here today, or which is still accompanied by the facts we are denouncing today.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: – For Brussels, an asylum invasion alone is not enough, because with visa-free travel for 80 million Turks, the European Union will soon also be invading turkish. In the Netherlands alone, 400 000 Turks will soon be able to invite neighbours, cousins, nieces, brothers and acquaintances to come to our country and stay there. Because more and more illegal immigrants come from countries that no longer have a visa requirement.  We must protect Western culture, democracy and freedom. Turkey is not part of the EU. Turkey has no say in democracy, freedom of expression and gender equality. And Erdogan shows that to us every day. We must never bow to Islam. We must not bow to an Islamic dictator and it is a disgrace that you are still doing business with dictator Erdogan. That's why today the Turkey deal has to be off the table, visa-free travel in the trash. And let the Turks know that they can never, ever, become a member of the European Union.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to remind you that in 2013 Turkey only wanted to sign the Readmission Agreement if there was also visa liberalisation for it, for scientists, students and businessmen. Even then, it was a kind of blackmail, but it was about visa liberalisation for these groups of people and not about visa exemption. That is why what Minister Hennis-Plasschaert said at the beginning is not right that this is really just an acceleration of the process. We are now talking about visa exemption under the EU-Turkey agreement. But now, once again, Erdogan is defiant and even trying to put pressure on the European Parliament. But we will not be put under pressure. We were actually only amused by this when, a few years ago, Erdogan even called for this 'irrelevant European Parliament' to be abolished. We know the Turkish President's understanding of democracy. At the end of the day, Erdogan wants to prevent – and we all know this – that he must change his anti-terrorism law. He still needs this in order to destroy the opposition in parliament, to push it out and then hold new elections or by-elections, so that he can finally have his constitutional majority and finally legitimise what he is doing now, which is to govern the country alone with a hard hand.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: – Mr President, the decision on visa liberalisation for Turkish citizens is under pressure. Under pressure because Turkey trades visas with its obligation to accept refugees back into its territory from Greece. Only 396 have returned refugees since the European Union-Turkey agreement was in force. This is what the Council calls a good result, and I call it too bad an outcome.  The Commission cannot convince us that all 72 visa waiver criteria are met because this is simply not true. If the Commission is convinced that it offers a good asylum policy and credible solutions for guarding the external borders, why should this fire decision be taken? It is unacceptable, Commissioner, not to ask national parliaments.  There are no serious guarantees about the credibility of passports, the risks of forgery and trade in personal documents. We are not convinced of the intentions of the Turkish services to cooperate with Europol to submit information in European databases, nor in changing anti-terrorism laws.  The decision on visas is not only technical. We lack political analysis of its consequences, mainly related to border security, to citizens. We are not ready to accept a new great wave of economic migration from Turkey, let alone the many who will seek political asylum.  In Bulgaria, Commissioner, we have a wonderful proverb. I think it's extremely relevant to today's situation.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, I have read in the online weekly EUobserver, usually well-informed, the opinion of the European Parliament's legal expert, who says that this agreement with Turkey is not really an agreement, that it is not legally binding, that it is not legally enforceable and that it is just a political declaration. So I'm asking, where did we find ourselves? So has the European Commission and the European Council hired Turkey to do their dirty work on a good word, promised them something they do not want and cannot deliver on, and now we are actually in a situation from which we do not know how to get out? I guess so, i guess that's the case. But I think that's unacceptable. The situation here is that the European Union is unable and unwilling to protect its external borders, it is unable and unwilling to act hard against illegal migrants, and the Member States are unable and unwilling to modify their social systems that encourage migrants to come to Europe. Before that, no outsourcing of this problem towards Turkey will save us, this situation is unsustainable in the long run.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Mr President, it is impossible to detach this issue from the agreement with Turkey, because this is not a logical step in negotiations with a candidate country. The context is another: in exchange for you closing the door, I give you six billion and I withdraw the obligation to withdraw a visa. The latter could be legitimate and even desirable for everyone to travel more freely, but the above, the agreement, is illegitimate, deeply unfair and unacceptable.  Commissioner, in the last year I have travelled three times to the Turkish State — last time, seven days ago — and, after hearing his words, I conclude with surprised that we went to two different worlds in terms of managing and welcoming migrants and refugees, public policy and security and fundamental rights. My colleagues in the GUE/NGL Group have explained this perfectly. And from what I can see, he didn't get to the southeast either, where a town, the Kurdish, is being massacred.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: PPE). Mr President, there is good news. The European Union-Turkey agreement brought the first positive results. Migration flows have been reduced to a minimum. But the European Union has found itself unprepared to welcome one million refugees, when countries such as Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey, much poorer countries than European Union countries, have welcomed six times as many migration flows. There is no solidarity between European states, especially for host countries such as Greece and Italy.  For visa liberalisation Turkey must meet all the criteria: the 72 criteria, including the Terrorism Act, from Turkey, without any exception. Mr President, the European Parliament should not approve the visa for Turkey unless all the criteria of the European Union are met, if the Council of Ministers does not proceed to a formal opinion and if we do not effectively protect European borders. The smart border decision package must go ahead, European borders are non-negotiable and will only be protected by European institutions and European states.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are many elements that make us look with great concern at developments in Turkey. And I think I can say that only foolish and out-of-sight politics can pretend not to notice. Immediately after the announcement of the resignation of the Turkish Prime Minister, Erdoğan reiterated in a defiant tone that Turkey will not give in to European demands concerning Turkish domestic policy, thus himself disasing the agreement reached with the European Union on the management of migratory flows.  So what can be done? I believe that the first thing to do is to send this tone of defiance back to the sender, first and foremost by blocking visa liberalisation, until all the answers are given positively. Europe cannot afford to be blackmailed by the Turkish President. The fragile balance on which the compromise between the European Union and Turkey is based can be broken if Erdoğan continues along the path of intransigence and the erasure of freedoms and the Turkish President, not us, has to take full responsibility for it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Commissioner, this unreasonable proposal for an agreement is yet another serious political mistake by the European Commission. Dictator Erdogan makes fun of you daily, even recommending that you go your own way, which is usually somewhere far away.  At the same time, freedom of speech is trampled every day in Turkey, journalists are imprisoned, journalists, political opponents are killed, MPs fight in the building of their national assembly. Turkey is carrying out ethnic cleansing and genocide against the Kurdish people and has proven to supply Islamic State with weapons, heal and finance the activities of this organization.  Against this background, you are offering us visa liberalisation. The proposal is degrading and is an unworthy mockery of the principles of so-called European values that you claim to uphold.  Therefore, Dear Commissioner, I recommend that you address your colleagues and clearly tell them in your eyes that this agreement is harmful, unreasonable, that it is the product and result of political hypocrisy, and please do not mislead us that the criteria are met. Everyone in this room know this is a lie.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, I call on the Conference of Presidents to give the green light to the visa liberalisation report for Turkey, as we did for other countries. We should not have double standards. The criteria must be fulfilled without shortcuts, but no strict interpretation either. We have granted visa freedom to 55 countries – including Brunei, United Arab Emirates, Venezuela, Columbia – without objections on fundamental rights. We need to find a solution, common ground on the terror law and to stop bashing constructive dialogue, that is what we need. Visa freedom for Turkey is not new nor fast. The EU agreed to start visa dialogue with Turkey in 2013. In exchange for the readmission agreement let us stick to our commitments. Visa freedom is for the people to promote people to people contact – a driving force for reforms. By delaying visas we undermine the democratic forces in Turkey and we punish the people not the establishment. When I was shadow rapporteur for Bosnia and the Western Balkans, that was what the United Left and the Greens were saying: political criteria, not a mathematic roadmap. Why is it different for Turkey?  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), question with "blue card". – My dear colleague, I have a very simple question: we are a Union of twenty-eight Member States. You'll agree with that. Turkey has obligations to 72 criteria vis-à-vis the Union. Of these, several have not been fulfilled by the Commission's assessment and, moreover, Turkey does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus, does not recognise its borders and these are recorded in the report itself. Who are you with? With the Union or with Erdogan? That's my question.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, I am on the side of the interests of the European Union and of this Parliament. We have taken a commitment, and at the moment we are not sticking to our commitment. The roadmap for visa liberalisation is clear: their standards and their criteria should be the same for all the 55 countries. Why are we putting extra criteria for Turkey? Why do we not even have a report on the table when it is not any other country? We did not have a report on the table when the criteria were not fulfilled, and as the Commissioner very rightly said, there is exceptional progress going on. Even with the five issues – if I am not wrong – that are still pending, progress is happening. Why are you all just bashing and dashing Turkey, which is a key partner for the European Union? We need to work with them, to have a dialogue, to have a constructive cooperation for the common interest. I am not taking sides. It is the wrong approach.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, we need cooperation, it is clearly strategic cooperation with Turkey. We recognise Turkey's efforts in terms of welcoming refugees and, above all, we advocate that there be a greater and better relationship between the Turkish people and the peoples of Europe. But this Parliament, until the seventy-two conditions imposed by the international community as a whole are fulfilled, without any exception, without any exception, to liberalise visas, will not do so in the case of Turkey. We are not going to cover our eyes with what is happening in that country today in terms of corruption, data protection, human rights violations or violation of the rule of law. We are not going to cover our eyes and, above all, this Parliament will not do is accept blackmail from anyone, wherever they come from, because obviously visa liberalisation cannot be a currency of exchange to avoid assuming our legal and moral obligations on refugee reception.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: – Better half-turned than completely lost. This week, the Leiden professor Zürcher drew that conclusion. He returned a Turkish award, which he received in 2005. He added: "I was wrong. Turkey cannot be part of Europe". Our political leaders must now say this in no uncertain terms. Hats off to Mr. Zürcher.  I say it clearly today: stop the deal with despot Erdogan. He throws journalists in jail, he closes churches, he intimidates refugees in the camps, he lets them shoot at the borders. Turkey cannot become a member of the European Union. I will listen carefully to the Commission and to the Presidency of the Council whether they have the courage to see and reverse their errors today, and to start with plan B.  (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: "blue card" question. I wanted to ask the member who has just spoken - everything he has said I endorse, so I agree with him: if there was a magic wand and you were the Commissioner instead of Avramopoulos, who we do not know whether he is sleeping or if he is still awake, what would he do?

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" answer. I do not know whether this is a question. Mr Buonanno criticised the Commission. I think you're asking, if you had a magic wand now, what would you want?  My alternative proposal is to possibly reserve the Greek islands in order to take in refugees there. It's really good. Then we keep the money under control and we can decide for ourselves what we do on those islands. We'll be able to register the people there. We can clearly determine which real refugees we let through to Europe and who we do not let in. And we have no mess with discussions about Turkey's accession or visa freedom. So plan B: that's top!

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: Mr President, the Commission gave a very mixed assessment of Turkey's efforts to meet its 72 criteria. In fact, according to our calculations, only 19 were satisfied. Today, everything would have miraculously changed, and Turkey would meet almost all but five requirements, including biometric passports, the fight against corruption, data protection and cooperation with Europol. At the same time, the threat of a re-establishment of visas for two friendly countries, Canada and the United States, the liberalization towards Turkey may still seem surprising. I propose that we finally affirm a triple choice with a clear line: no to any prospect of accession, yes to a financial effort and no facilitation of visas without readmission.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Mr President, I believe that with the history and course of Turkey's unreliability in implementing agreements with the European Union, but also through its actions and omissions, there is at this time that we are talking about even one fellow MEP who believes that Turkey will ever actually apply the 72 criteria which, in a telegraphical way, we are talking about. , began to apply them to the paper; Is there even one who can now trust Turkey for its credibility, when in 2005 it got the ticket to start accession negotiations promising and pledging to implement the Ankara Protocol and for eleven years mocking the European Union and mocking all its Member States and the European Parliament itself? Is there anyone who believes that Turkey will respect the European Parliament and the European Union when Erdogan, as well as other Turkish actors, insult and provoke it every day? I think that another very important issue is how to implement an agreement when Turkey does not recognise a country that is within the 28th - and you are in agreement with it - and the readmission agreement cannot be implemented, since Turkey not only does not recognise borders for Cyprus, but is currently illegally violating its territorial integrity, it is threatening its EEZ. , violates human rights. Legally, morally, really how can this agreement of 72 criteria be implemented? So we shouldn't make fun of anyone and say it clearly. This agreement with this country cannot be implemented in practice.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, Turkey can meet dozens of technical requirements for visa liberalisation, but it is alarmingly backwards in political criteria, with military campaigns that massacre the Kurdish population and persecution of critics of the regime, such as journalists Dündar and Gül, for denouncing the help of Turkish forces to terrorist groups, including Daexe and Al-Nusra. President Erdogan blackmails and mocks the European Union because the Council and the Commission have put it in the way of the dirty business for the outsourcing of refugees in exchange for visas. And he refuses to conform anti-terrorism laws to human rights and the rule of law to use them in the personal power project, which involves expelling the opposition-elected HDP party from parliament. In those circumstances, this Parliament cannot consent to visa liberalisation. But that is not enough: we must denounce and condemn the undemocratic project to which Erdogan wants to drag Turkey.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Colleagues, in the context of the migration crisis and citizens' concerns, it is, of course, appropriate to examine very seriously the conditions for Turkey's fulfild conditions for visa liberalisation. Citizens' concerns are perfectly understandable. I would like to say that I am against Turkey's accession to the European Union, I am in support of its privileged partnership with the European Union. But if Turkey can meet the security conditions, then I am also in support of visa liberalisation. Of course, if they meet the essential security conditions that we are talking about here. So far, we know that it has failed, whether it is biometric passports or cooperation with Europol. And for us, these are essential conditions that Turkey must meet. Time cannot play a role here, the conditions fulfilled play a crucial role.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Mr President, colleagues, the report adopted by the Commission presents a number of progress escans made by Turkey in achieving the benchmarks. However, the Ankara authorities have not yet met all 78 criteria in the roadmap. A number of crucial elements still present difficulties that need to be addressed: the fight against corruption, data protection, judicial cooperation, the revision of terrorism legislation and practices. I believe that it is necessary for the Ankara authorities to make maximum efforts to achieve these objectives. However, the support that Turkey provides to the European Union in the event of a massive influx of refugees must also be taken into account. That is why I believe that the European Union can and is committed to providing the necessary assistance for Turkey to meet its commitments. Only through cooperation and constructive dialogue can we resolve the migrant crisis and pave the way for the European Parliament and the Member States to decide to abolish the visa requirement in the future.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, let's set things principled: Turkey is neither the first nor the last country to expect visa liberalisation with the Member States of the European Union. So, if there are 72 criteria, Turkey needs to meet 72 criteria, as ukraine, Georgia or Kosovo needs to meet. If we start trading political criteria, I think we're going to run into big problems. The issue of corruption in all countries, both Ukraine and Georgia and Kosovo, but also Turkey, is an open question. So, I think it's only principled to set things: 72 criteria, here you go to meet them, and then we can have a liberal visa regime.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Erdoğan recently stated that Ankara does not intend to change its anti-terrorism legislation in any way. Yet the revision of terrorism legislation is one of the requirements that Turkey must meet in order to obtain the abolition of visas from the European Union. It would therefore be logical to suspend the discussion of the visa issue with Turkey, just as it is logical to ask questions about the goodness of the agreement with Ankara on the management of migratory flows, an agreement which, as you know, does not provide for any concessions as regards respect for human rights. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to put in place a more effective verification system to ensure compliance with all the requirements of the agreement and to ensure proper treatment in line with European standards for refugees and migrants. Europe absolutely cannot accept threats or blackmail from Turkey, especially on rights and values.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, visa liberalisation is an important new process in our project with a key partner of the European Union, Turkey. It is one of the very concrete measures that Turkish citizens are feeling and that can increase the attachment of Turks and Turkey to the partnership with the European Union, but essential are the 72 requirements grouped in the five thematic chapters, some of them unfulfilled, as the 2014 and 2016 reports clearly show, and at the same time clearly , as we have seen today, it is also a political decision because, beyond these technical requirements, it is very important for Turkey to reform, improve its attachment to human rights and also to stop illegal immigrants. Turkey still has a lot of work to do.  I hope that they will meet all these requirements, all these expectations because otherwise it will be difficult to receive visa liberalisation.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D). Mr President, I begin by saying that my intervention remains exclusively on the 72 evaluation criteria that the Commission has presented to us. We are a family of 28 Member States and we are a family to which Turkey has undertaken to meet 72 technical criteria. I will not refer to political criteria, but to those, ladies and gentlemen, which the Commission is supposed to have already decided have been fulfilled. So they remain strictly technical. Criterion 15: Turkey must also cooperate with its neighbouring Member States of the European Union in managing their borders. Turkey does not even recognise the borders of the Republic of Cyprus. Criterion 44: Turkey must respect the judicial authorities of the remaining 28 Member States. Turkey does not even respect the decisions of the European courts, especially for Cyprus. You judge which side you choose to be on. With Erdogan or with the principles and values of the European Union?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, the lifting of the obligation to consider Turkish citizens is the latest blackmail turkey has made towards the European Union. And, of course, the European Union has consented, accepted it. For those who know both Turkey and the European Union, the attitude of both was to be expected. But the position that Turkey will be able to meet the 72 criteria directly offends our intelligence by the end of June. How is it possible in such a short period of time that Turkey will be able to fulfil obligations it has not fulfilled in many years? Another position which directly offends our intelligence is the common position taken by Mr President-in-Office of the Council. Timmermans and Mr Avramopoulos on the fact that in its relations with the European Union Turkey has made significant progress. Because Mr . Timmermans is an answer, I turn to Mr Avramopoulos and I ask: is it progress, Mr Avramopoulos, to constantly invoke Turkey's casus belli against Greece? Is the non-recognition of the Republic of Cyprus and the illegal occupation of 37% of its territory progress? Is the recent killings of Syrian refugees by Turkish soldiers progressing, in which there have even been women and children? Is the flood of the European Union, the rest of Europe, but also Greece and Cyprus, by hundreds of thousands of Turks progress? Such reports, Mr. Avramopoule, give the right to some to mock Greece and say that if it did not exist the European Union would .... [The President interrupts the speaker]

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D). Mr President, until last week only 384 illegal immigrants returned from Greece to Turkey and 135 Syrian refugees were transferred to Europe. Indeed, flows have decreased, but this is due to the refusal of refugees to risk their lives and spend a large amount of money and in the end to be trapped in Greece. I would like to ask the Commissioner: last week we saw in the European press that if the agreement with Turkey collapses and the visa issue does not go ahead, then the islands of the eastern Aegean will be turned into Jordanian and Lebanese refugee camps. We would like a clear position of the Commission on this.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I am surprised that the debate on visa-free liberalisation with the Turks is in some way preceded by the fulfilment of those conditions. The seventy-two conditions are not met, that is an objective fact, and it is quite paradoxical that, in fact, in this situation, the Commission is already saying that this visa-free regime should be liberalised. But the whole debate is, in my opinion, made more difficult by a number of paradoxes. We consider Turkey to be a real partner in the defence alliance. Of course, many European Union countries are also members of NATO, and we consider it a proper partner there. However, if we are talking, for example, about anti-terrorism laws, in this case I think that Turkey is clearly violating human rights. And I ask: What will happen when the Turks do not really change these laws? Will this mean that we will resign to the dogma of protecting human rights under the weight of the fact that hundreds of thousands more refugees can come to us? I believe that these issues should be dealt with precisely by the Commission, because the Commission has actually put its decision before it to some extent and put us, the Members, in an intractable situation.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, liberalising visas for Turkish citizens would be a serious mistake, in my opinion, which would consolidate this state of difficulty and, above all, the weakness of the European Union towards Turkey. There is no question that a positive relationship with Turkey would be very important to us, both in the future and in the management of the emergency and today. The problem, however, is that we are faced with a country which not only evades the checks that the Union is asking of it, but which in the meantime objectively worsens the conditions in place. Turkey has in recent months distinguished itself by a resurgence towards the Kurds, the questioning of agreements and respect for relations with Cyprus; it calls into question the fundamental rights of the people who live there, it takes away the freedom of the press, individual freedoms have been reduced to the light.  Is it possible to ignore all this and proceed in separate segments, as if nothing had happened? I believe that this would be a serious mistake, particularly in the case of visa liberalisation.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I could clearly hear your concerns voiced in this debate, but let me assure you once again that the Commission will continue monitoring the progress in fulfilling the outstanding benchmarks of the visa liberalisation roadmap. We have put forward a proposal to comply with the strict timeframe provided for in the 18 March statement. You all remember that. The decision is now to be taken by you and the Council in the co-decision procedure. The Commission hopes that your final decision will be positive, provided that all the criteria of the roadmap are fulfilled by Turkey. We have been very clear from the very first moment on that. I would like to conclude by underlining, one more time, the strategic importance to give a successful conclusion to the visa liberalisation process; a process which the European Union and Turkey have jointly started already since 2013. Successfully concluding this process by fulfilling all benchmarks of the roadmap will be indeed very beneficial for both the European Union and for Turkey. It will not only contribute to create a higher level of security and a better management of migration and mobility for our citizens; more than that it will create further possibilities for people-to-people contacts between the citizens of Turkey and those of the European Union, thus facilitating mutual knowledge and building confidence. Ultimately, I am convinced it will represent a decisive step forward for Turkey as a candidate country in the process of its legal approximation towards EU standards in the field of justice and home affairs. In this perspective, I am convinced that the Commission took the right decision to present the proposal. It is now clearly up to the Turkish authorities to do the last effort, to walk the last mile, allowing to fulfil the outstanding requirements of the roadmap. The European Union must, and will, stand by Turkey in its efforts to accompany the country in its endeavours.  The Commission will continue in the weeks to come to stay in close contact with the Turkish authorities and provide assistance and advice to ensure that jointly the European Union and Turkey will be able to conclude this process. As I said in my introductory remarks, it is beneficial for both sides. Let us approach this in a positive way, because we have already the first tangible results and outcome of this cooperation. Let me answer Nikos Androulakis in Greek.  Κύριε Ανδρουλάκη, το ερώτημα που θέσατε τέθηκε και στην προηγούμενη συζήτηση. Δεν θα ήθελα να επαναλάβω αυτά που είπα, απλώς να σας πω ότι δεν υπάρχει plan B, εργαζόμαστε και συνεχίζουμε πάνω στην αρχή της αλληλεγγύης που είναι και ο οδηγός μας. Η φημολογία και όλα αυτά που γράφτηκαν τον τελευταίο καιρό στις εφημερίδες για το θέμα που θίξετε δεν έχουν καμία βάση. Και εγγυητής για την εφαρμογή των όσων έχουμε συζητήσει και αποφασίσει εδώ είναι η ίδια η Ευρωπαϊκή Επιτροπή. Δεν υπάρχει λοιπόν κανένας λόγος ανησυχίας.  Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your attention.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – The abolition of the visa requirement is, of course, primarily intended to increase cooperation between Europe and third countries, including With Turkey. But this can never be done without maximum guarantees in terms of safety. Only citizens with the latest biometric passports will therefore be eligible. Turkey must meet all the conditions before the European Parliament can agree to the demand for visa liberalisation.  If there are no major legislative changes, our group will not approve visa liberalisation. The EPP also wants such an agreement to establish a robust emergency mechanism, which will allow the visa requirement to be reintroduced immediately if the number of asylum seekers gets out of hand or if Turkey flores over the conditions. There must be a correct implementation of the agreements made, no more, but no less, while respecting all the criteria agreed. This is different from the partner country, which is also a neighbouring country, trying to provoke and raise tensions in delicate negotiations. Certainly in this case it is wiser not to pour oil on the fire, but to constructively seek solutions and to achieve results. An efficient solution to the flow of refugees is, of course, part of this.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. – It seems that Turkey is a kind of European Guantanamo: to do outside the doors what we cannot do inside. We have increasing reports of the violence perpetrated by the Turkish authorities on asylum seekers. The Council felt that solidarity that did not work between member states would work with Turkey. Many are still unwilling to receive asylum seekers from Greece or Turkey. Today we are faced with the counterparts of this agreement. Parliament has a decisive word here: there will be no visa-free travel if all the requirements are not met, as for any other third country. But that's not the essential problem. Turkey is, and has always been, a strategic partner for the European Union. But this quality should not give it exception status. This agreement may even reduce the number of people arriving at our borders, but it remains an agreement contrary to our values. Let us make mistakes for those who think that today we are hostages of Turkey — we are not. Today we seem to be hostages of our own desnorte, but there is always a good alternative: to act together, to face this problem with the European dimension that it has.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU is part of the package of four new laws prepared recently by the European Commission. The purpose of this legislative offensive is to radically reduce the scope for aggressive tax planning, tax evasion and tax avoidance and create a level playing field for all businesses in the EU. I congratulate the Commission for this initiative. The purpose of the present proposal is to further strengthen and improve administrative cooperation between tax authorities in Member States and to increase transparency of tax policies across the EU. The directive proposal provides for the mandatory automatic exchange between national tax authorities of information regarding country—by—country reports filed in each Member State by multinational enterprises involved in cross-border business activities. The obligation of filing country—by—country reports extends to all multinationals with a combined turnover of more than EUR 750 million. The directive proposal is in line with accepted international standards and specifically with the OECD report on the action plan on base erosion and profit shifting – the so-called BEPS report. The OECD package was also endorsed by the G20 leaders. It is therefore essential for the good functioning of the internal market that Member States transpose political commitments until BEPS enters their national legal systems. We broadly support the Commission proposal. We think it is timely, proportionate and goes in the right direction. We propose however two amendments. First, we want to involve the Commission to become part of the automatic mandatory exchange of information between Member States and this is for two reasons. Firstly, we want the Commission to be able to control the process of exchange of information in order to ensure the compliance of multinational companies and of Member States with the directive. Secondly, there is a state aid dimension to tax exemptions granted by Member States and the Commission should have access to this information to make sure that no illegal state aid is involved. The second amendment we propose is to request the Commission to report systematically on the results achieved under this directive and to present publicly the aggregate summary of country—by—country reports. There were also two other changes proposed by some MEPs. The first proposal was to lower the threshold required for filing country—by—country reports from EUR 750 million down to EUR 40 million. The other proposal was to make all country—by—country reports public. Both these proposals were rejected in the vote in the ECON Committee because they would introduce double standards – one more demanding for EU companies and the other less demanding for non-EU companies. If accepted, these two proposals would clearly put EU companies at a competitive disadvantage vis—à—vis non-European companies. Mr President, dear Members of Parliament, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation in preparing our report and the parliamentary services for technical support.  I call on this House to vote in favour of our report. Citizens in our countries are waiting for a strong signal from this Parliament that we are in favour of more transparency, fairness and efficiency in tax policies in the European Union.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, Mr rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased to be here today to continue our debate on tax transparency, which will keep us busy throughout this term. I promised you that the transparency revolution was underway. A new step has been taken today, thanks to Parliament, whose action I welcome.  You know that the Commission has been particularly active in recent months on the transparency front. Last December, an agreement was reached in record time on the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings between tax authorities in the EU. Since January, the Commission and I have pushed this revolution by putting on the table two major proposals: a directive on the publication of country-by-country reports on the activities of multinationals, country by country report between the tax authorities of the Member States of the Union. That is what we need to discuss tonight. Finally, there is also a proposal to amend the accounting directive, which would make this type of report public, and you know that, from the beginning, that is the position I have been strongly defending. We are determined to push the boundaries of transparency even further with Parliament's strong and constant support for this work. Our current work is thus moved in three directions.  The next immediate step for the Commission is to examine whether and to what extent the transparency requirements in the Anti-Money Laundering Directive could also be used to combat tax evasion. As early as next month, the Commission will present a proposal for an amendment to this directive. She is also thinking about how to shed more light on the activities of tax planning scheme proponents- including tax advisors, this happens to them - used by taxpayers to evade tax.  Finally, we are working intensively on the development of a European blacklist of non-cooperative jurisdictions. There is one, but it is too much the result of a compilation of national lists, which are themselves heterogeneous; all of this would be a precursor to an OECD list. I had the opportunity to speak on this subject again last week with the OECD Secretary-General, Angel Gurra, and our teams are working in perfect intelligence This is the global framework before we now get to the very point of the debate. Why is the automatic and compulsory exchange of information between the tax authorities of the Member States so important? Quite simply, because it is a fundamental mechanism for them to be able to quickly detect and respond to harmful tax practices. Clearly, this mechanism, as you have explained, will allow for better tax control and ensure more virtuous practices on the part of multinationals. A word, first of all, to explain how this proposal fits with our international work. As you know, this is a proposal that transposes Action 13 of the OECD's BEPS action plan into EU law. This has already been agreed at OECD level and approved by the G20 in November 2015 in Antalya. The Commission's intention is therefore not to create a new EU standard but simply to fully implement the OECD recommendations. We must at all costs stay the course of what has been agreed, avoid creating loopholes that could be exploited by multinationals. The benefits of an initiative at European level are, in my view, extremely clear. This will ensure a coherent, effective and comprehensive approach to the European Union and will enable country-by-country information to be published in the internal market. This initiative also provides greater legal certainty for tax authorities and businesses, and will contribute to the development of an international standard for the automatic exchange of country-by-country information. I now come to the heart of the proposal itself. With regard to substance, this proposal requires large multinationals to report to the tax authorities the tax they pay in each jurisdiction in which they operate, as well as other relevant tax information.  As far as its scope is concerned, all multinationals that reside tax-based in the European Union or abroad but are active in the internal market will have to comply with the new rules.  As far as the timetable is concerned, the directive will come into force in 2017. The first exchanges of information will therefore focus on accounting exercises that begin on or after 1 January 2016. Date. I turn to the rapporteur, Mr Rosati - in fact, I have not stopped turning to him - to thank him very warmly for his report, these thanks are of course true for all those who have contributed to it. I know that Parliament would like to go further on several aspects. So I would like to bounce back on some of the points of your work as well as some of the progress that is being made.  First, there are plans to make the information public by country. This is progress, as you know, that is close to my heart and which I have supported since I took office at the Commission. I am therefore pleased that the Commission has adopted the proposal amending the accounting directive which provides for the advertising of the activities of multinationals, the publication of country-by-country information, and as part of this initiative, the Commission is working to respond to the urgent demand from citizens and the European Parliament for more transparency, with a concern that you share for most of you. , which is to preserve the competitiveness of European companies. Therefore, from now on, it is a proposal that is in the hands of the co-legislators. We took the first step, it was not a simple decision to make but we made it, and we hope that now we will be followed.  With regard to the role of the Commission, it is hoped that country-by-country information reports will also be shared with the Commission. As the Commission is not a tax authority, with no jurisdiction in the administration of the enforcement of member states' national tax laws, it cannot receive or have access to the content of the publication of information by country, which is expressly intended for national tax administrations. The information exchanged should essentially be used by the tax authorities to assess the risks in the area of transfer pricing and better target tax controls, areas in which the Commission, too, is not competent. Member States and the OECD also believe that sharing the publication of country-by-country information with the Commission would not be in line with the confidentiality clause of the OECD agreement. So I would like to agree with you, but you see that there is little room for manoeuvre. Another point: the content of the reports. Some amendments provide for the inclusion of additional information. Again, this would not be compatible with the primary objective of this initiative, which aims to implement and transpose BEPS within the Union. To depart from it would be to create a new standard of the European Union and, therefore, a new stratum of reporting obligation, which would thus increase the administrative burden for multinational companies. Honestly, we want to identify fraudsters, we want to fight tax evasion, we want to limit the erosion of tax bases, we do not want to overwhelm businesses. Last point, it was proposed that the Commission draw up annual reports to the Council and the European Parliament that assess the effectiveness of the automatic exchange of information between Member States. But the directive on administrative cooperation already exists. Member States provide the Commission with all the information necessary to assess the effectiveness of this cooperation as well as an annual evaluation of effectiveness including the practical results obtained. In addition, the Commission must also produce a report on the application of automatic exchange of information by 1 October 2018 and submit a report on the implementation of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation to Parliament and the Council every five years. We believe that these provisions are sufficient, proportionate and, indeed, already respond to the legitimate concern that you express and which I fully share.  In any case, be assured that the Commission will closely monitor the implementation and impact of the directive, and that it will propose, if necessary, relevant amendments.  Ladies and gentlemen, I conclude, to strengthen transparency, to strengthen the fight against fraud and tax evasion, these are the objectives which are at the top of our political priorities and which are very clearly at the very heart of my mandate in the Commission.  We have already made significant progress with a tight and ambitious timetable. We are helped, it must be said, by a public opinion revolted by the successive revelations: those of last year, those of the Panama Papers, more recently. We must, without a doubt, build on this revolt to move things forward decisively. Your Parliament and the Commission, I believe, actually work in the same spirit and hand in hand. I am often in this House to present to you the proposals that we are drawing up, which are a very concrete manifestation of this commitment. I have an ambition and I know that you share it: that the European Union should be a leader and a driving force in the now global fight for tax transparency.  At the beginning of my speech, I was telling you that I would come before you to talk about these issues throughout this mandate. Yes, for sure, our work is far from over. There are still key proposals to be discussed such as the Anti Tax Avoidance Package Directive, which is on the Council's table - I hope an agreement on this in a few days at the Ecofin Council - as well as the proposal on country-by-country public reporting.  I have heard dissatisfaction. I think we must also be aware that in doing so, we will really be the first in the world to make such a proposal. It is essential that we continue to work together. I am happy to do so here in plenary. I do so in the relevant committees, before the TAXE Committee, before the ECON Committee because I know once again that, without cooperation between the Commission and the European Parliament but also without the conviction of the Member States, these proposals would remain an empty shell. This is neither my intention nor yours.  I am convinced that together we will really advance this cause that we share and that Mr Rosati's report illustrates very highly with view and precision.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, CBCR is not only part of the OECD BEPS project, but a key component of our efforts to collect taxes more effectively, and to make sure that the taxpayers pay a fair amount of taxes, regardless of the size and the type of the firms in this case.  I believe this is one of the key components as it will provide the tax authorities with data about the taxation on the level of the group and not just on the level of individual countries. This should allow the tax authorities to make a better decision about which tax check of the firms deserves the most attention. This is just the beginning of the process, but I believe we can succeed, and we are actually succeeding. Maybe some of you have noticed a recent article in the Financial Times stating that a lot of firms are warning shareholders about future profits because of expected higher tax checks, not because the taxes would be rising, but because of our efforts to collect taxes better. Let me just make three points concerning the report. Firstly, it is good that we are separating the debate about public CBCR from the CBCR itself. CBCR should be implemented as soon as possible and the debate on publication will be complicated. Secondly, we were facing the problems in debate with the Council. I hope in the future that the Council will take the opinion of Parliament more seriously. Lastly, I want to stress that the efficiency of CBCR will depend on how well the national authorities work with the data. They are obliged to use the data to make the tax collection more efficient.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Pierre Moscovici has just said that the Commission is embarking on a revolution. I do not know whether I will repeat this statement, perhaps a little optimistic, but what is certain, colleagues , and we all know , is that most revolutions are born on the soil of fiscal injustice. As the Commissioner quite rightly said at the time, there is exasperation among our fellow citizens because, revelation after revelation, they realize that one of the most sacred principles of our democracies - that is, equality before tax - is flouted and undermined by a number of practices such as aggressive optimization, tax optimization, which make a number of multinationals pay a ridiculously low tax and , in countries where they have no real economic activity. Indeed, Mr Moscovici, you have said that there are dissatisfactions. I would say more about the requirements, but at the same time we recognize - because we have to admit - that this work that is presented to us today - the tax package that you presented in committee and in plenary - is definitely going in the right direction. That is what our fellow citizens expect from us and, from that point of view, it is good. Then there is a debate that Mr. Rosati alluded to at the time. We, the Social Democrat group, believe that, on a number of issues, we can go further, particularly at the threshold level. That's why we say: "Let's move on from companies that make more than 750 million euros in turnover to 40 million." What for? Not because we are maximalists, but because it is a position that has already been adopted by the European Parliament. I would remind you that with the Shareholder Rights Directive, that is what we voted unanimously on. Second, because in practice, we are in a negotiation. As you all know, the Council is not very good on tax issues, and in particular on transparency. The European Parliament must have added value and send a clear signal. I think we can and we have to do it. In any case, what is certain is that, if we are not dissatisfied, we are demanding, vigilant, but also enthusiastic about going further with you, Commissioner.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, country-by-country reporting of tax information is a clear step forward in the fight against tax evasion. The rapporteur, Mrs Rosati, has taken this important matter forward vigorously, and I would like to thank her for that. Country-by-country reporting will provide authorities with better tools in the future to monitor multinationals paying their taxes to the Member State where the profits have been made. The proposal is based on the work carried out at the OECD, which has now moved to EU level. Aggressive tax planning is an international problem for which international solutions are needed. At the latest, data leaks such as Luxleaks and the Panama Papers have revealed how brashly international big business avoids the taxes they are due to. In public, however, companies want to present them as honourable and socially responsible bodies in every way. However, country-by-country reporting and exchange of tax information by public authorities are not enough. Transparency is also needed. The ECR Group is positive about public country-by-country reporting, but it does not consider disclosure to be covered by the Assistance Directive. Moreover, the majority of the ECR is not in favour of lowering the reporting thresholds from 750 million to 40 million. Personally, I believe that it is precisely in terms of greater transparency and thresholds that the proposal will remain halfway through. It is important that competition between companies is fair and that everyone also pays their taxes on the result in accordance with the same rules of the game. It is important that citizens can see what the company's tax footprint is like. Transparency is the best way to create more public pressure on businesses and to ensure that the right income is reported by country and taxes are paid. Achieving country-by-country reporting is a clear step forward in the fight against tax evasion. Hopefully, in the future, we will be able to take these steps more quickly and further.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – We are here with a lot of tax spokesmen together. You must have all done something that I did this afternoon: #Panamapapers tap on Twitter. And what do you see? It's not about Panama or the Panama Canal anymore. It's an endless stream of tweets, angry tweets mostly, from citizens about the latest revelations, especially now that the offshore leaks can all be seen online.  What is the essential thing about this? That it has now become a global discussion of a European discussion about Luxleaks. Today, the good news has also become known that Panama itself now wants to adapt to the OECD directives. That is the gain of the PanamaLeaks, namely that we now have not only a good proposal here in Europe – a proposal that the ALDE Group also supports – to no longer have a non-binding voluntary exchange of data between tax authorities, but a compulsory and automatic exchange, and that this will also be extended to the rest of the world. Because if we only put a fiscal cordon around Europe, we are not there yet. Fortunately, Commissioner Moscovici has just indicated that he will also fight on the international playing field. We must ensure that we do not disrupt our playing field in Europe. At the same time, we must ensure that we achieve what we all have to do, which is that everyone pays their fair share of taxes, from the individual citizen to the largest multinational.  Finally, I would like to thank Mr Rosati for his excellent report and also for the extremely enjoyable cooperation we have had in the negotiating team.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, this timid proposal by the European Commission falls far short of what is needed and the expectations of citizens. Indeed, the launch of the various tax packages and action plans, announced under the pressure of the various scandals, has raised legitimate hopes on the part of the people. However, as we see the realisation of all these plans, it is absolutely clear that the ambitions have been revised down. What we see is the adoption of minimalist measures and far below what is necessary. It is ironic that this negotiation is being made under the Dutch Presidency of the European Union, and the Netherlands is one of the most important tax havens in existence, as the Starbucks scandals, among others, demonstrate. What the European Commission proposes is to follow OECD rules by proposing a confidential country-by-country report in which multinational companies will provide tax administrations with information on their activity and taxes. As is acknowledged, the confidentiality of this information takes away the full effectiveness of the measure and, in particular, its deterrent effect.  We therefore call on the Commission to make it compulsory to advertise this information, as is the case with banks. We do not understand the 750 million euro limit, which exempts the vast majority of multinational companies from this measure. In a sense, we demand from the European Union coherence and consequent actions in the fight against this social iniquity, which is inseparable from the capitalist system, which promotes the concentration of wealth and social inequalities.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, this law requiring the automatic exchange of information about where companies make their money is a step towards transparency. In future, tax authorities will be able to see where companies earn money and create value and if they shift profits to avoid paying tax. But this is a long way short of the full public country-by-country reporting that we as Greens have been calling for. We need this information to be publicly available and for all multinational companies, not just a few of the large ones.  The EU can, and should, be a global leader in ambitious actions for tax justice. The leak of the Panama papers exposed the extent of the network of tax havens and overseas territories that help wealthy people hide their money. The data make it clear that the UK is at the heart of the web of offshore tax havens.
