Over half of the companies listed had been registered in the British Virgin Islands, and when you trace the people or companies behind these shell companies the UK itself ranks fifth for linked companies. David Cameron has a real opportunity this week to demonstrate his commitment to tax transparency as he hosts the UK Anti-Corruption Summit. He can put an end to shell companies by requiring British overseas territories to introduce a mandatory public register of beneficial ownership. This would be a real step towards ending tax havens and secrecy jurisdictions and I support the calls made this week by over 300 economists for this to happen. Let us end tax havens once and for all.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal that I have heard and read seems to me to be rather timid. I am pleased that Commissioner Moscovici is pointing to country-by-country reporting, which is public, but I have my doubts that his boss Juncker and also the President of the Eurogroup, Mr Dijsselbloem, are particularly in favour, precisely because their states have enjoyed this tax system for more than twenty years, so it will be very difficult to find a compromise. Compromises must not be found on these matters, because 1 % of the population is against 99 % instead of suffering. So here politics must examine its conscience and move in a single direction, which is that of the citizens and not of the lobbies and multinationals.  Credibility, with Juncker in government of this ship that must move towards that kind of legislation, is by no means credible. The aim is to maintain, among other things, a great much of the confidential information in this proposal. So there's really no basis for leaving. In addition, there are no mention of banks, which are the ones that manage all financial flows. I mean, we could act there, put sanctions in place. The Panama Papers are an example of this, the banks manage all the flows and advise on how to circumvent. We're a little tougher, especially with these.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Moscovici, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his EUR 70 billion is lost annually to the Member States of the European region through aggressive tax planning by multinational companies. That is why combating tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning is a priority for national budgets. However, it is equally important in order to create conditions of competition that are the same for multinationals and for small and medium-sized enterprises. We know that SMEs or small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe pay on average one third more corporation tax than multinationals.  It is also important for transparency – the report we are discussing today is particularly important – but also in order to create effective taxation at the place of value creation, that is to say, profits should be taxed where the economic activity takes place. Tax evasion is a global problem, which is why global solutions to this problem are also needed. The OECD-BEPS initiative, a 15-point action plan to combat profit reduction and profit shifting, is a very important point in this context. What is important here is the international coordination on the taxation of company income and the closing of tax loopholes, but also the increase in transparency. More than 100 countries around the world have already committed themselves to the international exchange of information, including Panama, as we have already heard today, but only the United States. Delaware has more letterbox companies than residents. However, Europe is already one step further in this area, namely with country-by-country reporting, a mandatory country-by-country reporting for multinationals with a turnover of more than EUR 750 million. These groups must disclose sales, profits and income taxes, both open and paid, to the tax authorities. However, this threshold affects a large number of companies, namely ten percent of all companies operating worldwide, and 90 percent of the sales that are made in this area – 6500 companies are affected.  What is important here is that Europe does not go it alone, but fits into this global concert, into these OECD BEPS provisions, as the rapporteur and also the Commissioner have said. No double standards for Europe, no competitive disadvantages for European companies! That is why it is important to leave the turnover limit at EUR 750 million, to coordinate the level of information exchange and also the nature of the disclosure. I would particularly like to thank rapporteur Rosati for his commitment here to ensure that there will be no competitive disadvantages for European companies.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I agree with the rapporteur's thanks. We have been working for country-by-country reporting for years, and we have already won it with the banks. For this reason, of course, I welcome the OECD initiative on the one hand and the Commission's proposal on the other, which goes beyond that, because the reporting also goes to the Commission, because once a year there is a report from the Commission to the Council and Parliament, and because small and medium-sized enterprises are largely excluded and therefore no longer burdened. Nevertheless, it must be made clear that this can only be a first step. Country-by-country reporting must be made global and public, because only the public ensures that we can clearly see which countries are promising which companies what. SMEs pay taxes, and large companies have been able to do better in the past through fragmented tax legislation in Europe. This must finally come to an end! This is not about trade secrets, it is about greater transparency and comparability in the European internal market. Tax competition requires equal tax conditions. And there must be no more letterbox companies in Europe – and hopefully soon also globally – that generate millions without employees. Taxes must be paid where value creation is generated and jobs are created. Transparency is a prerequisite for finally closing all tax loopholes.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: Mr President, the amendment of this directive is not a mere minor development. I think this is really a crucial step in the fight against social dumping and tax avoidance. This is a fight that many of us are fighting here in the European Parliament with you, Commissioner. I think it is really a struggle for the fierce defence of a fairer vision of society in which everyone has the same chance of success, because of course we cannot accept that the richest, the best organized or the least scrupulous manage to evade taxes and let others pay the bill. When Google, Facebook, Amazon, Apple or others organize themselves not to pay taxes in Europe, it is obviously SMEs, the middle classes, workers and civil servants who go to the checkout. We all know that tax is the funding of our schools, employment aid, public transport, security; it is really all that allows us to live together in a society that tends towards more justice. That is why I regret a little that the amendment to this directive concerns multinationals so little. Our goal is not to target only the largest multinationals, the most high-profile ones or those whose stores we frequent on weekends. Our goal is really to cover as many multinational companies as possible. And why? Just to avoid tax evasion. I think this is the necessary condition for re-establishing the same market conditions between multinationals and national companies in Europe. It is therefore essential that the threshold for the application of this standard be set for all multinational companies considered to be large companies by the accounting directive: 40 million euros in turnover and 250 employees. Without this, the directive would affect only one in ten multinationals. So, rather than restoring some fiscal justice, we could even create a little more injustice, by creating two categories of multinationals: those that can continue to organize massive tax evasion with impunity and others. I therefore believe that a strong and clear signal must be sent: multinationals - all multinationals - must submit to country-by-country reporting. When you have nothing to complain about, you have nothing to hide.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We have heard time and again that there are black sheep among multinationals that do not pay their fair share of taxes – that is outrageous. It is very satisfying that something is finally happening, that the European Parliament is doing something about it. Those who do not pay their taxes fairly do two kinds of damage: on the one hand, they bruise the treasury, they bruise the community of taxpayers who have to pay for it, and on the other hand, it damages competition. In this respect, I think it is very good that the European Parliament has sent out a clear signal here too. This problem is also a competition problem. Those companies that pay their taxes fairly are at a disadvantage compared to those that do not – whether those who pay their taxes fairly are large corporations or medium-sized businesses or small businesses. But there are the black sheep who don't. We are now doing something about this by making it important that the Commission, which is responsible for illegal aid, which is responsible for distorting competition, is also informed of what taxes are paid and what taxes are not paid. I find it very irritating that the Commission, in its own legislative proposal, has proposed that the Commission should not be informed. Ladies and gentlemen! Where are we? If the Commission has a task, it is to protect competition and prohibit illegal state aid. And then the Commission must also be informed. In this respect, it is good that the proposal provides for this.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, our concept of revolution is at least a little different.  I think this debate is a good example of the state we have reached. We are discussing today an issue as basic as the automatic exchange of information in the field of tax taxation. How did we get here? It was certainly not by divine will or natural disaster: it is by unjust legislation, because many of these practices are legal, but they are absolutely unfair.  To multinationals everything is allowed; to those who work and to small and medium-sized enterprises, all obligations. The escape from the tax of multinationals is, moreover, compensated by massive doses of austerity on those who comply. With regard to this proposal, I do not understand why such a large number of multinationals are left out. We do run the risk of increasing layers of injustice rather than fighting fiscal injustice. Transparency is fundamental, but the issue of tax havens, tax fraud and money laundering is even more fundamental. These, yes, are urgent measures. Our citizens cannot accept more cosmetics.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are talking about the proposal to better exchange the tax data of large multinationals in order to make tax evasion more difficult. That is, of course, right – a legitimate concern. But let us see the whole thing in an overall context! In the meantime, the Commission has initiated a number of tax projects. It wants a harmonised corporate tax law through EU law, it wants to establish taxation at the point of profit, tax transparency, deepen tax cooperation, etc. If everything is implemented, the EU will have comprehensive and new tax powers. Income tax law is entirely within the competence of the Member States. Through these measures, the EU is increasingly attacking the fiscal sovereignty of the Member States. And a state that is no longer sovereign in tax matters loses its statehood. Many want that. I don't want that.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Mr President, I would like to congratulate our rapporteur, thank the Commissioner for the quality of his cooperation and, with regard to the three institutions, make a point and a recommendation. First, a point: once again, it is proposed to amend an existing regulation whose ink is barely dry, since cooperation between tax administrations in the Union gave rise to a directive in 2011 which was updated in 2014, that is to say yesterday. "Better legislation" is often translated as "less, shorter laws." This philosophy must be complemented by saying "less laws, but laws that last longer" because they deal with all aspects of the problem and are accompanied by credible sanctions. Then the recommendation: here and there, we are in the process of putting in place a whole range of laws on the information obligations to which multinationals are now subject. These texts are necessary to move from the era of darkness to the age of transparency. But let us have the common sense to be consistent: between banking, logging and mining operations, shareholder rights, country-by-country declarations, OECD recommendations, EU texts and national laws that exist, here and there, ensure that the same criteria, rules and obligations are retained. Experience shows us that the race to virtue is more conducive to the silent development of vice than the fixation, once and for all, of a common rule, even perfectible.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Mr President! Thank you to the rapporteur and also to thank our Commissioner in particular for putting perspective on this very important debate that we are having today.  What we are discussing is, in fact, a standard that should have been introduced long ago with regard to the obligation of multinationals to provide information to our tax authorities so that we can ensure that they pay the tax they are supposed to. Sometimes, when there is such a debate, I think many citizens think that it is really quite absurd that we live in a global world where these standards do not yet apply. That is why I believe that the European Union has a huge role to play in being at the forefront of implementing these things, also at global level, in the OECD, in the G20 and in other contexts, and in fighting for the standards we are developing here in Europe to become global standards as well.  We know that in Europe alone eur 1000 billion a year is being swindled and tax-cheating if both companies and individual citizens' tax evasion are taken into account. Money that could have gone to welfare, money that could have gone to create new jobs. We know that small and medium-sized enterprises, which create 85% of all jobs in Europe, have a tax burden that is 30% higher than that of the large multinationals. That is why what is going on with tax evasion and tax evasion for large companies is destroying jobs in Europe.  I believe that transparency, effective cooperation and common standards are the three things that are needed, and I would like to say that this proposal is very good. However, I would have liked to have had the same limit as for the banks in terms of the amount of reporting, i.e. EUR 40 million.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In recent years, the challenges of tax fraud have arrived significantly. Automatic exchange of information is intended to be an important tool in the fight against this phenomenon. However, it is very important that SMEs do not suffer as a result of these solutions – let us remember that they create almost 70% of the jobs in the European Union. The functioning of groups of multinational companies can lead to distortions of competition on national markets, which is why the solutions proposed by the European Commission are so important. It is crucial that tax rules do not hinder economic growth. The proposal proposes concrete solutions for the automatic exchange of tax information, increased involvement of the European Commission, an information exchange process and greater transparency. Please note that this must not interfere with the privacy policy.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, my thanks to the Commissioner and to the rapporteur. When I listen to this debate it sounds like nearly no taxes are paid in Europe, but companies do pay taxes; small and big companies pay taxes. Income takers and employees pay taxes. It is said that we have the highest tax load in the world. In Europe we pay 10 to 15% higher taxes than any other region in the world, which is of course a problem for us regarding investment in the European economy.  So we need to fight those who do not. We need to fight tax fraud and illegal tax avoidance; not make it more difficult to run companies in Europe. That is why it is so important to stick to international cooperation, and international cooperation between national authorities requires that we have international standards, and we in Europe go beyond that. Then we are creating problems for honest industries and companies but we are also creating grey zones and loopholes and incentives to make tax avoidance.  So, Commissioner, let us stick to international standards and international cooperation, then we will get fair taxes in Europe.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr President, I believe that we all agree that this is a step in the right direction and that it is not the only one; we've been doing things, Commissioner, in the right direction, and I think this is good on this road. Now, I would like to denounce, in view of what Parliament's role is in this debate, three things which I think are important.  The first is that I would like to remind you that our role in this debate on taxation is a role of mere consultation, that is, that our report, Mr Rosati, as it may be, is a report which only raises the opinion of the European Parliament. We have no legislative capacity. And it is a sign that I want to make in the face of what the future of the reforms of our European Constitution must be.  Secondly, the Council does not listen to us. Because I would like to remind you that, already in the previous reform of the Directive, before the report on the proposal for the reform of the Directive was adopted here, the Council had already decided that the Commission had no role in the exchange of information on the rulings, which means that, in addition to having no political role, the Council has not listened to us.  And thirdly, I mean the same thing can happen here. The Council does not give the Commission any role in the exchange of information and I think that is serious because, in this area, the Commission, Mr Moscovici, has to play an important role like the one you are playing in this initiative.

name: Sander LOONES
text: – Everyone has to pay their taxes fairly. It is therefore good that we are tackling this issue here in the European Parliament as well. What we do better together, we should not do this separately and this dossier is a very good example of that. From now on, we will oblige multinationals to share information with the tax authorities, information about the number of jobs, about the profits they make, and so on. It is important to combat unauthorized tax avoidance, especially in these Panama times.  We have always said it and we will continue to repeat it: we must comply with and implement OECD standards, and at the same time we must not be blind. We must not be blind and think that Europe is an island, nor should we be blind to the burden seen on our SMEs today. So let's be clear: no additional burdens can be added to that. That is also why tomorrow we will vote against many amendments tabled by the United Left, because they have understood this differently and want to impose additional administrative burdens on our SMEs.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Mr President, I congratulate Mr Rosati on this report and also congratulate Commissioner Moscovici on the desire for the European Union to be at the forefront of the world in adopting the necessary legislation to prevent tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering. We have four objectives to achieve as quickly as we can because European citizens are asking for it. First, eliminating secrecy from the financial system by automatically reporting financial information so that there is no place in the world to hide income and wealth. Secondly, knowledge of the final beneficiaries, of all firms registered offshore, and this can be done through public registers. Thirdly, taxes should be paid in countries where value and sales are made, and this is done by reporting country by country.  And finally, fourthly, the clear penalty of tax jurisdictions, of non-cooperative tax havens.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I think it is right to acknowledge that you have approached the issue of tax harmonisation and, above all, that of transparency with great courage, even when it was not on the agenda and in the public eye because LuxLeaks and the Panama Papers were not yet recurring issues, they had not yet attracted the attention of many commentators.  Now, however, with the same frankness, I have to tell you that the plant proposed to modify the solutions indicated by the OECD is inadequate. There is a risk that we will have a good intention and frustrate it because of the objective limitations that have been set out here in its implementation. There are basically two problems, as you know and as you also loyally mentioned in your introduction. The first concerns the threshold: the threshold is too high, 750 million correspond roughly to 2 000 companies – very few. Paradoxically, thresholds of this nature risk penalising smaller farms. The proposal that was made in committee, and which the Commission did not accept, of EUR 40 million led to 15 000 companies involved. The second issue is the scope: reporting must be public in all jurisdictions.  Only the combination of a much lower threshold than that proposed and, on the other hand, the extension of the scope will give substance and also effectiveness to an action that we can entirely support, such as the one you have presented to us here.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The obligation to report financially and tax on a country-by-country basis in which large companies operate can contribute to a partial level playing field with SMEs, and as we have heard many times here, the tax burden on SMEs is on average 30% higher than for corporations. Thus, the modification of the current directive is also important in this respect. Nevertheless, such a system will not fully fulfil its role until this information is made public – and this seems to me to be much more important than the dangerous extension of the European Commission's powers – and as long as we continue to tolerate tax havens such as Luxembourg in the European Union. I also believe that the revenue threshold of EUR 75 million per year for companies subject to reporting obligations will de facto leave a significant proportion of companies outside the proposed control system.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Mr Rosati on his report and indeed for the work in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) where I think he received a huge majority for the work that he was doing with other rapporteurs.  As others have said, the whole question of aggressive tax planning is an issue of public concern for citizens, for SMEs, and we have got to respond to that in a way which is appropriate, fair and balanced. The OECD agenda is the agenda to follow and I think Commissioner Moscovici was right earlier when he said: ‘the key question now is on implementation’. We now have under Chapter 13 of the OECD BEPS Action Plan clear sets of obligations and actions on the part of EU Members. We must ensure that we follow those actions up and we must ensure also that where the Commission feels that Member States are not living up to their obligations under the OECD agenda, that they say it clearly. Secondly, on the question of automatic tax exchange of information. I come from a country, Ireland, which signed with the United States of America a FATCA arrangement, the second country in the world to do that, which is arguably the gold standard of tax exchange information now, where effectively the tax authorities give information on an annualised basis. It is not just important in terms of the tax paid, it is also crucially important in ensuring that we diminish loopholes and that we try to understand how companies get around the taxation system. I want to put on public record my support for Commissioner Moscovici’s proposal for an effective blacklisting of territories and Member States that may well be regarded as tax havens. It is about time that Europe did this, so that we can put to one side the allegations that are made of smaller Member States from time to time by larger Member States. We should get to that interpretation; it will be good for Europe and good for our businesses in Europe as well.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, if we are ever to tackle tax dodging, we have to close all the legal loopholes across all our pieces of legislation, so I like to start by congratulating Mr Rosati on his report. I do believe it is a step in the right direction, although I would have liked you to have gone further to make sure that more companies are required to submit these country—by—country reports. I think it is also important that the amendment by the S&D shadow rapporteur to ensure that companies submit these reports is fully supported. In the interest of tax transparencies, these reports really need to be made public as well. Mr President, the progressive members in this House fully understand the importance of country—by—country reporting as a tool to tackle fraud. Tomorrow, the UK Prime Minister is organising an important summit on tackling corruption and tax evasion. I welcome this initiative, and hope that his Tory colleagues in this House will be consistent with their government and their leader and vote for the first time in favour of country—by—country reporting to shine more light on a murky world of tax avoidance and evasion. At the same time, we need the Council to really pay attention to the opinions of the European Parliament on these tax matters. Together, we can tackle tax invasion in a proper way.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Corporate tax losses across the European Union amount, as estimated by the European Commission, to around EUR 120 billion per year. This means that, for many countries, these reductions are simply greater than the revenues from this tax – this is the case for my country Polish, where corporate tax revenues amount to around PLN 30 billion and the european Commission's calculations amount to as much as PLN 46 billion. We therefore welcome this european Commission's initiative on automatic exchange of information, but it seems that the adoption of this solution should only apply to companies with a turnover of EUR 750 million – this volume should be absolutely reduced so that the rules that the Commission proposes concern a wider range of companies than before.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think most citizens were greatly surprised when they became aware of the extent of tax avoidance, within Europe and beyond, especially when every single worker – albeit in the public sector or the private sector – has to pay every single cent they are due in tax, no avoidance possible, and pursued to the limit if they are tried. At the same time, multinationals were able to utilise their resources to avail of every loophole to create billions and billions of extra revenue. This has to stop and I am glad that this is a first step, but not a final step. Mr Lamassoure said that we need to move in to the age of transparency, and this is only the start of transparency. I am at a loss to understand why we put the threshold so high at EUR 750 million, and – as has been said – that only catches one out of 10 multinationals. Everybody and every company and every multinational should pay all their taxes.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Congratulations first of all to the rapporteur, of course, for a very good job and to begin by saying that I have been dealing with tax problems for a very long time and that I have always advocated fair and moderate taxation.  I don't think taxes should be that high to discourage companies from creating. On the other hand, we must not allow taxes to be evaded, that aggressive tax planning and tax avoidance are being used. Therefore, this experiment and the Commission and us together to make the tax area more transparent is a step in the right direction.  But let me conclude with this: I would be even more ambitious. I have checked in my country, in Slovenia, how many taxpayers will have if this threshold is proposed: not even ten companies will be obliged to report. I therefore think that we could be even more ambitious in the following.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the challenge posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has taken on considerable proportions, becoming one of the main concerns of Europe and the world.  Greater transparency about tax information is key to countering aggressive tax planning. Unfortunately, in the current legal framework, The Member States do not yet provide for the mutual exchange of reports from country to country. The instruments and mechanisms laid down in the Directive on administrative cooperation in the tax field must therefore be strengthened. I welcome the proposals on the threshold for multinational companies obliged to submit country reporting, the designation of the competent authority, the scope of the information exchanged and the timetable for implementation and reporting interval. I also think that Parliament's involvement in the tax transparency process is crucial. To this end, it would be desirable for the European Commission to present an annual report out of the main results of the Member States' national assessments.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam Presidents, tax havens and tax avoidance are always a topical topic, and the echo of the Panama Papers affair among citizens puts even more pressure on us to finally get tax collection under control. Taxes must be paid if we want our countries to remain functional and the European Union to be successful and rich. But I fear that some political forces are using this to promote a highly repressive tax policy propagated to some extent by the European Commission. Multinationals should certainly return some of their profits to the companies in which they operate and earn, but I think it is extremely unfair to over-tax them and make them pay for other people's political failures and social experiments instead of investing that money in research and development and job creation.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I must confess that I feel a certain embarrassment every time we discuss proposals to combat tax evasion. Very small steps forward are taken, sold as great victories, but in reality the basic situation always remains the same, with the same critical issues and problems that no one wants to face to the end. But what can be expected from a Commission led by luxembourg's head and magician of taxation and a Council led by the Netherlands, one of the tax havens within the EU? Is the European Parliament the guarantor of a more intransigent line? Not quite. But I do not know what we could hope for differently if we have ourselves, among our legislators, condemned precisely for tax evasion.  On this particular proposal, we are at least calling for all information to be made public and accessible, otherwise in a few years' time we will still be here hypocritically scandalising situations such as LuxLeaks without anything really changing.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like once again to thank you, all of you, for your comments and the collective impetus that this Parliament is giving to our joint action for fairer and more transparent taxation. I am once again convinced that our two institutions - beyond the differences in sensitivity that can emerge here or there - are on roughly the same wavelength, simply because we have the same objective - more transparent, more efficient and, at the same time, fairer taxation. I also welcome the level of ambition that some of you have mentioned and which Mr Rosati's report has of course reflected. In this regard, I would like to assure you that the decision to limit the application of this directive to multinational groups, whose turnover is above the threshold of some EUR 750 million per year, is not - contrary to what I have heard - the result of some cowardice or weakness on the part of the Commission, but simply of in-depth reflection and common sense which is also based on the conclusions. Many of you have told us that we must not build a new stratum, a new standard, or that we should still complicate things. Not all multinationals are affected by this threshold, but it is important to know that this threshold is actually very effective, as it covers 90% of the revenues of multinationals in Europe. If it were lowered, a new administrative burden would actually be imposed on companies that account for only 10% of the revenues of multinationals, but companies that are not themselves subject to this obligation, if we follow the country-by-country reporting rules of the OECD. It would therefore be very expensive, very cumbersome and, in truth, totally ineffective. That is why, if we want to change this threshold, we can understand it, and to understand even more the revenues of multinationals, it is at the OECD level that we must act to try to bring down, in the collective framework of the BEPS project, this threshold which is still, I believe, quite remarkably effective. With regard to the role of the Commission, I have heard those who want it to be stronger, and I would like to thank them, even those who are members like Mr Lucke who are usually more critical of this Commission. After all, if they decide, for once, to express their appreciation, I can only thank them too much. But there are the simply legal and legal limits that I indicated in my introduction. I would like to assure you once again that we will be extremely vigilant, attentive and strict in order for this directive to be properly applied within the framework, of course, of our powers. By the way, I will also tell you that I am getting tired of this antienne which consists of systematically targeting the President of the Commission, in the name of his nationality, or the President of the Council, the current President of the Eurogroup, on behalf of his own. As it happens, the President of the Commission is Luxembourgish, the previous Presidency of the Council of the European Union was Luxembourgish, the President of the Eurogroup is Dutch and the current Presidency of the Council is Dutch. You will judge the result, and I would like to tell you that the work with the Luxembourg Presidency has been quite remarkable, since it has enabled us, in seven months, to conclude the directive on the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings. The work of the Dutch Presidency is equally remarkable. I hope to come back to you in June with a positive conclusion on the package of measures on the fight against tax evasion. I note a remarkable support from Jeroen Dijsselbloem. Finally, I can assure you - and I say this all the more to those who are kind enough to consider that I have done a voluntary job here - that I have the full support of President Juncker. I have never been left with — and I know I will never happen — being held back in what is not zeal, but simply a commitment. Today, I truly believe that the Commission and Parliament are taking another step - a new step - in the right direction. I have heard your comments, I think they are helpful, and we will take that into account. I know as you do that this fight is not over, and it will never be over, because every time, technology, legal, accounting and financial tricks will try to find circumventions or deviations, and this is humanity — not the newspaper Humanity - as it is. So there is work to be done me for five years, work for you for five years and work for my successor, my successors, the successors of your successors. We are engaged in a rather new approach, which we must welcome. We must continue it together and take decisive steps towards this revolution of transparency that I call for. Nothing is ever perfect, we would always like to know more and go further. It is true that we are entitled to ask the Member States to do their job, but at the same time we do not act as if we do not need them. We know what our rules are, what the Commission is proposing, that Parliament is a co-legislator and also that, without the Member States, we cannot do anything. That is why we must push them collectively in the right direction, but at the same time be able to greet them when they take a good step forward, which, I assure you, is happening. It is not always spontaneous, it is not always easy, they too listen to the opinion. However, I note that, of course, in tax matters, it is extremely difficult to move forward. I have talked about tax harmonization, I want it, and as a politician, I am in favour of it. I also know how complicated it is, simply because of the unanimity rule that is blocking. On the other hand, I note that when it comes to transparency texts - because there have been the LuxLeaks, the Panama Papers, because there is the European Parliament, a voluntary Commission - it is much better and much faster. It is customary to say that it takes about five or seven years for a directive on tax legislation to come to the end of its journey. On the tax rulings, it took seven months, on the Antitax Avoidance Package, I am hopeful that five months will suffice. So where it took seven years or five years, on these subjects, it takes five months, which is to say how fast and hard we work, and will continue to work fast and hard together. I invite all of you to contribute, as you obviously do, to ensuring that this debate is always at the forefront of our Union's political agenda, building on - it is true - this formidable citizen demand that turns to us. Europe is criticised, too criticised. We have an opportunity here to show that Europe is useful, strong and good, and also to show, quite simply, what we want to do with our Europe.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I address my thanks to all the speakers for this interesting debate. I am very happy to see this overwhelming unity in which we all share concern about the growing scale of tax evasion and tax avoidance across the globe. This is a very worrying phenomenon as it undermines national budgets, as it puts small and medium-sized enterprises in a disadvantaged position and of course undermines the fairness of the taxation systems in all our countries. I would like therefore to express my satisfaction that we all agree that this issue has to be tackled and that we all agree that taxes should be paid where the value is created. On several contentious points let me make a quick comment. On the threshold, I think Commission Muscovici has explained what is the rationale behind adopting this relatively high threshold. If we went for a lower threshold that would certainly cost us much more, with marginal revenues from that move diminishing, so that I think we have to be ambitious, but not perhaps ambitious to the point as to undermine the efficiency and effectiveness of the tax system. If we manage to collect more than 90% of taxes within this system with a threshold of 750, I think we should start with this; but of course, if we are able to start negotiations at the OECD level in order to lower this threshold, I would be all in favour of that.  And the same holds true for the publicity, for the transparency. I am also in favour of that, but simply, my point is that we would not like to adopt unilateral obligations because they would certainly undermine the competitive position of our EU companies. If we can find a system that would not undermine the competitiveness of the European Union, I again would be very much in favour of more publicity and more transparency. One last point is on the role of the Council. I have to say that I regret that the Council has taken its decision before Parliament actually prepared its opinion. This is against the rules. Although the decision is up to the Council, the Council should take a decision at the end of the whole procedure after the Parliament has expressed its opinion. I think in future we will not have this kind of unfortunate practice. Finally, I would like to express my thanks to Commissioner Moscovici for excellent cooperation and to all the shadow rapporteurs and to all the speakers during this debate.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – (20) We are dealing with an attempt to respond to what has become known as the Luxleaks scandal, which directly involved the current President of the European Commission when he was still finance minister and later Prime Minister of Luxembourg. The discovery that not only this, but also several other governments of EU countries have concluded secret agreements with multinational companies to save them from paying taxes, opening the door to tax avoidance and depriving states of huge revenues that would result from the due collection of taxes, generated just and understandable outrage across Europe. For those in charge of the EU, we had to make sure that something changed in appearance so that everything stays the same. It is ironic that this negotiation is being made under the Dutch PRESIDENCY of the EU, and the Netherlands is one of the most important tax havens in existence, as demonstrated by the starbucks scandals, among others. The European Commission proposes a country-by-country report – confidential – in which multinationals will provide tax administrations with information about their activity and their taxes. Confidentiality compromises the effectiveness of the measure and its deterrent effect. Moreover, the limit of EUR 750 million leaves out the vast majority of multinational companies.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. Although it has been a good trick to hide behind a company to pay for black income in an exotic country, it will soon be easy for those fishing in turmoil to be exposed to their national tax authorities. However, it should be said that there has always been an exchange of information between the countries concerned where a tax convention has been concluded or, since countries which are tax havens have not, by definition, concluded an agreement to avoid double taxation, or only with a few countries, if a convention specifically relating to the exchange of tax information has been concluded. However, previous conventions have not proved useful enough, and it has been shown that we need unified action, which is now embodied in Mr Rosati's report. I believe that there is now a new financial revolution taking place in the world, which includes the re-regulation of offshore, but there are many question marks in this regard.  It's an offshore global problem based on income dispossession, but there's not much to do about it. However, it should also be added that the convention on automatic data exchange requires serious preparedness from the national tax authorities, and it is a big question how this can be achieved, for example, in my country in Hungary. The IRS is not prepared for so many asset assessments, so it can also be difficult to interpret complex company law and financial data, which can lead to litigation being dragged out.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - The mandatory automatic exchange of tax information is an important step towards tax transparency and the prevention of tax evasion. A tax system that allows tax avoidance between €50 billion and €70 billion a year is not a fair tax system. Small and medium-sized entrepreneurs who need to be drivers of our economy and who duly meet their tax obligations are more tax burdened because multinationals use loopholes in tax legislation to avoid paying taxes. The same rules for everyone should apply. The recently published Panama Papers showed us the scale of unfair tax practices. I therefore welcome the mandatory automatic exchange of tax information in this form as only the first step towards a fair, transparent and effective tax system that will prevent aggressive tax planning and tax evasion. The European Union must collect taxes more efficiently and channel these funds into growth and jobs.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. – In the wake of the recent Panama Papers scandal and in order to tackle tax evasion affecting many EU Member States, the European Commission places particular emphasis on the automatic exchange of information between companies. In particular, the EU proposes the introduction of country-by-country reporting for multinational business groups, as they are also the protagonists in the practices of tax avoidance and tax evasion by eroding the respective national tax base. In addition, multinational companies should give a full report on the amount of income and profits before income tax. Of course, the mandatory exchange of information is not enough to deal with these practices. All EU countries should take steps to ensure that every business is taxed in the country where its profits are made, and not resort to tax havens - as the Panama Papers revealed when 214,000 offshore companies were set up. Multinationals should also stop using the practice of intra-group transactions, thereby negatively affecting the budgets of the Member States.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. – Mandatory country-by-country reporting for multinationals is one of the Commission's main legislative offensives on MNCs' tax avoidance practices. Tax inequality in favour of businesses and wealthy individuals is a democratic problem. We know that wealthy people can move in the grey area of legislation and choose which rules they follow in their countries of origin and which they do not. Transparency is a fundamental weapon in the fight against tax avoidance and tax evasion! The automatic exchange of information will make a significant contribution to improving cooperation between tax authorities and increasing transparency. For this, however, country-by-country reporting must be made public! The publication of certain information is essential for the comparability of indicators and does not, as some claim, be a trade secret. It must be clear how many employees a company has in which country and how productivity, turnover and profit develop in the respective country in relation to the number of employees. We can only achieve full transparency if these indicators, which are important indications for possible letterbox companies, are published. A second point is the level of the threshold: we must ensure that as many companies as possible are covered – not just the largest ones. Only then will this legislative measure also have an effect!

name: Thomas HÄNDEL
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner! The Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has once again addressed the growing inequality in Europe. It has been growing steadily for years and has never been so crass since 1961. That is not what I am saying, as the OECD says. This will not worry those, including those in this House, who are more equal than others. However, we should not only be alarmed, but we should be absolutely appalled. The richest 10 percent have 9.6 times higher incomes than the poorest 10 percent. The richest 10 percent of households own 50 percent of net wealth– the poorest 40 percent own just three percent. Downhill it wasn't just the poorest – it went downhill with the bottom 40 percent of the population! A quarter of people in Europe live at or below the OECD poverty line. This Europe is about to squande its credibility with a growing number of people – with all the political consequences that are already visible.  But not only that: growing inequality is hurting everyone. It is not only the social and political problems that are increasing, but also the economic problems. This is detrimental to inclusive and sustainable economic growth. There is a growing consensus in international organisations: the increase in income inequality and wealth inequality must be addressed. The OECD concludes: "The challenge is therefore to find appropriate packages of measures that are both growth-friendly and contribute to reducing inequality."  This, ladies and gentlemen, requires a holistic approach, including social and macroeconomic measures. After all, the effects of asymmetric crisis shocks ultimately affect all countries. The proposals to combat this problem are manifold – they have not yet been addressed. It is proposed to improve the quality of social policy instruments such as unemployment insurance. It is proposed to increase minimum wages, not only at country level, but also to create a level at European level. It is proposed to create better social benefits – for example, for the social situation of single parents. And there has long been a proposal to create more work from which one can live on one's own poverty-free basis, instead of creating more and more precarious working conditions. The Commission seems to have understood that the proposal now before us for a pillar of social rights is to be welcomed. But I say that beautiful headings will not suffice.  The Committee on Employment asks: firstly, does the Commission consider that its Work Programme 216, in which it describes inequality as a major challenge, adequately addresses the decline in growth resulting from increasing inequalities among EU citizens and sees the need to promote upward social convergence?  Secondly, if so, can the Commission explain the relevant policy areas of the programme in more detail? Thirdly, what measures and specific strategies will it propose in its next work programme to promote inclusive and sustainable economic growth by reducing inequalities and improving upward social convergence?  I firmly believe that Europe needs a social state constitution. We need a Europe with social justice, with good work, from which one can live independently and poverty-free, good education for all, more public services of general interest and an economically and ecologically sustainable economy. An anti-social Europe, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, is doomed to failure – with devastating consequences. A social Europe, on the other hand, will be good for everyone – people and the economy.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, at the very heart of the Commission’s work programme for 2016 we focus on two mutually reinforcing priorities: more job-related growth and enhanced social convergence. For the return to robust and sustainable growth, we have proposed action on two fronts: firstly, investment in Europe’s sources of jobs and growth, and secondly, the completion of the European economic and monetary union to create the conditions for lasting recovery.  President Juncker’s EUR 315 billion investment plan will reach its stride in 2016 and then, combined with European Union funding instruments, it will deliver to citizens in almost all walks of life. This will accrue in parallel with an upgrade in the investment climate, thanks to the digital single market, the single market strategy, the energy union and the capital market union. Moreover, central to the Five Presidents’ Report on completing the European monetary union is the idea that fair, well-functioning labour markets and welfare systems are vital to the success of the European monetary union and are part of a broader convergence process towards more resilient economic structures within the euro area. To this end, the Commission is delivering on upward social convergence through the European pillar of social rights, as well as a number of targeted initiatives outlined in the Commission work programme for 2016. The aim of the pillar is to foster convergence by setting up a number of essential principles to support well-functioning labour markets and social protection systems within the euro area, thereby contributing to efforts to achieve for Europe a social triple—A rating. The pillar will build on and compliment the acquis in order to guide policies in a number of fields. The pillar should become a reference framework to screen employment and the social performance of participating Member States and to drive for reforms at national level.  The Commission put forward a first preliminary outline of the European pillar of social rights on 8 March. Public consultation is open until 31 December. The results will inform the final proposal to represent it early in 2017. Between now and the end of the year, the Commission is actively engaging with other institutions, national authorities and all kinds of stakeholder at EU and national levels to discuss and get their opinion on the pillar. Social partners have been invited to play an active role in shaping the pillar. In line with the principle of subsidiarity, Member States are primarily competent for their employment and social policy. Action at EU level is needed in order to promote greater social progress and cohesion and to conceive social policy as a productive factor which reduces inequality, maximizes job creation and allows Europe’s human capital to thrive.  Indeed, we need to screen whether the European social model is still fit for purpose. We are confronted with long—term challenges like globalisation, an ageing society and changing work patterns. We are also still confronted with the aftermath of the crisis and the great divergence in employment and social outcomes between euro zone countries and a divergence which is a threat to its long—term sustainability. In order to achieve upward social convergence, these challenges need to be confronted and met head—on. The Commission work programme for 2016 contains concrete initiatives to address inequalities. The forthcoming skills agenda will focus on skills as an innovator to employability, as well as creating the right environment to allow skills to drive competitiveness and fair and balanced growth. Moreover, it will set out actions for a reinforced engagement with businesses and for a shared commitment to deliver a skills rich Europe. The Commission’s proposal to revise the posting of workers directive aims to ensure equal remuneration between posted workers and national workers. The preparation of the fresh start to the work/life balance will aim to fight inequality between men and women on the labour market, equipping the European Union with a legal and policy framework to allow parents and carers to better and more fairly balance their work and carry out their responsibilities.

name: David CASA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, Europe is once again facing huge societal challenges. The current Commission has made it important to see that it is the most political imperative to bring back more social fairness in Europe and to reconnect with the social dimension of our Union. The European Commission is working to achieve a social triple—A for Europe, and this provides a number of challenges in a world where low—income families are on the rise. Different studies are showing us that when poverty reaches the middle classes it can hamper growth and weaken social cohesion by limiting opportunities, not only for the most deprived sections of our society, but also those at risk of exclusion from the decent living bracket. No-one needs to be left behind when we formulate new policies, and we need to invest more in our citizens. This is particularly important because jobless households with children are facing a lot of difficulties. We need to create employment opportunities in order to avoid the inter-generational transmission of poverty and social exclusion, with particular emphasis on pre-schoolers.  I believe that upward social convergence is important for a sustainable model social Europe, and this needs to be reflected in our policies in order to address the current challenges which persist in many Member States.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Now we are standing here again and have to say that the gaps in europe are widening both between countries and between people. Last year, unemployment in the Member States ranged from around 5% to more than 25%. The fact that the increase in unemployment is often met with unilateral austerity and welfare cuts has further aggravated the situation. Jobs have also become more precarious and temporary. High unemployment and deteriorating social conditions also erode faith in the ability of politics to change society. Extremism is growing and it is worrying. More people must therefore have the chance to enter the labour market. More people need to get the chance to get an education. And equal pay for equal work is a given. In fact, it is already a treaty-entrenched right, and should be something that was already in place. Here, the Commission, and not least President Juncker, is now being challenged by yellow cards for further work on the Posting of Workers Directive. Of course, this must not delay or change the work on this core directive. This means so much to everything else we talk about. It is crucial if we are to recover a labour market that works, and thus reduce disparities. At the same time, the European Youth Guarantee must be given more muscle. Women must be given living conditions that allow them to be in the labour market just like everyone else. And, we need to strengthen – not cut back on – welfare. The economic crisis has shown that countries where the social partners, and wage formation, were attacked during the economic crisis have more difficulty than everyone else to get out of it. Please read Eurofound's latest report on this, and then get to work and make sure that we actually get something important done. Thanks!

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, much of what I am going to tell you may be very much intended for your previous colleague, Mr Moscovici, because the unequal dynamic in which we are involved ends up being destructive to economic growth. That's a classic. And besides, we went into a vicious circle. Why? Because it negatively affects economic growth, then there will be more unemployment, then there will be more financing problems, more pension costs, etc.; then there's going to be less growth. That has to stop it now, because we've gone too far. But you have to look at it from the point of view of economic policy. Both the OECD and the International Monetary Fund have said this: it is already going too far. And here comes the crun of the matter. Look, indispensable social policies serve to alleviate: to alleviate poverty, to alleviate unemployment, and so on. They don't solve structural problems. Structural problems must be solved with appropriate economic policies, fiscal policy—fundamental, fundamental—, redistributive policy, income policy, investment policy—essential—, sectoral policies... Those are the ones that are going to break an unequal economic dynamic. And that's measured, measured, Commissioner. These are the Palma indices, the Gini indices. I'm talking about very basic economics. What the Commission and the Member States, which the Commission must help, have to do is to focus from now on the unequal dynamics with the same interest with which they have focused on financial balance or even on opening up the single market. Why not put in the six-monthly assessment made by the Commission, in the famous European Semester, also a number of objectives relating to the Gini or Palma indices and see the evolution of this destructive unequal dynamic?

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, we will not reduce inequality if we do not invent a new type of development, if we do not loosen the stranglehold of austerity by increasing labour pay and small and medium-sized pensions and if we do not get out of the precariousness of work. Even with a level of wealth produced equivalent to what existed before the 2008 financial shock, the population is now living worse, inequality is growing, there are more people and working poor. We must therefore move away from current logics and create the conditions for a new distribution of wealth and a new way of producing it.  There is an urgent need to move towards new social rights for employees, to act against tax evasion, which costs european state coffers EUR 1 trillion a year, to close tax havens and to create a harmonised capital tax system. It is also necessary to use the leverage of credit, in particular this EUR 1 trillion of monetary creation of the European Central Bank, so that it really serves the useful investment that creates jobs, production, ecological development and human development, and thus new services which are the essential tools to combat social and territorial inequalities. This is an urgent project that needs to be opened and which would give credit to a new European social project.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we need to talk first of all about what we mean by sustainability. In my book, it is something which is capable of lasting, therefore the issue of ecological transition that was raised by our committee president is extremely important in this; otherwise, we basically use up what we need to sustain ourselves. I think we also need to be questioning whether the goal is growth or whether growth is a mechanism for something else. What we are really talking about here is decent life on a finite planet, so we need to consider how we are going to do that. We heard from the Commission that the investment plan is going to reach all walks of life. I would like to ask: how do we know that this is going to happen? How is this going to be directed? How is this going to be measured? I represent London – not the City, the financial part, but London as a whole – which is a city of massive inequality. One in five earns less than the necessary living wage to live in London, 50% of the self-employed are low paid, we have an enormous wealth concentration at the top, and the bottom 10% are basically in a debt economy. The OECD talks about wealth concentration as being a barrier to investment. So how can the European Union take steps on the issues about reducing the inequalities, not only by raising the bottom end, but also by reigning in the massive growth that is happening at the top end for the few?

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, alas, we seem to be faced with a Commission suffering from a very serious form of bipolarity, because I, when we talk about the social package, social reforms, upward convergence, the only package I have seen is the third aid package to Greece. A few days ago, the third package was approved, which is not an aid package, but an aid package to die for. We have condemned Greece to exhale its last breath. It is a pity, however, that when we are here talking, a few kilometres from here, people die, people fall ill, cannot be cured, parents cannot feed their children and inexorably die. So it is true: either social policies are accompanied by courageous, coherent economic policies that really have results, or we will continue to talk about them. And while we're here chatting, there's a people dying, and that's our responsibility.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Thomas Händl for addressing such an important problem as the build-up of social and economic inequalities, particularly in some countries. They are not only a national problem– they can have very negative effects on economic growth and the competitiveness of the European Union as a whole. I would like to call on the European Commission in particular to include appropriate instruments in the 2017 work programme to improve the socio-economic situation in Europe. Action to reduce inequalities should consist of a number of policies. Today I would like to focus on three key points, in my opinion. Increasing social and economic inequalities are very often at the root of the family. Poverty, unemployment, lack of adequate education are passed on from generation to generation. Our focus should therefore be on supporting families in a responsible and sustainable way. The key is professional activation, the creation of flexible forms of employment combined with adequate social security, as well as quality childcare facilities. Ordinary transfers of money will not have the desired effect, on the contrary, they can push women out of the labour market for a long time, for example. Another very important issue is education from an early age based on innovative teaching methods adapted to today's modern realities. The priority should be to create a level playing field at the very start. We can achieve this by developing pre-school and early childhood care, and by giving all children, regardless of social status, access to education as early as possible. The last thing I would like to draw attention to is social investment. I am convinced that Europe needs a new, more innovative and bold thinking today. We need to believe more in people and, instead of the usual financial support that is often addictive, offer support that will help develop and build our independence.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – Let me start positively. The European Commission seems to have seen the light and is making a welcome u-turn. At least that is what I thought when commissioner Moscovici published the economic outlook last week. That economic outlook no longer focuses on reform, but this time the Commission expresses its concerns about growing inequality in Europe.  Better half-turned than completely lost. I fully endorse this analysis. A more equal society is not only fairer. It is also a proven recipe for economic growth. It was also the reason for the OECD to ring the bell and call on countries to take action. The Commissioner just said that our social model is 'fit for purpose'. But if so, we would not be dealing with growing unemployment and growing inequality. In recent years, the European Commission has been unequal in its interest in the unequal results of the compelling advice to the Member States to cut back on the welfare state. Austerity that has hit the weakest hard and pushed up inequality in many countries.  That is why I am very curious to see the consequences of the Commissioner's own new insights. Are the policy recommendations to the Member States now taking a different direction? Will there be a policy that combats inequality rather than strengthens it? And secondly, will there also be a more important role for trade unions? After all, labour incomes have been falling for years. The workers get an ever smaller part of the pie. The top business and shareholders are leaving with the bulk of the profits.  If we put inequality on the agenda, not out of charity but because it threatens prosperity, then it must be about more than analysis. We need to tackle things in concrete terms in order to combat inequality.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Madam President, there is strong evidence, from sources such as the International Monetary Fund, that 'inequality is a drag on growth'. This quote is not mine, it's from Nobel Economics Prize laureate Paul Krugman.  Inequality has continued to grow in Europe. There are currently 123 million poor people— a quarter of the population — and the richest 1% have one-third of the wealth across the continent, and this is not the result of chance, but of the political decisions that have had the consequences of the crisis on the most vulnerable. How far have we come when even García Margallo, the current foreign minister of the Spanish Government of the People's Party, has said that "we have spent four villages with austerity" and consider that this is to blame for killing the golden egg hen, that is, economic growth? It is not only a question of social justice, which it is, it is also a question of wisdom and economic intelligence. I conclude by quoting another Nobel laureate, Joseph Stiglitz, who says that "what Europe needs, rather than structural reforms in its member countries, is a reform of the structure of the eurozone itself and a reversal of austerity policies that have failed time and time again in their attempt to re-ignite economic growth."

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Madam President, the latest OECD report shows how bad inequality is for people but also for economic growth. This is yet another reason to underline the need for the European Union to return to the path of strong, sustainable and inclusive growth.  The debate on inequality cannot be reduced to purely economic and social considerations. Inequality also weakens our democracy and the European project, which, as a reminder, aims in particular to bring together the economies of the different States and also to bring about a harmonisation of social conditions.  Inequality must be denounced, but it is even more important to have concrete policies that will reduce them. In this regard, I would like to emphasize four elements. The first is jobs, the creation of sustainable and decent jobs, sustainable jobs. This is the first element to reduce inequality and, in this sense, I support the Commission's investment plan initiative. The second is to ensure professional transitions in a constantly changing economy. The third is to combat all forms of exclusion, in particular school exclusion. And finally, I expect that the pillar of social rights will allow for a real convergence upwards. This is something that is essential and, on these various points in this case, I am convinced that the action of the social partners must be given a central place.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the figure of change that citizens are asking us for is part of a strong and tangible commitment by the European institutions to promoting policies that really combat inequalities.  Austerity policies focused on cuts in public spending have decimated the rights chain – I am thinking of the thousands of people suffering from the discomfort of deprivation, I am thinking of the thousands of people who give up care, not to mention the thousands of homeless families for income unavailability, not to mention young people who give up building another future for themselves within training and education pathways. I am thinking of the work that is not there, but I am also thinking of the work that is there and that remains inaccessible to a very large number of people.  I am therefore thinking of the need to look at poverty at last, Commissioner, by promoting policies that will increase opportunities for the most vulnerable people, stronger public policies geared to inclusive growth. It takes courage, of course, it takes capacity for innovation within a new paradigm, that of inclusive development – immediately, however, because there is no more time.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, we certainly need action to promote social progress in today’s world of globalisation, an ageing society and – as you have said yourself, Commissioner – changing work patterns. Yes, of course, reviewing our tax systems: and the debate we had before this was very relevant in that area. We need a fair distribution of income, fostering of growth and, of course, a redistribution of our taxes. But we also need to promote employment, and employment with fair working conditions and a minimum wage, a living wage. That needs to be encouraged and promoted in all Member States: employment that will focus on small and medium businesses and that will provide valuable jobs for women, for young people, for minorities. I say to all those who are opposed to the trade deals that have been negotiated at present: those trade deals are focused on generating employment within the European Union. They are very important for small and medium enterprises, especially those that want to trade internationally.  We need to enhance access and performance in education and particularly to focus on providing people with skills. In this area I would mention in particular our young people: 20% of them are unemployed. That is not equal. Young people, women, minorities – they are the ones who are unskilled and trapped in low-paid jobs. So, education and focusing on retraining people to provide them with the necessary skills for today’s world: that is the key to reducing inequality.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate and the question that has been tabled have a very specific purpose: we cannot ignore the effects of the growing inequalities between rich and poor in our societies and we must ask the States, but also the Commission itself, to do more. The worsening of wage policies and social protection systems at national level is increasing the risk of poverty and social exclusion. Inequalities produce individual tragedies and also threaten the very essence and future of the European project, as well as being a real obstacle to growth and economic progress.  As the OECD study shows, today the richest 10 % of the population earns 9.5 times more than the poorest 10 %, reaching a peak compared to the last thirty years. That is why we need a new development path, an effective programme that will require much greater political actions and budgetary resources than at present and must be contextualised in a sustainable development strategy that includes the environmental, economic, social and cultural dimensions. Finally, income inequality is closely related to inequality of opportunity. The growing generation of children and adolescents who are coming to terms with deprivation and exclusion will only be able to express their potential if they are properly supported and if measures are taken to break out of the vicious circle, otherwise we will force them into permanent marginalisation.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, the increase in inequalities in the eastern Member States of the European Union, where the savings rate is also extremely low due to the incomes of the population, has particularly painful consequences. According to a recent survey, there are also huge differences between the countries of the Central and Eastern European region: while the average amount of savings is EUR 39 400 in Austria, only EUR 10 900 in the Czech Republic, EUR 8 000 in Slovakia and EUR 2600 in Romania. If I add to this the fact that in the country where I come from, in Romania, 70% of employees earn below EUR 380 net per month, then inequality is already being shed a different light.  In these income conditions, we also need to interpret the middle class differently. What is a middle-class lifestyle in Western Europe is the privilege of the rich in the East. Economic growth must also be supported by an increase in consumption, but low income levels limit the growth of services and the growth prospects of small and medium-sized enterprises. The future of Europe will also depend on reducing inequalities between Member States and within individual Member States. Maintaining a strong cohesion policy is one of the instruments the EU has and its resources should continue to be used to catch up after 2020.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, almost a quarter of the population in Europe is at risk of poverty or social exclusion. The number of people living in severe material deprivation has increased by 7.5 million in 19 countries of the European Union to 50 million. Inequalities in Europe have generated profound and complex dynamics and have decisively hampered economic recovery.  It is clear that the policies implemented by the various States and by Europe itself have a major impact on increasing or reducing inequalities: poverty and the increase in inequality are not inevitable phenomena, but are often the result of bad political choices – I am thinking of economic theories about austerity or fiscal systems that are often uniquitous and not sufficiently progressive.  It is necessary to put in place initiatives that stimulate growth by reinvesting resources in public services, guaranteeing all decent wages and quality and sustainable jobs. Only in this way will we be able to project our society towards inclusive and sustainable economic growth in the European Union and thus achieve the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, at a time of economic crisis, violent fiscal adjustment, merkelic austerity and the break-up of the social state, combating inequalities and strengthening sustainable and inclusive growth is a delusional dream. Europe is filled with armies of unemployed and poor. The long-term unemployed in the European Union amount to 12 million. Unemployment in Greece in the Memorandum reached 25%. We therefore need to change the economic model, abandon austerity and hit the tax evasion of multinationals that do not pay taxes, so that states have fewer resources for social policy. However, the root cause of inequalities is the very unequal distribution of wealth generated. so in Germany, where unemployment is only 4.5%, according to deutsche welle's tv show the day before in that country, Germany, there are currently the greatest social inequalities in the European Union, since 10% of the richest part of the population has twice as much wealth as 40% of the poorest part of the population.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, of course the crisis has led to unprecedented divergences among Member States, with higher unemployment and increasing inequality having disrupted social cohesion in many of them. Unbalanced growth in some countries before the crisis often went hand-in-hand with lower productivity, a decline in competitiveness and too little investment in human capital. While there are some signs that divergences between Member States are starting to decline, this remains an issue of concern for us. Inequality hampers growth and undermines political and social stability and progress, and it undermines one of the European Union’s raisons d’être, namely fostering economic convergence and improving the life of all European citizens.
