Of course I agree with you when you mention all the questions about income policies and about how to address inequalities. But, as you know, speaking about the income policies, speaking about the minimum income for example, the EU has no competence to adopt legislative measures setting requirements on minimum income at EU level. As minimum income schemes aim to combat poverty and social exclusion, they fall within the remit of Article 153 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union: the legal basis for the adoption of measures in the field is therefore Article 153.2 and it lies in the hands of the Member States. Nevertheless, the Commission has been providing policy guidance to the Member States to help them to develop adequate levels of minimum income, notably through the 2008 Commission communication on active inclusion, the 2013 Social Investment Package and various country specific recommendations within the European Semester. The Commission has also been funding the establishment of the European Minimum Income Network and is elaborating a methodology to develop across nationally comparable reference budgets in Member States. This will serve as means of helping both Member States, to design efficient and adequate income support, and the Commission, to monitor the adequacy of income support at Union level. Of course we must strive for upward convergence in employment and social policies. That means ensuring that no-one is left behind: that people’s quality of life is improved as the European economies strengthen. Since its first day in office, a key goal of this Commission has been to create a Europe worthy of a social triple-A rating. This requires fair and balanced growth leading to the creation of decent quality jobs, as well as equal chances for success and the protection of all throughout their life cycle. We have already put fairness at the core of our agenda. The Commission work programme 2016 made it clear that tackling inequalities in the Union requires a focus on two mutual reinforcing priorities: more job-rich growth and enhanced social convergence. This is not only our mission as a European Commission. It is a joint responsibility to achieve results in addressing inequalities. We need to activate the support of Member States, the social partners, and all the stakeholders. It is important that our citizens see that Europe is working for them. This must be our common goal – that Europe creates quality jobs and promotes fairness, ultimately generating wealth and offering decent opportunities to all.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Persistent inequalities are a real problem and therefore the European Union should carry out measures in both social and economic policies to help level them up. However, it should be borne in mind that much depends on the Member States and that all measures must respect the principle of subsidiarity. The Union does not have the competence (and should not have) to introduce a uniform income at European level or a minimum wage. The economy of each country has its own specificity and operates in a free market. At EU level, we should create the right framework and conditions for European citizens to benefit from economic growth and existing opportunities on an equal footing. I therefore welcome the Commission's initiative on the European Pillar of Social Rights. I believe that the initial top priorities in this area are well presented: equal opportunities and access to the labour market, fair working conditions and adequate social protection. I hope that the Commission will put forward a concrete and ambitious proposal in early 2017 as planned.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. – Inequality in Europe has increased significantly during the financial crisis. The adjustment of living standards and the reduction of social disparities between countries are among Europe's main objectives. Unfortunately, however, this adjustment is happening downwards rather than upwards. This inequality is a problem in many ways. First of all, for those affected, who are getting poorer and poorer. In unequal societies, families from weaker social classes find it harder to realise their chances of education and thus social advancement. Rising inequality, however, not only affects society, it also affects a country's economic prospects. The more unequal societies are, the less economies use their full potential. In order to achieve sustainable economic growth, we need a change of course. We must promote equal opportunities in the labour market, create high-quality jobs and invest in education and skills.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Andriukaitis, today's debate allows us to debate an issue that is very important to our citizens. On behalf of the ENVI Committee, whose position I represent here, I would like to stress the need for compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foods. As a result of certain food scandals in Europe, there is an urgent need to guarantee clear information to consumers and greater transparency and accountability in the agri-food chain, and as direct representatives of the citizens we are the spokesman for these demands through this resolution. Specifically, the measure covers meat other than beef, pigmeat, sheepmeat, goatmeat and poultrymeat, processed meat, milk, milk used as an ingredient in milk products, un processed foods, single-ingredient products and ingredients representing more than 50 % of a food stuff. As a Eurobarometer survey shows, in 2013 around 90 % of EU citizens consider it necessary to indicate the origin of these foods, and it is clear from this that this is one of the factors likely to influence consumer behaviour. The ENVI Committee therefore believes that the obligation to indicate where it comes from on the label is essential to ensure transparency and traceability and to reassure European consumers who are asking for the indication of origin and to regain their confidence. On 20 May 2015, the European Commission published a report on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin, accompanied by a study on milk and other meat, according to which the costs of compulsory origin labelling for milk used as an ingredient in dairy products increase as the production process becomes more complex. The ENVI Committee considers that these costs are overestimated and that the European Commission's own study suggests that some Member States have overcalculated the impact of compulsory origin labelling on their competitive position, as there has been no clear explanation for the high expenditure forecasts they have provided. The report put to the vote tomorrow therefore calls for the establishment of a European Commission working group to further assess the report and its impact in order to determine whether these costs can be reduced to a level acceptable to businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises. The ENVI Committee also stresses that the overall willingness of consumers to pay for source information is relevant. Indeed, many consumer studies on WTP show that they are largely prepared to pay more for information on the origin of the products they buy, even though the European Commission has told us on this point that it considers this availability to be rather modest. Before I begin to conclude, I would like to reiterate that the ENVI Committee confirms that it is asking Parliament to support compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of origin and calls on the Commission to implement it accordingly by drawing up legislative proposals in the areas mentioned. It also calls on it to present legislative proposals making it compulsory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods, in order to ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain and to better inform European consumers in the wake of the meat scandal and other cases of fraud. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that it is our duty to give our European consumers complete and clear information about the origin of many of the food products that are part of our diet. It is a question of sharing the goodness of a general principle which will enable us to establish a system that allows conscious and transparent purchases. In conclusion, I call on the Commission to give us its point of view and I strongly urge that the political will of this Parliament be respected, if supported by the majority of Members, through the preparation of certain sectoral legislative proposals, which we are obviously prepared to deal with and analyse on a case-by-case basis and which will have to take account of the transparency and legibility of information for consumers. , while at the same time allowing European companies to operate in an economically viable manner.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, consumer sensitivity to the origin of the foods they eat has certainly grown over recent years. Consequently, origin has become of increasing relevance for businesses and also policymakers. As a result of this, the Union legislators required the Commission to assess the possibility of introducing mandatory origin labelling for certain food categories. In this context, the Commission has so far adopted three reports on meat used as an ingredient, on dairy products and certain meats, and on unprocessed foods, single-ingredient products and ingredients that represent more than 50% of a food. Turning to the oral question, on the first point inviting the Commission to present the findings of these reports to Parliament, I would like to remind you that the Commission has presented the reports in question to Parliament twice: to the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development on 16 July 2015, and to the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on 15 September 2015.  As regards the second point, the Commission report on meat used as an ingredient concludes that mandatory origin labelling does not appear in this case to be the most appropriate way forward at European Union level, taking into account first, limited consumer willingness to pay for such information, the administrative burden linked to the setting up of additional traceability systems and more generally , the impact that this may have, including on European Union competitiveness and trade.  Consequently, the Commission is not considering any legislative follow-up on the matter. This position has been communicated to Parliament in response to the European Parliament resolution of 11 February 2015 on country of origin labelling for meat in processed food.  The honourable Member’s third point calls for the Commission to define, I quote, ‘lightly processed foods and to look at the possibility to limit the scope of mandatory origin indication to that category of foods’. Here I should point out that it would be difficult to establish criteria to define what is ‘lightly processed’. It would be in practice a challenge to ensure legal certainty and clarity in order to be able to implement and enforce rules based on such a notion.  Such an approach could also have the unintended consequence of leading to price increases for lightly processed foods and consequently of directing consumers towards heavily processed foods. Therefore, the Commission is still of the opinion that voluntary origin labelling appears to be the most suitable solution, offering the possibility for consumers to select foods with a certain origin if they so wish, without imposing additional burdens and costs on all food business operators and authorities. We should also keep in mind that, as a general rule, origin labelling becomes mandatory when its omission may mislead consumers. The Regulation also reinforces the rules on voluntary origin labelling. When the origin of a product is given and the origin of its primary ingredient is different, this difference will have to be indicated on the label. Modalities for applying this rule still need to be fixed, but we are working on them. Finally, the Commission would like to recall that the Regulation provides a possibility for Member States to require mandatory origin labelling for specific categories of foods if this is duly justified. Two notifications on this matter are currently being assessed by the Commission.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We have just heard that the Commission has established that mandatory origin labelling for milk, milk and meat products, other meats, etc. would lead to price increases. And she has found that the consumer is not really interested in this. For him, price, taste and durability take precedence. But a majority in this House is ignoring this reality for purely populist and protectionist reasons. Some Member States want to close their market and the consumer is then suggested that national products are better and that they want to help them. Both are not true. But that is precisely what we want to do is identify origin. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the This shot backfires. In the end, the additional costs are not paid by the consumer, which is paid by agriculture. After all, the food chains will put even more pressure on agriculture. Isn't our dairy farmers already doing badly? If you go to the factories, also to the processing, then you will see that sausage is not an "easily processed" product, and you may understand why one cannot define "lightly processed" so easily. Fresh milk must also be transported, stored and processed. In the case of compulsory origin marking, dairies need separate tankers, refrigerated tanks, processing machines and packaging for each origin. Can SMEs do that? The fact is that anyone who wants to buy nationally or regionally has been able to do so for a long time. There are products with voluntary indications everywhere, and every butcher knows where the meat he sells comes from. It's just a little more expensive than in the supermarket. But if you want to know, you can certainly pay the price for it. For all these reasons, my group will not support this resolution.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, it really is disappointing, to say the least, that we are discussing the issue of country of origin labelling yet again following a lack of action by the Commission. In 2011 when we dealt with the food information regulation Parliament voted for mandatory country of origin labelling for meat and dairy products. Last year this Parliament adopted a resolution calling for the mandatory country of origin labelling for all meat in processed food. Yet still the Commission says that voluntary labelling is enough. Well, it clearly is not enough because we know that consumers want this labelling. 84% of consumers support origin labelling for milk and 90% would like to see this labelling for meat in processed food. It is also supported by farmers and consumer organisations across Europe and actually the cost is really quite minimal.  At least Member States are now waking up to this demand, with France bringing in legislation for origin labelling for milk and for meat in processed food. Italy and Portugal are also considering similar legislation. So it seems as if everyone wants this labelling except for the Commission.  This is about clear, honest labelling which does not mislead consumers. It would allow consumers to make informed decisions about the food they buy for a variety of reasons: environmental, animal welfare and, yes, to support their local farmers if that is what they want to do. It should be their choice. It would also be positive for the food industry and would help restore consumer confidence, which has been very badly damaged in recent times. So I hope MEPs will support this resolution and I hope the Commission will finally listen to Parliament and, more importantly, finally listen to consumers and at last come forward with legislation to ensure that consumers know where their food comes from.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Do we really believe that the mandatory mention of the origin of milk in a jar of yoghurt or of meat processed in a lasagna increases the quality of those products, fights fraud, protects employment and restores consumer confidence? The debate on compulsory origin labelling once again lacks the necessary sense of reality, and I regret that. Yet the facts are crystal clear. Origin labelling indicates the origin but does not increase the quality, does not increase traceability, does not prevent fraud. Mandatory origin labelling is a reference to protectionism, is at odds with the principles of the single market and is particularly at a disadvantage to smaller export-oriented regions and nations, such as Flanders, and of border regions.  Additional rules will not restore breached consumer confidence. On the contrary, we must work towards stricter enforcement of existing agreements, tougher sanctions if necessary, and to continue to work on the run of voluntary origin labelling, which is already being applied cost-effectively today.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – I understand that some consumers want to know where the ingredients in processed foods come from. However, I am not in favour of the EU making it compulsory to mention this on the label.  Imagine a bowl of breakfast yoghurt. This yoghurt is made from milk, milk powder, fruits, cereals and sugar from different countries. Under the proposal, the origin of all those ingredients should be compulsorily declared. It's going to be a long-standing label. The red tape and controls for this origin labelling leads to higher costs and therefore a higher price. A higher price that the consumer does not always want to pay for it. In addition, some manufacturers already voluntarily indicate on their label where the ingredients come from, in order to distinguish their products from other products. In other words, if the consumer really wants to know where the ingredients come from and also wants to pay for these extra costs, they can do just that. The EU does not need to intervene to do this.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, certainly origin labelling is nothing new to this Parliament. Just over a year ago we passed a resolution which urged the Commission, once again, to come forward with legislative proposals to make such labelling mandatory for meat in processed foods and, perhaps unsurprisingly given that we seem to be dealing with a Commission which is reluctant to legislate on anything at the moment, we have heard very little since then on potential proposals. So while not giving up on this resolution, in the interests of working with the Commission we came up with a proposal where, Commissioner, you could at least act on the lower hanging fruit so that you can demonstrate your willingness to stop sitting on your hands. But now, having listened to you today, I think that you have actually made the argument and the case for full origin labelling for meat in processed foods.  Consumer confidence in our food supply was naturally incredibly damaged by the horse meat scandal, and not just by the scale of the food fraud, but by the complexity and the length of the food chains revealed. The vast majority of consumers, as we have heard from many of the speakers, want to know where their food comes from, and it is important that we do not stall on this issue. The arguments on cost do not stack up. In Ireland we have demonstrated this: we have a scheme, processed foods are labelled by country of origin, and in fact food producers are opting into the scheme and retailers are demanding it, so in fact it is good for business to have country of origin labelling.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, as my colleagues said, it is true that we had a resolution on 11 February 2015 on meat in processed foods. Parliament had also asked the Commission to make legislative proposals to us to make it compulsory, not optional, to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods.   Today is May 11, 2016, so it's been over a year. What has the Commission done? Apart from reports, as you have indicated, Commissioner, there are still no legislative proposals. Moreover, we are extremely disappointed because you are saying: "This should not be mandatory, it should be optional. But we work for all European citizens. Many countries, whether France, Spain or Portugal, want the origin of food. You are telling us that the cost is high. It's not true.  Many associations have shown that the cost is not higher. Some colleagues mentioned the Eurobarometer survey, which shows that consumers are in favour of the indication of origin, the UFC-Que Choisir also reported that the majority of consumers want the origin at the level of the products. And now, the resolution states that it is planned to indicate the origin of the meat so that it represents more than 50% of the weight of a processed product. But I want to tell you that the lasagna scandal is only 10%.  Therefore, I ask my colleagues to support the amendment of the environmentalists who ask only 10% because, if not, beef ravioli, lasagna and quiches will be off the grid. It's very important. Commissioner, make an effort, we need legislation and we need the obligation to labelling.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Madam President, the dominance of food monopolies in the internationalised jungle of the capitalist market, the Common Agricultural Policy, by concentrating agricultural land in the hands of large enterprises, is taking out small and medium-sized farming. In those circumstances, the indication of a country of origin in meat and milk alone cannot guarantee either the health of consumers or the interests of small producers. TTIR, the economic NATO, with its methodical restrictions, will deal a major blow even to the indication of the country of origin. Of course, many voices of support for it are not defending small and medium-sized farmers, but opposing big interests. In Greece, where farmers are uprooted, it is methodized to remove the indication of origin for feta cheese and Kalamata olives. In addition, lengthening the shelf life of milk and heavy imports are destroying cow farmers by dramatically reducing producer prices to the benefit of the industry's megathers. Monopolies, the Common Agricultural Policy, the European Union, the TTIR and governments must be in the crosshairs of farmers' struggle for their survival and prospects.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, this is a recurring debate which seeks an objective using arguments which, in my view, are unsustainable. It is argued that this labelling will prevent fraud. Not at all. Remember that during the horse meat scandal the traceability system worked, it became known where the meat came from and who committed the fraud, who certainly did so intentionally and not because of a lack of labelling rules. It is suggested that this labelling will improve food quality and safety, but it is that in the European Union we already have food legislation that makes our food the best, highest quality and most food-safe in the world. All we have to do is comply with the legislation we have, only with greater effective checks and sanctions that deter those who break it. And above all, Commissioner, consumers are used as a pretext, without explaining that this information, if it is mandatory, will lead to an increase in prices. We already have mandatory labelling for raw and voluntary foods for processed foods, in addition to PDs and PGIs. Let's face it: going beyond this is not to inform the consumer, nor is it to seek higher quality; it is a weapon for exerting a food patriotism that serves as a weapon of pressure for certain groups; is the total denial of Community solidarity, because it goes against the single market; and finally, it would generate an uncontrollable administrative monster, also for producers. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: "blue card" question. "Madam, you say that labelling would lead to nationalism, to protectionism. But when you have meat that comes from your country compared to meat that comes from the United States, you are still sensitive to CO2, you are still sensitive to the resolution that we voted to reduce global warming. Therefore, a consumer will prefer to consume a local product rather than eat meat that has traveled hundreds or thousands of kilometres.  I would like to know your position on that.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: "blue card" response. – Mrs Rivasi, I would advise everyone to consume European products, which is what we should do, because they are the ones with the highest quality. Otherwise, everyone can choose; we have voluntary labelling and when a producer is interested in knowing the origin of a processed food, even if it costs more, it does. And the consumer knows what he's buying. This is nothing more than, I said, food patriotism, and it serves to put pressure on some sectors to use these products. Let's not kid ourselves. It's not to protect the consumer. It is not for higher quality and is not for greater food safety. There are some unconfessable arguments behind all this.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Madam President, Commissioner, you often say, Commissioner, the life expectancy of Europeans is rising sharply. At the same time, the concern of Europeans who want food security, that is, to know what they eat, what they have on the plate, is increasingly important.  Therefore, this is a measure - and it is the resolution that says so - to protect the health of Europeans that is at stake and which we must have in mind. It is not, of course, protectionism, it is a question, by setting up this traceability system for prepared meals but also for dairy products, of promoting the protection of the health of Europeans, as they ask us to do.  90% of European consumers surveyed want to know the origin of the meat used in their prepared meals. Indeed, despite your voluntarism, Commissioner, the Commission is hesitant because the agri-food industry expects costs to increase by 20-50%. However, as we know, studies have been done, this is by no means an extra cost of 20 to 50%, but only 0.015 euro cents for a tray of lasagna at 2.20 euros. I think, Commissioner, now is the time to go. Let's go, allowing greater food security through the implementation of this traceability system. In doing so, we will contribute to this beautiful and great image of the European Union, which will then protect the health of our consumers. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I listened attentively to my pre-speech speech. He talked about the fact that mandatory food origin labelling is related to food safety and food quality, but this has nothing to do with it. Therefore, I have a question, how does he want to ensure and from what does the consumer know, when he is obliged to know the country of origin of a particular food, that the food is of better quality and safer? This figure does not say anything about food quality.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: "blue card" answer. There are numbers that speak for themselves." According to a recent February 2016 survey, 54% of prepared meals do not mention the meat used; 74% of dishes containing chicken, 75% of Strasbourg sausages and 92% of ham sandwiches do not specify the origin of the meat they contain. However, in recent years we have seen scandals, mafias that have been organized, and - I know and you know it, all of us - we have been confronted in the previous mandate with the case of animals that had been raised with antibiotics and yet had entered the food chain illegally.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Madam President, consumers are giving a very clear message: they want to know where their food comes from. Country of origin labelling does not only benefit consumers, it can be an opportunity for food producers as well. But I do understand the Commission’s concerns; country of origin labelling will increase the regulatory burden, it will add cost which will have to be passed onto the consumer, and in multi-ingredient products it will prove to be impractical to reinforce. However, in the case of processed meat and dairy products, for example yogurts and sausages, there already is a very high level of voluntary declaration and this is a cost that consumers are prepared to pay. So, in the interests of fairness and consistency, I urge the Commission to bring forward proposals for mandatory country of origin labelling for all lightly processed products.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has You know, I am concerned with people and animals – living beings made of flesh and blood – and not with the profits of the economy. For the economy is supposed to serve man, not the other way around. That is why it is so important to me that consumers know what is on their plate, what routes their food has taken, how and where it has been produced. Consumers do not want a beef to be bred in Denmark, for example, fattened in Romania and slaughtered in Germany and processed into sausages. When TTIP comes – and we must take this into account – consumers should know whether the chicken in their ready meal comes from the EU or from an American slaughterhouse where the meat was treated with chlorine. After all the scandals, consumers want safe food from animal welfare. Above all, however, they want healthy foods with clear, transparent labelling. Commissioner! Please stand behind the interests of consumers, people, and not the interests of business. Because that's what people expect of you.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The argument that nine out of ten consumers want this is a serious argument. However, we must also say that consumers have a right to know where their food comes from. We must accept that this transparency in the food chain should be included! The arguments that are now being put forward against labelling have also been put forward against the labelling of eggs, which have been put forward against the labelling of vegetables. Now they are put forward in milk or processed meat. That is incomprehensible. This is also possible with milk! Why not? And we help the local farmers who produce regionally there. Customers want to have regional goods – that's the trend! Regionality is the trend in the whole food industry. I am convinced that farmers will benefit if the consumer knows nearby that this is where the milk comes from, and I want to support my farmer, I want to get the milk there. This has nothing to do with nationalism at all, it has something to do with strengthening regional cycles. That is the point! I cannot understand why the Commission is following the industrial arguments so easily and saying that this would be too expensive. There are enough examples to show that the costs are not excessive. And both sides – consumers and farmers alike – have something of it.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are once again making the same request to the Commission. I hope that this time we will be heard. Some argue that the costs and administrative burdens of rejecting this resolution are increasing, but both farmers and processors already have an obligation to trace. So I find it hard to believe that asking for more transparency is such a complication. Nevertheless, this is an essential point for future legislation.  We want to strike the right balance between the interests of consumers and the competitiveness of our businesses. It should also be remembered that this is a demand from consumers, they want more information and more transparency.  We must take into account the possible increase in costs and administrative burdens, but we must also reconcile consumers with their food after the various food crises we have experienced.  Others point to the questioning of the unity of the internal market. But let's face it, the internal market is not one. Consumer expectations are very diverse from one Member State to another, as are national legislation. The question is absolutely not who has the best product but to answer the questions that consumers might have in relation to societal expectations. Moreover, it seems to me that a mandatory common European base would create less distortion than a voluntary rule. Finally, I fear that the mere use of the voluntary indication of the origin of products will lead to two categories of consumers: those who will have the choice of the product they want and those who will not.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the obligation to label indications of origin has, on the one hand, guarantees for conscious consumer choices and, on the other, the possibility for European producers and processors in the agri-food sector to be better able to compete on the markets. In this respect, we see a real paradox: the opacity of the situation on labelling and the lack of transparency create mechanisms of unfair competition that violate the rules of the free market, to which the opponents of origin indication on the label then appeal to highlight negative aspects of the indication of origin. A genuinely free market feeds on transparency, does not hinder but rewards production with high standards of food safety; a genuinely transparent market does not encourage competition in the dark, made up of imports of cheap agri-food products and dubious quality and origin.  The Commission's reports show that the costs of ensuring transparency in the food supply chain may be too high and that consumers, while interested in this information, would not be prepared to support it. Well, these reports are incomplete and do not take sufficient account of the positive aspects of product origin marking, such as increased consumer confidence in the products they consume and greater awareness of choice.  I therefore call on the Commission to re-evaluate its proposal, in the light of more objective studies and by properly assessing the benefits for consumers of origin marking. In this regard, I would remind you that voluntary labelling schemes have produced positive results in several Member States, both in order to protect consumers' right to information and for producers, who have little or no impact on production costs.  Faced with the absurdity of the timidity shown by the Commission, Parliament is called upon to respond clearly to the demands of the citizen-consumer.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: – Mr President, I would like this Commission to have the courage to show up in any of the villages of Asturias, Galicia, León or any of the territories of the Spanish State and to tell people, looking them in the eye, that their land, that their roots, that the origin of what they produce does not matter too much. You say that labeling is expensive, that it makes the product more expensive, and that people prefer to pay less than know what they buy, but the discussion is not what percentage of consumers want to know and which ones care less. The point is that citizens have the right to know the origin of what they eat and producers have the right to defend what is theirs: their production. And in that defense, in the defense of proximity trade, local production, food sovereignty, our ranchers and our ranchers is where they will find us. Labels are not expensive, ladies and gentlemen, what's expensive is that people downstairs always pay the cost of maintaining the status quo of those above.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: – Compulsory labelling of origin is a political tool of some regions and Member States for their own product marketing, at the expense of farmers, at the expense of the European food sector and at the expense of our internal market. This has nothing at all to do with the fight against food fraud, but with the harsh protectionism of Member States.  Food fraud is combated with equal enforcement in the EU, with effective inspection and not with unnecessary and useless additional bureaucratic requirements regarding origin labelling for ingredients. Fresh meat must already be traceable and its origin must already be mandatory on the label. Don't introduce double bureaucracy now. How is our butcher going to get his ball chopped or his sausage? How should a dairy cooperative separate its milk on the basis of origin and set up separate production flows?  Mandatory labelling leads to excessive additional production costs for our SMEs and for the food sector. In fact, labelling of origin threatens agricultural jobs by increasing production costs by 8% to 45%, as we read in the Commission's report. Food companies in the border regions of the Union are being penalised as a result. Their ingredients are often supplied from several Member States.  In the meantime, the consumer appears unwilling to pay for the slightest price increase in the store. The price pressure of these enormous extra costs is thus, as so often, passed on to our farmers, who are already in crisis. Compulsory labelling of provenance is an unworkable, unaffordable bureaucratic burden on the craft middle classes and entrepreneurs, a bureaucratic burden that we, the EPP Group, want to reduce together with Commissioner Frans Timmermans. Don't do this to the consumer. The consumer does not want compulsory labelling of origin, resulting in this large price increase.  And finally, voluntary labeling ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which Commissioner Andriukaitis, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent report, which What you have here, and what we are discussing here, is the political will of Parliament. And, I believe, you should once again listen to us, to Parliament at this point. It has been said on several occasions that consumers have clearly expressed the wish that they want to know where their food comes from and that they very much want the origin marking.  I also believe that we will be more likely to have what has been mentioned here, namely protectionism, if there is labelling in individual countries and not in others. I hope that we do not have a patchwork in the European Union, but that we should act uniformly and that consumers in all the Member States of the European Union will be provided with this knowledge. A great deal has already been said about the costs. I think everyone here takes the numbers that suit them best. However, I would like to point out once again that voluntary labelling also entails costs. And since some people like to do this, it probably can't be that high. So, I think the cost argument is a pre-advanced and not really clear. I would like to make a third point: I believe– quite the contrary to the previous speakers – that it should be more about more stable relations between producers and the manufacturing industry. And we as S&D hope that these relationships will also become more stable by having indications of origin.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Mr President, many European producers in the milk and pork sectors are selling their products below the production price, which is unacceptable. We need to take more action. The indication of origin for dairy products and pork should be mandatory for the protection of European producers, but also because it seems clear to me that it is synonymous with quality and food safety.  It is important to avoid double interpretations for consumers, such as what often happens in Portugal, where we see on sale products with the national designation, which are produced or packaged in other countries, or even when there is dishonest use of certain brands of dairy products, by indicating on the label that they contain milk from the Azores, for example, creating added value for that product, when they indicate on the label that they contain milk from the Azores, for example, creating added value for that product, when , in fact, this is non-existent or represents less than 1 % of the product.  It is important that European products should not be confused with low-quality products from third countries, which reach us at prices with which it is impossible to compete, given the lower requirements to which they are subject. But above all, it is our responsibility to give Europeans the opportunity to help their producers, European farmers, at a time when we are going through a huge crisis.  Measures should also be defined to protect dairy products from the outermost regions, such as the Azores, the region from which I come from, which, with the Russian embargo, the end of milk quotas and various trade agreements, see their main export market flooded with milk and their derivatives, and is not recognised by it, in terms of price and income to the producer , the added value of its enormous quality.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Mr President; Commissioner, you are well aware that food is one of the main determinants of health, especially important for the most vulnerable populations. Labeling information means quality and combating fraud. Agromafia moves more than 750 billion euros in the year. It was horse meat, then; last April 22nd, it was the beef for beef in the burgers.  I understand that it may place a greater bureaucratic burden on businesses, but I cannot understand the assertion that it will lead to an increase in prices for citizens, let alone that we legislate or act with our backs on our own consumers, who are asking us for that food security and information. And that's what I appeal to: that we take safety and what consumers are asking of us.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I have to say that, if you came into this House with no fixed views on whether you are for or against country of origin labelling, you would leave confused because the arguments on both sides are very valid but very confusing. I have always been behind the concept of giving consumers the information they want, including country of origin information. We started this in beef, because of a crisis in the beef sector many, many years ago. There were concerns at the time about its impact in the marketplace but it has settled down. I have to say, though, that those who argue that labels prevent fraud really are on thin ice because what prevents fraud is an effective inspection regime in the Member States, followed up by action in the courts to stop criminals in their tracks. On the particular issues of dairy and dairy products, we have to acknowledge the problems that dairy farmers are facing. The country I come from is a major exporter of dairy produce and there could be an unintended consequence for those who export into the internal market if there is a re—nationalising of the marketplace. I appreciate the comments made by colleagues who say that they want to support their own farmers. That is a very natural instinct, but I would hope that would extend to supporting farmers across Europe in a way which does not discriminate. So I think there is a need for caution here, while accepting that there is an interest for us in giving consumers the information they look for.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the willingness of European citizens to know the origin of agri-food products is clear and legitimate, and as legislators we must ensure that our consumers are fully, transparent and non-distorting.  We already have legislation requiring origin labelling for many food products, including, for example, all fruit and vegetables and almost all types of meat. We must now take a step forward by extending the European obligation to other sectors gradually. The sensitivity and the most advanced positions of some countries such as Italy, for example, can be a stimulus to arrive at a single European legislation.  Our citizens are asking us to be informed and we must ensure that they have transparent labelling that informs them, but that does not make them the conditions in their choices, such as the 'traffic light' labelling system that some British supermarkets have adopted.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: – A year ago, I spoke out against mandatory origin labelling of processed meat. Today I say that extending such an obligation to milk is, if possible, even more unwise.  After all, what does mandatory origin labelling mean for the dairy sector? More administration and more costs, which in this case will most likely end up on the milkman's neck. They are certainly not waiting for that today. Because let's face it: in practice, this does not simply amount to an extra label or an extra flag. It is about much more: transport in different storage tanks, storage in separate silos, a production process with separate dairy flows, increased workload. In short, over-investment for a sector that can barely keep its head above water for little added value.  Because the current comprehensive regulations on food safety are already more than sufficient. The quality of our milk is always guaranteed, fortunately, and all milk sold in Europe is traceable to the farmer. Food safety therefore has nothing to do with the country of origin.  Finally, two more questions. How credible do slogans sound like 'support SMEs' and 'support our agriculture', if we are to charge our farmers with such measures through the back door? And how credible are we for young people who expect vision and leadership from Europe and who are given that unnecessary regulation? You can answer for yourself.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There are environments in the European Union that, in the name of the lofty objectives of health and life protection, continue to multiply over-regulation, disproportionate to the risks and needs. However, the solutions pushed for in their consequences rarely protect the values raised, but they generate huge financial and political costs for citizens on the Community side. They undermine the seriousness of the EU institutions, including the European Parliament, leading to an erosion of respect for us by an increasing number of Europeans. Building pyramidal bureaucracy, multiplying the enormous costs of doing business and increasing the fear of draconian penalties discourages an increasing number of citizens from doing business, especially on a small scale, but worse, also within the European Union itself. Unfortunately, such proposals are also the ones that are being debated today. That is why they deserve our negative opinion.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: – Mr President, it is easy to talk about food. We all have a close relationship with it. However, few people produce food themselves these days. Origin marking is a confidence-building act. The consumer needs to know the origin of the food, and the majority of consumers want to know the origin. Labelling shall be such as to provide consumers with sufficient information, to be implemented cost-effectively by operators in the food chain and to be monitored by public authorities at the lowest possible administrative cost. There have been a wide range of objections to compulsory origin marking. In the wildest visions, food prices will rise by up to 50%. There has been talk that trade would suffer, producers would be in trouble and that would be protectionism. Firstly, in this proposal, we assume that the label does not always have to be 'Made in Spain', it can also be a certain area. Who says there is protectionism when wine bottles have a mark where it was produced? It's a guarantee of quality, it inspires confidence. I was disappointed when the Commissioner said in his introductory speech that the Commission was not going to take action. I hope that Parliament's position – as has already been expressed – will be taken up, because European consumers want more information, they must have it. All the Commission's own reports show that costs do not stand in the way of this.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the whole debate, and I must say that I have not been very convinced by the supporters of the new mandatory regulation. There is a simple answer to the basic argument that most citizens want, which has been used here. It is possible for citizens to buy products that have a voluntary country of origin designation. After all, every consumer can choose what he expects from his product, what information he wants written on it. There is therefore no need to introduce new mandatory regulation from Brussels, especially at a time when we are seeing new and new regulations and citizens are increasingly criticising Brussels. I think the argument about prices and the cost of prices is correct. It brings one more thing closer, it will also be the costs of individual states, which will have to check whether the origins are sufficiently indicated on the products. This means, it will be the costs of individual countries, individual countries, not just the cost of products.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Mr President, the traceability of food is a duty to the consumer. He asks for it and he is right: he asks for his health and freedom of choice. There have already been too many scandals in this area, the horsemeat that has struck the most minds. What is the downside of labeling the provenance of food ingredients? We are told about additional costs that would be exorbitant, but that is not true. They would only play at the margin on costs. The need for traceability is such that a number of countries have themselves taken the initiative to move in this direction. The European Union and the Commission would therefore be well advised not to be in tow, but to take the initiative on a subject that brings European citizens together. It is in their interest, but it is also in the interest of producers and processors.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, according to the Eurobarometer, the vast majority of the citizens of the European Union consider it necessary to indicate the designation of origin of food products, in particular dairy products. Protection measures for agricultural products against unfair competition must be strengthened. This will only preserve the traditional character of manufacturing but also the reputation of a geographical indication which is an intangible collective good. Unfortunately, however, the European Union has chosen to pursue a liberal agenda. In Greece at the moment, in the name of adaptation with the OECD toolkit, the production of yogurt with milk powder is attempted. Thus, there is a risk that a traditional Greek product will be lost once and for all, as the poor Greek farmers will not be able to compete with the prices of imported products and low quality raw materials. Traditional Greek yogurt must be protected, as must other agricultural products endangered by TTIR and other corresponding agreements aimed at deregulating the European market and abolishing products of designation of origin, such as Greek feta cheese and Kalamata olives.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to strongly support the mandatory indication, on understandable and guaranteed labels, of the country of origin or place of origin of meat and processed meat and of consumer milk and that used in dairy products. I support this measure for the same reasons I did yesterday with fish and preserves them. It is a way of adding value to products, giving back the quality they have and enabling much of it to reach producers, which are the origin of everything. Cooperatives of producers, such as the Basque dairy Kaiku, prove that in a crisis market there are alternatives based on a better distribution of the value chain, and the possibilities that this offers to be able to stabilize prices and improve the product. The advertising I see in many parts of Europe proves that this identification between products and places of origin works among consumers, who know that, in the food, quality and values sectors, they are in fact even.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the consumer is asking for it, the producer is hoping to find security there. If we are at this point, the responsibility of the agri-food industry is very important because it is its dysfunctions that have resulted in the questioning, the doubt, the skepticism of the consumer with regard to what is in its plate. You refute mandatory labelling, you advocate voluntary labelling, I fear that, one way or another, we will lead to a split of the single market.  Commissioner, whatever measure you are advocating, the real question I am asking myself is: what means will we have to make it really enforce and respect it so that it actually secures the consumer?

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, labelling processed meat and dairy products with the country of processing, but not of production, is both misleading to consumers and unfair to farmers. To say mandatory labelling challenges competition ignores the fact that British farmers face unfair competition from wrongly labelled products, according to the FSA, amounting to GBP seven billion of lost income last year, or 10% of the food on British shelves.  I was proud to launch the Red Tractor Mark in East Anglia and my constituent, who is its Vice-Chair, a farmer on the Norfolk/Suffolk border, believes that he and other farmers are undermined by the current voluntary scheme. Instead, the Commission should be helping to tackle this food fraud, supporting the new environmental technologies to test food authenticity, such those developed by the University of East Anglia, and like the former Labour Government in my own country, which backed local food hubs in Ongar in Essex, and Woburn in Bedfordshire, also in my constituency, the Commission should recognise the environmental benefit of local purchasing. The time for mandatory labelling is now: for consumers, for farmers, and for the planet.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, I share the idea that the consumers have the right to know where foods come from, but, at the same time, I firmly believe that we should address this issue in a balanced way. Two reports of the Commission concluded that the cost of mandatory labelling would be extremely high. Costs could rise by 45% for some milk and dairy producers, and SMEs would be unfairly hit by the additional administrative burden. I do not think consumers are willing to pay for it. The most important concerns for them are quality and security, and the EU already has the highest standards for its citizens. The Commission already allows for voluntary labelling for anyone who wants to use it. If we make it mandatory, we risk falling down in protectionism, since everybody could claim indication, for example, small towns, regions, etc.  We need a balanced way, taking into account consumer needs, without affecting small businesses negatively and raising consumer prices.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the arguments for and against. As you know, in this House, too, some are in favour of supporting mandatory labelling and some are not. The arguments were very different from different points of view. Of course, as you know, the various surveys showing that the cost is not important refer to cases of voluntary schemes, but this cannot be compared with the cost entailed by any EU-wide mandatory scheme. Surveys show that – not me, but surveys.  There are obviously some benefits, no doubt, and environmental grounds are legitimate. However, any benefits also have to be assessed in the light of negative impacts. Those negative impacts are also on the ground. We must also assess those from all positions.  The conclusion of our work so far is that mandatory origin labelling would rigidify supply chains, disturb the internal market and international trade. We are also thinking about the international situation. It is not about TTIP, but about our producers, our consumers and the European situation. I would like to thank you for this draft resolution and for the very stimulating debate on the topic of mandatory food origin labelling, including on the Commission report on this matter. I have listened to the discussion carefully and with great interest. I have taken note of your views and will pass these on to my colleagues in the context of any further reflections on the matter.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – I welcome the move to make indications on the country of origin mandatory, recognising the value these labels have for consumers. However, I have to again call on the Commission and the Irish Government to take into account the impact these requirements have on jurisdictions such as the island of Ireland, where beef reared on one part of the island and slaughtered on the other is unfairly labelled ‘mixed-origin’ and subject to discrimination on shop shelves. Flexibility for these regions and the option to have voluntary labels are vital.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – 'Mandatory indication of the country or place of origin of certain types of food' – Information on the country or place of origin of meat and milk used as an ingredient in milk products is an elementary right of the consumer. The majority of the citizens of my country, Polish, do not want food of unknown origin on their tables, so I want to express my full support for this resolution and I trust that other foodstuffs will also be included in the future.  In the case of imports of food products from outside Europe, produced on the basis of standards which differ significantly from those applied within the European Union, we have a duty not only to ensure the transparency of the food chain, but also to restore the confidence of consumers who have the right to consciously choose products on their own table.  The introduction of a permanent order to show the country or place of origin of meat and milk, as well as their preparations and its extension to single-ingredient foods or prepared with a predominance of a single ingredient, is of great importance, particularly for persons burdened with allergies or food intolerances for whom their consumption is the cause of serious and often incurable diseases.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. – Under Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 on food information for consumers, the European Commission had to submit a report on the mandatory indication of the origin of certain foodstuffs. The results of the reports examining dairy products and meat products other than beef, pigs, sheep, goats and poultry show a colourful picture. The consumer demand for origin information and the economic impact of requiring a mandatory designation of origin vary considerably in the different categories. While consumers are interested in the origin of milk and meat products used as ingredients in dairy products, their willingness to pay for this information seems rather modest.  From the producer side, the indication of this information would entail additional costs and an increase in administrative burdens. According to the report, voluntary designation of origin would be the least disruptive to the market and would not affect the price of products. According to the national survey of Hungarian consumers, it is particularly important for the vast majority of customers that a food should be of Hungarian origin. In order to take purchasing decisions, they require that, in the case of milk and milk products, sufficient and reliable information on the origin of the product is provided.  The question therefore is whether the ratio of costs to benefits justifies the mandatory introduction of an indication of origin. In order to do this, voluntary and mandatory options for designation of origin should be examined, taking into account consumer aspects and the opportunities of those working in the food sector.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Writing. The aim of this resolution on food labelling is to ensure greater transparency and fairness. The high quality of our food must be visible! Only fair labelling can be the key to transparency. We want to know whether the food on our plates comes from a cheap import or from top Austrian quality. "Cover-up chains" must finally end! Only with EU-wide origin labelling can we guarantee product safety and demonstrate animal welfare. The Commission is therefore called upon to urgently draw up legislative proposals for a mandatory indication of the origin of meat in processed foods, as well as milk and processed dairy products such as cheese and uppers. However, when we talk about honest and fair food labelling, we must also include eggs and egg products on the list. After all, what good is it for us if we ban battery packs in Austria, when precisely such caged eggs from Ukraine, for example, are sold again on the domestic market in processed products, because there is no labelling? I will continue to insist on honest labelling. For animal welfare and domestic production.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – This resolution is a step in the right direction, although I regret that the labels on the products do not contain information on the full lifecycle of the product from farming to shelf with key elements that may affect the quality of products such as the place of cultivation and the date of slaughter and the date of the first freezing of meat. Such labelling would prevent fraud with the placing on the shelves of meat several years old. Also, marking the origin of products on our shelves could not sell lower quality milk that does not pass quality controls such as milk produced in Croatia, or milk that even arrives in powder. There is a similar situation with eggs that are produced in Croatia often have to meet higher standards than the competition. I welcome the points of resolution that speak of excessive fear of rising prices due to the indication of the country of origin. Past experience shows just the opposite. A number of labelling schemes work successfully while the impact on the price is small or insignificant. Country of origin can protect local producers, especially small and medium-sized farms, and thus strengthen the strength of rural space and local communities across Europe. Listing the country of origin in no way means less Europe, but more Europe in its diversity.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – We must prioritise and support the health of the citizens of the European Union in all our decisions. It's our duty, whereas we have to give everything else a secondary role. The indication of the country of origin or place of origin of meat and processed meat products has already provoked serious debate at commission level. It has caused serious concern among some operators because they consider that such a mandatory indication of origin would result in a significant additional cost of production. Yes! However, such a price effect applies only if the raw material in fact has so far come from third products or products of doubtful origin. However, if the raw material originated in a country already sourced from the EU market or with adequate quality assurance, this negative impact is low.  I therefore do not consider the rhetoric of price-impacting to be acceptable! In fact, I'd like to go further: Why not extend this option to other products? In nature, this can only be solved through a serious planning and legislative process and clarification of definitions. But I consider the principle itself to be supportable. I think it is important to mention that this is not a good or bad product designation, and indeed it is unacceptable to me that the designation merely 'harmful' or 'healthy' is unacceptable, for example, depending on sugar or salinity. This is about ensuring that the consumer can decide whether he wants to buy food produced in the EU's high quality system or choose something else.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. This is a lie that is only intended to protect multinationals in the agri-food sector! Companies already doing this labelling have seen their costs increase by only 0.67%. Parliament is therefore voting this afternoon for a new formal notice so that legislation on this matter can be introduced and that the consumer is heard. The Commission, as the spokesperson for the companies, refuses to mention the origin of meat and milk on the grounds of an extra cost to companies. As a reminder, at the end of 2013, the results of the large DNA test operation revealed that more than 5% of the beef controlled was not. In some countries, such as France, this figure rises to 15%. It is therefore essential that a significant increase in controls on processed meats be accompanied by the new legislation. By voting on this text, the European Parliament is once again the voice of citizens' rights. Europeans need to know what they have on their plate and therefore have the essential information to make an informed choice. Origin labelling is mandatory for fresh meat, there is absolutely nothing to prevent this from being the case for prepared meals and milk.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – I consider that the labelling of milk and meat products with countries of origin is extremely important. Mandatory labelling would give shoppers more confidence in food products. At the same time, such a food supply would be more transparent. The European Commission must stand up for decisive action in this area. Food coming from the EU market, especially from smaller countries such as Slovenia, is considered to be of better quality. In this way, too, we will be able to take better care of our competitiveness.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for giving the Commission the opportunity to have an exchange on a highly important issue: hydroelectric power. First and foremost, with 40% of all renewable electricity generation, hydropower is Europe’s largest renewable energy resource. Hydropower will continue to play a key role within the European Energy Union as it will contribute to the delivery of the three priority objectives of security, sustainability and competitiveness.  The Commission aims to give all electricity generators equal access to hydropower concessions. The granting of equal access will have a positive impact on investments, on local communities, thanks to higher fees paid by concession holders, on the integration of hydropower in the electricity market and ultimately, on consumers.  The Commission is well aware of the economic, legal, social and environmental aspects of hydropower generation. Member States remain, in principle, free to design their models for the exploitation of hydroelectric plants. We do not question the Member States’ competence to impose relevant obligations on hydropower operators when granting hydropower concessions. In this way, Member States can strike a balance between competition requirements and other legitimate interests. However, Member States must respect the relevant European Union law, for instance when a Member State decides to exploit those plants via concessions, European Union public procurement rules need to be respected. This ensures not only an adequate level of competition but also equal treatment and transparency among the economic operators. In this context, European Union public procurement rules are infringed when the initial duration of a hydroelectric concession is extended to the benefit of the incumbent concession holder without due justification.  The applicable European Union law may be different depending on the approach chosen, but that does not necessarily exclude the operation of hydropower generation from the scope of European Union law. Where applicable, national hydroelectric concession regimes should respect European Union energy rules, such as the Electricity Directive, as well. Indeed, competitive procedures for hydropower concessions and fair treatment of economic operators are important for a well-functioning energy market. Finally, when granting hydropower concessions, the EU Member States may be subject to EU competition rules, namely antitrust and state aid. A Member State that grants hydropower concessions to a dominant public company may infringe antitrust rules when this has anti-competitive consequences by creating unequal conditions of competition allowing the dominant public company to maintain or strengthen its dominant position on the relevant electricity market.  The granting of hydropower concessions may qualify as state aid if several conditions are met: if state resources are involved, a selective advantage has been granted to certain companies in the relevant electricity market and there is an effect on trade and a distortion of competition. First, state resources have to be involved, for example, in the form of state revenues or fees that could be foregone. Second, a selective advantage has to be granted to certain companies over their competitors in the relevant electricity market. Third, there must an effect on trade and a distortion of competition, which is likely to be the case since electricity is sold across Member States on competitive markets.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the hydroelectric sector is crucial to achieving the decarbonisation targets and completing the single energy market. Unfortunately, the situation of the granting schemes in Europe is not uniform. There are countries with endless concessions, others with the possibility of renewal and others that are liberalising their market. This actually prevents a real level playing field for operators; The result is a loss of competitiveness on the part of our businesses. It is therefore clear that we need to promote a uniform regulatory framework if we really want to create a level playing field in market access on the basis of open and fair competition. With the oral question that is at the root of this debate, Commissioner, we ask you how the Commission intends to promote greater convergence in the European hydroelectric sector, taking into account the differences in the licensing systems and procedures. We therefore ask you to play a more active role in this area, not just to worry about compliance with the rules of competition. In fact, the existence of too many different licensing systems in the hydroelectric sector is yet another proof that the time has come to change the rules of competition at European level. These rules must be designed and developed in the service and in the interests of businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and not by pursuing abstract bureaucratic processes that end up putting employment and growth in Europe at risk, but also in the competitiveness of our production system in the world.  Therefore, Commissioner, I realise that you are not responsible for the sector, and I am well aware – as you have done so many times – that the Commissioners on duty in this House are not responsible, but I would ask you to take a proactive part in a stronger initiative on the part of the Commission, because only action to monitor compliance with the rules is not enough if we really want to support the hydroelectric sector.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall not dwell on the importance of this sector, on its economic value ( just think that its economic contribution is equal to Slovenia's GDP), because you have already mentioned this importance, Commissioner. However, I would like to tell you quite frankly that the things you have told us are absolutely abstract and do not correspond to the reality of this sector, the problems and the need for action.  As has been said, there are obstacles to be removed. The first is the diversity, in different countries, of the granting schemes and the whole procedure for the use of hydroelectric resources: this has a distorting effect and has a very unbalanced impact from a competitive point of view, on investment certainty and on the possibility of using this source.  The second obstacle is that the Commission has different and opposing approaches, direction by direction, not day-by-day, but direction by direction. The competition directorate does one thing, the environmental management does another, and several countries are threatened or initiated by totally different and random infringements. I will tell you more: if there is no coordinated approach, we will arrive at the current paradox: some countries, such as my own, are penalised, there is a start on infringement because not all liberalisation has been carried out very quickly; other countries, which have ninety-year regimes, with no time limit and no competitive procedures for concessions, have no appeal, nothing.  I say this, Commissioner, because I too would like to ask you to make a very specific speech – it will not be up to you, but it will be up to someone in the College – to have a uniform regulatory framework, without which there will be no real competition and real market - the things you have told us about - and also to have a different and comprehensive approach to infringements. Europe is a bad image if you feel that this start of procedures is being initiated in the various countries and that each direction is sovereign and opposed to the other. I believe that in this way we will also help the single energy market.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Since the European Commission presented the strategy of creating an Energy Union in February 2015, the aim has been for everyone in Europe to have access to secure, green, sustainable and competitive energy. Hydropower has a particularly important role to play in how we live up to the Energy Union's targets, as 16% of the energy produced in 2013 in the EU comes precisely from hydropower. In 2006, it was only 10%. However, the eu's increasing energy needs cannot only be met by better regulating existing resources. We also need to look at how we can use unused hydro-energy resources. There is enormous potential in the Balkans for hydropower, for example in Bosnia, Serbia, Croatia and Albania. That potential is far from being fully exploited. In Bosnia, only 37% of that energy is estimated to be used today. In Albania it is 35%. So, Mr President, let me be clear and repeat: it is not only by linking and better regulating existing resources, but we must also look at our neighbourhood in order to achieve the objectives of the Energy Union. It is at the heart of European cooperation that we have founded over the last 70 years – that we are getting stronger by doing things together. This also needs to be done in terms of hydroenergy and energy supply. Thanks!

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I am pleased to have this opportunity for the debate, because on the two occasions I have asked in writing about the concessions to the Spanish hydroelectric plants, the Commission claimed a lack of information in its reply.  I am concerned about competition issues. Regulated payments to hydroelectric plants have far exceeded the cost of investment and there are a number of cases of abuse, such as delays in reserve assignments or the return of concessions to the public sector.  I would like a specific answer on this situation, because I am surprised that the Commission , so active in other areas – seems to ignore the harm to consumers by companies active in the sector. And not just when it comes to concessions or regulated costs. Fines in Spain, for example, for the tactical use of hydroelectric plants to manipulate the marginal price highlight the need to consider that electricity regulation in Spain is favouring large producers. That's what we've been denouncing.  I ask this from the conviction that hydropower plays a relevant role in the energy transition, especially because of its ability to adjust production against the increased intermittency of other renewables. That is why its activity must be well regulated and respond to the general interest. To this end, consideration should also be given to its environmental and landscape impact and its compatibility with ecosystem preservation and agricultural activity.  They are sensitive issues and better coordination between different agencies and responsible management would be desirable in this regard. We would like to know what the Commission intends to do also in this direction.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, water dams are a real heritage for every European country. They can certainly produce electricity, but not only: they have also shaped landscapes, altered valleys and altered river flows. The stakes are not only energy, they are also strategic and safe for the population basins that have adapted to the river route. In the case of the renewal of concessions, the question is not whether the operator should be public or private, since, in any case, it will pay the same royalties. Rather, the question is what added value a new dealership will bring and, most importantly, how dealers will work together to manage the common valleys. A great danger looms with the renewal of concessions and their competition. The fragmentation of concessions and the lack of a comprehensive approach could threaten the proper management of a resource that is as vital as it is dangerous. Accidents are rare but are preventable, provided that dam activity is well coordinated, upstream and downstream, through a consolidation of dams in the same concession. My question is simple: will the Commission favour dam concession contracts or follow the obvious and necessary logic of valley consolidation?

name: Roger HELMER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I have often argued in this Chamber against wind and solar power, so it is refreshing to find a renewable technology which I can support wholeheartedly. Hydro is predictable. It is reliable. It is controllable. It is affordable. It takes relatively little maintenance, and it operates without subsidies. In fact, in every respect, it is the polar opposite of the solar and wind that we have wasted vast resources on in recent years, driving up energy prices and forcing energy—intensive businesses to move out of the European Union altogether. The problem, of course, is that availability of hydropower is restricted by the availability of suitable locations and suitable topography. We are now facing calls for the harmonisation of rules for licensing hydropower projects. We, in my party, will oppose any such moves for European harmonisation. Hydro resources in my country, the UK, are a national asset and we will take a very dim view of attempts to control these assets from Brussels.
