name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Imagine a bell, two boxers appear on the boxing field— one with both hands raised, the other with one hand raised, because the other hand is tied behind his back. In this situation, we would all shout immediately – it is not fair competition! But, friends beloved, what do we have right now in the electricity market? In fact, in the electricity market, precisely related to hydropower.  We have different rules in different countries that apply specifically to this electricity generation. Its difficulty is that electricity flows freely across national borders, but competition is distorted because the rules vary. Then we have different subsidies — perhaps small hydropower plants, whether large or not —different in each country. The authorisation systems are different for us, investment requirements vary for us, whether fish roads are needed or not, and so on, but electricity flows across national borders. It's like a boxer fighting with one hand, the other hand tied, and the other not being tied.  So, if we want to build a fair and competitive electricity market in Europe, we need to create the same rules of play for everyone, we need to tie the boxers both hands.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Mr President, with this oral question on the hydropower sector in Europe, I wanted to draw the Commission's attention to the very important role of hydropower: firstly, because it is a renewable and stockable source of energy and contributes both to the decarbonisation of our economy, to the security of our supply systems and to the autonomy and independence of Europe; secondly, because the hydroelectric sector and the operation of the various dams are involved in the development of the territory and the maintenance of local employment. There are very concrete realities behind every hydroelectric project. Power plants and their operations have an impact on many sectors - such as agriculture, drinking water, navigation, tourism, water support, flood management - and contribute in various capacities to territorial cohesion and development. I would therefore like to draw the Commission's attention to the need to clarify the situation of the hydroelectric sector in Europe and to take into account the plural organisations and regulations of the Member States, the fruit of their history and geography, as the study of the Florence School of Regulation recently showed. The hasty opening of hydroelectric concessions to competition - as discussed in some Member States, while there would be no impact on others - risks permanently destabilising this ecosystem. That is why I call on the Commission to start a quick reflection on this issue, while warning it not to open the door to a policy of 'double standards', which would be very detrimental to the Energy Union in Europe.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Europe is one of the regions of the world with the greatest hydroelectric use, although much of the facilities, because of their seniority, present opportunities for technological improvement in installed power, but they are already an opportunity in themselves. This renewable is especially useful for its storage capacity, which brings stability to the market at a time when other sources experience spikes in inactivity. Therefore, betting on the hydroelectric sector should be a priority objective for the Union. This commitment is enhanced by the dispersion of legislation within the Union itself, which affects access, concession and renewal procedures in order to be able to use water for hydroelectric purposes, cooperation schemes and thus a long etcetera. That is why we need to create legal and administrative conditions to ensure convergence and legal and financial certainty of investments. In some countries, such as Spain, entrepreneurs are caught up in a procedure on the renewable aid scheme, which is an example of the effects that the absence of a European strategy produces on operators and users, and how it drags the contribution of renewables to the supply of energy. That is why, Commissioner, I would like to know how long this uncertainty can be cleared and how we are working with operators and concession issuers in order to set European standards in this sector.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Mr President, with 16% of the world's electricity generation, hydropower is the world's third largest source of electricity generation, and this is particularly important because it is a vital energy for our territories, which represents thousands of jobs that are not relocated. It fits perfectly into its human and natural environment, whether in urban, rural or mountain areas. The rehabilitation of mills, abandoned sites, as well as dams, contribute to the preservation of the architectural heritage, while ensuring a complementary source of local energy revenues. Secondly, it is decarbonised energy, as has already been said, that is fully in line with The European energy and environmental objectives. But hydropower is not only a renewable energy deposit, it is also one of the few sectors that allows storage. However, the liberalisation of water concessions undertaken at European level must not be done in a brutal and hasty manner. Many countries, including France, have made great efforts in this area. Unfortunately, we do not want to take that into account. We must avoid holding back investment in this sector at all costs. Today's signal from the European Commission to investors has not been positive enough. Even though competition is impossible, or very difficult, in some high-production Member States of the European Union, those who have made efforts in this area have sometimes been unfairly singled out. Therefore, how does the Commission intend to support the development of this particular sector, and I must say that there is a great deal of concern in the mountain territories about this?

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I am very pleased that we are having this discussion – albeit late at night – on this very important area, renewables. In hydroelectricity, we have a sector that boasts 100 years of knowledge and experience, the highest level of efficiency of any electricity—generating technology, at between 80% and 95%, and a clean energy source that can play a massive role in helping us to meet our climate and energy targets. With 380 terawatts of hydroelectric power installed in the European Union, it is one of the most significant contributors to our energy mix. This equates to around EUR 24 billion per year of savings in fossil—fuel imports, and therefore 100 million tons of carbon emissions avoided.  The EU is moving to deploy more renewable energy, not only in response to climate change, but also to lower our EUR 400 billion yearly bill for fossil fuel imports. Hydroelectricity is an ideal complement to the variability of renewables, as when the sun shines or the wind blows reservoir levels can be allowed to increase to prepare for a time when there is no wind or sunshine. Let us remember also, at a time when more and more resources go into developing effective energy storage, that hydropower is the only large—scale and cost—efficient energy storage technology available today. Hydroelectricity offers cost—effective flexibility and firm dispatchable storage. So what’s the outlook? It all depends on prices, and we have to use the new electricity market design to give it significant value in recognition of the flexibility that hydroelectricity offers.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to make two very specific points - the timetable forces me to be very practical and simple). In Europe – and the Commission must be aware of this – there are many ways of allocating hydroelectric concessions: there are countries that do not compete, as some of my fellow Members have said, there are countries that compete, but as a result of these competitions the concession then extends unreservedly, therefore without being replaced by other tenders. And then there are also countries where competitions are held regularly, so, at the end of the concession period, there is a subsequent competition.  In these countries there is a legal and economic problem which, it seems, the Commission has not considered properly, because if the depreciation of investments lasts longer than the concession, it is normal that at the end of the concession there should be a residual depreciation. Therefore, whoever wins the race will have to pay the remaining depreciation to the previous concessionaire. It is a very simple economic and legal concept. Well, the Commission has not understood this and has therefore intervened by punishing the countries that apply this rule, which is a rule of transparency and competition.  So, in my opinion, it is right to support those who make investments, but it is also right to support those who, through free competition, decide to guarantee investors the normal market rules. It is good that the Commission is aware of this.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today we are debating an extremely important issue. In Paris, we agreed on a comprehensive global commitment to a sharp reduction in climate change. And to do this we need to have new energy, alternative energies, low-carbon energy. Hydropower is one of them, it is the main one, it is the one that also allows us greater flexibility in the production process. But hydroelectric power in Europe is severely undermined, because there is a risk of no new investment, there is a risk that there will not be a replacement for existing investments due to the absence of a uniform regulatory framework. Some of my fellow Members have spoken of unfair conditions of competition: it is the reality, it is the most serious problem, not least because it is not possible for there to be someone in the same market – in that single energy market that we want in Europe – who retains privileged positions, enjoying the unique opportunities that he has on the national market, and who then has the opportunity to go to the other markets. , while for others the domestic market is in fact open but they do not have the opportunity to go outside.  So, Commissioner, that is why we need a new and uniform regulatory framework, one that puts everyone on an equal footing, guarantees competition and encourages investment.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, a dam is used to generate electricity, but it is also a land-use planning tool, it is also a tool for the attractiveness of the territories. The fate of dams is therefore a matter that concerns the local populations. The differences that exist today between the european Commission's branches can no longer last. We need a single discourse, we need a coherence of energy policy, on the one hand, and competition policy on the other.  The landscape of water operating regimes in Europe is diverse. We need a new text that sets a framework that is understandable to all, that is applicable to all and that helps to make, in hydraulic matters, again, a Europe of energy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the hydropower sector produces 15% to 20% of the electricity, both in Greece and in the European Union as a whole, employing around 80,000 workers. It is, and will remain for several years, the first of renewable energy sources and therefore plays a key role in the implementation of the Horizon 2030 targets. It is no coincidence, then, that in the sell-off of PPC in Greece, attempted by the troika and the memorial governments, hydroelectric dams are first-class fillets for prospective investors. The hydropower sector, however, needs the necessary investments to keep it competitive: investment in innovation, as well as to improve the efficiency of existing capacity, but also in the management and prevention of the environmental impact of hydroelectric dams. These investments will never be made by individuals looking forward to immediate and short-term profit. The Greek hydroelectric dams must therefore remain under public control, far from the hands of the troika and the lenders, solely for the benefit of the Greek people and their prosperity.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members for this very useful debate. Hydropower is a key renewable energy source and the hydroelectric sector is an important area within the European Union. But the diversity of the national regulatory regimes in this area has to be acknowledged. As stressed, it is important that national regimes on hydro concessions fully respect applicable EU law. The Commission will continue to oversee that EU rules are observed. This is in line with the aims of the Energy Union to ensure, inter alia, an integrated energy market where energy security is guaranteed. The Commission is currently looking into hydroelectric authorisations and concessions in a number of Member States. It has already launched infringement procedures and it may open more if it appears that there has been an infringement of EU law, including the concessions directive, the services directive and competition laws.  Some have mentioned that in the Commission you see a lack of cooperation. No, there is good cooperation between DGs and cooperation between DG GROW, the DG for Energy and the DG for Competition. There is also no unequal treatment of Member States and the Commission is already now looking at several national hydroelectric regulatory regimes and will act where necessary to ensure compliance with applicable European Union rules.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – Renewable energies, including water and geothermal energy, will play a key role in Europe's energy supply in the coming years. Renewable energy is the key to the energy independence and security of EU Member States. This is particularly important for the EU, which buys eur 1 billion worth of energy resources per day, or Hungary, which is almost entirely vulnerable to Russian natural gas and nuclear fuel. The EU is more or less well on track to meet its 2020 targets, with a 16% share of total energy use. However, there are some Member States which, unfortunately, are not paying enough attention to the energy of the future. This includes Poland, which is re-dusting coal plants, or The Paks Nuclear Power Plant Expansion, which has opted for the expansion of the Paks nuclear power plant Hungary.  Renewable energy production in Hungary has not developed since 2010, despite the fact that, after Iceland, it has by far the best capacity in Europe in terms of geothermal energy, for example. In Hungary, the use of geothermal potential is only 6%, despite the fact that it would be suitable for generating electricity equivalent to four paks nuclear power plant blocks. It is therefore of the utmost importance that compliance with renewable energy targets can be held to account in the Member States, which often oppose development by hiding in the robe of energy sovereignty. The development of renewable energies is one of the most important issues of modern economies in the 21st century. I hope the doubters will recognize that as soon as possible.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – The hydroelectric sector is key to maintaining and strengthening the relative energy independence of the European Union. This is a type of energy that does not use fossil fuels and is based on a renewable resource: the water cycle. In recognising what I have mentioned and other advantages, I must also point out that it is not a panacea and there are not negligible environmental impacts. For example, the dramatic change in river basins entails the coverage of vast territories, which has heritage implications for the culture of the existing villages and the level of the existence of species and their habitats. In Portugal, there have been great struggles for cultural heritage and ultimately led to changes in construction plans or losses of incalculable value. More recently, it has been pointed out that this sector hinders or prevents even the migration of fish and invertebrates, causing the decrease of their populations and affecting some activities, such as river fishing, whether professional or playful. More than giving advice that serves any case, I want to warn of the problem and stress the importance of comprehensive, serious and consequential environmental impact studies. Only then can we build a better Europe!
